DOC.HEAD: Activists Try to Change Hearts And Minds About Capital Punishment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, ```Should we ...,' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with status of appeals; picks up 5th graf, `On Monday ...'
DOC.TEXT: California's first execution in 23 years may be less than a week away, and some surveys suggest that 80 percent of the state's residents think it's about time. But there's a small, vocal minority trying to change the hearts and minds of those who believe that death is the proper punishment for taking a human life. At 3 a.m. on April 3, unless appeals are successful, 37-year-old Robert Alton Harris will be strapped into San Quentin's 7-square-foot apple-green gas chamber, and a cloud of cyanide gas will end his troubled life. State attorneys in San Diego on Tuesday filed their response to Harris' federal appeal, saying there is nothing new in the latest petition to warrant a stay of execution. Harris' attorneys were to reply Wednesday and a hearing was scheduled for then. If U.S. District Judge William Enright rejects their stay request, the defense lawyers' next move would be to file a petition with the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. A denial at the 9th Circuit would leave only an appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court, which has denied Harris' appeals four times. Jim Young of Oakland is conducting a three-week vigil outside the prison. ``Should we as a society use the same language as the murderer _ the language of death _ and create new victims? Society must rise above the level of the murderer,'' said Young. On Monday, Young, a member of Death Penalty Focus, sat by a black cardboard coffin and signs reading ``Don't Kill For Me'' and ``The Death Penalty Is Dead Wrong.'' Two other people, including the wife of another death-row inmate, stood nearby. Also on hand were a man and a woman, who declined to identify themselves, carrying signs applauding the execution and urging people to remember his victims. On Tuesday, Roman Catholic priests from around the state led a prayer service outside the main gate against the execution. Four capital punishment foes were arrested for blocking a road, authorities said. Harris, on parole after a manslaughter conviction, was sentenced to die for the 1978 murders of San Diego 16-year-olds John Mayeski and Michael Baker. He abducted them at a burger stand to use their car in a bank robbery. ``We know we're up against a hard rock of public opinion. But (people) say they're for the death penalty because it's been sold to them,'' said Young, burned by the sun and slightly weak from the early stages of a 10-day fast. ``That's why we're out here at the gate _ to give out information.'' Members of other groups opposed to capital punishment also have been fasting, speaking out, taking turns in the vigil and writing to Gov. George Deukmejian asking for clemency. In London on Tuesday, about 30 members of Amnesty International protested outside the U.S. Embassy. The human rights organization left a letter for the ambassador expressing concern that there will be a precedent created for other American states not currently carrying out executions. Death penalty foes also fear Harris' execution could be quickly followed by many others in California. More than 270 other men are on San Quentin's death row. Prosecutors discount such a possibility because each prisoner gets the same appeals that have helped delay Harris' execution for 11 years. Opponents argue that capital punishment is immoral, is not a deterrent and is a poor way to convince people that murder is wrong. Yet the San Francisco-based Field Institute, which conducts The California Poll, found in mid-1986 that 83 percent of Californians supported capital punishment and 14 percent were opposed. California law provides for life without possibility of parole. But some people are skeptical it assures murderers won't be released to kill again. ``What's to say the people of the state of California ... won't elect another Jerry Brown into office and end up with a parole board to let those people out?'' said Steve Baker, a policeman and the father of one of Harris' young victims. Brown, the state Democratic Party leader, is a former governor known for his liberal judicial appointments. Michael Rushford, president of the Criminal Justice Legal Foundation, a national victims' rights group based in Sacramento, argued that sentencing murderers to life without parole does not assure they will not kill other prisoners or guards. Rushford maintains there's little risk of executing an innocent man. ``The chances of an innocent person being convicted of a serious crime in this country is many, many times less than the chance of being murdered,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Chunk of I-90 Slides Into Lake, No Injuries
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 feet of Interstate 90 collapsed and slid into Lake Coeur d'Alene on Tuesday evening, but there were no injuries, authorities said. The section of the eastbound lane east of this northern Idaho resort town ``sloughed off'' into the lake near a boat ramp, said a state police spokeswoman who would only give her name as Glenna. There were no injuries and no cars left the highway, she said. Traffic was restricted to the westbound lane. The accident occurred at a site where contractors hired by the state have been filling about 5 acres of the lake with dirt to make room along the shore for an I-90 interchange being built. The section fell into the lake because mud on the bottom of the lake apparently didn't support the weight of the fill, said Don Johnson of the state Department of Transportation, who was called to the site.

DOC.HEAD: New Black Leaders Discard Socialist Roots, Look To Capitalism
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: This new country's black leaders, avowed socialists during their long exile, are now looking to businessmen and foreign investors to help develop the nation. The week-old government says it has learned from the mistakes of Africa's socialist-oriented economies, which have failed even more dramatically than those in Eastern Europe. President Sam Nujoma, in a major economic speech one week ago on independence day, did not make a single reference to socialism and promised ``a dynamic role for the private sector.'' ``We are committed to a mixed economy,'' said Nujoma. ``We look forward to a good partnership between the state and the private sector.'' Less than a year ago, Nujoma and other members of his South-West Africa People's Organization, or SWAPO, were returning from exile and declaring their ``belief in the moral superiority of socialism over capitalism.'' But as independence from South Africa neared, the rhetoric changed. ``I think the leaders were quite impressed with the development in many parts of the country, especially Windhoek,'' said Rainer Ritter, a private economist. ``They were coming from poor (African) countries, and they didn't want Namibia to go the same way.'' A senior South African official, who requested anonymity, said SWAPO leaders revised their economic policies after Western nations said they would not provide aid to a socialist-oriented economy. The Soviets and former East bloc nations, the main backers of SWAPO during its war against South African rule, had no money to give. All the southern African nations that have relied on state control of the economy _ Angola, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Tanzania and Mozambique _ have suffered economic declines or fallen far short of their potential. All now are making at least limited attempts to restructure their economies. The one black-ruled capitalist country in the region, Botswana, has one of the highest growth rates in the world and often is cited by economists as a model for development. Nujoma and his Cabinet, made up mostly of ex-guerrilla leaders with no experience in managing an economy, stress that the skills and money of white businessmen and foreign investors are essential in building Namibia. Nujoma has named two white businessmen, Otto Herrigel and Gert Hanekom, as his ministers of finance and agriculture. On independence day, the government announced an agreement with the British firm Lonrho to build a $150 million sugar refinery that could create 4,000 jobs in a country where the unemployment rate is more than 30 percent. The huge, arid nation boasts profitable mining, fishing and farming industries and one of the best economic bases in Africa, much of it built with money from South Africa, which ruled Namibia for 75 years. The 23-year war between Nujoma's guerrillas and the South African-led security forces claimed more than 20,000 lives, but was restricted to the rugged bush in the north. The fighting caused only limited damage to roads, schools and villages. Namibia's annual per capita income tops $1,000, a figure only a handful of Africa's more than 50 nations have reached. However, the wealth is disproportionately controlled by whites, who account for just 75,000 of the country's 1.3 million people. SWAPO estimates that whites own about two-thirds of private property and earn about 10 times as much as blacks on average. The most pressing economic task for the government will to be meet rising black expectations without alienating whites, who can move to neighboring South Africa. The Namibian government is facing a deficit of almost $200 million on this year's budget of about $900 million. The foreign debt is more than $300 million, relatively modest compared to most nations on the heavily indebted continent. So far, Namibia's leading aid donors have been West Germany, which has agreed to give $59 million, and Britain, which will give $16 million. The United States has not yet completed an aid package, but is expected to announce a plan shortly. South Africa has cut assistance to Namibia after steadily reducing its aid in recent years, but South African President F.W. de Klerk said trade talks and other ties will remain strong. Namibia is heavily dependent on South African for imports. More importantly, South Africa controls Walvis Bay, the only deep-water port along Namibia's coast. Walvis Bay is more than 600 miles from the nearest South African territory. But the Pretoria government claims ownership based on Britain's 1884 decision to annex Walvis Bay and make it part of South Africa's Cape Colony. Namibia's constitution claims Walvis Bay as part of the new nation. South Africa, which has army, naval and air force bases in Walvis Bay, said it is willing to enter negotiations on the status of the territory, which has 26,000 residents.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Thrift's Collapse Could Cost More Than $2 Billion
DOC.TEXT: The government is examining $328,000 in political donations by the chairman of a failed Florida thrift, while a top regulator says the institution's failure could rival the $2.5 billion collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. A ``fraud squad'' of federal examiners is investigating the legality of contributions from CenTrust Savings Bank Chairman David L. Paul to state and national politicians, said L. William Seidman, head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp. The propriety of meetings between Paul and politicians and regulators also is being examined, Seidman said Monday. Any evidence of wrongdoing will be given to the Justice Department, he said. Seidman, in testimony to the House Banking Committee, said the failure of Miami-based CenTrust, Florida's largest S&L, will cost taxpayers ``probably in excess of $2 billion.'' Until now most analysts counted Lincoln, based in Irvine, Calif., as the nation's worst S&L collapse. ``It's going to be a horse race and I'm afraid that whoever the winner is, it's going to set a record,'' Seidman said. CenTrust, which spent millions of dollars on yachts, limousines, fine art, gold-plated toilets and other luxuries, was seized by the government Feb. 2. It made few residential mortgages and specialized in junk bond investing, many underwritten by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. In other S&L developments: _The Office of Thrift Supervision reported Monday that the nation's S&Ls lost $19.2 billion last year, up from $13.4 billion in 1988 and the third straight record. S&Ls lost money in 33 states, earned profits in 15 and broke even in two. _Lawyers for Lincoln S&L spent the 13th day of hearings trying to convince U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin in Washington that regulators' April 1989 takeover of Lincoln was unwarranted. Testimony focused on a tax-sharing agreement that regulators said Lincoln owner Charles H. Keating Jr. used to funnel money from the S&L to his holding company. Rep. Chalmers Wylie of Ohio, the ranking Republican on the Banking Committee, released a list of Paul's political contacts, which included a luncheon with former President Carter in June 1988. Paul met twice with Sen. Donald W. Riegle, D-Mich., chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, in November 1987 and August 1988. The second meeting included Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., the No. 2 ranking Democrat in the Senate. Riegle and Cranston are among the so-called ``Keating five'' _ senators who accepted political contributions from Keating and are accused of improperly intervening with federal regulators on his behalf. Paul's desk calendar, according to Wylie, showed that Sens. Bob Graham, D-Fla.; Timothy Wirth, D-Colo.; and John Kerry, D-Mass., flew on CenTrust's corporate jet in 1987 and 1988. All are now members of the Senate Banking Committee, although Kerry was not at the time. The CenTrust chairman held receptions aboard his $7 million yacht maintained at company expense in September 1988 for Louisiana Democratic Sens. J. Bennett Johnston and John Breaux. Atlanta-based federal regulators told the House Banking Committee they were not contacted by politicians on behalf of CenTrust, although they said Paul frequently bragged of his connections. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the banking panel, said examiners in Atlanta recommended seizing CenTrust as early as January 1986 but were ignored by superiors in Washington. Paul met four times with M. Danny Wall, then chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board _ in September and November 1987 and January and June 1988. Paul had been scheduled to testify to the committee, but he said through an attorney that he had not decided whether to appear. Gonzalez gave Paul two weeks to set a date and said he could be subpoenaed if the committee approves. A list of political contributions provided by Seidman showed that most of Paul's gifts were to Democrats, although Republicans received some smaller donations. Among contributions of $5,000 or greater were: _$5,000 in 1988 to Sen. Jim Sasser, D-Tenn., a member of the Senate Banking Committee and now also chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. _$10,000 in 1989 to Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee. _$5,000 in 1988 to Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J. _$12,000 from 1987 to 1989 to Rep. Larry Smith, D-Fla. _$106,500 from 1987 through 1989 to Democratic fundraising efforts. _$50,000 in 1986 and 1988 to the Alliance for Capital Access, a pro-junk bond lobbying group. _$10,000 to former Florida Gov. Reuben Askew, $15,000 to former Rep. Buddy McKay and $5,000 to Florida Insurance Commissioner Bob Gunter, all running for the Senate in 1988. _$5,000 in 1987 and 1988 to Rep. Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., who was running for president.

DOC.HEAD: Accusations of Racism Hit Capitol Police Force
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Capitol police officials cope with terrorist threats, tourists and foreign leaders, but their toughest current challenge may be allegations of racism aired by their own black officers. The accusations have left the police force racially polarized. Black officers have accused top commanders, all white, of discrimination. The police brass has denied the allegations, and white officers have backed their superiors. Blacks brought their grievances to a House hearing last week, appearing in such large numbers that a police security detail normally would have been assigned to crowd control. This time it wasn't necessary, because the orderly spectators _ and key witnesses _ at the House Administration subcommittee hearing were the police. Rep. Mary Rose Oakar, D-Ohio, chairwoman of the police subcommittee, promised after hearing from both sides that reforms were coming to ease the tension. She urged a ``constructive dialogue'' between the black officers and Chief Frank A. Kerrigan. The police force that guards the Capitol complex has 1,238 officers, including 336 blacks _ 27 percent of the force. However, the top ranks of lieutenant, captain, inspector, deputy chief, assistant chief and chief include 61 whites and four blacks, a minority percentage of 6.2 percent. House Sergeant-at-Arms Jack Russ, a member of the three-man Capitol Police Board, said that before an objective written test was instituted in 1983, the department was a ``good old boy network'' with ``car pool promotions.'' ``But that's been changed,'' said Russ, who serves on the governing board with Senate Sergeant-at-Arms Henry Giugni and Architect of the Capitol George White. Sgt. Ronald L. Richardson, executive director of the newly organized Capitol Police chapter of the National Black Police Association, said ``cronyism and nepotism'' still exist in promotions, assignments and training for advancement. ``We do not have a single black in a policy or decision-making position above the rank of captain,'' he said. Blacks who apply for top positions are told vacancies have been filled, only to later learn ``the person selected for the position was hand-picked,'' Richardson said. ``Soon, it also comes to light that the person selected ... had been chosen prior to the official announcement of the job vacancy.'' And why, Richardson demanded to know, were several black officers fired after being accused of drug use, while white officers similarly accused were allowed to remain on the force. Chief Kerrigan said he was unaware of those cases and has told Richardson to provide him a list of specific examples of discrimination. ``I won't stand for any type of discrimination whatsoever. If it was brought to my attention I would do something about it. I asked for a third party to investigate. If there's any discrimination, I'm unaware of it,'' Kerrigan said. Russ added: ``There may be racism in this department. If there is racism, where is it? Come back with a list of your problems. We never had one complaint until a couple of weeks ago.'' A number of white police officers, including several women, wrote the subcommittee to deny any discrimination. ``As a female Caucasian official on the United States Capitol Police force, I do not feel that there is a problem with discrimination,'' wrote Sgt. Ruth B. Micer. She recalled using her vacation to study for written and oral tests she regarded as fair to everyone. Another letter, by Lts. Price S. Goldston and Stanley J. Grochowski Jr., both white, added: ``We have no knowledge of racial discrimination existing within the United States Capitol Police.'' Kerrigan said the best way to make room for blacks at the top is to create a new retirement system. Currently, top white officers stay at their jobs because they must work 30 years and be age 55 or older to qualify for retirement _ longer than in other local police departments. The chief proposed a system to allow retirement at age 50 after 20 years of service, or after 25 years of service regardless of age.

DOC.HEAD: The Nixon Rule: No Man Can Write His History
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Richard Nixon says he has resigned himself to what history will say about him if it can say it in only a sentence: ``He resigned the office.'' He would have it otherwise, he suggested, but he can't budge history's version. Presidents can write their slogans, but not their epitaphs. Jimmy Carter campaigned on, ``I'll never lie to you,'' but that's not what people remember about him. Gerald Ford came closer. Installed in office unelected, he went to Congress modestly, saying: ``I'm a Ford, not a Lincoln.'' History agrees. The matter of capsulizing presidents in a sentence came up in an interview Nixon had with Time magazine to coincide with the publication of his latest book. ``Clare Boothe Luce (writer, diplomat, wife of Time magazine's founder) once said that each person in history can be summed up in one sentence,'' said Nixon. ``This was after I had gone to China. She said, `You will be summed up, `He went to China.''' Added Nixon: ``Historians are more likely to lead with `He resigned the office.' ``The jury has already come in, and there's nothing that's going to change it. There's no appeal. Historians will judge it harshly.'' What would history say, in a sentence, about other presidents? Lyndon Johnson, Nixon's predecessor, a complicated president, takes two thoughts. Something like, ``He declared war on poverty, but got bogged down in Vietnam.'' Ford, Nixon's successor, served two years and achieved little of lasting effect. But his first words as president were, ``Our long national nightmare is over,'' and he, in fact, healed Watergate's wounds until he reopened Watergate's divisions. Sum him up: ``He ended a nightmare, then pardoned Nixon.'' Ford was succeeded by Jimmy Carter, who is remembered for a single word he did not utter: ``malaise.'' Carter made a midway speech about the nation's vague sense of unease. Its theme characterized his tenure. He provided plenty of images: the unimperial president walking down Pennsylvania Avenue, wearing a sweater on television, persuading the stubborn leaders of Israel and Egypt to make peace, a detail man who worried about who would use the White House tennis court. Sum it up: ``His micromanaged presidency didn't work.'' At the time Ronald Reagan occupied the Oval Office, Washington talked of ``the Reagan revolution,'' but in a year's retrospection it was a revolution that didn't seem to have changed so much. Reagan was disengaged but persuasive, a hands-off president. His contribution seems more one of spirit than substance. How about: ``He gave America confidence _ and deficits.'' Harry Truman felt like ``the earth, the moon and the stars'' had descended on him when Franklin Roosevelt unexpectedly died and left the presidency to him. He is most memorable for his gutsy 1948 election campaign, winning when all thought he would lose. For Truman: ``The little man who beat the odds to keep the office.'' FDR was the only president elected four times, and was despised by his enemies for that and a lot of other reasons. They would have chosen epithet for epitaph: ``A traitor to his class.'' But history's already in: ``He led America out of the Depression and the Allies to victory.'' Dwight Eisenhower succeeded Truman, a grandfatherly figure of enormous popularity but a bare record: ``They liked Ike.'' John F. Kennedy was young, elegant and eloquent, but his presidency is summed up in one sad fact: ``He was shot to death in Dallas.'' There were a lot of other presidents, 41 so far. Except for two so famous they need no names, first or last (``father of his country'' and (``freed the slaves and saved the union''), history would have trouble summarizing most of the rest in a sentence. It's hard enough remembering their names.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Mike Feinsilber has been observing presidents in Washington for 21 years.

DOC.HEAD: Jessica Tandy Latest Honor is `Tip-Top'
DOC.TEXT: After six decades as an actress and with everything from a Tony to an Emmy to an Obie under her arm, 80-year-old Jessica Tandy could have picked up the actress Oscar and said it was about time. Instead she wondered aloud why the producers of ``Driving Miss Daisy'' chose someone whose forte is the stage to play a lead in a movie. ``I think I'm very lucky they trusted me with such a wonderful part,'' Miss Tandy told reporters backstage at the Los Angeles Music Center Monday night. ``They could have picked someone with more experience,'' she said, drawing incredulous laughter from the press corps. ``I never thought of myself as a movie actress.'' And the many honors she has earned over the years didn't blunt the thrill of winning Hollywood's coveted golden statuette. ``It means tip-top. It's very, very important,'' she said. ``I'm walking on air at the moment.'' Informed that she was the oldest winner of an Academy Award, Miss Tandy replied, ``Am I the oldest? Well good for me!'' But not by much. In 1976, George Burns won for his supporting performance in ``The Sunshine Boys.'' He was 80 and three months at the time. Miss Tandy is 80 and nine months. She has won many acting honors: Tony awards for her stage role as Blanche DuBois in ``A Streetcar Named Desire,'' and her parts in ``The Gin Game'' and ``Foxfire;'' an Obie for her part Samuel Beckett's ``Not I,'' and an Emmy for the Hallmark Hall of Fame TV production of ``Foxfire.'' The actress had fierce competition in the category: Isabelle Adjani for ``Camille Claudel,'' Pauline Collins for ``Shirley Valentine,'' Jessica Lange for ``Music Box'' and Michelle Pfeiffer for ``The Fabulous Baker Boys.'' Miss Tandy's husband, the celebrated actor Hume Cronyn, was asked before the 62nd annual Academy Awards show how it felt to have his wife take the spotlight all for herself. ``Furious, jealous, unhappy,'' he growled, ``and very proud.''

DOC.HEAD: Union, Companies Disagree Over Success of Walkouts at Nuclear Reactors
DOC.TEXT: Labor leaders call walkouts at 37 nuclear power plants a success as workers made a bid for union representation, but companies involved say insignificant numbers of workers stayed off the job. About 3,000 radiation technicians at nuclear reactors across the nation closed for refueling were encouraged to walk off the job Monday in a nationwide effort to have the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers become their bargaining agent. ``All I can tell you is it's working,'' said IBEW official A.V. Griffies, who said it was impossible to say how many of the 3,000 technicians involved refused to go to work Monday. But several utility contractors said the walkouts had little impact at the reactors where they provide workers to monitor radiation levels. ``It has been business as usual,'' said Karen Armour, a spokeswoman at Asca Brown Boveri Inc., of Stamford, Conn., the parent of Power Systems Energy Services Inc. The company has more than 600 technicians working at nine sites. ``Very few'' workers failed to show, she said. Frank Ingram, a spokesman for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said the agency had been monitoring the situation and had not received any reports that work at the closed reactors had stopped. Griffies said striking workers set up only one picket line _ at the Turkey Point nuclear plant south of Miami where about 100 workers stayed off the job. Another 100 contract workers at Florida Power Corp.'s Crystal River nuclear plant refused to work. Griffies declined to elaborate on why only one picket line was established or to say how long the walkout would last. The IBEW, which already represents the majority of permanent nuclear power plant workers, targeted eight utility contractors who provide traveling ``health physics technicians'' to reactors that close down for refueling or maintenance. Those technicians make between $11 and $14 an hour and have not received pay increases in eight years, Griffies said. James P. Schmitt, spokesman for Westinghouse Electric Corp. in Pittsburgh, said the strike ``is not having an impact with the Westinghouse workers in the industry.'' ``The call for the job action has had little or no impact,'' Schmitt said. Between 300 to 500 Westinghouse technicians are involved, he said. The company has a pool of 1,000 workers, he said. Schmitt said substantial majority of technicians were on the job, but ``we've had a couple here and there that have called in sick. The numbers are insignificant, so it's conceivable that their illnesses are legitimate.'' Baltimore Gas and Electric Co. spokesman Art Sluzark said the strike had not affected the company's Calvert Cliffs nuclear power plant. All 98 of the technicians who work for Bartlett Nuclear of Plymouth, Mass., reported for work Monday, he said.

DOC.HEAD: World Demand for Oil May Soon Equal Production Capacity: Schlesinger
DOC.TEXT: In as little as two years, the world could be using oil as fast as it can be pumped out of the ground, says former Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has been producing at more than 90 percent of capacity, while Soviet production has dropped, Schlesinger told the Senate Energy Committee on Monday. And he said that Iran and Iraq, despite ending their war, are marketing considerably less oil than had been anticipated. ``With the call on OPEC growing at over a million barrels per day each year, we are only a couple of years away from the point that demand would theoretically reach the level of present capacity,'' Schlesinger said. John J. Easton Jr., an assistant energy secretary, gave the committee a more optimistic report, although he and Schlesinger agreed that U.S. oil production will continue to decline if present consumption and exploration trends continue. In the long run, Easton said, ``Through concerted efforts to find and produce more of our domestic resources, we may be able to slow the rate of decline in U.S. production, but it is unlikely under current conditions that we will be able to reverse the trend.'' Schlesinger, who also has served as director of the CIA and as secretary of defense, said U.S. national security and economic interests are threatened by the growing demand for foreign oil. ``There is a strong possibility of a 30 percent or 40 percent increase in prices,'' he said. ``That we will have a price surge in the decade seems to me to be beyond question.'' U.S. demand for oil will grow by about 2 percent a year until there are steep price increases, Schlesinger said. In a recent month, he added, the United States had to rely on foreign sources to meet a record 54 percent of its oil demand. Schlesinger said that by 1995, U.S. imports should reach as much as 11 million barrels a day, compared with a net average of just over 7 million barrels a day in 1989. ``The oil import bill then will likely exceed our present trade deficit,'' he said. That would be in range of over $100 billion a year. ``That statement, if correct, is of profoundest concern to the U.S. economy,'' said Sen. Bennett Johnston, D-La., chairman of the Energy Committee. While domestic demand for oil has been growing, Schlesinger said, U.S. production continues to fall. Drilling activity is low by historical standards and the giant Prudhoe Bay field in Alaska is in declining production, he said. ``We may as well acknowledge that over the past decade the United States as a practical matter abandoned the quest for energy independence _ indeed, even the quest for low energy dependency,'' Schlesinger said. ``If we are to limit our future vulnerability, either for national security or international financial reasons, we shall have to reverse course _ and take vigorous action.'' Schlesinger's formula for reducing imports includes increased conservation, more tax incentives for domestic producers and expanded drilling. Relying on renewable energy sources _ such as solar energy _ will not solve the problem because those sources do little for transportation, which is responsible for the growth in demand for oil, he said. Despite relaxed East-West tensions and the end of the Iran-Iraq war, Schlesinger said, the Strategic Petroleum Reserve should be increased from the present 750-million-barrel supply to 1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Names In The News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: O. Stillman Rockefeller, scion of one of the world's richest families, was bitten by a shark while swimming at an exclusive island resort once owned by Malcolm Forbes. Rockefeller, 30, was injured Saturday in waist-deep water off Laucala Island, according to The Fiji Times newspaper. He said he felt his right leg being pulled and looked down to see cuts caused apparently by two bites. He said he swam to shore and crawled to his bungalow, where he telephoned for help. At dawn Sunday, he was taken by the Forbes private plane to a hospital in Lautoka, Fiji's second-largest city, and later flew to the United States. Rockefeller is the grandson of James S. Rockefeller, who was a chairman of the City Bank of New York, which became Citibank. The isolated resort is owned by the Forbes estate. Forbes, the multimillionaire publisher, died Feb. 24.

For better or worse or until billions do them part, says the lawyer for Ivana Trump, who thinks his client should get half of her estranged husband's fortune _ which he estimated at $5 billion. ``Marital property is property gained by the husband and wife during marriage regardless of in whose name it is held,'' said Michael Kennedy. Papers were filed Monday saying Mrs. Trump had no intention of seeking a divorce and had never waived the right to an ``equitable share'' of the money Trump made during their 13-year marriage. Trump had no immediate response. Trump's lawyers have sought to enforce a 1987 post-marital contract. But Kennedy said that contract ``does not waive or release Mrs. Trump's right to such marital property.'' Kennedy denied reports that the contract called for Mrs. Trump to receive $25 million in the event the marriage broke up.

Zsa Zsa Gabor hasn't completed half the community service she was ordered to perform for slapping a policeman but is organizing a charity auction instead. Municipal Judge Paul G. Rubin, who sentenced the hot-tempered celebrity to 120 hours of work at a shelter for homeless women and children, said he may hold a hearing to decide if Gabor's plans meet the court's order. That suggestion left Miss Gabor fuming. ``That Judge Rubin, who I find utterly disgusting, thinks he was punishing me with this but he is not,'' Miss Gabor said recently at her Bel-Air home. ``I have done more than he said I should _ this auction has taken so many hours I can't count them.'' Miss Gabor, convicted of slapping Beverly Hills police Officer Paul Kramer during a traffic stop June 14, was sentenced to the community service and three days in jail and was ordered to pay court costs and fines totaling more than $12,000. The jail term was stayed while she appealed the conviction.

President Bush's daughter is hoping to avoid a court fight with her estranged husband by having a third party help the couple sort through their troubles. Dorothy Bush LeBlond of Cape Elizabeth, who filed for divorce from William LeBlond on Jan. 3, filed court papers asking to go before a mediator on April 17. ``It's a way to get a neutral party involved,'' LeBlond's lawyer, Thomas H. Allen, said Monday. ``There are financial issues and issues related to children.'' Mrs. LeBlond's lawyer, Phyllis G. Givertz, was out of her office Monday, a secretary said. Mrs. LeBlond's divorce petition cited irreconcilable marital differences but disclosed no details. The couple have two children, ages 5 and 3.

Joy Baker, wife of former Senate Republican leader Howard Baker, will undergo lung surgery Wednesday, says a family spokesman. Mrs. Baker was admitted Monday to St. Marys Hospital in Rochester, Minn., said spokesman Tom Griscom. The hospital is affiliated with the Mayo Clinic. Mrs. Baker underwent surgery for lung cancer in 1982. Griscom said he did not think she had experienced a recurrence of the disease, but that Baker wanted to wait until after the surgery to provide further details. Mrs. Baker is the daughter of the late Senate Republican leader Everett Dirksen. Baker served in the Senate from 1966 until 1984 and was President Reagan's chief of staff in 1987-88.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Nabs Reputed Top Crime Figures, Tapes Mafia `Blood' Rite
DOC.NOTE: Eds: O'Callaghan in 16th graf is cq
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BX1, BX2
DOC.TEXT: Kingpins from New England's most powerful organized crime family were taken into custody in a three-state FBI sweep that authorities said proved both the existence and vulnerability of La Cosa Nostra. ``The case represents a stake in the heart of an organized crime family from the boss on down,'' U.S. Attorney Dick Thornburgh said after all but six of 21 alleged organized crime figures were under arrest Monday. The 113-count indictments were especially significant for their extensive description of a solemn blood initiation rite, said Thornburgh, who was joined in Boston by FBI Director William Sessions and U.S. attorneys for Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut. ``It should lay to rest once and for all any doubts that the Cosa Nostra is a figment of law enforcement's imagination.'' FBI agents fanned out Monday over the three states to arrest the alleged criminals on a range of charges including murder, racketeering, kidnapping, drug trafficking, gambling, obstruction of justice and witness intimidation. Reputed boss Raymond ``Junior'' Patriarca, son of the region's late reputed mob leader, was arrested at 6:30 a.m. Monday at his home in Lincoln, R.I. Patriarca, 45, was transferred to Boston after a brief appearance before a U.S. magistrate in Providence, R.I. In Massachusetts, a magistrate ordered the alleged crime boss and co-defendant Carmen A. Tortora held pending a hearing April 6. The 20 others named in the indictments were allegedly members of the Patriarca organized crime family, whose induction ceremony was detailed in the indictments secretly handed up last week and unsealed Monday. According to the indictments, Patriarca and 17 other alleged family members attended a ceremony in which four alleged mob candidates ``received instructions concerning the rules of La Cosa Nostra, agreed to kill any individual who posed a threat to the organization and its members.'' The indictment said the four took the following oath in Italian before drawing blood from their index fingers: ``I ... want to enter into this organization to protect my family and to protect all my friends. I swear not to divulge this secret and to obey, with love and omerta.'' Omerta refers to the code of silence. A holy card with the image of the saint of the Patriarca family was then burned as the following was repeated: ``As burns this saint, so will burn my soul. I enter alive into this organization and leave it dead,'' according to the indictments. Authorities did not identify the saint. Sessions said the tapes of the induction ceremony in Medford in October showed the bureau's ``ability to invade the inner sanctums ... with the intention to destroy them.'' Other alleged mobsters were in custody pending court appearances or held on previous charges that were superseded by the new indictments. Lawyers said four suspects were expected to surrender today, while two others remained at large Monday night. If convicted on all counts, each of the defendants faces from 40 years in prison and a fine of $500,000 to 85 years in jail and a fine of $2.5 million. ``This has always been one of the major (organized crime) families,'' said Dennis O'Callaghan, special agent in charge of the investigation. ``And we've basically got the entire hierarchy.'' Raymond Patriarca Sr., who died in 1984, was identified as head of the New England La Cosa Nostra during 1969 U.S. Senate committee hearings. He was arrested more than 40 times and convicted of 18 crimes ranging from playing dice on a Sunday to armed robbery and conspiracy to murder. He served seven years in prison. Law enforcement officials generally believe that Patriarca's son inherited control of the New England mob on his father's death.

DOC.HEAD: Akira Kurosawa Wins Honorary Oscar; Declares He Needs To Learn More
DOC.TEXT: Japanese director Akira Kurosawa, who at age 80 received an honorary Oscar for 47 years of film making, got a chuckle from the audience Monday night when he said he still had much to learn. But Kurosawa, the director of such films as ``Ran,'' ``Rashomon'' and ``Seven Samurai,'' was serious. He said he feared he did not deserve the Academy Award because he did not fully understand his art. ``Cinema is a marvelous thing, but to grasp its true essence is very, very difficult,'' Kurosawa said through an interpreter. ``But what I promise you is that from now on I will work as hard as I can at making movies, and maybe by following this path I will achieve the true understanding, the true essence of cinema and earn this award.'' Kurosawa was introduced by directors Steven Spielberg and George Lucas, with Spielberg praising him as ``a man who many of us believe is our greatest living film maker and all of us know is one of the few true visionaries ever to work in our medium.'' Backstage, Lucas said that Kurosawa has a ``brilliant sense of the cinema.'' ``He's a director's director,'' said Lucas, who was inspired by Kurosawa in making the ``Star Wars'' films. The audience gave Kurosawa a standing ovation as he took the stage at the Los Angeles Music Center. The director then watched a filmed greeting from Tokyo, where he was presented with a cake for his 80th birthday on Monday. The audience in Los Angeles joined in singing ``Happy Birthday.'' Kurosawa, credited with helping the world appreciate Japanese film making, directed three films nominated for Academy Awards. His 1975 film ``Dersu Uzala,'' submitted by Russia, won as best foreign language film. Along with Lucas, other directors have been inspired by Kurosawa. ``Seven Samurai'' was remade in the United States as the ``Magnificent Seven'' and ``Rashomon'' became ``The Outrage.'' The spaghetti western ``A Fistful of Dollars'' was a remake of ``Yojimbo.''

DOC.HEAD: Social Club Fire: a Nightmare Foretold
With AM-Social Club Fire, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The tragedy was foretold, its prevention attempted. But law enforcement failed customers of the Happy Land Social Club, as experts say it is failing to protect the patrons of other illegal nightspots. ``These places are fire traps. They're in violation of every code imaginable,'' state Sen. Jeremy Weinstein, who led an investigation of social clubs in 1981, said Monday. ``It's true for every city in the country.'' But it is in New York that the nightmare was realized: Eighty-seven lives snuffed out in a rush of flame and toxic smoke early Sunday. The Happy Land's habitues, mainly poor immigrants, were trapped and felled in moments. It should not have happened. A year and a half ago, when seven died in a similar fire, the mayor formed a task force to close down unlicensed clubs. Soon after, the city ordered Happy Land closed for fire safety violations. It apparently did close for a time _ and then opened again, unnoticed by officialdom. ``These places reopen as fast as they shut 'em down,'' said Charles Ryan, an ex-fire captain and now fire science department chairman at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. As a result, despite a renewed crackdown announced Monday, he said, ``It wouldn't shock me if this happened again.'' The simple problem is inadequate law enforcement, Ryan and others said. But they also called it more complex than that _ a combination of the city's enormous problems, shrinking budget and paralyzing bureaucracy. And there is another, equally daunting factor: Tremendous demand for the illegal but inexpensive clubs, particularly in poor immigrant communities where life is difficult, diversions are scarce and danger is commonplace. ``People who are living in tough conditions of life are going to look for opportunities to blow off some steam,'' said Professor William Kornblum, director of the Social Research Center at the City University of New York's graduate school. ``They're going to pay less attention to the dangers around them.'' The hazards can be legion. At the Happy Land, authorities say there was no open fire exit, no first-floor sprinkler system, no proper emergency lights, and bars on the sole window. The only way out was through the front door, and it was blocked by flames, allegedly ignited by an arsonist. The deaths are all the more tragic for the city's failed effort to shut the Happy Land down. ``This should never have happened,'' said Mayor David Dinkins. ``That club had been inspected. It had been cited. And it had been ordered closed.'' He immediately launched another crackdown, with police posting vacate orders on 187 social clubs Sunday night. But vacate orders alone cannot solve the problem. ``Issuing a piece of paper and saying, `You're closed' doesn't mean anything unless you come around and whack the guy on the head,'' said Ryan. Identification of illegal clubs has been adequate, he said, with 2,031 inspections last year by the task force formed in 1988 by then-Mayor Edward I. Koch. ``It's the follow-up that's weak,'' Ryan said. ``That's the nut of the problem: inadequate enforcement.'' Better enforcement would require more manpower. The police estimate there are 1,220 social clubs in the city, with about 1,000 listed as inactive. But Happy Land was one of those ``inactive'' clubs, and Kornblum guessed the city in fact has 500 to 600 operating social clubs _ some legal, many not. ``It is true that complete enforcement is futile. The clubs are always moving to new locations, always trying to stay a step or two ahead of the authorities,'' Kornblum said. But he said aggressive followup could save lives, if the city provided the resources. There are other approaches, as well. With a view of social clubs as cultural centers, Kornblum suggested low-interest city loans for legally operated clubs that could take the place of illegal dives. Ryan, for his part, suggested cracking down on the liquor merchants who keep the clubs supplied, and possibly placing a legal limit on retail liquor sales. Weinstein said he would investigate the idea. Yet Weinstein, a Brooklyn Democrat, noted that little of this is new. In 1981, his panel's report on illegal social clubs included this warning, ``The potential fire hazard alone is of such proportion that numerous lives could be lost at any time no matter how minor the fire was at the outset.'' ``How ironic that after so many years, we're still back where we started,'' he said. ``Now a lot of people are going to be up in arms over this. And then, eventually, it's going to fade _ until it happens again.''

DOC.HEAD: Hot Dog Business Hops for Former Cuomo Commissioner
LaserPhoto AB1
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo's former drug treatment commissioner started his new career Monday outside the state Capitol with the same relish _along with some mustard _ that took him to the upper reaches of government. ``I've never failed at anything, so I intend to succeed as a hot dog vendor,'' said Julio Martinez, as he stirred onions and sauerkraut in his new chrome steam cart featuring the message: ``He's Back! Knishner Martinez.'' Martinez was director of the State Division of Substance Abuse Services until he resigned in December amid allegations he had steered state contracts to friends. But on Monday, he manned the only food cart on State Street on a cold, snowy day typical of early spring in Albany. ``I'm doing this because Julio Martinez has bills to pay,'' he said. ``This is an honest and a decent way to make a living.'' Martinez' first customer was his successor in state government, Arthur Webb, New York's new director of substance abuse services. ``I have a friend who is selling hot dogs. I'm just buying a hot dog,'' Webb said. He pronounced his lunch of a dog with ``the works'' and soda delicious. State Sen. Joseph Galiber was Martinez' second customer, and Ramon Rodriguez, director of the state Parole Board, was next. ``I wish he'd sell things like black beans and rice _ good Latino dishes,'' said Rodriguez, as he downed his hot dog with sauerkraut. ``In about two minutes I'll have indigestion.'' Martinez, assisted by his wife Judy, had plenty of customers lined up through the lunch hour, many stopping by during a break from a conference for state Hispanic leaders. Martinez said his new venture wasn't meant to embarrass Cuomo or protest his treatment by the administration. ``The governor was good to me. He's one of my heroes,'' said Martinez. Martinez, who made $87,300 a year in his state job, said he'd continue to deliver the anti-drug message along with frankfurters. ``If a parent comes up I'll give her the right information, I still have a lot of contacts in the field,'' said Martinez, a former heroin addict who wore a ``Knockout Drugs'' T-shirt under his white chef's jacket. ``If a kid comes up and wants to talk, I'll sit down and talk. It's advice from the top dog, You can't get any better,'' he said. Webb refused to accept his 25 cents in change. ``Take it for the kids,'' he said. ``We're going to start our own drug program out here.'' The sidewalk space allotted for Martinez' city vending permit used to be directly across the street from the state Capitol and was visible from Cuomo's second-floor office window. But this year, the vendors' spaces were moved a few hundred feet up the street at the request of state officials, city officials said. Martinez' return to the state Capitol has received much attention in the news media, but Cuomo apparently hadn't noticed. ``I didn't know Julio was outside,'' Cuomo said when asked if he planned to lunch on Martinez' dogs. ``It's not on the schedule, but you never know.'' Last week, Cuomo said it wasn't likely he'd be eating his former commissioner's fare. ``I don't eat frankfurters,'' said Cuomo. ``Does he sell pizza?'' But it looks like Cuomo will have to go elsewhere. ``I'm not going to bend the rules for him or anybody else. It says hot dogs, knishes and sodas. No pizza,'' said Martinez.

DOC.HEAD: US Wants Expanded UN Observer Force for Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: The State Department is calling on the United Nations to increase a proposed observer force for Nicaragua to keep tensions at a minimum when President-elect Violeta Chamorro takes office next month. Under a plan agreed to last year by the five Central American presidents, about 200 U.N. observers were to monitor the Nicaraguan-Honduran border. But under an agreement reached on Friday, the observers would be assigned to protect the security of enclaves in Nicaragua where Contra rebel leaders said they will deploy their forces next month. The agreement also calls for an internationally supervised cease-fire in Nicaragua and for the disarming, by April 20, of Contras based in Honduras near the Nicaraguan border. The administration has been worried that progress toward national reconciliation in Nicaragua, highlighted by last month's elections, could be set back if warfare resumes between the Sandinistas and the Contras. Mistrust between the two sides remains high. On Monday, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler called the agreement historic and congratulated the parties on it. They included the rebel leadership, officials of the Nicaraguan Roman Catholic Church and aides to Mrs. Chamorro. She will take office April 25. The agreement is to be guaranteed by the U.N. Observer Force for Central America (ONUCA) and a separate commission comprised of U.N. and Organization of American States officials. The U.N. force would be comprised of military personnel from Spain, West Germany and Canada. The Bush administration has asked Congress for $30 million to finance the peaceful reintegration of the Contras into Nicaraguan society. ``We would encourage the parties to move forward as rapidly as possible,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``Towards that end, we urge the United Nations to deploy an enlarged ONUCA force to Nicaragua as rapidly as possible.'' Left unclear from the agreement was the time frame for demobilizing the Contras who are in Nicaragua. Published reports said Monday that the rebels intend to remain in the enclaves for months after Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration. U.S. officials estimate the number of Contras inside Nicaragua at about 5,500. President Daniel Ortega has said the total is 4,000 to 6,000 and has warned that the Contras plan a big offensive shortly before Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration. The Contras have said they are reluctant to disarm unless the Sandinista security forces do the same. They are worried that Mrs. Chamorro might not be able to control these forces once she takes office. Ms. Tutwiler said the ``full cooperation'' of the Sandinistas is required for fulfillment of the accord, including the ``assurance of secure conditions for the Nicaraguan resistance.'' This is consistent with the longstanding U.S. view that the Contras should be required to demobilize only after ``democratic and safe conditions'' prevail in Nicaragua.

DOC.HEAD: US to Combat Cattle Plague with Sterile Flies
DOC.TEXT: The Americans plan to do a favor for the Libyans by bombarding their country with billions of green flies over the next few years to help wipe out a plague that threatens livestock and humans. Researchers hope to wipe out the screwworm by releasing sterilized male Mexican screwworm flies, who will mate with females and prevent them from laying eggs that will hatch. The screwworm normally is transmitted from animal to animal, but in cultures where people live close to their livestock, the flies lay eggs in people's noses, and the worms eat their hosts' brains. The U.S. Agency for International Development is sponsoring the project, and the actual aerial release of the sterile flies will be from planes flown under international auspices. The flies found their way to Libya in mid-1988 apparently through a shipment from South America. Previously, the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans had protected the rest of the world. Now there is no large body of water to prevent them from spreading to other continents. A research laboratory of the U.S. Department of Agriculture in North Dakota determined that the Mexican and Libyan species are compatible. President Bush recently signed a law that permits the sterile Mexican flies to be used outside the Western Hemisphere. Andrew Natsios, director of AID's Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance, told reporters on Monday that the flies are especially dangerous in countries where people live close to their farm animals. ``In many developing countries the animals sleep in close proximity to people and what happens at night when people are sleeping is that the flies get into the nasal cavity of people and lay their eggs ... and the eggs hatch,'' he said. ``People don't know it's there until it's well along in the process. They have to have surgery to have the worms removed. What happens is that if it's left untended the screwworm eats through the nose into the brain and the person dies.'' The scientific name for the fly is cochliomyia hominivorax, the man-eating spiral midge. The screw-shaped larvae burrow deep into flesh, bone and tissues. Official reports from Libya say 30 people have been infected. Unofficial estimates go as high as 300. Wildlife is also affected, including endangered species, according to AID. The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization says 70 million head of cattle are in danger in North Africa alone and the cost there could reach $250 million a year. The organization will run the program. ``My office tries to prevent disasters before they happen,'' Natsios said. ``I do not look forward to running famine programs in countries which have been attacked by the screwworm fly.'' He called the screwworm more dangerous than the locust, because the threat is constant. Locusts come in cycles and the threat periodically dies away. Natsios said the program will cost about $80 million, some of which will be contributed by other countries. It could put an end to the threat before it gets out of Libya, but if it spread much further all of Africa, the Middle East, parts of Asia and southern Europe could suffer, AID said.

DOC.HEAD: Report Sees U.S. Inroads in Foreign Vegetable Oil Market
DOC.TEXT: An Agriculture Department trade report says the United States may gain some of the foreign vegetable oil market for rapeseed and canola but probably will take a back seat to Canada as a major supplier. ``More and more U.S. farmers are interested in getting on the rapeseed bandwagon,'' the report said. ``Now, even non-traditional growing areas are getting excited about the prospect of growing rapeseed.'' Although the report uses the term rapeseed generically to include canola, it does explain the distinction between the two crops. Modified versions of rapeseed developed in Canada are recognized as canola. The report, in the April issue of AgExporter magazine, said there are no official USDA figures on rapeseed production, although industry estimates are in the range of 65,000 to 100,000 acres of so-called double-O or canola-type seed and 10,000 to 20,000 acres of industrial-grade rapeseed. Plant geneticist Dick Auld of the University of Idaho, who pioneered much of the current research in rapeseed varieties for U.S. cultivation, said most of the increase is expected to occur in the Southeast. Winter rapeseed is attractive as a rotation crop for winter grain and as an erosion control on idle land, Auld said. Thus commercial expansion of rapeseed in the Southeast will hinge on the development of winter varieties that can be double-cropped dependably with soybeans. The High Plains and Pacific Northwest will see smaller increases in rapeseed production. Some lower-yielding wheat in the plains probably will give way to rapeseed, and in the Northwest the crop could be rotated every fourth year with wheat. Field trials of early maturing hybrid winter rapeseed in the Midwest have had mixed success, and Auld in the report predicted widespread commercial use of high-yielding winter hybrids is not likely before 1995. The report was written by Margaret E. Thursland and Jeanne F. Bailey of the USDA agency's oilseeds and products division. Rapeseed is an ancient crop, a member of the Brassica family, which includes mustard, turnips and cabbage. It is well-known throughout Asia, Middle East and Europe as a vegetable oil and for industrial purposes. Canada is the leading exporter of rapeseed and Japan is the No. 1 single-country importer. Canada's rapeseed exports to Japan average about 1.5 million metric tons annually. In 1989, U.S. exports to Japan were less than 2,000 tons. ``While the United States certainly cannot compete in volume with Canadian producers, there could be a niche as a residual supplier of rapeseed to Japan and Mexico, the two largest importers of rapeseed outside of the European Community,'' the report said. Another factor in the future of U.S. production is the easing of federal commodity programs to allow the substitution of certain crops _ including rapeseed and canola _ without losing crop acreage base.

An Agriculture Department survey shows that wind damage to land in the Great Plains has increased sharply, mainly because of lingering drought in North Dakota. Manly Wilder, associate chief of the department's Soil Conservation Service, said Monday that 4.93 million acres were reported damaged through February since the season began on Nov. 1. That compared with about 4.7 million acres damage by wind in the same four months of 1988-89. ``We're seeing the continued effects of several years of drought,'' Wilder said. ``There's not enough vegetative cover, and this year there's also not been much snow cover in a lot of places.'' The greatest damage was in North Dakota, with a state record of 1.6 million acres damaged, about one-third of the total reported for 541 counties in the 10 Great Plains states. Only in the 1954-55 season was more land damaged by wind in the Great Plains during the first four months of the season, Wilder said. The season runs through May. In the seven-month 1988-89 season, a total of 14.3 million acres were damaged by wind in the Great Plains, the most since nearly 16 million acres were damaged in 1954-55, the year the agency began keeping records. According to the survey, the state-by-state breakdown comparing damaged acres through February with the damage during the same four months a year earlier, included: _Colorado, 263,890 acres damaged this season and 154,550 in 1988-89. _Kansas, 161,840 and 520,905. _Montana, 888,595 and 1,393,625. _Nebraska, 87,550 and 81,180. _New Mexico, 88,290 and 54,600. _North Dakota, 1,603,276 and 474,200. _Oklahoma, 68,250 and 85,565. _South Dakota, 234,190 and 407,980. _Texas, 1,152,185 and 1,047,791. _Wyoming, 379,113 and 474,863.

DOC.HEAD: Economists See No Drop in Interest Rates
DOC.TEXT: Consumer and business interest rates are unlikely to go lower in coming weeks despite political pressure on the Federal Reserve to abandon its tight-money policy, private economists say. These analysts are forecasting that the prime lending rate offered by banks will stay at 10 percent, where it has been since early January. The prime rate is used by many banks as the benchmark in setting about half of their business and consumer loans, including adjustable-rate home equity loans. Mortgage rates, which are currently averaging 10.26 percent nationally for fixed-rate loans, will remain close to that level at least until fall, when they might start falling slightly, analysts say. This forecast is based on an assumption that Federal Reserve officials, who were in Washington today to set monetary strategy, will decide that inflationary risks make it unwise to reduce interest rates further. ``The economy is growing, although weakly, while at the same time inflation is unacceptably high. We have a tug of war between those two factors and that will produce no change'' by the central bank, Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co., said Monday. David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a government securities dealer, said that while there were indications that economic growth is rebounding and inflationary pressures are moderating, it is too soon for the Fed to know for sure that these favorable developments are occurring. ``The Fed is going to have to wait for at least a couple of months to get a true reading on where the economy is right now,'' Jones said. ``For that reason, I see no change coming out of this meeting.'' Federal Reserve policymakers, including board members in Washington and presidents of Fed regional banks, meet eight times a year behind closed doors to review the economy and revise their interest rate targets. Private economists said they believed the central bank would stand firm against Bush administration pressure to move quickly to reduce interest rates as a way of boosting economic growth. The Fed last eased credit conditions just before Christmas and has resisted repeated urgings by the administration to make further changes. A published report earlier this month quoted an unnamed presidential adviser as saying President Bush was ``mad as hell'' and would not reappoint Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board next year because of Greenspan's refusal to heed pleas for a looser credit policy. As the year began, many analysts were looking for quick action by the Fed to lower interest rates in an effort to keep the country out of a recession, given the fact that the economy in the final three months of 1989 had turned in its poorest performance in three years. However, business activity picked up early this year, leading Greenspan to say that he believed the danger point for a recession had passed. Also working against a looser credit policy is the fact that inflationary pressures increased significantly in recent months, driven upward by crop-killing freezes and a spurt in energy costs. In addition to domestic concerns over inflation and growth, the Fed is keeping an eye on international markets, where the dollar has been climbing, especially against the Japanese yen. The dollar's strength so far this year concerns the administration and is one reason the White House has been pressuring the Fed to lower interest rates. Lower U.S. interest rates serve to push down the dollar's value because they mean lower profits for foreign investors. A lower dollar improves America's trade fortunes because it makes U.S. goods more competitive on overseas markets and raises the cost of imports to American consumers. David Wyss, chief economist of DRI-McGraw Hill, said that while he was not looking for any immediate action by the Fed, a small move toward lowering interest rates could occur later this spring if the central bank remains concerned about the dollar's strength.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Government Appeals for Help on Refugee Problem
DOC.TEXT: The government is appealing for international help in dealing with a growing number of refugees _ mainly from Arab and African countries _ who have sought shelter in Poland after being deported by Sweden. The refugees have topped 700 and are stretching the means of municipal authorities in the Baltic port of Swinoujscie, the PAP news agency said. The official news agency said the refugees first began arriving by ferry from Sweden on Thursday and that at least 300 had been denied entry by that country. It said Poland's government has appealed to the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees in Geneva for advice on how to deal with the situation. Elzbieta Piela-Mielczarek, the mayor of Swinoujscie, also sent a cable to the commissioner appealing for assistance because the city does not have the means to provide basic care, PAP said. The Polish government, in the midst of implementing radical economic reforms that are seriously taxing the Polish people, has nevertheless decided to grant funds to take care of the refugees and has assured them free medical treatment, the agency reported. Television showed pictures of the refugees, including children huddled with their baggage. The report also showed refugees in Swedish buses that were loaded onto a ferry. It said some refugees were not allowed out of the buses during the 20-hour trip across the Baltic. ``Here at least is democracy,'' one refugee said in the television report. Most of the refugees hid their faces from the television camera, however. ``We escaped from Lebanon because there is war,'' one teen-age girl said. The Polish government has ordered border officials to check the documents of foreigners boarding ferries in the city of Swinoujscie to see if they have valid entry visas for Sweden, PAP said. Forged Swedish visas can be bought in Poland on the black market from Arabs for $200 to $2,000, according to the television report. Many of the refugees have run out of money, PAP said. About 300 of the refugees were being lodged at vacation homes belonging to two power plants, and another 400 were being housed in private homes, the agency said. Over the weekend, Jacek Piechota, a parliamentary deputy from the port of Szczecin, about 50 miles south of Swinoujscie, appealed to Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki to take action to resolve the situation.

DOC.HEAD: Presenters, Winners Make No Secret of Disdain for Oscar Snubs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to RECAST lead and add detail on criticism of failure to nominate `Miss Daisy' director for any award. Pick up 9th graf pvs, ``But there is...
DOC.TEXT: ``Driving Miss Daisy'' director Bruce Beresford was the ``forgotten man'' when they handed out the Oscar nominations, but he got his share of accolades from others honored for their work on the film. Academy Award ceremony host Billy Crystal was the first to lament the absence of an Oscar nomination for Beresford, whose film was the most honored of the night, with four statuettes. In his opening comedy routine, Crystal called ``Miss Daisy'' as ``the movie that apparently directed itself.'' Crystal's comments were met with steady applause. When ``Miss Daisy'' won its first award, for makeup, winner Lynn Barber said in her acceptance speech, ``I'd also like to acknowledge Bruce Beresford.'' Again, the audience applauded. Jessica Tandy, who won for best actress for ``Miss Daisy,'' called Beresford, ``that forgotten man, my director.'' Similar sentiments were expressed by Alfred Uhry when he picked up the screenplay statuette for adapting his own Pulitzer-prizewinng play, and by Richard Zanuck, accepting the best-picture award for ``Miss Daisy.'' In a similar gesture, presenter Kim Basinger made no secret of her disdain for the Academy's snub of Spike Lee's ``Do the Right Thing,'' a much-admired story of racial prejudice. ``We have five great films here,'' Miss Basinger said as she introduced the first of the films nominated for best picture. ``And they are great for one reason: they tell the truth. ``But there is one film missing from this list that deserves to be honored because, ironically, it might tell the biggest truth of all. And that's `Do the Right Thing.''' As her remarks were met with applause. Miss Basinger thrust both clenched fists into the air, shouting ``Yes!'' Director Spike Lee's ``Do the Right Thing'' landed on 81 film critics' Top 10 lists, but received just two nominations, for original screenplay and supporting actor for Danny Aiello. Anton Furst won an Academy Award for his art direction of ``Batman.'' The film is the third most popular in box-office history, but received just one nomination. Jack Nicholson, who co-starred as the Joker in the film, was overlooked in the best supporting actor competition. ``For me to be here in front of Jack Nicholson ... and we were the ones who got it,'' Furst said backstage. ``I must say it was quite embarrassing.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Deserters Rounded Up, Beaten by Soviet Paratroopers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 22 grafs to UPDATE with Communist headquarters taken over. Picks up 21st pvs, `Moreover, in ...' ^LaserPhotos VIL2,MOS6
DOC.TEXT: Soviet soldiers on Tuesday began rounding up Lithuanians who fled the Red Army, raiding hospitals where the men sought refuge after the republic's declaration of independence from Moscow. Witnesses said some of the young men were beaten as they were taken from a decaying psychiatric hospital in Vilnius. A trail of blood led down the steps and out the front door of the hospital. It was the first reported violence in the confrontation between Lithuania and the Kremlin that began March 11 with the Baltic republic's attempt to withdraw from the union. Soviet troops also took over the Communist Party headquarters, a showcase office building in the center of the Lithuanian capital. It was the fifth party building Soviet forces had seized in recent days. Before dawn, paratroopers took about two dozen men into custody at a psychiatric hospital in Vilnius, sharply escalating tensions that officials said Monday seemed to be easing with the opening of talks between Soviet military and republic officials. A police officer in Kaunas, about 65 miles to the west, said by telephone that Soviet troops had taken control of the Red Cross hospital there, which had served as a second sanctuary for deserters. The police officer, who did not identify himself, said the soldiers were not allowing Lithuanian police to enter the grounds of the hospital. It was not immediately known if anyone was taken into custody there. A Lithuanian Interior Ministry official said a third hospital, in a small town outside, also was raided and that two or three former soldiers were taken away peacefully. Soviet military authorities had warned they would seize the men they considered deserters if the men did not return voluntarily by last Saturday. The Lithuanian government contends the Red Army is an army of occupation. Lithuania was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 _ along with the other two Baltic republics of Latvia and Estonia. Independence movements have also sprung up in Latvia, Estonia and other Soviet republics, posing one of the biggest challenges to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev since he came to power in 1985. The actions came after Gorbachev told Sen. Edward Kennedy on Monday that he would not use force in Lithuania _ except to save lives. In Vilnius, a nurse said about a dozen of the men who had been staying at the hospital escaped and that others were beaten by their captors. ``They beat them with their fists,'' a duty nurse said of the Soviet soldiers who broke into the hospital about 3 a.m.. She refused to give her name. ``I was afraid they would shoot me too.'' The Interior Ministry official, who did not give his name, and a Lithuanian journalist said two Lithuanian policemen also were beaten by the soldiers when they sought to intervene to stop the violence. A television crew from the American ABC News network arrived at the scene while the troops were still there, was held at gunpoint and forced to surrender its video tape. ``They held us at gunpoint and told us not to move,'' said Andrzej Lewandowski, a member of the camera crew. His colleague, Chris Burzynski, said the soldiers made them take all their equipment out of their car and seized all their video cassettes. Lithuania's president, Vytautas Landsbergis, suggested Saturday that the deserters seek sanctuary in churches instead of the hospitals. But few if any youths appeared to accept the proposal. Some Lithuanian leaders said Monday that talks that began the previous day with Soviet military commanders had eased tensions in the breakaway republic, but others were not so optimistic. Lithuanian Deputy Premier Romualdas Ozolas, one of two officials who met two Soviet military officers Monday, told reporters: ``After coming out of this meeting, I can say the mood has changed.'' ``It is evident the conflict will not be escalated,'' he said. But President Landsbergis was more skeptical. He said he had not received clear assurances that no more buildings would be occupied. Moreover, in a separate interview with the U.S. National Public Radio, Landsbergis said the situation had become ``very dangerous'' in the light of Gorbachev's remarks to Kennedy. ``Before, he always said that he would not use force in Lithuania, but now we have a situation where he's qualifying that statement and setting a condition under which he could use force.'' Soviet television said Monday that Soviet helicopters have been patrolling Lithuania's borders daily because of reports ``territorial guard forces'' set up by the popular independence movement Sajudis have been erecting border signs. Paratroopers appeared in Vilnius on Sunday at the Higher Party School and the Institute of Marxism-Leninism. Lithuanian officials said there also were soldiers at the Vilnius Communist Party headquarters. Ozolas said that during the talks, the army said it occupied the buildings at the request of Lithuanian Communists who remain loyal to Moscow. The majority of the party split with Moscow in December. Reports in Vilnius on Monday night said paratroopers had occupied another building, the Communist Party committee's headquarters in the port of Klaipeda, 200 miles northwest of Vilnius. Lithuanian journalist and activist Vilus Kavalauskas told reporters the paratroopers had arrived in response to a request by Klaipeda's assistant party chief. Kavalauskas did not say when the building was seized. A helicopter dropped leaflets on Vilnius urging people to attend an anti-independence rally Tuesday outside Parliament. One set of leaflets was unsigned, while another was signed by ``USSR citizens in Lithuania.'' The republic of 3.8 million has a large Russian minority. ``They are pushing the Lithuanian people into an abyss of independence,'' the leaflets warned. ``Think! Will we be free in this `free state' where the right to own property is given again into alien hands?'' Kennedy said Gorbachev told him he was committed to solving the dispute with Lithuania peacefully and only would use troops if lives were in danger. Speaking to a news conference after the meeting, Kennedy said the Soviet leader ``indicated to me that the position of the Soviet Union was that there would be no use of force unless the lives of others were threatened, and that he was committed to a peaceful resolution.'' Gorbachev did not say whether he thought any threat to human life was imminent in Lithuania, the Massachusetts Democrat reported. At Monday's talks in Vilnius, Ozolas and Lithuanian Interior Minister Marijonas Misiukonis met with Col. Viktor Smokarev, deputy chief of the Vilnius military garrison, and Col. Vladimir Trikoz of the Interior Ministry. They agreed not to take any steps affecting security without first informing the other side, Ozolas told reporters. Last week, Gorbachev ordered Lithuanians to turn in all firearms and on Thursday he told them to stop signing up for volunteer military units and threatened to round up Soviet army deserters.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 31,825.96, down 14.53 points, or 0.05 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lead, new quote from Zanuck, minor editing; should stand for AMs.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' the heartwarming story of a crotchety Jewish widow and her friendship with a patient black chauffeur, won the Oscar as best picture Monday and captured the top acting prize for Jessica Tandy. Its total of four awards made it the year's most-honored film. Daniel Day-Lewis was named best actor for his role in ``My Left Foot'' as Christy Brown, who battled cerebral palsy to become an acclaimed artist. Brenda Fricker, who played his devoted mother, won the best supporting actress award. Oliver Stone was honored at the 62nd annual Academy Awards as best director for ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' the story of a Vietnam soldier's transformation from bitter paraplegic to anti-war activist. It was the second such prize in three years for Stone, who also won for the 1986 anti-Vietnam epic ``Platoon.'' ``My deepest thanks for your acknowledgment that Vietnam is not over, though some people say it is,'' said Stone. For the first time since 1981, the directing award did not go for the year's best picture. Bruce Beresford, who directed ``Miss Daisy,'' was not even nominated, an omission that was commented on frequently during the presentations. ``We're up here for one simple reason,'' said Richard Zanuck, who produced ``Miss Daisy'' with his wife, Lili. ``And that's the fact that Bruce Beresford is a brilliant director.'' Denzel Washington, the runaway slave turned soldier in ``Glory,'' won the best supporting actor award. ``My son said he was going to make one of these out of clay for me, now I've got a model for him,'' an exultant Washington said as he held up his gold statuette, first award of the evening. ``I never expected in a million years that I would be in this position. It's a miracle!'' said Miss Tandy, who at 80 becomes the oldest performer to win an Oscar. The slender, white-haired actress received a standing ovation from the crowd that packed the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion of the Los Angeles Music Center. Day-Lewis had to overcome tough competition from ``Miss Daisy's'' Morgan Freeman and ``Fourth of July's'' Tom Cruise to win his Oscar. ``For everyone involved in the film, all our desire to make the film, all the strength that we needed, all the pleasure that we took in making the film came from Christy Brown,'' Day-Lewis said. ``I don't believe this!'' exclaimed the Dublin-born Miss Fricker as she came on stage. She added her thanks to ``Christy Brown, just for being alive, and to his mother, Mrs. Brown. Anybody who gives birth 22 times deserves one,'' she said, referring to the Oscar.
