The awards were spread in unusually even fashion during the 3-hour, 34-minute show that was televised live on ABC-TV and reached a worldwide audience estimated in advance at 1 billion. ``Miss Daisy'' also won for screenplay adaptation and makeup, making it the night's leader. ``Glory,'' the inspirational story of the first black regiment to fight in the Civil War, also won trophies for cinematography and sound, to finish with three. Besides the directing prize, ``Fourth of July'' won just one other Oscar, for film editing. Washington becomes the fourth black performer to win an Oscar. Previous black winners were Hattie McDaniel for ``Gone With the Wind,'' in 1939 and Louis Gossett Jr. for ``An Officer and a Gentleman'' in 1982, in supporting categories, and Sidney Poitier for ``Lilies of the Field'' in 1963 as lead actor. Alfred Uhry, who adapted his own Pulitzer Prize-winning play, won the screenplay adaptation award for ``Miss Daisy.'' Tom Schulman, the author of ``Dead Poet's Society,'' won for best original screenplay. The award for art direction went to ``Batman,'' the top moneymaker of 1989 at $251 million that failed to win a nomination in any other category. Another top box-office draw, ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' picked up an Oscar for sound effects editing. The Oscar for visual effects was given to the underwater thriller ``The Abyss.'' ``Henry V'' took the prize for costume design. Disney's much-praised animated fairy tale, ``The Little Mermaid'' won two Oscars _ best song for the calypso ``Under the Sea,'' and best original score. Italy's ``Cinema Paradiso,'' a reminiscence of growing up in a Sicilian village, was named best foreign film. The announcement of the foreign film award came after a tortuous satellite feed from Moscow where Jack Lemmon and Soviet actress Natalya Negoda rattled off the nominees with a triple echo coming though the sound system. Japanese filmmaker Akira Kurosawa, director of such classics as ``Rashomon'' and ``The Seven Samurai,'' was awarded an honorary Oscar. In his acceptance speech the aging master struck a humble note, saying ``I really don't feel yet that I have grasped the essence of cinema.'' The Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award was given to veteran producer-director Howard Koch. Comedian Billy Crystal, host for the festivities, drew laughs as he came on stage with a reference to last year's widely panned opening dance sequence between actor Rob Lowe and a life-size fairy tale heroine. Acknowledging the hearty applause, he asked: ``Is that for me or are you just glad I'm not Snow White?'' Besides the references to Beresford, another dig at the nominating judgment of academy members came from ``Batman'' costar Kim Basinger. Introducing clips from one of the year's best picture nominees, she criticized the omission of Spike Lee's ``Do the Right Thing'' from that list. ``There is one film missing from this list that deserves to be on it because, ironically, it might tell the biggest truth of all,'' Miss Basinger said of Lee's hard-hitting story of racial intolerance.

Monday night's show marked the first time the Oscars have gone truly international. Besides the announcements at the Music Center, envelopes were sent to entertainers for unsealing in four other cities: Art direction by Glenn Close and Mel Gibson in London; foreign language film by Jack Lemmon and Russian actress Netalya Negoda in Moscow; sound and sound effects editing by Bryan Brown and Rachel Ward in Sydney; documentaries and shorts by Charlton Heston and Norma Aleandro in Buenos Aires. ``I looked at every awards show since 1955, and one thing stands out: how much the Oscars reflect the times,'' said the show's producer, Gilbert Cates. ``If you wanted to know the history of 1955, you could get a good impression from the show, including what people wore, what their entertainment was, what was on their minds. ``When you consider all the changes that happened last year in Europe and other parts of the world, it made sense to have a show that reflected those changes.'' A win for best picture brings not only glory to the filmmakers but millions in revenue for the releasing company. Last year's triumph, ``Rain Man,'' provides an example. Reports Barry Lorie, MGM-UA marketing chief: ``On the week before the Oscars, `Rain Man' was playing in 1,542 theaters and grossed $3,003,521. On the week following the Oscars, `Rain Man' played in 1,581 theaters and grossed $5,537,165. So it earned $2.5 million more as a result of the Oscars. ``A best-picture Oscar is important in this country, but the biggest effect can be felt overseas. It is vitally important in selling a film in foreign countries.'' Richard Zanuck, co-producer of ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' agrees: ``Being able to advertise `winner of the Academy Award for best picture' is a tremendous boost overseas, also in the videocassette and other markets. ``Even the nominations gave `Miss Daisy' a tremendous boost. And we were ready if our picture won the award; 300 more theaters were added this week.''

DOC.HEAD: Phnom Penh Gains Confidence After Battlefield Victories, May not Compromise
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The Vietnam-backed government, having passed a crucial battlefield test, appears more entrenched domestically and may make fewer compromises in negotiations to end the 11-year-old civil war. The avowed September pullout of Vietnam's forces left the untested and jittery Phnom Penh government facing a three-party guerrilla coalition that includes the powerful Khmer Rouge. Initially, the Chinese-armed guerrillas made headway in northwest Cambodia. But as the monsoon season approaches, signaling a slowdown in fighting, the tide appears to have turned. The Khmer Rouge has failed to take the northwest's major city, Battambang. The U.S.-backed Khmer People's National Liberation Front is suffering sharp setbacks, and troops loyal to overall coalition chief Prince Norodom Sihanouk have yet to make significant gains. Although Vietnam's reinvolvement is denied by Phnom Penh, the change of fortune appears at least in part to have been due to the return of some Vietnamese troops. This has not, however, detracted from the confidence evident among Cambodian government officials. ``I think they're feeling pretty good about themselves. They've surprised themselves,'' said one Western aid official who requested anonymity. ``They're concerned about the future, but they think they have compromised as much as they will, can and need to.'' Knowledgeable diplomats caution about predictions for this volatile, tragic country, but sketch one possible scenario that sees Phnom Penh trying, while coping with the civil war, to slowly improve economic conditions and deepen political control. Eventually, it would gain international recognition and aid. Few nations now recognize Phnom Penh, but lower-level contacts have intensified. In recent months, Phnom Penh has hosted British and Australian officials as well as former U.S. Secretary of State Edmund Muskie, who called for changes in Washington's hostile policy toward Indochina. Officials in this capital deny military successes will harden their stance at the conference table, saying the draining ``half war, half peace'' that exists is unacceptable. ``Look around you at this rundown country,'' said Pong Peng Cheng, a senior advisor to Prime Minister Hun Sen. ``How can you have development when war remains the top priority, when 40 to 50 percent of the budget goes to the military?'' To date, round after round of negotiations _ in Paris, Jakarta and Bangkok _ have failed despite a stack of peace plans and active participation by the world's major powers. A major obstacle to peace is the future role of the Khmer Rouge, widely detested for its 1975-78 reign of terror when hundreds of thousands of people were killed. But non-Cambodian diplomats involved in the negotiations also say leaders of the warring parties, including Hun Sen and Sihanouk, are wary of making concessions that could dissipate the power they now wield. Each leadership group, the diplomats say, is gauging whether it could win a free election or a tussle for power in Phnom Penh should some kind of political solution be reached. The Hun Sen government would have major handicaps at the polls. It is communist in a country which has suffered the most radical of communist revolutions. It is tainted by growing corruption, which is admitted by officials and criticized with increasing vehemence by ordinary Cambodians. On the positive side, the government follows liberal economic policies and last year allowed peasants to own plots of land. Recent rice harvests have been good, with Western aid sources estimating the country will face a 30,000-ton food deficit in 1990 _ far less than in the earlier years. Un Buntha, a vice director in the planning ministry, said that despite the continuing conflict, Cambodia's gross national product increased by an estimated nine percent last year and further growth was anticipated. But he admitted that the outside investment needed to revive Cambodia's shattered infrastructure was not forthcoming. ``The foreigners are hesitating because they are afraid of the war and we do not yet have regulations and guarantees for investors,'' he said in an interview. A major Phnom Penh asset may be its enemy. ``If it wasn't for the Khmer Rouge, this government would have a very hard time mobilizing the people. But with them out there, they don't need much more,'' said an international aid agency official. The war, however, exacts a hefty price which may move the government towards political compromise. Observers say the mass conscription of young men, the villages of widows and hospitals full of children maimed by mines may stoke hatred for the Khmer Rouge and its allies but it also creates bitterness against the Phnom Penh side.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Denis Gray, chief of the AP's Bangkok bureau, made his first trip to Cambodia in 1979 shortly after the fall of the Khmer Rouge regime.

DOC.HEAD: Sasser Says Pentagon Renovation Out of the Question
DOC.TEXT: The head of a Senate panel on military construction says the Bush administration may as well forget about spending $1.1 billion to renovate the Pentagon. Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., acknowledged Monday that the 47-year-old building needs work but said the administration's call for $1.1 billion over seven years runs counter to a tide of shrinking budgets. ``The military construction bill is going to get smaller not larger,'' Sasser told Pentagon officials at a Senate hearing. ``There's simply no room for such an undertaking.'' The chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on military construction faulted past defense secretaries for failing to get the General Services Administration to provide sufficient funds for the building's upkeep. The GSA owns the Pentagon building, with transfer of control to the Defense Department expected some time this year. The Pentagon, the largest office building in the world, has 17.5 miles of corridors, 131 stairways, 19 escalators and 13 elevators, and covers 29 acres in northern Virginia.
DOC.HEAD: 94 Percent of Business Leaders Oppose National Health Plan
DOC.TEXT: An overwhelming majority of the nation's business leaders oppose a government-run national health plan, according to a poll commissioned by the Health Insurance Association of America. The Roper Organization poll released Monday found that 94 percent of the business executives surveyed would reject a health-care system with a budget controlled by the states or the federal government. A majority of the executives, 62 percent, said they favored improving private-sector efforts to control health-care costs and relying on the current level of government regulation, while 31 percent said they would favor more government regulation to control physician and hospital prices. Two-thirds of the executives said that in the last year their corporate health care costs rose by 11 percent to 20 percent; one in six said their costs were up 21 percent to 30 percent. The poll also found that nine of 10 business leaders have made major changes in their health plans over the last two to three years to contain costs. The most popular option, chosen by three-quarters of them, was to shift more of the cost to employees by increasing deductibles and co-payments and the workers' share of premiums. Also, 62 percent said they have adopted managed care programs, such as those based on health maintenance organizations and referred provider organizations.
DOC.HEAD: Administration Hails Elections in Hungary
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration says the results of Hungary's first free parliamentary elections in more than four decades is a positive step for democracy. ``We are encouraged by the elections as an indication of further movement along the path of democratic development for the Hungarian people,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Monday. Partial results of the weekend election indicated voters overwhelmingly chose opposition candidates over Communist reformers, and that it appeared likely that a coalition of opposition parties would run Hungary. Fitzwater noted that there was a tight contest between two non-communist factions _ the conservative Hungarian Democratic Forum and the liberal League of Free Democrats. The Socialists, the successor to the Communists who once ruled the Warsaw Pact nation, were trailing badly. ``Eastern Europe is undergoing dramatic economic and political changes,'' Fitzwater said. ``Hungary has been one of the countries in the forefront of these changes.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rebound, Dollar Continues To Climb
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index rebounded from early losses and closed only marginally lower Tuesday, while the dollar extended its climb against the Japanese yen to eight consecutive trading days. The dollar closed at 156.96 yen, up 0.56 yen from Monday's 156.40-yen finish. It opened at 156.90 yen and ranged between 156.80 yen and 157.20 yen. The dollar gained 4.76 yen over eight days. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 14.53 points, or 0.05 percent, ending the day at 31,825.96. In the morning session, it lost 346.71 points. ``Although the index opened higher this morning because today is the start of a new fiscal year for majority of Japanese companies, it soon fell back as market players lacked energy to continue buying,'' said a dealer with Yamaichi Securities Co., who requested anonymity. ``It's all because of the yen's decline,'' he added. Japan's fiscal year begins April 1, but the new month for stock transaction starts four days prior to the calendar date. The dealer said the market appeared to bottom out when the index dived below the 29,000-point mark last week, but it will take time and continued ups and downs to recover even to the 33,000-point mark. On Monday, the index gained 1,468.33 points, or 4.83 percent, the second largest single-day gain ever. On March 19, the index dived 1,353.20 points to begin a three-day plunge that took it below 30,000 points before it began rebounding last Friday. Higher interest rates caused by the yen's weakness also dampened interest in stocks, dealers said. The yield on the benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bond, which rises when the price falls, rose to 7.255 percent from 7.17 percent Monday. The dollar remained strong despite dollar-selling by the Bank of Japan and selling by investors who sought to take profits at the 157-yen level, said Toru Kanai, a currency analyst with New Japan Securities Co. Traders said the central bank sold the dollar actively to try to halt its rise, but the amount sold was not immediately available. The Bank of Japan does not comment officially on its market intervention. ``The decline in share prices in part contributed to the yen-selling,'' Kanai added. ``The market now views the United States as allowing the current dollar-yen rate, since the Fed took no immediate action even after the Hashimoto-Brady meeting,'' he said. Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady met over the weekend and confirmed they would continue close coordination to maintain the stability of the exchange market, but did not promise any steps to stop the dollar's recent rise. ``Unless the United States shows a clear position on the appropriate dollar level, the dollar won't stop rising,'' Kanai added. Meanwhile, Hashimoto told a post-Cabinet meeting news conference that events in Lithuania were probably having a great effect on the exchange market. Political instability often increases demand for dollars because of the perceived safety of U.S. investment. He called the current dollar-yen exchange rate ``a headache'' and said he was continuing to watch foreign exchange market movements with concern.

DOC.HEAD: `Falcon Rest' _ A Cable Channel Entirely for the Birds
DOC.TEXT: Couch-bound bird watchers are entering a new television season watching their favorite stars, two peregrine falcons in the permanent eye of a cable channel's camera. The camera mounted on the 21st story of a downtown office building clicked on again Monday, giving watchers a bird's eye view of the falcon's nest. The falcons became TV stars last summer when the cable company mounted a camera near their nest on a ledge of the 23-story Monarch Place office building. The pictures were broadcast on a channel devoted to educational programming. The show proved hugely popular with the cable outlet's 43,000 subscribers and this year systems in Westfield, Enfield, Longmeadow and Northampton will also carry the falcons. Nobody else is using the public access channel, so it's entirely for the birds. ``It amazes me that someone can sit and watch the birds hour after hour,'' said Brian Lambert, general manager of Continental Cablevision. ``I am one of them. It stays on in the office all day long. We just kind of wait to see the bird move or the eggs or whatever. It's mesmerizing.'' Tom French, director of the state's endangered species program, said the show is more than an entertaining glimpse of nature. ``It's an incredible opportunity,'' he said. ``It's absolutely incredible that they're so visible.'' ``We often joke around the office that we spend tens and hundreds of thousands of dollars on new customer service features or new programming services and almost as a second thought we covered the peregrine falcons story and overnight it became an instant success,'' Lambert said. Running cable to the building and mounting the camera behind reflective glass cost about $10,000, Lambert said. Among the first season highlights were the first hatchings of young peregrine falcons in western Massachusetts in 40 years and a June thriller when French rappelled down the side of the building to rescue a baby falcon that was choking on a piece of meat. Alert viewers had noticed the chick's distress and called in the situation to cable officials. This season, the first egg is expected to appear in early April, the first hatching in mid-May and the first fledgling flights near the end of June. The show could have a long run, because falcons mate for life and generally return to their nests year after year, French said.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 41 Killed, 22 Injured As Bus FalLs on Power Lines
DOC.TEXT: A passenger bus skidded off a railroad overpass in eastern India and fell onto high-voltage electrical lines, killing at least 41 people and injuring about 20, news agencies reported today. United News of India said the bus caught fire after hitting the power lines Monday night near Kharagpur in West Bengal state, 780 miles east of New Delhi. The town is 70 miles from the state capital of Calcutta. United News said 41 people were killed and 21 injured. Press Trust of India said 50 people were killed and 22 injured. Press Trust said the crash was one of India's worst bus accidents and only skeltons of the victims remained in the completely burned vehicle. It said train service on the affected tracks, one of the busiest in the state, was temporarily suspended. The bus was carrying 72 people, Press Trust said.

Here are some facts about ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' named best film at the 62nd annual Academy Awards on Monday night: Cast: Jessica Tandy as Daisy Werthan; Morgan Freeman as Hoke Colburn; Dan Aykroyd as Boolie Werthan. Director: Bruce Beresford Producers: Richard D. Zanuck and Lili Fini Zanuck. Production cost: $7.5 million. Box office gross: $74.5 million in 15 weeks of release. Academy Awards: Film, actress (Jessica Tandy), adapted screenplay (Alfred Uhry), makeup. Other nominations: Supporting actor (Dan Aykroyd), actor (Morgan Freeman), editing. Notes: Film bucked conventional Oscar wisdom by winning best picture while the director was not nominated.

DOC.HEAD: `Miss Daisy' Director Missing in Oscar Action
With PM-Oscars, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The producers of the Oscar-winning ``Driving Miss Daisy'' wasted no time bringing up The Big Snub. ``We're up here for really one very simple reason and that's the fact that Bruce Beresford is a brilliant director,'' co-producer Richard D. Zanuck said as he accepted best-picture honors Monday night. ``It's as simple as that.'' The movie, an account of a growing friendship between a white Southern widow and her black chauffeur, won four awards, but Beresford wasn't even nominated for the directing honor. It's a fact nobody watching the 62nd annual Academy Awards was allowed to forget. Jessica Tandy, claiming the actress statuette for her lead role in ``Miss Daisy,'' called Beresford, ``that forgotten man, my director.'' Host Billy Crystal quipped that ``Miss Daisy'' was ``the movie that apparently directed itself.'' Beresford was unavailable to comment on the flap. He was out of the country after finishing a film in Nigeria. Beresford, born and raised in Australia, was nominated in 1980 for co-writing the screenplay for ``Breaker Morant'' and in 1984 for directing ``Tender Mercies.'' Before making his mark in the United States with ``Tender Mercies,'' Beresford established himself as a leading Australian director with ``Don's Party,'' ``The Getting of Wisdom,'' ``The Club'' and ``Puberty Blues.'' ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' released by Warner Bros., won the screenplay Oscar for Alfred Uhry, who adapted his own Pulitzer Prize-winning play. It also won the award for makeup. Zanuck's co-producer is his wife, Lili Fini Zanuck. Made for $7.5 million, the film has grossed $74.5 million in 15 weeks of release. Backstage at the Oscars, David Zanuck said he couldn't understand why Beresford was bypassed in the nominations. ``He had his stamp on this film,'' Zanuck said. ``Why he wasn't nominated, we'll never know.''

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Rights Activists Bring Boycott Threat To Andrus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No decision is expected by Andrus today
DOC.TEXT: Abortion rights activists are threatening Gov. Cecil Andrus with severe economic consequences for his state if he signs the restrictive state abortion law to be planted on his desk today. ``They're organizing all over,'' said Gwen Dempsey, a Republican state Senate candidate in Michigan who was meeting with Andrus today. She and others have been trying to generate a boycott of Idaho potatoes if Andrus refuses to veto the bill banning abortion as a means of birth control. ``Women can put a stop to it now by using their pocketbooks and make it a dead issue,'' Ms. Dempsey said. The abortion bill was to reach Andrus' desk today but he wasn't expected to act immediately. Once the Legislature adjourns, by week's end, Andrus will have 10 days to make a decision. If he decides not to act on the bill, it becomes law and would still take effect July 1. On Monday, Andrus made his first public comments on the bill since it cleared the Legislature last Thursday. The Democratic governor acknowledged the boycott threats and the mounting pressure from both sides. ``This issue has a tendency to polarize people more than anything I have seen,'' Andrus said. ``I don't enjoy the threat of a boycott. But that type of reactionary measure is normal in cases like this. I would hope it wouldn't generate that much steam or interest.'' Anti-abortion senators have said they have been receiving calls and letters from their supporters, pledging to buy more Idaho potatoes. But despite his longstanding opposition to abortion except in cases of rape, incest and to save the life of the mother, Andrus said he had not decided yet whether to sign or veto the bill. ``It's a major piece of legislation that cannot be looked on lightly,'' the governor said, announcing he would consult unidentified outside experts. The legislation would ban abortion except in cases involving a threat to the woman's life or physical health; severe fetal deformity; incest if the victim is under 18, and nonstatutory rape reported within seven days. Based on a National Right to Life Committee model rejected by other states as too restrictive, it carries civil penalties against doctors performing illegal abortions. Abortion rights advocates said the bill is unconstitutional and have promised an immediate legal challenge should it become law. That would give anti-abortion forces the court test they want of the U.S. Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion. Since the bill's approval last week, pro-choice activists have been holding nightly candlelight vigils outside the Capitol.

DOC.HEAD: Contra Disbanding in Doubt As Rebels Stream Across Border
DOC.TEXT: With the ink barely dry on a Contra promise to disband by mid-April, U.S.-backed rebels have streamed into Nicaragua and their military leader says they won't disarm until the Sandinista army does. ``We are speaking of total demobilization _ that includes both ourselves and the Sandinistas,'' rebel military chief, Israel Galeano, said Monday. International observers said there appeared a split among the Contras over the pact signed Friday in Honduras. Rebel loyalty seemed divided between Oscar Sovalbarro, a commander who signed the agreement, and Galeano, who did not. The Sandinistas, defeated at the polls last month, have said they won't hand over control of the army and police to the new government headed by Violeta Chamorro until the U.S.-backed rebels turn in their weapons. There were reports of intensified fighting and, In Washington, the State Department asked the United Nations to increase the number of observers it is sending to the region to so tensions can be kept at a minimum. The 200-member force is to monitor the disbanding of the Contras and tranfer of power from the long-ruling leftist Sandinista's to Mrs. Chamorro's victorious alliance. Representatives of Mrs. Chamorro negotiated Friday's accord, which says Contras in Honduran camps will demobilize by April 20, five days before the conservative coalition takes office. But the agreement sets no deadline for disbanding rebels on Nicaraguan territory, now at least half the 12,000-man Contra army. Galeano said it was unrealistic to expect immediate demobilization. ``An eight-year process cannot be decided by the dismantling of an organization in 15 days,'' he said. Most of the Contra army that set up camps in Honduras after U.S. military aid ended in 1988 began returning to Nicaragua in September. As many as 4,000 were believed in Nicaragua by the Feb. 25 elections. Sovalbarro, who negotiated the accord for the Contras, said Monday that an ``insurgent military contingent of 2,000 rebel fighters'' has returned since Friday and ``its numbers could increase at any moment.'' Contra bases across the border in Yamales, Honduras, are practically empty, according to journalists and international observers. They ``have become ghost camps. There's just a few of them left there,'' one international observer said on condition of anonmity. Friday's accord also calls for an immediate cease-fire, a provision the Sandinistas say the Contras have already violated. The Defense Ministry said that on Friday, a dozen soldiers and four rebels were killed when 100 Contras ambushed Sandinista troops. Mrs. Chamorro's newspaper, La Prensa, condemned the attack as ``terrorism'' and insisted the Contra's disband ``without fail and without pretext.'' The ministry also reported a 30-minute firefight between soldiers and rebels on Sunday. It said that on the same day 100 Contras seized a truck, robbed the passengers of cash and jewelry and demanded the owner pay a $500 ransom. Sovalbarro denied there had been any fighting. ``It is totally false,'' he said. ``It was made up to fit the interests of the Sandinistas.'' Sovalbarro said rebel fighters inside Nicaragua were under orders to ``avoid combat, but maintain their positions.'' All clashes took place near the provincial capital of Jinotega, 100 miles northeast of Managua on the Honduran border. Jinotega province is the northern tip of a corridor used by the Contras to infiltrate Nicaragua. Whether or not the rebels disband by the April deadline appears to depend on which Contra leader is talking. While Galeano insists on bilateral disarmament, some field commanders say they will hand over their guns as soon as the United Nations team arrives. Both Galeano and Sovalbarro deny any differences between them. ``The agreement reached with the new government of Nicaragua surprised our combatants at first,'' Sovalbarro said. ``But now we are all happy over what happened.'' Should there be a split, one international observer said Galeano would command the loyalty of about 60 percent of fighters while 40 percent would follow Sovalbarro. The demobilization pact says the Contras inside Nicaragua will move into ``secure zones'' monitored by the United Nations and Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, the archbishop of Managua. A United Nations team is gathering in Nicaragua and another is already in Honduras.

DOC.HEAD: RETRASMITS to fix cycle designator
On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: The federal government didn't really want Banjo to stand up and be counted, but somehow the cat did get a census form. The pet's name was included on the mailbox of Steve and Carole Shanks when census workers went door-to-door in 1988 to identify rural route addresses. That may be why the couple's census form was addressed to their 5-year-old cat, the Census Bureau said. Bill Mullins, assistant manager of field operations for the Indianapolis office of the Census Bureau, said the name on the form is unimportant. The incorrect name should be, ugh, scratched out _ and the form completed and returned.

A Texas restaurateur wants 2 million Americans to join him in thanking Mikhail Gorbachev _ just leave your name at the beep after you hear the grateful message. Plugging into the craze over 900 telephone numbers, John David Tinsley of Huntsville is assembling a recorded message to the Soviet president that allows callers to sign on by name and address. He told reporters Monday the proceeds from the effort will go to promotion and to flying himself and two respondents from each state to Moscow on July 4 to deliver the message personally. The message says in part: ``We the people of the United States of America have watched the recent events in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union with amazement, inspiration and joy. This is our personal and united message of support. For your courageous leadership which has brought life to hope for the future, we thank you.'' The call to 1-900-988-TIME costs $3.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Leader Arrested After Shootout, 2 Killed
DOC.TEXT: The leader of a 3{-year-old armed insurrection in this South American country was arrested after a shootout with soldiers in which two of his security guards were killed, the military said. Ronny Brunswijk, leader the Jungle Commando guerilla group, was arrested Monday on drug charges and was being held at an army post in the capital of Paramaribo, military spokesman Borger Breeveld said on state television. Breeveld said the charges were related to Brunswijk's announcement Sunday that his men had seized more than a ton of unrefined cocaine from four Colombians forced by bad weather to land their plane near one of his bases. Breeveld did not say where Brunswijk was arrested, but it was believed to have been somewhere in the capital, where the guerrilla leader had been since Friday for talks on ending the Jungle Commando insurgency. The spokesman said two of Brunswijk's security guards were killed when they tried to intervene and an unspecified number of Brunswijk's aides taken into custody. The peace talks had broken off over Brunswijk's demands for continued authority in the jungle interior of this former Dutch colony. His guerrilla group has found support among descendants of African slaves who live in the interior and comprise about 50,000 of the country's 400,000 population. Officials said President Ransewak Shankar dispatched Minister of Justice Jules Ajodhia and Deputy Vice President Willy Soemita to army headquarters to discuss the arrest with the army general staff, leading to speculation the government had not been consulted beforehand. Lt. Col. Desi Bouterse, the armed forces commander and former ruler of Suriname, has opposed a tentative peace agreement reached in June on the grounds it failed to disarm the Jungle Commando, which is believed to number between 200 and 400 men. Brunswijk is a former bodyguard of Bouterse.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect in Social-Club Arson Was an Army Deserter From Cuba
DOC.TEXT: Jailed as an army deserter in Cuba, the Mariel refugee charged with setting the nightclub fire that killed 87 people was described as a street hustler who recently lost his job and girlfriend. Julio Gonzalez, 36, was moved Monday from the Rikers Island jail to the psychiatric ward at Kings County Hospital, where he was under a suicide watch, said Ruby Ryles, a spokeswoman for the city Corrections Department. Gonzalez, charged with murdering 87 people by torching the Happy Land Social Club early Sunday, had no prior criminal record. Gonzalez told immigration officials when he arrived in the United States in 1980 that he had portrayed himself as a drug trafficker to Cuban authorities in order to get kicked out of Cuba, Duke Austin, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, told The New York Times. There was no evidence Gonzalez was involved with drugs here, officials said. U.S. officials have complained that many of the 125,000 people kicked out of Cuba in the boatlift had criminal records or mental disorders. Others were simply dissatisfied with life in Cuba. Gonzalez reportedly lost his last job, at a lamp factory, about six months ago. Detective James Malvey said Gonzalez since had hustled money washing cars and peddling. For the past three months Gonzalez has lived in an $80-a-week furnished room in the Bronx. Before that he had lived with 45-year-old Lydia Feliciano. ``He was just a normal guy,'' said Ray Davis, the building manager. ``He's a nice, quiet, clean guy.'' Gonzalez allegedly told police he torched the club after quarreling with Ms. Feliciano. Franco Mena, who showed up at the club after the fire, said he and another man prevailed on Ms. Feliciano to identify Gonzalez as the arsonist. ``She didn't want to talk because she thought nobody had heard her argument,'' Mena said. Bronx District Attorney Robert Johnson said Gonzalez's shoes still reeked of gasoline when he was arrested at his apartment 12 hours after the fire. According to immigration records, Gonzalez arrived in the United States at Key West, Fla., on May 31, 1980, as part of the Mariel boatlift. He was detained at Camp McCoy, Wis., then Fort Chaffee, Ark., until Feb. 21, 1981, when he was released, said Verne Jervis of the immigration service. He was sent to live with a sponsor family in New York. The agency that handled that placement said it was still looking for Gonzalez' records. Gonzalez told federal officials that he was in a Cuban prison from 1971 to 1974 for desertion. But that account had not been confirmed, officials said. Jervis said Gonzalez had never applied for permanent residence, which makes him deportable after doing time for a criminal offense.

DOC.HEAD: `Pretty Woman' Debuts At No. 1
DOC.TEXT: ``Pretty Woman,'' the latest grownup film from Disney, collected $11.3 million to head the list of top-grossing movies last weekend. The thriller ``The Hunt for Red October,'' with Sean Connery as a Soviet submarine commander, submerged to second place with $9.1 million after three weeks on top. The film so far has grossed $67.3 million. The Warner Bros. comedy ``Joe vs. the Volcano,'' starring Tom Hanks in a love affair with Meg Ryan, cooled to finish third with $5.3 million. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' winner of four Academy Awards on Monday night, parked in fourth on the money list with $3.7 million, and double-Oscar winner ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' hung on in ninth with $1.3 million. ``Driving Miss Daisy'' and ``Born on the Fourth of July'' were the only non-debuting films in the Top 10 with an increase in ticket sales. ``Daisy'' now has grossed $74.5 million and ``Born'' has racked up $65.4 million. New Line's ``House Party,'' an independently produced teen sex comedy that finished in fifth place, took in $3.2 million to bring its gross to $13.4 million. That was a resounding success because the film is being shown on only 700 screens. The convent comedy ``Nuns on the Run,'' starring Eric Idle and Robbie Coltrane as thieves with unusual habits, also continued to play well in its second week of limited release, netting $800,000. ``Lord of the Flies'' was swatted to sixth place with $2.5 million in sales. ``Blue Steel,'' starring Jamie Lee Curtis as a rookie cop with bad taste in men, finished seventh. ``Bad Influence,'' with Rob Lowe hurting the good guy, and ``Hard To Kill,'' with Steven Seagal hurting the bad guys, also saw sales plunge and fell to eighth and tenth, respectively. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. DOC.BYLINE: Tiny Fat Bubbles Enlisted to Fight Cancer ^Eds: For release at 6 a.m. EST ^By MALCOLM RITTER
DOC.TEXT: Children with a deadly bone cancer are being injected with microscopic, drug-carrying bubbles of fat in hopes that the experimental therapy will work where chemotherapy has failed, a researcher says. While it is too soon to tell if the strategy is working, some early signs give encouragement, said Eugenie Kleinerman of the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. The approach may also help some day with other forms of cancer, she said Monday at a science writers seminar sponsored by the American Cancer Society. The patients in her study have osteosarcoma, a childhood bone cancer that produces some 700 cases a year in the United States. The cancer is treated with surgery to remove the bone tumor, plus chemotherapy to attack cancer cells that have spread elsewhere in the body. Nonetheless, some 30 percent to 40 percent of patients die from cancer that had spread to their lungs before surgery, Kleinerman said. Her therapy is aimed at destroying microscopic tumors in the lung by activating white cells called monocytes in the blood and others called macrophages in lung tissue. When activated, these cells kill cancerous cells, she said. The white cells can be turned on by a drug called muramyl tripeptide phosphatidylethanolamine, abbreviated as MTP-PE, she said. The drug is enclosed in the tiny fat bubbles because monocytes and macrophages readily digest them. Once devoured, a bubble spills its load of MTP-PE, activating the cell to fight cancer. In this fashion, the drug can be delivered only to the desired cells, which cuts down on side effects, Kleinerman said. The bubbles, called liposomes, are about the size of red blood cells, she said. In mice, the strategy was able to eliminate cancer that had spread to the lung, she said. It also worked in dogs, even without help from chemotherapy, she said. The current study has so far enrolled 14 children for whom chemotherapy has failed and whose cancers have spread to the lung. Participants have been getting liposomes bearing MTP-PE intravenously twice a week as an outpatients for three months or six months. An earlier study showed that side effects are minimal, including fever and chills. Kleinerman said it is too early to see if the strategy is working in the new study. But participants' lungs show dead cancer cells and scar tissue around tumors, indicating that the treatment is having some kind of effect, she said. If the liposome strategy does work, she said, she hopes it will be combined with chemotherapy after the initial bone tumor is removed. The idea is that the activated monocytes and macrophages would kill cancer cells that resist the chemotherapy. She also said the strategy may pay off for other cancers that spread to the lung, such as the skin cancer melanoma, or which spread to the liver, such as colon cancer. Liposomes are taken up by the liver and spleen as well as the lung, she said. Asked about prospects for treating lung cancer, she said she knew of no studies of that possibility. John Weinstein of the National Cancer Institute, who has studied liposomes, said previous studies give ``a good rationale for going forward'' with the work Kleinerman is doing.

DOC.HEAD: Neighborhood Copes With Fire Tragedy
With PM-Social Club Fire, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A stunned neighborhood near the Bronx Zoo tried to comprehend why many of its sons and daughters perished inside a social club in the city's third worst fire. ``I told my son not to go there. He told me he wasn't going there,'' said Eledia Alvarez, whose 22-year-old son Danny was one of the 87 people who died in the fire early Sunday. Police cars and fire rescue trucks were still parked Monday near the Happy Land Social Club, with its incongruous name and yellow ``happy face'' above a fire-blackened entrance and a single barred window. Several hundred people loitering behind the blue police sawhorses shook their heads or shrugged when asked if they knew Julio Gonzalez, 36. He is alleged to have poured gasoline in the doorway of the illegal nightspot and then set it afire, trapping partyers in an upstairs dance area. Most suffocated before they could flee down the two narrow stairways. Classes were underway as usual at Public School 67, which on Sunday served as the clearing house for families and friends to view police photographs of the victims. On Monday, a task force of seven city, state and private agencies was still using part of the building to help relatives make funeral arrangements. The city offered $900 to survivors who need burial assistance, and the state Crime Victims Board will pay up to $2,500. Mrs. Alvarez was among some 200 relatives and friends who returned for that purpose. They spoke with disgust about how the Happy Land was able to operate despite having been ordered by city authorities to close, and with sorrow that some people continued to patronize it despite its reputation as an unsafe place. Rene J. Mena, 63, said his 30-year-old son, Rene Jr., the oldest of 10 children and himself the father of three, had invited him to go out on Saturday night. ``I told him I didn't want to go to that place. That is a very dangerous place, and I'm not going there.'' Rene Jr. died in the fire.
