DOC.HEAD: Broken Beds, Scattered Mattresses After Troops Storm Hospital
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet troops left behind broken and overturned iron bedsteads, scattered mattresses and a trail of blood today after storming a hospital to arrest Lithuanians who fled the Red Army. In the ward where about 36 deserters had been staying, a soldier's wool hat with the Soviet army insignia torn off lay on one cot. Two feet away, a half-eaten loaf of black bread rested on a white sheet. Iron-barred windows were broken. A trail of blood led down the hospital steps and out the front door. ``They beat them with their fists,'' a duty nurse at the psychiatric hospital in Vilnius said. ``I was afraid they would shoot me.'' The hospital was one of at least two raided by Soviet troops making good on Moscow's promise to arrest Lithuanian deserters who hadn't returned to barracks by Saturday. After their government declared itself independent on March 11, hundrds of young Lithuanians fled the Soviet army and many sought refuge in the hospitals. The middle-aged nurse grew increasingly hysterical as she recounted her story for reporters at the hospital after the pre-dawn occupation. She said two truckloads of soldiers drove up to the hospital and beat on the front door before being let in. She said they rushed up the stairs to the second-floor ward where the young men were staying, often surrounded in the daytime by Soviet and foreign journalists. She said about two dozen men were beaten and taken away, while another 12 were able to escape. Two Lithuanian policemen were also beaten when they sought to intervene. An ABC television crew arriving at the scene was held at gunpoint by soldiers and forced to surrender videotape. ``They told us not to move,'' said Andrzej Lewandowski, a member of the news crew. His colleague, Chris Burzynski, said the soldiers made them take all equipment out of their car and seized their videocassettes. In Kaunas, about 65 miles west of the capital, Soviet soldiers took over the Red Cross hospital, which served as a sanctuary set up for the deserters by the Lithuanian government, a police officer said. About 50 soldiers arrived in five trucks, said the officer, who did not identify himself. ``They broke down doors and rousted all patients looking for soldiers,'' he said. ``They asked all likely young men and wound up taking two.''

DOC.HEAD: Death Came in Seconds to Saturday Night Revelers
With PM-Social Club Fire, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Atop the rickety wooden staircase, the dance floor trembled under heels tapping and shuffling to the beat that shifted from salsa to calypso. Disco lights glittered on silk clothes, Saturday night's finest. Suddenly, flames roaring in the bottom floor turned the top room into a blast furnace. Within seconds, superheated gases and thick smoke had silenced the place. Only a handful had escaped. The $5 cover was a small price to pay for a night out in the poor Latino community of East Tremont, near the Bronx Zoo. People dressed up nice and they partied hard. ``The whole floor moved with the music, it was sleazy and very, very hot,'' said Denise Garcia, 20. ``People liked to go there and show off.'' Lately, the patrons say, the mostly Honduran clientele had expanded to include other Hispanics. Sometimes a gun or a knife flashed, or someone whipped out a crack vial. Three of the victims played amateur soccer for a Bronx team named after one of the big teams in Honduras, where many of the youths hoped to return some day. ``They all dreamed of returning with more money, they were full of Hispanic machismo,'' said their coach, Miguel Reyes. At about 3:15 a.m. Sunday, there was a ruckus downstairs in the tiny entryway. A bearded Cuban patron was harassing his former girlfriend who worked at the club, and a bouncer was called over. ``Don't push me, don't push me,'' the patron said, according to witnesses. And then: ``I'll be back.'' The man identified as Julio Gonzalez, 36, angered by his rejection by ex-girlfriend Lydia Feliciano, fetched gasoline from a service station, according to police. Then he stood at the club's exit and splashed the fuel on the floor and wall inside. Then he struck a match. The Happy Land Social Club's name referred to America, regular patrons said, a place of hope for the young immigrants who frequented the club. When the fire allegedly lighted by Gonzalez took, fire investigators said, the ground floor became an inferno; the windowless second floor, where all but 18 of the 87 victims were found, was a gas chamber, with wall-to-wall bodies. The few survivors included Ms. Feliciano; Gonzalez, under suicide watch at a psychiatric ward, is charged with 87 murders. Long after dawn, a stream of corpses left the Happy Land on stretchers, covered with white sheets. Some died instantly. Rescue workers told of finding victims with glasses in their hands. Others were sitting at the bar, their legs still wound around bar stools. ``Lungs are seared by hot gases, and it becomes impossible to take a second breath,'' said Dr. Alexander Kuehl, director of emergency medicine at New York Hospital. ``And when there is not enough oxygen coming in to feed the fire, you get carbon monoxide, which can kill you in a minute.'' ``It was a huge rush of superheated poison gas. We call it a flashover, it is instant. If you are breathing in, it is deadly,'' said Zachary Goldfarb, Emergency Medical Service deputy chief of operations. Some victims, facing the wall of fire that came from downstairs, frantically tried to escape. Bodies were piled four deep by the upstairs door, a testament to their desperation. ``You can't imagine what went on in there; you can't imagine what these people did to try to survive,'' said firefighter Dennis Devlin. ``There was one woman who looked to be holding onto her boyfriend for dear life,'' said Emergency Medical Services worker Kerry Naughton, ``There was a man lying over a woman, as if he was trying to shield her with his body.'' There was no sprinkler system on the ground floor. The sprinklers on the second floor discharged after 87 people were dead, authorities said. Firefighters arrived in a few minutes, but there were no screams, no cries.

DOC.HEAD: Brothers Plead Innocent to Killing Their Parents
LaserPhoto LA2
DOC.TEXT: Two brothers pleaded innocent to the shotgun slaying of their parents that police said was carried out to obtain a $14 million inheritance. Erik Menendez, 19, and Lyle Menendez, 22, stood solemnly as they entered their pleas before Municipal Court Judge Judith O. Stein. The two could face the death penalty if convicted. The pair chatted quietly before the proceedings began, occasionally smiling and turning to nod at relatives sitting in the packed courtroom. The two stood as Ms. Stein read the charges against them: two counts each of murder, with allegations of committing the killings for financial gain, lying in wait with a shotgun and committing multiple murders. The sons are accused of killing their father, Hollywood film executive Jose Menendez, 45, and their mother, former beauty queen Kitty Menendez, 44, so they could inherit the couple's fortune. Ms. Stein set an April 9 date for them to return to Municipal Court for pretrial motions and the setting of a preliminary hearing date. At that time, the judge will consider a prosecution motion to unseal paperwork containing the evidence prosecutors say justified a search of the office of family psychologist Jerome Oziel. At issue is whether tape-recorded conversations between the brothers and Oziel may be used as evidence in the case. Such therapy sessions, like conferences with doctors and lawyers, are generally not admissible in court, but exceptions can be made in cases where threats are made. Deputy District Attorney Eliott Alhadeff said the privilege had been violated because threats were made during the conversations with Oziel. He also suggested some conversations took place outside a therapist-patient relationship. But Lyle Menendez's attorney, Gerald Chaleff, said he believes none of the tapes are admissible. Without the tapes, Chaleff said he believes the case is ``highly circumstantial and one that can be proved only if they are assumed to be guilty.'' Prosecutors say the sons fired repeated shotgun blasts at their parents as the couple watched television last August in an upstairs den in the family's Beverly Hills mansion. The killings were so bloody, and clues so few, that many in Hollywood believed the hard-driving Menendez had been killed by mobsters. They thought he might have run afoul of organized crime in his role as head of Live Entertainment, a video company affiliated with Carolco Pictures, the producer of the ``Rambo'' movies and other action films. After more than six months of investigation, police arrested the sons. The motive was greed, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders 131-Year Prison Term For Sexual Mutilation of Boy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents, especially 7th graf, `The 40-year-old...'
DOC.TEXT: A man whose rape and mutilation of a 7-year-old boy sparked a rewriting of sexual predator laws was ordered imprisoned for 131{ years by a judge who called him ``a danger to the defenseless.'' Pierce County Superior Court Judge Thomas R. Sauriol sentenced Earl Kenneth Shriner on Monday to three times the maximum standard term under state law. Even with time off for good behavior, Sauriol noted, Shriner still would have to serve more than 88 years. Shriner, diagnosed as slightly retarded, had a 25-year history of violence against young people. His case galvanized public efforts to get repeat sexual offenders off the street. The state Legislature enacted a strong sexual predator law. Sauriol told Shriner the crime had angered and troubled him more than any in his 37-year legal career. ``I don't think that I have ever heard of a case that borders on extreme cruelty more than this one,'' Sauriol said. ``The reality is, Mr. Shriner, you present a danger to the defenseless.'' Shriner, who did not testify in his own defense, said nothing. The 40-year-old Shriner was convicted Feb. 7 of first-degree attempted murder, two counts of first-degree rape and first-degree assault in the May 20, 1989, attack on a 7-year-old boy in a wooded area near their homes in south Tacoma. The boy was raped, choked and had his penis cut off. Neighbors said they found the boy naked, bloody, covered with mud and practically incoherent. A jail inmate testified during the trial that Shriner admitted mutilating the boy, who has since undergone reconstructive surgery. The boy, who identified Shriner in court as his attacker, was not present. The victim's mother, Helen Harlow, dabbing her eyes and comforted by friends, said she was satisfied with the sentence. Deputy Prosecutor Barbara Corey-Boulet said, ``I think that it served the purpose.'' Defense attorney Dino Sepe said he would appeal the verdict and the sentence. If the convictions stand, defense attorneys said Shriner's sentence should have been within the standard range of 34 years to 43 years, 10 months. Harlow's voice broke as she described to the court how the attack had shattered her and her son's lives. ``It all comes down to forgiveness,'' she told the judge. ``If we are to forgive him, it will be in the context of knowing that we are safe from him.'' In sentencing Shriner, Sauriol criticized legislation that would have permitted a 75 percent reduction in prison terms for sex offenders who voluntarily submit to surgical castration. The measure died in the state House of Representatives after clearing the Senate this year. Corey-Boulet had argued for a longer prison term partly because a similar bill might one day become law. Shriner was declared a ``defective delinquent'' in 1965 after choking a 7-year-old girl. The term, now abandoned, referred to violence-prone juveniles with emotional or mental problems. He subsequently was confined at Rainier School for the retarded; Western State Hospital, a mental institution; and the Washington Corrections Center, where he served 10 years for assaulting two 16-year-old hitchhikers.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Lawmakers Balk at U.S. Trade Demands
DOC.TEXT: Japanese lawmakers meeting with Washington officials today balked at American demands they enact broad economic reforms to help shrink the $49 billion U.S. trade deficit with Japan. In trade talks last week, U.S. officials urged Japan to revise land-use policies, streamline its retail distribution system and increase government spending in order to boost consumption of imports. Lawmakers attending the breakfast meeting said U.S. Embassy officials were told the reforms would be difficult to achieve quickly. At Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's request, the Japanese government has drawn up proposals aimed at meeting the U.S. requests made during the ongoing trade talks. In remarks to Parliament, Japanese officials have said the reforms should be undertaken for the sake of Japanese consumers. But some leaders of the governing Liberal Democratic Party are less conciliatory toward the United States, said party lawmaker Takujiro Hamada, who chaired today's meeting. ``The parliamentarians said resistance to the reforms was very strong in their constituencies,'' Hamada said. Another Liberal Democratic lawmaker, Ichiji Ishii said: ``The opinions expressed by the Japanese legislators were rather severe.'' ``They said the `menu' of U.S. demands was much too big,'' he said. Japanese newspapers have said U.S. officials gave Japan a list of more than 200 suggestions aimed at eliminating structural barriers Washington says prevent foreign companies from entering Japanese markets. Japan says problems on the U.S. side also contribute to the trade imbalance. In the latest round of trade talks last week, Japan suggested the United States raise taxes, wean itself from energy-wasting cars and limit the use of credit cards, the mass circulation newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun reported. The suggestions were among 80 Japanese proposals for cutting the U.S. federal budget deficit, increasing savings and investment and improving worker training and education, the paper said. The measures were designed to boost the competitiveness of American exports, it said. Acccording to Hamada, the powerful former foreign minister, Shintaro Abe, said charges Japan had done nothing to resolve the trade imbalance were ``absolutely wrong.'' ``It seems almost as if Japan is being scolded for having such a powerful, competitive economy,'' Hamada said. Japan and the United States are both to come up with interim reports on the trade talks in early April. A final report is expected in July.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd item on Trump to UPDATE throughout with accusations of adultery, details
DOC.TEXT: For better or worse or until billions do them part, says the lawyer for Ivana Trump, who thinks his client should get half of her estranged husband's fortune _ which he estimated at $5 billion. Mrs. Trump's lawyers said in papers filed Monday that she does not intend to file for divorce, despite allegations that Trump in 1987 ``was engaging in adulterous relationships ... including the notorious relationship with Marla Maples.'' ``She wants to preserve the family unit,'' her attorney, Michael Kennedy, said at an afternoon news conference. Lawyers for Trump refused to comment on the allegation of adultery and said the papers were ``legally and factually deficient.'' They have 20 days to file a response. The papers filed Monday state that Mrs. Trump never waived the right to an ``equitable share'' of the properties Trump accumulated during their 13-year marriage. Kennedy said Mrs. Trumpe was not advised by her former attorney, Lawrence H. Levner, of her right to up to half the property acquired by either partner during the marriage, as provided by the 1980 state Domestic Relations Law. Trump attorneys Jay Goldberg and Stan Lotwin called the action a ``low blow.'' They denied Kennedy's assertion that Trump had forced his wife to accept Levner as her lawyer. Levner declined to comment. Goldberg said Mrs. Trump's claim to be a ``worldly, wise and knowledgeable woman'' who made significant contributions to the Trump empire was inconsistent with her assertion that she was unaware of her rights when she signed a 1987 post-marital agreement. Kennedy denied reports that the contract called for Mrs. Trump to receive $25 million in the event the marriage broke up. Golderg called the move by Mrs. Trump a ``pressure tactic designed to force a settlement.'' ``He will not surrender,'' Goldberg said of Trump. ``Through his own brains he made it. She took care of the kids and did the laundry.'' Asked if Trump intended to file for divorce, Lotwin said, ``He has really left his options open.'' The Trumps' marital problems came to light last month when the developer left his wife, setting off a geyser of headlines and speculation about Trump's relationships with other women.

DOC.HEAD: Stars Celebrate Hollywood's Biggest Night
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, to RESTORE name of academy president Malden. Picks up 15th graf pvs, `Cates acknowledged...
DOC.TEXT: After watching the Motion Picture Academy dole out awards over 3{ hours, Hollywood's stars fanned out from the downtown Music Center to glittery parties thronged by hoards of fans. ``Was it a good show? You can never tell when you're there,'' said Anjelica Huston, at a bash at the Mondrian Hotel Monday night. Miss Huston wandered around the palm tree-lined patio with the likes of Rob Lowe, Dudley Moore, Billy Crystal, Christina Applegate and former California Gov. Jerry Brown. Oliver Stone, winner of the best director Oscar for ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' was mobbed in the lobby by autograph-seeking fans. He posed briefly for pictures with Crystal and was hustled into an elevator. A few blocks up Sunset Boulevard, hundreds of squealing fans cheered a procession of limousines dropping off passengers at the prestigious Spago party put on by literary agent Irving ``Swifty'' Lazar. Inside, guests dined on Wolfgang Puck's famous pizza and pasta. Back downtown, the prestigious Board of Governors Ball took on the festive atmosphere of what it must have been like when the Academy Awards were celebrated in ballrooms at local hotels. The Music Center patrons had only to move a few yards into a huge white tent with oversized balloons at the top. Winners and losers congregated around the dance floor and congratulated and commiserated with each other in a communal spirit rarely seen in today's Hollywood. Warren Beatty and Jack Nicholson, who handed out the best picture award to ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' checked out the scene and chatted with friends like Jessica Lange and Daryl Hannah. Best actress winner Jessica Tandy and her husband of 47 years, Hume Cronyn, accepted congratulations at their table while Martin Scorsese, Spike Lee and Danny Aiello represented the New York crowd in their own corner. ``Mighty good show,'' commented Oscar winner Gregory Peck, who presented the award to Miss Tandy for her starring role in ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' The air at the Governors Ball was largely one of self-congratulation, with the 3{-hour show drawing plaudits from those who attended. Academy President Karl Malden quieted the crowd to introduce Gilbert Cates, who produced the 62nd Oscar presentation. Cates acknowledged that he was trying something unique in the satellite feeds from four foreign capitals but general opinion was that the gimmick worked. Earlier in the day, former President Ronald Reagan and his wife Nancy kicked off the third annual Oscar night gala to benefit Athletes and Entertainers for Kids at a Beverly Hills hotel. Reagan told 40 disadvantaged and sick youngsters from various hospitals and inner city community centers that people indeed care about them. ``We're so proud of each and every one of you for your strength and courage,'' Reagan said before handing out yo-yos. Mrs. Reagan, in an emotional voice, said, ``I know it's tough but you'll make it. I just want to say I'm proud of you and I love you.''

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Urges Gorbachev to Stop Military Pressure On Lithuania
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa today appealed to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to halt Red Army pressure on Lithuania and open a dialogue with the independence-minded republic. Walesa said Gorbachev's reform policies, including his decision to end the Communist Party's monopoly on power, were ``unquestioned achievements,'' possible only because of the Soviet leader's ``bold politics.'' But in a letter addressed to the Soviet president and released by Solidarity headquarters in Gdansk, Walesa expressed grave concern over Soviet moves in neighboring Lithuania. ``I am filled with greatest anxiety by the Soviet actions in Lithuania,'' Walesa said of today's arrests of Lithuanian deserters from the Soviet army and occupation of Communist Party buildings in the republic. In the letter, the Solidarity leader said the actions were ``in striking contradiction with the spirit of the policy you have been carrying out for years.'' Walesa, who led the political forces that ended Communist rule in Poland, warned that recent history in Eastern Europe has shown military force to not be an effective means of resolving political problems. ``Violating the sovereignty of Lithuania is an action directed against the process of constructing a new democratic order in Europe,'' Walesa said. ``I turn to you, Mr. President, to abandon the practice of military pressure and undertake political dialogue with the Lithuanian government.'' The Polish government supports Lithuania's drive for self-determination. The Soviet Union forcibly annexed Lithuania and the two other Baltic republics of Latvia and Estonia in 1940. The republic declared its independence from Moscow on March 11. A hihg-powered Polish parliamentary delegation arrived in Lithuania on Friday for talks with Lithuanian President Vytautas Lansbergis, caucus spokesman Jacek Zakowski said.

DOC.HEAD: Government to Start Processing U.S. Toy Company's Entry
DOC.TEXT: In a case seen as a test of alleged unfair barriers to entering the Japanese market, the government has agreed to consider a U.S. toy company's move to open a store in the country, officials said today. Toys ``R'' Us has announced plans to open a 53,800-square-foot discount store in Niigata, 160 miles northwest of Tokyo. Local shopkeepers were strongly opposing the move, news reports said. Under Japan's Large-Scale Retail Stores Law, designed to protect small retailers, they must be consulted before the opening of any large stores in their areas. While some Japanese retailers have had to wait up to 10 years for permission to set up large new stores, ``consideration is under way to shorten the maximum waiting period required under the law to two years,'' said an official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. The Minister for international trade, Kabun Muto, told a news conference today that he urged his aides to work out plans to shorten the consultation process required under the law. The ministry and local agencies in Niigata prefecture agreed Monday to start procedures for the store-opening plan by Paramus, N.J.-based Toys ``R'' Us, said the ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity. The official, of the ministry's Industrial Policy Bureau, said local retailers will receive an advance explanation of the plan by mid-April. The U.S. company then is to submit formal notification of the plan to the trade minister, and deliberations by a group of local retailers, consumers and scholars will follow, he said. The Large-Scale Retail Stores Law has been among targets of U.S. officials seeking changes in what are seen as structural barriers that contribute to the United States' $49 billion deficit in trade with Japan. In addition to making entry to Japan's market difficult for foreign retailers, it works against larger Japanese stores that would be more likely to carry foreign products, U.S. officials say. Japan says U.S. economic practices such as widespread credit purchases also contribute to the trade imbalance. The two sides have been negotiating steps to change such practices, and each side is to produce an interim report on reform plans in April.

DOC.HEAD: Oscars Ceremony Stresses the International
With PM-Oscars, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``'Twas a fine night for the Irish,'' said Gregory Peck at the Governors Ball following the 62nd Academy Awards. And for the English, the Italians, the Japanese and Americans. The first International Academy Awards were truly that, both in award giving and in the program's origins. The Academy voters gave their prized trophy without concern for chauvinism and with a pervading prejudice for humanism. The Irish were triumphant with ``My Left Foot,'' winning Oscars for Daniel Day-Lewis as best actor and Brenda Fricker as supporting actress. Although Day-Lewis is English, Miss Fricker is Irish through and through. So, too, is ``My Left Foot,'' filmed in Dublin on a $2.5 million shoestring budget. It's the saga of a curious Irish hero, Christy Brown, the cerebral palsy victim who vanquished superhuman odds to become an acclaimed artist and writer, using only his foot to communicate. ``Cinema Paradiso'' was a popular winner for best foreign language film. The Italian movie, like Monday night's Oscar cast, celebrates the love of film. It tells the story of a village boy who spends much of his youth in the projection room of the local movie house. Jessica Tandy, London-born and now a U.S. citizen, added to the internationalism with her best actress win for ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' Americans also figured in the honors, notably Denzel Washington as supporting actor in ``Glory'' and Oliver Stone for directing ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' The Academy voters were not impressed by the megabuck achievers, awarding one lesser Oscar apiece to ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade'' and ``Batman.'' Their principal concern seemed to be the human condition, whether it entailed race relations (``Driving Miss Daisy'' and ``Glory'') or the plight of the handicapped (``My Left Foot'' and ``Born on the Fourth of July.'') In one of the evening's most heartwarming and significant events, Steven Spielberg and George Lucas presented a special award to Akira Kurosawa, considered by many critics as the greatest living filmmaker. Kurosawa was greeted by fellow workers in Japan who led a ``Happy Birthday'' serenade. The director of ``The Seven Samurai'' and ``Ran'' reached 80 last weekend. Satellite feeds from London, Moscow, Sydney and Buenos Aires gave diversity to the telecast, even though Jack Lemmon was subjected to a triple echo in Moscow. Despite its bloated length at more than 3{ hours, the Music Center ceremony generally got good reviews from those attending. Billy Crystal was a popular emcee, his flashes of humor almost always on target. Oscar organizers say there seems to be no way to reduce the excessive length unless a half-dozen or more awards are eliminated or given off-camera. A move to do either would meet with screams from the Academy's various category divisions. The Academy has long preached that all the nominees are winners, and that theme was carried out for a second consecutive year. Instead of the timeworn phrase, ``And the winner is...,'' the presenters were instructed to say, ``And the Oscar goes to... .'' That may be of some consolation to the losers. Then again, probably not.

DOC.HEAD: Japan, U.S. Exchange Notes on Sparrow Missile License
DOC.TEXT: Japan and the United States exchanged diplomatic notes today allowing Japan to manufacture an improved version of the U.S.-made Sparrow missile system under license, Defense Agency officials said. Japan's Air Self Defense Force will use the improved AIM-7M missile system to arm its F-15 jet fighter planes and other types of aircraft, a Defense Agency official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The new, more reliable missile will replace the AIM-7F missile system currently used here, he said. The official refused to provide other details, including the number of missiles to be manufactured in Japan. Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama and U.S. Ambassador Michael Armacost exchanged the notes on acquisition and production of the AIM-7M Sparrow missile system, developed by Raytheon Co. of Lexington, Mass. The system will be produced in Japan by a group of companies, with Mitsubishi Electric Corp. as the main contractor, the official said. Japan's Air Self-Defense Force maintains 112 U.S.-designed F-15 fighters, most of them built in Japan under license. Some ``blackbox'' components that use secret technology, including computers and advanced avionic systems, are sent from the United States for installation in the planes, said another Defense Agency official, also speaking on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Transport Airplane Crashes Near Kabul
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Changes to crashed near, sted crashed over; SUBS 3rd graf to correct spelling of accommodates.
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet Aeroflot airlines transport plane of the Il-76 type crashed today near Afghanistan's capital of Kabul, the official Soviet news agency Tass said. ``The fate of the crew and the causes of the accident are being investigated,'' Tass said in a brief announcement. The Il-76, a freight transport, accommodates a crew of seven, including two freight handlers. Tass said the plane was carrying civilian goods and crashed as it was flying toward Kabul airport at noon local time. The Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan in 1980 and says it lost about 14,000 soldiers in the nine-year war there before pulling out in 1989. It still provides supplies to the Kabul government, which is fighting U.S.-backed Moslem rebels.

DOC.HEAD: World Leaders Urge Moscow to End Show of Force in Lithuania
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: European leaders today urged the Soviet Union to end its military show of force in Lithuania and to hold talks with leaders of the Baltic republic. At NATO headquarters and in capitals across the continent, leaders warned that today's storming of hospitals sheltering Soviet Army deserters, as well as the weekend display of military might, could slow democratic reforms in Eastern Europe and damage East-West relations. Poland's Solidarity leader Lech Walesa sent a letter to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev expressing the ``greatest anxiety'' about events in the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius. ``Violating the sovereignty of Lithuania is an action directed against the process of constructing a new democratic order in Europe,'' Walesa said. ``I turn to you, Mr. President, to abandon the practice of military pressure and undertake political dialogue with the Lithuanian government,'' he said. Norway's Prime Minister Jan P. Syse called Moscow's parading of tanks and order to confiscate firearms ``a shockingly unwise step. They have made an already tense situation dangerously acute.'' ``Monday's cautious hope for negotiations and dialogue today emerge as a tactical game, a completely destructive course, from which we sharply dissociate,'' Syse said in a statement. ``It is now crucial that Soviet leaders express willingness to negotiate before the situation gets entirely out of control. Continued use of power will not solve any problems, but can seriously jeopardize the results recently achieved in East-West relations.'' At NATO headquarters in Brussels, senior officials monitoring events in Lithuania fear ``adverse developments'' there could hurt the improved East-West climate, an alliance official said. ``If the situation is not solved peacefully through negotiations, it could derail a lot of other things,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. He said senior political officers of the 16 nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization met in a special session on Monday and continued their talks today. After Monday's closed-door discussions, the official said: ``There was a sense of the people at the meeting that talks between Gorbachev and the Lithuanians should take place in an atmosphere free of intimidation or pressure of any kind.'' He said it was also the feeling of those at the meeting that ``any adverse developments in Lithuania would have consequences for positive, international political trends.'' He declined to elaborate on the possible consequences. The Dutch government issued a statement expressing its ``worry about the increasing pressure ... that is being exacted on the Lithuanian population through a military show of force.'' The Dutch urged Moscow to use ``maximum restraint'' to ``peacefully solve the conflict with Lithuania along political lines.'' The British Foreign Office had no comment today, referring reporters to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's statement in the House of Commons last week. She said then that Britain supports Lithuania's desire to determine its own future, and that it never recognized Moscow's annexation of the Baltic republics.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative, Center-Left Parties Lead After Hungary Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with latest results, further details on slow counting; Picks up 8th graf, `The apparent ...'
DOC.TEXT: Rival center-right and liberal parties plotted strategies today to try to win enough support in runoff elections to form Hungary's first post-war non-Communist government. Final results of the country's first free elections in 43 years remained unavailable this afternoon, two days after the last of millions of voters cast ballots for the 394-seat Parliament. A final tally from the 11,000 polls was not expected before late today, and Janos Nemeth, chairman of the National Electoral Committee, blamed the Interior Ministry because its electoral office was supplying incomplete information on the voting to the committee. Nemeth did not specify whether he thought the Interior Ministry, which many Hungarians continue to associate with Communist repression because of its control of internal security, was willfully delaying results showing a poor performance by the old-guard Communist Party. An Interior Ministry official, who declined to give his name on the telephone, denied the the delay was deliberate. He said it was due to the slow transmission of data to the ministry from outlying polling stations. More than 70 percent of Hungary's 7.8 million eligible voters cast ballots, election officials said. By late Monday, only five of the seats were decided. With more than 80 percent of the ballots cast for 29 parties running counted, the conservative Hungarian Democratic Forum led with 24.7 percent of the vote, the center-left League of Free Democrats had 21.6 percent, and the rural-based Independent Smallholders was in third with 11.9 percent. The Democratic Forum wants to move more slowly than the Free Democrats toward market-oriented reform, in grappling with an economy beset by double-digit inflation and a $20 billion foreign debt after four decades of Communist rule. Neither of the two leading parties garnered anything close to the absolute majority needed for decisive victory, making a coalition government likely after runoff elections are held next month, possibly on April 8. Democratic Forum chairman Joszef Antall said the Independent Smallholders would be his first choice as coalition partners, and like the Free Democrats, he dismissed any idea of working with the Socialists. Far back in fourth place with 10.7 percent were the ruling Socialists, the successors of the old Communist party who campaigned on a democratic platform but apparently were still associated by voters with the Communist past. The apparent aversion to anything that smacked of socialism accounted for the poor showing by the Social Democrats, who hadn't managed to clear the 4 percent hurdle needed to gain representation in Parliament. Voters in East Germany on March 18 had a similar reaction to four decades of Communist rule, choosing a conservative coalition. The old-style Communists who refused to join the reform wing in founding the Socialist Party last October also fared badly. Their leader, Gyula Thuermer, finished a distant fifth in a western district and the party also failed to clear the 4 percent hurdle, preliminary results showed. Among the five seats decided outright were three taken by Democratic Forum members and one by Premier Miklos Nemeth, a reform Communist, the Socialist Party co-founder and chief supporter of democracy. Nemeth ran as an independent in his home riding of Szerencs, 70 miles northeast of Budapest. Nemeth said his outgoing government should receive credit for leading the nation to Sunday's historic vote.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Upholds Death Sentence For Bomber of KAL Flight
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today upheld the death sentence of a Communist agent convicted of bombing a South Korean jetliner in 1987, killing all 115 people aboard, court officials said. The officials said today's ruling marked the end of the appeals process for confessed North Korean agent Kim Hyon Hee, 27, but there were reports she might be pardoned. About a dozen family members of victims interrupted the proceedings shouting, ``No special pardon for Kim! Hang her!'' Court officials said Kim was not in the courtroom. She was sentenced to death after a trial that began in February 1989, more than a year after Korean Air (KAL) Flight 858 vanished over the Andaman Sea near Burma on Nov. 29, 1987. Local newspapers, quoting unnamed government officials, said prosecutors will recommend that President Roh Tae-woo give Kim a special pardon in consideration of her full repentance and cooperation. Pardons have been granted to some North Korean agents who have shown repentance in the past. Kim said at her trial that under instructions from Communist North Korea, she planted two bombs in the overhead luggage bin of the Boeing 707 that departed from Baghdad, Iraq, for Seoul. North Korea has denied any involvement. She said she and a male accomplice got off the plane during a stopover in Abu Dhabi. Several hours later, the plane disappeared and no survivors were found. The pair was caught in Bahrain, while they were trying to flee. Both attempted suicide with poisoned cigarettes when they were arrestecd. The man died, but Kim survived and was extradited to Seoul.

DOC.HEAD: Military Ruler Denies Allegations Of Pol Pot-Style Resettlement
DOC.TEXT: Military ruler Gen. Saw Maung today rejected criticism of his government's mass resettlement program and charges of official corruption in narcotics trafficking. In a speech during the annual armed forces day in Rangoon, the general who seized power in 1988 said foreign news organizations are interfering with Burma's internal affairs by broadcasting such critical reports. ``I hereby categorically deny all these groundless accusations as totally false,'' Saw Maung said. Foreign media have quoted Western diplomats in Rangoon as saying the government has moved up to a half million people from urban areas to outlying areas in order to break up regions of political dissent. In a statement received in Bangkok today, Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., compared the resettlement policy to that of ousted Cambodian leader Pol Pot. During Pol Pot's Communist Khmer Rouge government from 1975-1978, hundreds of thousands of Cambodians died from executions, famine and civil unrest. The U.S. State Department last week also criticized Burma's relocations. Saw Maung claimed the program was aimed at giving land to homeless people who had been living on religious land, cemeteries and rubbish dumps. Diplomats said it was designed to prevent a repeat of the massive anti-government protests of 1988, which the military brutally crushed when it seized power in September that year. Saw Maung dismissed as ``groundless'' what he said was a March 10 Voice of America report saying the flow of narcotics from Burma was out of control because of corruption among Burmese, Thai and Laotian officials. On Monday in Bangkok, U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Melvin Levitsky accused the Burmese government of colluding with narcotics traffickers and doing little to stem a record outflow of heroin. In his address, Saw Maung also attacked foreign media reports on the arrest and suppression of opposition groups. Moynihan's statement denounced Thailand for ``profiting from the desperation of the Burmese regime.'' Thailand has been one of the few countries to embrace Saw Maung's government. It has since secured valuable logging, mining and fishing concessions.

DOC.HEAD: Norway's Seal Hunt Begins, Hunters Find Peace in Arctic Storms
DOC.TEXT: Norway's seal hunt began this week, allowing hunters to escape to the relative peace of howling wind and bitter cold of an Arctic island. The real storm is on the mainland. Environmental and animal welfare groups demand an end to the heavily subsidized hunt for thousands of adult seals. Photographs of seal pups being beaten to death, so their white pelts would not be marred by gunshot wounds, sparked furious international protest and forced Norway to ban the hunt for pups beginning last year. Seal men complain of hate mail and death threats. Opponents collected 80,000 signatures on a petition in Sweden this month, and demonstrators poured blood-red paint outside the Norway's Embassy in Stockholm. Protesters say the hunt threatens seal stocks, a claim disputed by the government. The hunters' claim, that unchecked seal populations deplete coastal fish stocks, also is debated. ``Norway as a fishing nation must have the right to determine how its own ocean resources will be used. We cannot allow environmental groups to dictate our policy,'' said Karsten Klepsvik, of Norway's fishing ministry. Hunters and those processing the catch will get $1.4 million in state subsidies this year, to maintain employment and keep the hunt going, Klepsvik said. Two of Norway's active seal-hunting fleet of four vessels set sail on Monday for the Greenland Sea around Jan Mayen island, just inside the Arctic Circle. Animal welfare groups find abhorrent the traditional killing method of clubbing or hitting the animals in the head with a sharp pick. ``There is no rational reason for continuing the hunt. The whole hunt is an exercise in national chauvinism, maintaining tradition for tradition's sake,'' said Paul Bugge, of Greenpeace Norway. Sigbjoern Espensen, 17, was uncomprehending of the hubbub as he joined his second hunt. ``I guess I'm just bitten by the bug,'' he told the Dagbladet newspaper before sailing north. Veteran arctic skipper Paul Stark said he also has trouble understanding the uproar, figuring that seal-hunting will die out anyway. ``The ships are old and no one is building new ones,'' he said. The hunters have a quota of 34,400 adult seals, cut by 4,100 from last year. Prior to 1975, Norwegians killed 100,000 seals a year, Klepsvik said. ``We hope someday this wave of hate will ease and we will be able to sell the products again,'' he said. Christian Rieber, Norway's last big seal pelt buyer, said he received 5,000 pieces of hate mail on Monday alone. The total is about 100,000 post cards so far this year, in a campaign he said was coordinated in the United States. One card called Rieber ``the merchant of death.'' Another, from Orlando, Fla., ordered him to ``leave my seals alone.'' A third, from Sweden, threatened him with ``a slow and painful death.'' ``I'm used to it. It follows a pattern,'' said Rieber, 65. He claimed that campaigns start up whenever activists need money. Environmentalists say Rieber bears primary blame. ``The blame lies where the money is. Without him, the whole seal hunt would stop,'' Bugge said. ``We don't make any money on seals. The government pays for it,'' said Rieber, whose family has worked in the seal trade for 100 years. He said bans on importing pelts to many countries left his company with 100,000 unsold skins in storage.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Expelled 33,400 Members Last Year
DOC.TEXT: China's Communist Party expelled 33,400 members last year for ``unhealthy tendencies'' such as abuse of power or ideological shortcomings, the official party daily said today. Party inspection offices investigated 197,400 cases of discipline violations within the party, and measures were taken against 158,800 members, the People's Daily said. The 48-million-member ruling party urged a reappraisal of the credentials of all its members following last spring's pro-democracy movement that gained considerable support from party members. After the movement was crushed in June, party leaders said those who had failed to pass the ideological tests of the ``counter-revolutionary rebellion'' would face expulsion or other disciplinary action. However, the People's Daily report did not give a breakdown of reasons for the expulsions, and the number was not noticeably higher than in past years. In 1987 the party expelled 25,000 members, bringing the total number of expulsions between 1982 and 1987 to 177,000. No figures were available for 1988. In the past, most of those dropped from party ranks were charged with economic crimes such as bribery or accused of using their party office to obtain lavish banquets, good housing or preferential treatment for family members.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Federal Black Lung Benefits Law
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today upheld a federal law that one state court said makes it too difficult for coal miners who contract ``black lung'' to get a lawyer's help when seeking benefits. The justices unanimously reversed a ruling by West Virginia's highest court that the law, and its system for awarding lawyer fees in black lung benefits cases, violates due-process rights. ``The evidence relied upon by the West Virginia Supreme Court did not remotely establish either that black lung claimants are unable to retain qualified counsel or that the cause of such inability is the attorney's fees system'' used by the Labor Department, Justice Antonin Scalia wrote for the court. Pneumoconiosis, a chronic respiratory and pulmonary disease commonly called black lung, afflicts numerous coal miners. Under the Black Lung Benefits Act, Congress provides disability payments to those miners who are unable to work because of the disease. Those who apply for such benefits are entitled to have a lawyer's help, and lawyers who assist miners in obtaining benefits have their fees paid by the coal mine operator, its insurance carrier or the government. To get such fees paid, a lawyer must apply separately to the Labor Department and to the official that presided over the application hearing. No fees award is made until a miner receives a final award of benefits. West Virginia lawyer George R. Triplett, beginning in 1978, entered into contingent-fee agreements to help about 15 miners seeking black lung benefits. The agreements entitled Triplett to one-fourth of any back benefits collected by the miners. Since the fees Triplett collected between 1978 and 1983 were never approved by the Labor Department or any court, they were in violation of Labor Department regulations. The West Virginia State Bar's Committee on Legal Ethics in 1987 recommended that the state's highest court suspend Triplett for six months for violating the regulations. The state Supreme Court of Appeals, in a 3-2 decision in 1988, refused to enforce the suspension. The state court said the evidence made clear that most lawyers are unwilling to represent miners seeking black lung benefits because of ``inadequate fees'' and the long delays in collecting them. Once a miner is awarded benefits, the state court said, it often takes ``an additional two years ... for a lawyer to be paid his fee.'' There is no provision for interest payments. The state court ruling did not bar the Labor Department's own enforcement of its attorney-fee regulations, but it knocked out the primary method of enforcing those regulations in West Virginia _ state bar disciplinary hearings. Today's decision said the state court did not have enough solid evidence to make its ruling. ``As to the ... unavailability of attorneys, the court relied upon three lawyers' assessments,'' Scalia wrote. ``This will not do.'' He said past high court rulings ``made clear that this sort of anecdotal evidence will not overcome the presumption of regularity and constitutionality to which a program established by Congress is entitled.'' Scalia also said there was insufficient proof that the asserted unavailability of lawyers to handle black lung benefits cases could be tied to a fees system. The case is Labor Department vs. Triplett, 88-1671.

DOC.HEAD: Problems Could Delay U.N.-Coordinated Relief Program in Sudan
DOC.TEXT: Disagreements over the amounts of food going to government and rebel-held territories could delay a U.N.-coordinated relief operation to help millions threatened by famine. United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, in a message to a meeting of Sudanese government officials and Western donors Monday, urged fast action to head off a disaster in southern Sudan. Christian and animist rebels in the south have waged a 7-year-old war for autonomy from the Moslem-dominated government in Khartoum. The war created a famine estimated to have killed 300,000 southerners in 1988. ``Unless immediate and effective action is taken to expedite the delivery and distribution of food and other humanitarian supplies to the affected civilian populations, we may once more be faced with a disaster of major proportions,'' Perez de Cuellar said. The message was read at the meeting by Michael Priestly, the secretary-general's special representative for emergency and relief operations in Sudan. ``There are still substantial differences on the details of relief and rehabilitation allocations, and more recently, funding arrangements, which could further delay phase two of Operation Lifeline Sudan unless a more pragmatic approach be adopted by all concerned,'' Perez de Cuellar said. The U.N. work plan says that 4.5 million southerners need emergency relief assistance this summer. About 2.3 million live in the war-torn areas in southern Sudan, 400,000 others fled to border areas and about 1.8 million displaced people have gone to Khartoum. Operation Lifeline Sudan, a massive international relief effort coordinated by the United Nations in 1989, is credited with saving hundreds of thousands of lives. The operation was made possible be a de facto cease-fire between the government and the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army. The relief operation was halted when fighting resumed between the two sides late last year. About 87,000 tons of food and other supplies had been sent to famine areas, some 18,000 tons short of the targeted amount. The United Nations had hoped to start ferrying 104,000 tons of fresh relief supplies to the south by the beginning of next month. But last week the rebels claimed the relief program was biased in favor of the government. They hinted they might block it unless the United Nations decides to send more food to rebel-held areas.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Proposes Declaration of Commitment To Free-Market Principles
DOC.TEXT: The United States wants the Soviet Union and all other participants of a 35-nation economic conference to sign a declaration committing themselves to Western-style free-market principles, U.S. officials said today. A Soviet official at the meeting welcomed the idea of establishing guidelines for expansion of East-West economic cooperation but expressed reservations about the U.S. proposal. Alan F. Holmer, a former U.S. deputy trade representative who heads the U.S. delegation, said the United States wants to help lay the groundwork for increased East-West economic activity. ``Once you get the economic principles established (in the East bloc), the commercial relationships will flow relatively automatically. But without the right principles, you won't have the commercial relationships,'' Holmer said. John Evans, the No. 2 U.S. delegate at the conference in the West German capital, rejected any suggestion Washington was trying to set conditions for stepped-up U.S. economic involvement with the East bloc. But like Holmer, he made it clear free-market principles would foster greater economic links between the wealthy West and reforming East bloc countries. ``We should face up to the fact that market economies are what work,'' Evans said. The United States is asking the 35-nation Conference on Economic Cooperation in Europe to adopt what the U.S. delegates have called the ``Bonn Principles for Economic Cooperation.'' Among other things, the document says the 35 nations recognize the importance of ``international policies which support the expansion of free, open trade, investment and capital flows'' and ``full recognition and protection of rights of citizens to hold and use private property.'' A high-ranking Soviet official at the conference, Sergei Zotov, said he supports the U.S. idea of setting out principles for East-West economic cooperation. He also said the U.S. initiative could become a ``positive contribution'' toward broadening East-West economic links. But he said the U.S. document ``presents more a code of behavior'' for East bloc countries rather than concerning itself with ``purely principles of economic cooperation.'' Zotov is deputy head of the Soviet Foreign Ministry's Department of Security and Cooperation in Europe. Zotov also said he doubts whether there is enough time for the 35-nation conference to thoroughly discuss the U.S. proposal and act on it. The meeting of government officials and business executives began on March 20 and runs through April 11. The 35-nation group includes the United States, Canada and all Eastern and Western European nations except Albania.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Michigan Law Limiting Campaign Spending by Corporations
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today gave states new power to limit political campaign spending by corporations, upholding a Michigan law challenged by that state's Chamber of Commerce. Voting 6-3, the justices said such restrictions are justified by the state's interest in preventing corruption or even its appearance. The court rejected arguments that the Michigan law violates free speech rights of Chamber of Commerce members. Supporters of the state law said it is intended to prevent corporate giants, such as the major automobile manufacturers, from funneling millions of dollars through the chamber to favorite candidates without revealing the spending. ``Corporate wealth can unfairly influence elections when it is deployed in the form of independent expenditures,'' Justice Thurgood Marshall said for the court. ``We therefore hold that the state has articulated a sufficiently compelling rationale to support its restriction on independent expenditures by corporations,'' he said. Marshall also rejected arguments that the law is unconstitutional because it exempts labor unions and media corporations. He noted that union members who disagree with a union's political activities can decline to contribute to them without giving up their membership. Media corporations merit exemption to protect the role of broadcasters and publishers in reporting and commenting on newsworthy events, Marshall added. In a dissenting opinion, Justice Antonin Scalia said, ``The court today endorses the principle that too much speech is an evil that the democratic majority can proscribe. The principle is ... incompatible with the absolutely central truth of the First Amendment: that government cannot be trusted to assure, through censorship, the fairness of political debate.'' Justices Anthony M. Kennedy and Sandra Day O'Connor also dissented. The ruling is a victory for the Federal Election Commission, which supported an appeal by Michigan officials. The Michigan Chamber of Commerce has some 8,000 dues-paying members, about three-fourths of them corporations. The chamber planned in 1985 to place a paid advertisement in the Grand Rapids Press in support of Richard Bandstra, a Republican candidate for the state House of Representatives. Fearing the ad would be considered illegal under Michigan's Campaign Finance Act, the business group filed a federal suit seeking to have the law declared unconstitutional as applied to the chamber. The law generally prohibits corporations from spending in behalf of political candidates and carries a maximum $10,000 fine. The act permits a corporation to make such expenditures if it sets up a special fund, or political action committee, that is required to keep records and disclose the name of contributors. The chamber has such a fund. But it wanted to pay for the newspaper ad for Bandstra out of its general treasury, which is exempt from the record-keeping and reporting requirements of the campaign finance law. The 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals exempted the Chamber of Commerce from the law. The appeals court relied heavily on a 1986 Supreme Court ruling limiting the federal government's power to regulate corporate political spending. The justices said then that the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 violates freedom of speech when applied to corporations formed primarily to influence public opinion and not to make a profit. The high court in 1986 ruled in favor of a Massachusetts ``pro-life'' group formed to protest the legalization of abortion. But today the justices drew key distinctions between the Massachusetts group and the Chamber of Commerce. Marshall said the pro-life organization's narrow focus ensured its resources reflected political support for that issue. The Chamber's more varied bylaws contain no such assurances, he said. Moreover, he said, Chamber members may be reluctant for economic reasons to withdraw from the organization even if they disagree with its political views. The case is Austin vs. Michigan Chamber of Commerce, 88-1569.

DOC.HEAD: Purges in Kosovo Police
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `A Yugoslav ...' to CORRECT number of people hospitalized.
DOC.TEXT: Serbian police today began purging Kosovo's police force of ethnic Albanians who stand accused of inaction during ethnic unrest in the troubled province. Serbian police, who control the security force of Kosovo province, intend to purge 70 percent of ethnic Albanians from police ranks, and 100 already have been fired, according to news reports in Belgrade, the Yugoslav capital. Serbian authorities were also demanding the resignation of Jusuf Karakushi, Kosovo's ethnic Albanian police chief, the reports said. Kosovo is one of two provinces of Serbia, the largest of the Yugoslav republics. Ethnic Albanians represent 90 percent of Kosovo's 1.9 million population and have pressed for greater autonomy. But a year ago, the federal government approved constitutional changes that gave Serbia almost complete control over Kosovo, claiming the Serbian minority was being harassed by ethnic Albanians. Meanwhile, security forces in Kosovo braced for unrest expected Wednesday, the first anniversary of the amendments. The date was recently proclaimed a national holiday in Serbia. ``The proclamation of March 28 as a Serbian national holiday represents a provocation whose aim is to further escalate political conflicts in Kosovo and Yugoslavia,'' read a statement from the Democratic Union, the largest independent ethnic Albanian party in Kosovo. In Serbia, where the Communist leadership is determined ``to crush at all cost'' the ethnic Albanian drive for autonomy, the holiday will be marked with public festivities, news reports said. More than 60 people, mostly ethnic Albanians, have died in ethnic violence in Kosovo in the past year. Members of an international human rights commission touring Kosovo said the human rights situation in the province was ``poor.'' They said Yugoslavia, which seeks full membership in the Council of Europe, may have trouble joining the organization because of rights violations in the province. A Yugoslav parliamentary commission said Monday nearly 2,990 ethnic Albanians were hospitalized in Kosovo since Saturday complaining of lung and skin problems allegedly caused by a mysterious poisoning. Ethnic Albanians claimed the mysterious illness was caused by Serbs, while Serbs blamed ethnic Albanians for the poisoning scare, allegedly intended to trigger massive uprisings in Kosovo. No traces of any poisoning were found in any blood or urine samples and all Albanians had been released from hospital by late Monday, the commission said. Kosovo, which borders Albania, was a part of ancient Serbia. Most of the Christian Serbs in the province view the Moslem Albanians as intruders and allege Serbs in Kosovo are harassed by the Albanians. Yugoslavia, which broke from the Soviet bloc in 1948, is governed by an eight-man presidency, made up of representatives from the country's six republics and two provinces.

DOC.HEAD: Fonda Buzz, Fricker Party Vow and Jealous-Proud Husband at the Oscars
With PM-Oscars, Bjt

DOC.TEXT: The Academy Awards featured the usual sparkles of paparazzi camera flash, the usual eye-popping fashions, the goggle-eyed reception of Jane Fonda's date with Ted Turner. Somewhere in the glitter, real emotions seemed to surface. ``Furious, jealous, unhappy, and very proud,'' was how actor Hume Cronyn described his feelings about his wife of 47 years, Jessica Tandy, having the spotlight to herself. Miss Tandy won best actress for ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' An estimated 4,000 fans watched the stars step out of limousines and onto the carpeted entry to the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion. DOC.HEAD: Church Leader Wants International Probe Of Lawmakers
DOC.TEXT: An East German church leader today appealed for an international commission to probe allegations linking new lawmakers to the ousted Communist regime's secret police. The allegations, which involve some leaders of the non-Communist political parties and the likely new premier, are stalling efforts to form a government following the country's first free election on March 18. Manfred Stolpe, the chief administrator of East Berlin's Lutheran Church, recommended that former Swiss president and justice minister, Kurt Furgler, head the commission. In an interview with the West German newspaper Die Welt newspaper, Stolpe said the international commission should take up its work after the new East German Parliament is ``officially constituted, to prevent any further delays in setting up the country's new government.'' An alliance of leftist parties urged a full investigation be conducted before the legislature holds its first sitting. The alliance includes New Forum, the pro-democracy group that led last fall's peaceful revolution but did poorly in the election. The Christian Democratic Union, which won the election and has rejected such a probe before the Parliament's first session, said it hopes the new lawmaking body will be able to convene next Tuesday. Lothar de Maiziere, the Christian Democratic chief who is the party's candidate for premier, has said he hopes to form a new government before mid-April. De Maiziere has been implicated in the secret police allegations but has strongly denied ever working for the secret police. Ibrahim Boehme, whose leftist Social Democratic Party came in a distant second in the balloting, also denied similar charges against himself but on Monday temporarily stepped aside as party leader until the allegations have been cleared up by an independent commission. De Maiziere said Monday he believed he could form his government ``within two weeks.'' He has offered to form a broad coalition with the Social Democrats, now led by Boehme's deputy Markus Meckel, to gain a two-thirds majority needed in the newly elected 400-member Parliament for a decision on rapid unification with West Germany. The 85,000-srong secret police and its 109,000 informers were used to suppress dissent and keep tight control on East Germans before ousted Communist leader Erich Honecker resigned last fall under popular pressure for democratic reforms. Officials have said dismantling of the force, known as the Stasi, has been virtually completed, but many East Germans believe the secret police are still trying to disrupt the democratic process.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Refuses to Put Aside Change in Clean Air Legislation
DOC.TEXT: The Senate today refused to put aside an industry-sought change in clean air legislation that would give companies more flexibility in meeting permit requirements under the new law. Environmentalists have opposed the change, arguing that it creates loopholes that will allow businesses to avoid compliance with some pollution controls and inhibit federal enforcement of the law. The Senate voted 50-47 against killing the amendment and opponents immediately asked that the measure be considered again later, hoping some senators will change their votes and others who did not vote would oppose the measure. Sen. Don Nickels, R-Okla., had argued that the permit and enforcement requirements of the bill would spell ``economic disasters for thousands of businesses'' and result in a ``bureaucratic nightmare'' unless they are streamlined. But critics of the amendment said the changes envisioned by Nickels would allow polluters in some cases to obtain permits that would allow them to escape some provisions of the new law. It also would allow some polluters to tie cases up in lengthy litigation and inhibit citizen lawsuits seeking enforcement of pollution controls, opponents of the proposed change said. The clean air legislation, which imposes a wide range of emission controls on industry, imposes for the first time a federal requirement that companies obtain operating permits to ensure compliance with pollution control requirements. About 35 states already have laws requiring such permits. Under the bill, the EPA would have the authority to review the state and local permits to ensure that they comply with federal pollution control requirements. The Senate was expected to continue consideration of a wide range of amendments to the compromise clean air bill on the floor. Several issues remained unresolved, including whether to provide financial assistance to coal miners who lose their jobs because of tighter pollution controls on coal-powered electric utilities. The Nickels' amendment was supported by the Bush administration, although permitting and enforcement provisions of the bill were not included in the closed-door negotitiations that led to the compromise clean air bill now before the Senate. Senate leaders and sponsors of the compromise bill, therefore, are free to oppose the proposal. Among the industry groups that have lobbied vigorously for easing the permitting requirements were the National Association of Manufacturers; the Chemical Manufacturers Association; the Clean Air Working Group, an industry umbrella group; and the National Environmental Development Association.

DOC.HEAD: Illegal Clubs: A Problem in Some Cities
With PM-Social Club Fire, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with crackdowns announced in Chicago, Elizabeth, N.J., picking up 4th graf, `The fire ...; SUBS 3rd to last graf, `Officials in ..., to DELETE outdated reference to Chicago; edits throughout to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Officials in Chicago and Elizabeth, N.J., ordered a crackdown on illegal social clubs to prevent a disastrous fire like the one that killed 87 people in New York. But few other cities consider such clubs to be a problem. ``When a tragedy like this occurs, you don't want to ignore it,'' Daniel Weil, Chicago's building commissioner, said Monday. At least 100 non-profit social clubs in Chicago that are registered with the secretary of state will be inspected for hazardous materials and adequate safety systems, Weil said. City officials said they also are trying to locate any unlicensed centers that would be more likely to have code violations that could lead to a tragedy like the one early Sunday in New York. In Elizabeth, Mayor Thomas G. Dunn said city inspectors would put at least seven illegal nightclubs out of business in light of new attention drawn by the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx. Two owners of one club were arrested Monday and about 100 patrons chased from the place, he said. In Paterson, N.J., vice squad Sgt. Michael Recca said three or four such establishments have been shut down in the last month. ``Generally the violations involve illegal alcoholic beverage sales and with that we find a high incidence of drug sales between patrons,'' he said. Most cities have stiff laws prohibiting selling liquor without a license. ``If you operate in Texas without a license, you get put in jail,'' said E.P. McCracken, regional supervisor of the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission in Dallas. ``We don't run our business in Texas like they do in New York.'' New York officials say there are literally hundreds of clubs like Happy Land, a firetrap that attracted a largely poor, immigrant Hispanic crowd. The fire _ allegedly set by the former boyfriend of a club employee _ prompted a new round of promises by city officials to crack down on clubs that offer dancing and drinking to the city's poor. Illegal clubs have been a nagging headache to fire, building and liquor officials in Los Angeles, Omaha, Neb., Gary and East Chicago, Ill., and Lawrence, Mass. ``We arrest them on misdemeanor charges, and they can open up again in a week,'' Omaha police Lt. John Beers said. Omaha police found a locked front door and about 220 people in two small rooms when they raided the Dirty Dozen Motorcycle Club Sunday. ``If there had been a rush to get out, those people would have been trampled,'' Beers said. In Lawrence, Mass., outside Boston, there may be three or four illegal clubs operating, Fire Chief Raymond Johnson estimated. ``We shut them down and two weeks later they open someplace else,'' Johnson said. ``I guess it's a very lucrative business.'' In Los Angeles, a prominent club owner said aggressive crackdowns on unsafe or illegal nightclubs have failed to stop chic underground clubs from flourishing and evading detection by fire officials. ``I myself go to these places,'' said Steve Banerjee, who owns legal Chippendales clubs on both coasts. ``It's the whole theory of do something you shouldn't do. You think you are part of the `in' crowd, the `aware' crowd.'' Many big-city officials say they seldom or never see such establishments. ``That's bootlegging in Texas and we would shut them down,'' said Randy Yarbrough, assistant administrator for the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission. Officials in Boston, Detroit, San Francisco and Orange County, Calif., were among those saying they didn't believe their cities had a problem with illegal clubs. Some officials hoped news of the Happy Land disaster could boost support for inspection efforts for legal and illegal clubs alike. Said Lawrence Fire Chief Johnson: ``Now they will use this as an example.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Spokesman Says Foreigners Asked to Leave Lithuania
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet government today ordered foreign journalists, businessmen and diplomats to leave Lithuania, in another move by Moscow to assert more control over the Baltic republic. ``Foreigners have been asked to leave the borders of Lithuania and temporarily refrain from entering its territory,'' Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh told a Moscow briefing. Diplomats, including two Americans, had already been banned from the republic late last week, and journalists were told they could not travel there. Gremitskikh said foreign reporters currently in Lithuania would be allowed to stay until their previously announced departure dates, but ``Those who have not yet entered will not be allowed to enter Lithuania.'' The Soviet government has frequently closed areas of ethnic unrest to foreign correspondents, claiming their presence tends to exacerbate the situation and that their lives might be endangered. There have been no ethnic clashes reported in Lithuania, and the only reported violence since its March 11 declaration of independence broke out today when Soviet soldiers began to round up Lithuanian deserters. Foreign reporters must give the Foreign Ministry 48 hours' notice and an itinerary whenever they travel out of Moscow. The ban on foreigners in Lithuania was an additional measure taken to fulfill a March 21 decree by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on ``protecting the rights of Soviet citizens on the territory of Lithuania,'' Tass reported. On Saturday, the government asked all foreign diplomats to leave Lithuania and requested foreign journalists to ``temporarily refrain from trips'' there. Two U.S. diplomats based in Leningrad were among those affected by the order. Under Gorbachev's decree, the Soviet government has also ordered tightened control on the Lithuanian border, asked citizens to surrender their hunting rifles and to refrain from joining voluntary civil defense units.

DOC.HEAD: Spurned Boyfriend Charged in 87 Fire Deaths, Prosecutors Probe Ownership
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to focus lead on investigation of ownership, confirm reports on Turner's husband; picks up 7th graf, `Across from...' SUBS 21st graf, `Valladares was...' to UPDATE disc jockey's condition.
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors are investigating whether owners in a corporate chain that includes the husband of actress Kathleen Turner may share responsibility in the fire deaths of 87 people in an illegal nightclub. The Cuban immigrant accused of torching the club to avenge a romantic snub was under a suicide watch in a psychiatric ward today after allegedly telling police he set the blaze because ``the devil got into me.'' Julio Gonzalez, 36, was charged with murdering 87 people by setting fire Sunday to the jammed Happy Land social club in the Bronx. Miss Turner's husband, Jay Weiss, acknowledged through a statement by his lawyer that he and a partner are principals of Little Peach Inc., which leased the club site in 1985 from a corporation controlled by real estate developer Alex DiLorenzo III. Two years later Little Peach sublet the two-story building to Elias Colon, who operated the Happy Land club. Colon died in the fire. The statement by the lawyer, Roger Boyle, said Weiss' company ``has been actively pressing eviction proceedings against Mr. Colon and had hoped that a final eviction would have resulted from a trial scheduled for Wednesday of this week.'' The statement said Weiss and his partner, Morris Jaffe, ``are horrified at the events of this weekend and lament the loss of life which ensued.'' Bronx District Attorney Robert Johnson has said he has 10 assistants working on prosecuting Gonzalez and also ``working on the investigation of whether or not there is any possible responsibility, criminal liability, on the part of the club and-or the owner of the building.'' Across from the fire-blackened club in an impoverished neighborhood near the Bronx Zoo, families on Monday drifted in and out of Public School 67, where agencies helped arrange funerals and offered counseling and financial aid. Anger was directed at Gonzalez' former girlfriend, Lydia Feliciano, when she appeared at the school to inquire about aid for friends. ``I can't believe she is here. How could she show her face?'' said Edgardo Rodriguez, 22, who lost four friends and was awaiting information on financial aid to send their bodies home to Honduras. When asked why she came to the school, Ms. Feliciano responded, ``I lost people too. I lost friends.'' As a crowd gathered around her, two police officers escorted Ms. Feliciano out of a back entrance of the school. A huge wooden cross stood in front of the nightclub's ruins as neighbors prayed at an outdoor service conducted in English and Spanish. The service Monday ended with the singing of ``De Colores,'' a song about brotherly love. At the direction of Mayor David Dinkins, authorities visited 241 clubs citywide from midnight to 7 a.m. Monday and posted orders on 187 of them to vacate. Police issued 52 safety violations and 30 summonses, said Sgt. Dick Vreeland. Police said Gonzalez had vowed to ``shut this place down'' after an argument with Ms. Feliciano, a Happy Land employee who had split with the unemployed Gonzalez several months ago. ``I got angry, the devil got into me, and I set the place on fire,'' Gonzalez told authorities, according to a police source who spoke on condition of anonymity. Gonzalez was arraigned on 87 counts of murder committed in the course of arson; 87 counts of murder by depraved indifference to human life; one count of attempted murder, and two counts of arson. He entered no plea. Johnson, the Bronx district attorney, said he hoped Gonzalez would get consecutive sentences amounting to 2,000 years in prison if convicted. Gonzalez, who was jailed for army desertion in Cuba in the 1970s, came to the United States from Cuba on the 1980 Mariel boatlift. He told immigration officials he had portrayed himself as a drug trafficker to get kicked out of Cuba, The New York Times reported. The victims of Sunday's fire, many of them Honduran immigrants, suffocated, burned or were trampled to death. They had to ``choose between a wall of fire or retreating and dying of asphyxiation,'' Johnson said. Police believe five people escaped: three patrons; Ms. Feliciano, and the club disc jockey, Ruben Valladares. Valladares was listed in critical but stable condition today at Jacobi Hospital with burns over 30 percent of his body. Ms. Feliciano and the others escaped serious injury. Ms. Feliciano is in protective custody. Johnson said Gonzalez had described the following sequence: After arguing with Ms. Feliciano, with whom he sought to resume a relationship, he was ejected from the club. He bought $1 worth of gasoline at a nearby station, returned and faked making a telephone call when he saw someone. When that person left, he poured gasoline between the street and an inside door and ignited it. Gonzalez watched it burn for awhile, making statements to at least two witnesses about his role in the fire. Then he went home, where police found him a few hours later, his shoes reeking of gasoline. He made a videotaped admission to police. Johnson said Gonzalez knew the two-story club lacked windows, rear exits and adequate staircases. He also knew how crowded it was. ``He is a double animal,'' said Rene J. Mena, whose son, Rene Jr., 30, died in the fire. ``Here, they're going to have good food for him, a book, a movie. In Central America, we don't do it that way.'' A vacate order was issued in 1988 against the club and again a year later because Happy Land lacked a proper sprinkler system, exits, emergency lighting and signs. It also had no liquor or cabaret license, Dinkins said. Dinkins discussed Sunday's tragedy while addressing garment workers Monday commemorating New York City's Triangle Shirtwaist Co. fire, which occurred exactly 79 years before the Happy Land blaze. The 1911 tragedy claimed 146 lives and transformed workplace safety laws around the country. ``The sight of those bodies, lined along the walls like so many wax figures, and the realization of the panic and the pain they must have suffered in their last moments, will remain with me for the rest of my life,'' Dinkins said.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Sihanouk Accuses Vietnam Of Annexing Cambodian Land
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian resistance leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk today accused Vietnam of seizing control of two of his country's provinces and annexing several islands. ``The most serious threat to the survival of Cambodia is the modification by Vietnam of the frontiers of Cambodia,'' Sihanouk told a news conference.
