He claimed Vietnam redrew the two countries' shared border, invaded the provinces of Ratanakiri and Mondulkiri and annexed several offshore islands with the consent of the Hanoi-backed Cambodian government led by Hun Sen. He did not elaborate. There was no immediate comment from the Vietnamese government. He also reiterated charges that Vietnamese soldiers remain in Cambodia despite Hanoi's much-publicized troop pullout last fall. He said 1 million Vietnamese settlers are in the country, in some places making the Cambodians an ethnic minority. Many of the Vietnamese settlers moved to Cambodia to escape fighting during the Vietnam War. Sihanouk, who resigned earlier this year as president of the three-party resistance coalition, said general elections were impossible until the Vietnamese settlers were removed. ``Hun Sen's government gave them citizenship, but that's not acceptable to us. Hun Sen's decisions are illegal,'' he said. Sihanouk also repeated denials of cooperating with the Communist Khmer Rouge faction in the coalition. Hundreds of thousands of people died during agrarian reform and resettlement imposed by the Khmer Rouge when it ruled before Vietnam's invasion in late 1978, and there is concern that the group would regain power if the Hun Sen government is dismantled. ``I am not pro-Khmer Rouge. I am not red, not even pink,'' Sihanouk said. He said his forces and the Khmer Rouge occupy neighboring territories in Cambodia and when ``we attack the same enemy, a common enemy, how can we avoid seeing each other?'' Sihanouk in late February returned to Cambodia after an 11-year exile. At the news conference in his Beijing residence, he handed out a glossy brochure showing his quarters in one of Cambodia's liberated zones. He returned to Beijing this month because his mother-in-law has been hospitalized in the Chinese capital and is said to be near death.

DOC.HEAD: Husband of Kathleen Turner Is Social Club Landlord
With PM-Social Club Fire, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout make attribution directly to lawyer.
DOC.TEXT: The husband of actress Kathleen Turner is one of the landlords of the illegal social club where arson killed 87 people, his lawyer said today. Roger Boyle said in a statement that Jay Weiss and a partner, Morris Jaffe, principals of Little Peach Realty Inc., leased the Bronx site in 1985 from Clarendon Place, a corporation controlled by Alex DiLorenzo III. Little Peach sublet the property in 1987 to Elias Colon, who operated the Happy Land social club and was one of the 87 who died there early Sunday. Boyle added that Little Peach had been trying to evict Colon and an eviction trial was scheduled for Wednesday. Bronx District Attorney Robert Johnson has said his staff was working on sorting out the ownership of the building and looking into whether anyone in the corporate chain bears criminal liability in the deaths. Miss Turner and Weiss married in August 1984 after a romance that started when he helped her find a Manhattan apartment. MIss Turner, who starred in movies such as ``Body Heat,'' ``Romancing The Stone,'' and ``War of the Roses,'' is starring on Broadway in a revival of ``Cat On a Hot Tin Roof.''

DOC.HEAD: First Heart, Liver and Kidney Transplant Recipient Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with cause of death, additional details, background; no pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A 26-year-old woman who was the world's only recipient of a heart-liver-kidney transplant has died of hepatitis, hospital officials said today. Cindy Martin died at 6:04 p.m. Monday at Presbyterian-University Hospital, spokeswoman Lisa Rossi said. Mrs. Martin underwent a 21{-hour transplant operation Dec. 2-3. Mrs. Martin had contracted recurrent non-A, non-B hepatitis, an unusual and non-contagious form of the liver disease, which resulted in kidney failure, Ms. Rossi said. Her condition also was complicated by an overwhelming infection called sepsis, a common post-transplant complication. Because of anti-rejection drugs, which suppress the immune system, infection is a common problem with transplant patients, Ms. Rossi said. There was no sign of rejection to her heart, she said. Word of Mrs. Martin's death was not released until this morning at the request of her family, Ms. Rossi said. Although multi-organ transplants have been performed several times, this was the first involving these three organs, according to Dr. John Armitage, who performed Mrs. Martin's heart transplant. Since the surgery, her condition never improved beyond serious and she was often breathing with the aid of a respirator, Ms. Rossi said. Her family, including her husband, John, were with her when she died. Mrs. Martin had suffered from familial cardiomyopathy, an inherited heart disease. Her father died when he was 31 and many of his relatives died at a young age, her husband said in December. On Oct. 20, 1985, one day after getting married, Mrs. Martin was admitted to Presbyterian-University Hospital to await her first heart transplant. She received it a month later, but suffered chronic rejection of the heart and developed hepatitis and kidney dysfunction.

DOC.HEAD: Bishop Appeals to East Germans to Show Humaneness to Honecker
DOC.TEXT: Berlin's Roman Catholic bishop today urged East Germans to treat ousted and ailing Communist leader Erich Honecker with humaneness. ``As a clergyman, I believe that everyone should be given the chance to live out his life in peace, no matter what he has done,'' Bishop Georg Sterzinski told The Associated Press. Honecker, 77, has been living at a parish home outside East Berlin since January, after being kicked out of an exclusive wooded compound previously reserved for top Communist officials. The compound was closed after a peaceful popular revolt swept Honecker and his hard-line Communist government from power in the fall. It is now being used as a home for the mentally retarded. Honecker ruled East Germany with an iron fist for 18 years until his ouster in October. He is reported to be in poor health. He was arrested in January after leaving a hospital following surgery for kidney cancer but was released a day later because of his ailing condition. He and his wife have been living in virtual exile at the church refuge since then. An attempt last weekend by the outgoing Communist-led government to move Honecker and his wife to a more comfortable residence 80 miles from Berlin was thwarted by an angry mob. More than 100 people surrounded the home and forced authorities to move the couple back to their church residence after only one night. Dozens of people banged the roof of their car with their fists and made obscene gestures as the Honeckers were driven away. Honecker's wife, Margot, is a former education minister. Sterzinski said East German citizens should try to ``prevent their hate from running freely.'' He said Honecker should be given better accommodation and should not have to live in constant fear of being thrown out. ``If I knew what I could do, I would do it (to help Honecker),'' the bishop said. On Monday, East Germany's chief prosecutor said there were no legal grounds to prosecute Honecker for high treason, but he remains under investigation for massive corruption and abuse of power.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Sends Test Signal To Cuba
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with White House confirmation of TV Marti debut. Picks up 3rd graf pvs `The Cuban...'
DOC.TEXT: A U.S.-financed television operation began transmitting signals to Cuba early today, but Cuban officials blocked the transmission after 38 minutes and accused the United States of engaging in aggressive activity. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater confirmed the debut of TV Marti and said the administration planned to continue efforts to transmit news and entertainment programs programs to Cuba despite the successful jamming effort. ``We just hope that at some point they see the light,'' Fitzwater said, alluding to Cuban officials. He said the operation was consistent with national and international law. The TV test operation began at 1:30 a.m. EST and was clearly visible on Channel 13 in the Havana area until the jamming began at 2:08, said a Voice of America official, who asked not to be identified by name. The Cuban government news agency Prensa Latina said in a dispatch monitored in Mexico City that ``the debut was nothing impressive since in a 10-minute interval the principal technological power on the planet could not keep the invading signal from being rejected over the coverage area.'' ``Cuban authorities have warned that the beginning of these transmissions may form part of a larger maneuver and Washington may be looking for a pretext to unleash military aggression,'' the dispatch said. The Cuban government, the agency said, ``has placed responsibility on the government of that country for all the consequences of this action, which is aggressive and violates its sovereignty.'' Official Cuban statements have said retaliatory measures besides jamming would be taken, but none was announced immediately, the VOA source said. The station is designed to be a TV version of Radio Marti, which has provided news and entertainment to Cuban listeners since 1985. Radio Marti was not jammed this morning. Cuban officials, in addition to jamming Channel 13, also blocked the signals on several other channels, the VOA source said. He said that at 3:45 a.m. EST TV Marti switched from the test pattern to baseball highlights and musical programming but these signals were jammed as well. The signal was sent from a transmitter placed aboard a balloon dangling 10,000 feet above Cudjoe Key off the south Florida Coast. Technical problems have delayed testing for months. After the testing, the administration is supposed to make a legal and technical evaluation of the operation within three months, according to the legislation. If the operation proves feasible on both counts, formal programming can begin for a two-year period. The funds already have been appropriated. But if the testing interferes with Florida stations or violates aspects of international law governing such broadcasts, the operation will be scrapped. The administration has promised to stay within the law. President Fidel Castro has reacted sharply to TV Marti. Americans, he said recently, ``are not even capable of knowing how much they offend the hearts and sentiments of our people.'' ``They know it violates international law; they know it violates national sovereignty,'' he said. TV Marti's sponsors maintain it is an effective way to bring objective information to the Cuban people via television. They say that Cubans have been fed only propaganda for all 31 years of the revolution. Cuban officials have said a range of options are being considered in retaliation for TV Marti. Among others, they said that telephone communications and travel between the two countries might be suspended. Another possibility is that Cuba will activate transmitters capable of blocking U.S. radio broadcasts over a huge area west of the Mississippi.

DOC.HEAD: White House Reports `Preliminary Discussions' on Mexico Trade Pact
DOC.TEXT: The White House said today there have been ``preliminary discussions'' with Mexico on the feasibility of a U.S.-Mexican free-trade pact. President Bush proposed such an agreement during his 1988 presidential campaign, saying trade barriers should be dropped throughout North America. A free-trade agreement took effect between the United States and Canada in January 1989 under which virtually all tariffs, quotas and other trade barriers between the two countries will be abolished by the turn of the century. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said ``there have been preliminary discussions ... but no negotiations, no final decisions and we really haven't gone very far down that road yet.'' Noting Bush's campaign promise, Fitzwater said, ``he would like to see a Northern Hemisphere dedicated to free trade.'' The Wall Street Journal reported in today's editions that the United States and Mexico had agreed to negotiate a free-trade pact between the two nations.

DOC.HEAD: Dropout Driver Back Behind Wheel
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager who challenged a law restricting driver's licenses of school dropouts has regained the right to drive, but only because he turned 18. Michael Means celebrated his birthday Monday by paying the state $72.50 for his license, which was stripped from him 18 months ago when he quit school. West Virginia in 1988 was the first of several states to enact a law punishing dropouts by revoking their licenses until they return to school or come of age. ``I sort of forgot how to drive, almost,'' Means said after taking his father's car for a drive. Means is still pressing a lawsuit that is pending before the state Supreme Court. The youngster, who is unemployed, blames the law for costing him potential jobs and forcing him, his 17-year-old wife and 7-month old son to rely on his parents for support.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Tobacco Chief Challenges Cigar Company To Taste Test
DOC.TEXT: The director of Cuba's state tobacco company Tuesday challenged a leading European cigar merchant to taste test to determine whether the quality of Cuban cigars has declined. Franciso Padron, director of Cubatabaco, issued the challenge at a news conference to counter complaints made by tobacco merchant Zino Davidoff. Davidoff's company, based in Switzerland, is traditionally the supplier of cigars for Europe's wealhy industrialists and bankers. It broke its contract with Cubatabaco last year, contending that the quality and consistency of Havana cigars had dropped. Padron proposed a televised taste test in which cigar connoisseurs would judge the quality of Cubatabaco's La Havana cigars. ``Zino Davidoff hasn't been to Cuba for 20 years and he knows nothing about Cuban cigars,'' said Padron, puffing on a La Havana during the news conference.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Head Of Spanish Television Accused of Spending TV Money on Clothes
DOC.TEXT: The former director of state-run Spanish Television was indicted Tuesday on charges of misappropriating public funds and using them to buy designer clothes. A Madrid district court issued the indictment against Pilar Miro, 41. She resigned from her post in November 1988 after newspapers reported an internal audit indicated she had spent about $36,000 of public funds on her personal wardrobe and gifts. Miro said she made an honest mistake and had believed accounting procedures permitted her to buy clothes for use at the numerous official functions she said the job required her to attend. She reimbursed the the television station after the audit.

DOC.HEAD: Two Dead in Shootout in Dutch Hospital
DOC.TEXT: A man visiting a hospital where his wife was recovering from surgery shot the woman to death Tuesday and seriously injured the couple's young daughter before killing himself, police said. Police spokesman Ger Straatman said the 29-year-old man apparently got into an argument with his 23-year-old wife. He pulled a revolver, shot her and their 2-year-old daughter, and then shot himself to death, Straatman said. The incident occurred at St. Catherine's Hospital in this southern Dutch city. Straatman said it was unclear what the couple was arguing about. The woman was recovering from gallbladder surgery, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Expelled Cuban Ambassador Leaves Panama
DOC.TEXT: The Cuban ambassador to Panama has returned home after being expelled from the country because of his government's refusal to recognize the Panamanian government. Lazaro Mora Segade, his wife and three companions left on a Cuba de Aviacion flight late Monday night. Diplomats from the Dominican Republic and Ecuador were on hand to see him off. The ambassador did not speak to reporters nor allow them to take his photograph. Airport officials who asked not to be named said the ambassador took 80 suitcases and two pets with him. Cuba has refused to recognize the civilian government installed in Panama after the U.S. invasion in December that ousted military leader Manuel Antonio Noriega. The Cuban Embassy in Panama City gave refuge to Noriega's family for awhile after the invasion. Noriega is in Miami awaiting trial on drug charges.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Protests Execution Sentence
DOC.TEXT: Members of Amnesty International demonstrated outside the U.S. Embassy on Tuesday against the scheduled April 3 execution in California of Robert Alton Harris. Harris, 37, was convicted of killing two teen-age boys in San Diego in 1978. If put to death as scheduled in the gas chamber, he would be the first person executed in California in 23 years. About 30 demonstrators left a letter for U.S. Ambassador Henry Catto urging him to make a personal appeal to California Gov. George Deukmejian to exercise clemency. ``Amnesty International opposes the death penalty in all cases as abuse of the right to life and the right not to be subjected to cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment or punishment,'' the letter said. ``We are particularly concerned that this case will create a precedent for other states in the United States which are not currently carrying out execution,'' the letter said. ``We will continue campaigning until Harris is either executed or the death penalty rescinded,'' said Amnesty International spokesman Sarah Lee. The U.S. Embassy had no comment on the protest.

DOC.HEAD: Curfew Imposed, Protests Banned as Conference Begins
DOC.TEXT: The government imposed a dusk-to-dawn curfew and banned meetings and protests as political, professional and trade organizations prepared to draw up guidelines Tuesday for a new party to lead Gabon to democracy. Opposition movements and the Gabon Trade Union Confederation had called for demonstrations Tuesday, but the capital of this West African nation was calm. Police squads guarded the main intersections of Libreville. The official Gabon Press Agency announced Monday night that security police and troops had been deployed around the city. ``Those who provoke incidents or sabotage will be severely punished, and those who organize protest marches will be arrested immediately,'' a state radio broadcast warned. It announced a ban on meetings of more than five people, and a curfew from 7 p.m. to 6 a.m. All the measures appeared aimed at preventing incidents that might disturb the National Conference, which began meeting under the chairmanship of President Omar Bongo. About 150 organizations are taking part in the meeting, which is to establish a new party called the Social Democratic Rally. ``Divisions fed by resentful people .... can only hinder our march toward a more democratic society,'' Bongo told the meeting, which is scheduled to end April 2. Bongo agreed last month that the new party would be a broad grouping of various political movements and replace the Democratic Party, with which he has ruled Gabon as a one-party state since 1968. The president also has promised to install a multiparty state in Gabon, but has set no date. Bongo said the conference would define ``conditions for a framework to work toward a multiparty state.'' This transition period will expose the country to ``an uncertain future, letting loose arbitrary and dangerous outbursts,'' Bongo said. He appealed to ``the patriotism of everyone,'' and urged an end to strikes and unrest that have shaken his government recently. Bongo's government survived an October coup attempt, which was followed by months of strikes and civil unrest. On Friday, scores of unemployed people went on a rampage in Gabon's economic capital, Port Gentil, breaking shop windows, looting stores and setting cars aflame. Gabon is in the third year of an austerity program imposed as a condition of further credit from Western nations and institutions.

DOC.HEAD: Health Organization Says Half Billion People Suffering Tropical Diseases
DOC.NOTE: For Release at 7:01 P.M. EST, Time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: About half a billion people worldwide are suffering from tropical diseases such as malaria, river blindness and sleeping sickness, the World Health Organization said Wednesday as it launched a campaign to fight the illnesses. WHO officials appealed for more funds to pay for research and control programs for the ``great neglected diseases.'' It said they pose a risk of infection to the entire population of the African continent and much of Asia and South America. The U.N. agency's new campaign will focus attention on the seven most widespread tropical diseases, which can cause internal organ damage, limb deformities, blindness, brain damage and death. Dr. Shaik Khader Noordeen, a senior official in WHO's tropical diseases division, told a news conference that lack of money prevented effective use of preventive measures and drugs to counter the diseases. ``A lot can be done today, but it is not being done simply because the resources are not available in the endemic countries and the awareness is not present in the countries that could help them,'' he said. Dr. Alvaro Moncayo, another WHO expert, said the organization's current research budget into tropical diseases was $65-70 million spread over a two-year period. WHO's 1990 budget for its program on AIDS totals $109 million. ``These diseases affect the poorest of the poor,'' Moncaya said when asked why he thought tropical diseases had not received the same attention as AIDS. A WHO report said most victims of tropical diseases live in countries with average per capita incomes of less than $400, and where governments spend a yearly average of just $4 per person on health care. The 26-page report said malaria claimed the highest number of victims. It estimated that 270 million people carry the parasite spread by infected mosquitos, with 110 million new cases each year. It put the annual number of fatalities at 1 million to 2 million. The report said 2.1 billion people live in areas of the Third World where they are at risk. The parasite is showing increasing resistance to common drugs, it said. Schistosomiasis, a disease caused by water-borne parasites from snails, afflicted about 200 million people, destroying internal tissues and contributing to malnutrition, according to the report. More than 110 million people suffer from filariasis, caused by mosquitos and blackflies. It leads to river blindness, or onchocerciasis, a disease transmitted by flies that causes tumors, skin lesions and blindness. Filariasis may also lead to a painful swelling of the limbs known as elephantiasis, it said. WHO also singled out for concern chagas disease, found in Central and South America and occasionally in the United States. It said there were 16-18 million cases of the disease, caused by a parasite transmitted by a bloodsucking bug that lives in crevices of poor-quality houses. In later stages of the disease, the parasites invade body organs and eventually cause irreversible damage to the heart and intestines. The disease is said to be incurable but can be prevented by insecticides, better housing and health education. A fifth disease, sleeping sickness, is transmitted by the bite of the tsetse fly in several parts of Africa. The report said early diagnosis was difficult and for the 25,000 people who contract the disease each year, it was invariably fatal. It said insecticide spraying and tsetse traps had proved successful as preventive measures. It estimated that 12 million people were infected with leishmaniasis, caused by a sandfly bite. Some 400,000 new cases occur each year, with victims suffering ailments ranging from ulcers to chronic tissue destruction. In a glimmer of hope in the otherwise gloomy report, WHO said leprosy had recently become controllable by treatment involving three drugs. By the end of last year, 1.75 million of the 4 million registered patients had received the therapy. WHO estimates there are 10-12 million cases of leprosy worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Urges Inquiry Into Alleged Rights Abuses In Argentina
DOC.NOTE: For Release at 7:01 p.m. EST, Time set by Source.
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International on Wednesday urged Argentina to investigate allegations of torture, disappearances and killings of members of an opposition group who attacked an army barracks last year. The human rights organization published a report detailing violations against members of the small leftist Movement for the Fatherland, which tried to take over an army base on the outskirts of Buenos Aires. Twenty-eight attackers and 11 soldiers and police officers died in the Jan. 23, 1989 attack on La Tablada base. Sixty law officers were wounded and 13 attackers were arrested. Amnesty urged Argentina's president, Carlos Menem, to order an inquiry. In its 21-page report, the group said there ``appears to be strong evidence'' that two attackers listed as being killed in combat were summarily executed after surrendering. The report also said three others disappeared after being captured and that there was medical evidence to support prisoners' allegations they were tortured while in official custody. Amnesty International said Argentina's attorney general promised prompt investigations into these complaints last April. By the end of the year, the investigating magistrate had reached a decision in only one case. Amnesty International's report also said some investigations were flawed. It cited autopsy procedures, which it said were not of a high enough standard to determine whether deaths had occurred in combat or were the result of executions. The report alleged that security forces raided private homes, often without warrants, following the attack on the base. It said they threatened and in some cases tortured suspected sympathizers. Armed plainclothes officers reportedly stormed one home without formally identifying themselves or producing a warrant, tortured the couple, raped the wife and threatened to kill their 11-month-old child, the document alleged. Four women and 16 men, including a Roman Catholic priest, were convicted in October of planning or carrying out the attack on the military base and given sentences ranging from 10 years to life in prison. The attackers said they believed a military coup was imminent and that it was being coordinated at the barracks by rebel officers.

DOC.HEAD: Democracy Movement Brings New Freedom to Monks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Gandan for name of monastery and Gaandan for name of hamba lama are cq; most Mongolians use only one name.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's once-powerful Buddhist monks, nearly wiped out during seven decades of Communist rule, are cautiously joining the new pro-democracy movement in hopes of winning freedom from state control. When crowds first began rallying in December to demand free elections and other reforms, only one young monk, Baasan, dared join in. But buoyed by the successes of the activists in winning the ouster of top Communist officials, Mongolia's only surviving monastery has ventured into politics for the first time since the days of Bogd, a ranking monk who was king from 1911 to 1915. Gandan Monastery's agenda is short: it wants abolition of the State Committee on Religion, which regulates religious activities, and freedom to open more temples and monasteries. ``We would like to expand our religious activity ... train more monks and publish sutras,'' or scriptures, said Gaandan, the monastery's hamba lama, or leading monk. Mongols, like Tibetans, believe in lamaist Buddhism, a mix of Buddhism and tantric ritual. Monks are called lamas. Gaandan said he believes lamas can be forces for good in Mongolian politics. But he has no dreams of a return to the pre-Communist days, when Mongolia's more than 700 monasteries and temples wielded great power and absorbed half the male population as lamas. ``There may be several hundred'' monasteries in a few years if controls are lifted, he said, ``but not 700. Quality is more important than quantity.'' The monasteries were closed in the late 1930s, reportedly at the urging of Soviet leader Josef Stalin and on the pretext that they harbored Japanese spies and weapons. Their priceless gold and silver statues were sold, shipped to the Soviet Union or destroyed. Their lands were nationalized and monks were forced to find secular work. About 14,000 monks were killed, according to official figures. Government propaganda denounced the lamas as exploiters. A poster still hanging in the State Central Museum shows a lama with his mouth opened wide, swallowing up herds and people. In 1944, the government allowed Gandan in Ulan Bator to reopen but barred its monks from preaching outside monastery grounds. It now has about 160 lamas. Gaandan said the government plans to reopen two more monasteries this year. On March 11, several thousand Buddhist believers, lamas and members of the leading opposition group, the Mongolian Democratic Association, held a rally at a former temple in Ulan Bator that has been turned into a museum and demanded it be reopened for worship. They announced the formation of a non-official Union of Mongolian Believers to promote religious interests, the first independent religious group in Mongolia in decades. When several dozen pro-democracy activists held a two-day hunger strike for democratic reform in mid-March, lamas came to pray for them, Baasan said. He played an increasingly prominent role in protests organized by the Democratic Association. Last week, Gandan Monastery sent a letter to the Great People's Hural, or legislature, asking it to disband the Committee on Religion. The hamba lama's aide, Dorjgotov, said leaders from the democracy movement and the government have begun coming frequently to talk with Gaandan in the evenings. ``They don't come officially, but as human beings,'' he said. The hamba lama said he is open to both. ``According to Buddhism, everybody must be under compassion,'' he said. ``So our attitude will be the same to the current (Communist) party and to the democratic forces.'' So far, no one seems worried about such issues as separation of religion and politics, or whether the lamas could someday regain political power. ``It's impossible,'' said Ulankhu, a member of the opposition Social Democrats, said that would be impossible because the Communists ``completely destroyed the system; there are so few monks.'' Their influence over Mongolia's 2 million people also is in doubt. Dorjgotov insisted that most Mongolians remain Buddhist, despite the atheist education system. Many youths in Ulan Bator say they do not believe, although they have been culturally influenced by Buddhism. Some support its revival as a moralizing force, especially regarding protection of nature, which Buddhists revere. Buddhism also has appeal as part of Mongolia's national heritage, which only recently could be celebrated after decades of emphasizing socialist internationalism. ``An entire world is behind that word, lamaism _ our ancient philosophy, mathematics, linguistics, pharmacology _ our whole culture,'' said Dr. G. Boshigt, a physician and leading member of the Democratic Association. ``Even if the lamas don't make political demands, they will represent a political force.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Visit Canada
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will travel to Toronto on April 10 for talks with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and to attend the Toronto Blue Jays opening baseball game, the White House said today. The Blue Jays' opponent will be the Texas Rangers, the team of which Bush's oldest son, George Walker Bush, is a part-owner. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush and Mulroney will meet ``to discuss bilateral and international issues of mutual interest, particularly the changes taking place in Europe.'' ``They will also attend the opening day game between the Toronto Blue Jays and the Texas Rangers,'' said Fitzwater, who dodged a question on whether Bush or Mulroney would get to throw out the first ball. It is a night game. Bush will fly to Toronto Tuesday afternoon and return to the White House late that night, Fitzwater said. Bush is an avid baseball fan. He told reporters last week he wanted to find a way to attend an opening game as long as the public did not view it as ``frivolous.'' The baseball season is getting off to a belated start on April 9, a week late, including a Rangers-Blue Jays game in Texas. Baseball owners had locked players out of spring training camps for more than a month before the two sides reached a contract agreement. Bush, once captain of the Yale baseball team, attended several games last year, usually flying up by helicopter to nearby Baltimore to see the Orioles play.

DOC.HEAD: Officer Unkowingly Drives Robber to Bank, Then on Getaway
DOC.TEXT: An off-duty sheriff's deputy unknowingly became the driver of a getaway car after her passenger robbed a bank, authorities said. Volusia County Deputy Cynthia Gambrell said she become suspicious of her passenger, whom she did not know, after they stopped at the Commerical National Bank on Monday. She said police pulled her Jeep over before she had time to act on her suspicions. Cory Roe, 24, was charged with armed robbery, said Sgt. John Power, a Daytona Beach police spokesman. Ms. Gambrell offered the polite, clean-cut young man a ride after he knocked at her mother's door and said his car had broken down. At his direction, she drove him to the bank and waited for him. ``He went inside the bank, said `give me the money or someone's going to get hurt,' and implied he had a gun in his pocket,'' Power said. After a few minutes inside, he jogged back to the car.

DOC.HEAD: Author Sagan, 37 Others Sentenced in Drug Trial
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Retransmitting a0581 for all needing.
DOC.TEXT: A court Tuesday sentenced writer Francoise Sagan to a six-month suspended sentence for drug possession and 37 other people, including members of Paris' jet set, received sentences that ranged up to 15 years. They were the first sentences handed out following a trial of 45 people arrested in connection with a drug ring that supplied literary and social personalities with heroin and cocaine. The heaviest sentence went to Andre Trihan, described as a one-time link in the now dismantled French Connection. He received a 15-year sentence for his conviction of importing heroin into France. Ms. Sagan, 54, never appeared in court and was not present for the sentence. She was ordered to pay about $1,750 in fines as well as $63,160 to French Customs. The sentence will go on her record, the court said. She was one of 10 members of Paris' literati jet set tried for drug-related offenses. Others included the journalist Francois Debre, son of a former premier, who received a six-month suspended sentence; and Laura Travelli-Picasso, the ex-wife of a grandson of painter Pablo Picasso. She received a three-month suspended sentence and a fine. Police arrested Ms. Sagan last year after reportedly finding 300 grams of cocaine and 300 grams of heroine in her Paris home. The writer gained an international reputation with the publication in 1954 of her first novel, ``Bonjour Tristesse.'' She has written more than a dozen best sellers, plays and screen plays. Lucien Carrel, 65, said during the trial that he furnished heroin and cocaine for ``le Tout-Paris,'' an expression referring to the jet set. He was given a 12-year prison term. The trial started March 5 and ended March 16. The sentences were considered light. Prosecutor Jean-Paul Bazelaire had asked for a partially suspended sentence of six months to two years for Ms. Sagan and 18 years for Trihan.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Would Take in More Soviets
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration wants to take more Soviet refugees this year than the 60,000 who came in during the year that ended last September 30, an official told Congress on Tuesday. Princeton N. Lyman, head of the State Department's Bureau for Refugee Programs, said Bush and Congress will consult later this year to set the level. However, for budget purposes, he said his office had asked Congress to provide money for 110,000 admissions, 40,000 of them from the Soviet Union and 5,500 from Eastern Europe. The request also provides for another 29,000 immigrants from Vietnam, 23,000 from countries in East Asia such as Thailand which has given refugees emergency asylum, 6,000 from the Near East and South Asia, 3,500 from the Western hemisphere and 3,000 from Africa. He added that the administration puts high priority on getting Congress to pass a special bill to accommodate more Soviets. ``We want to be able to expand opportunities for Soviet refugees to come to the U.S. ... as our fair share of the number pressing to leave there,'' he said. He agreed with a private refugee support organization that more should be done by the United States and other countries to help refugees throughout the world. Lyman said there are 15 million refugees worldwide, up from 12.6 million in 1988. Roger P. Winter, director of the unofficial U.S. Committee for Refugees, complained of reduced government spending. In 1985 the U.S. budget for aid to refugees provided $20 per person which is now down by about half, he said. The comments came in testimony to the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations. Panel chairman, Rep. David R. Obey, said the administration's total request for money to help refugees is $30 million below last year's level. Rep. Matthew F. McHugh, D-N.Y., read Obey's statement since the Wisconsin Democrat was absent due to illness. ``Programs for children fare even worse in the administration's request,'' Obey added. He cited a decrease of $23 million in money for population programs and a $15 million decrease in the requested contribution for UNICEF, the United Children's Fund. Obey compared those figures with a $345 million increase in requested military aid and $245 million in economic support for Third World countries. He said the Agency for International Development is setting aside $75 million for countries reforming their economic policies. ``If reform doesn't take place does government funding get cut while children don't receive immunization or education?'' he asked. Mark L. Edelman, AID deputy director, said economic growth is the basis for development in the Third World. ``Without such a growth-oriented base, improvements in the prospects of children will not occur or will be short-lived,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Census Increases Spanish Telephone Assistance
DOC.TEXT: The Census Bureau is increasing the number of telephone help lines, after receiving nearly 50,000 calls over the weekend, the agency said Tuesday. The toll-free service for people with questions about the census opened Friday with 390 lines available. The total is now being increased to 460 lines. Lines for Spanish-speaking callers were a particular problem, officials said, and they are being increased from 88 to 160. ``The volume of calls we're receiving means there is a high degree of awareness and support for the census. But obviously we don't want people to get a busy signal when they call and we're taking steps to make sure that they don't,'' said census director Barbara Everitt Bryant. The assistance lines are staffed from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m., local time, seven days a week. The numbers are: English: 1-800-999-1990. Spanish: 1-800-283-6826. Cambodian: 1-800-289-1960. Chinese: 1-800-365-2101. Korean: 1-800-444-6205. Laotian: 1-800-888-3208. Vietnamese: 1-800-937-1953. Thai: 1-800-288-1984. Hearing Impaired: 1-800-777-0978.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians Demand Deserters Be Returned; Anti-Independence Protest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `In Washington ...' to UPDATE with White House comment.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos VIL1,2,3,50
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis today accused Moscow of ``inexcusable aggression'' and demanded that it return at least 23 Lithuanian army deserters who were beaten and dragged from hospitals. ``The government of Lithuania demands the return of its kidnapped citizens,'' Landsbergis said in a letter to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He also urged negotiations with Moscow ``in neutral territory.'' The letter's angry tone and the Soviet army's decision to round up the deserters marked a new, more volatile stage in the open confrontation between Lithuania and Moscow, which began March 11 with the republic's declaration of independence. The beatings reported during the round-up of Lithuanian deserters were the first violent action by Moscow since the declaration. Soviet soldiers raided two hospitals where the Lithuanian deserters had sought refuge, and witnesses said some deserters were beaten as they were taken from a decaying psychiatric hospital in Vilnius. A trail of blood led down the steps and out the front door of the hospital. ``They beat them with their fists,'' said a duty nurse at a psychiatric hospital where windows and iron beds were broken in the predawn raid. Landsbergis said he feared it could presage a full-scale crackdown on his Baltic republic. ``It is obvious that the Soviet armed forces have been given permission to use violence,'' Landsbergis said. The Soviet Union today also ordered all foreigners to leave Lithuania, Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said in Moscow. Last week diplomats and foreign journalists were told they could not travel to the republic. In Washington, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater refused to criticize Moscow for today's actions, saying ``we do not want to inflame the situation.'' President Bush has urged Gorbachev not to use force against Lithuanians. At a news conference at the Soviet Embassy in Washington, Deputy Ambassador Sergei Chetverikov said the Soviet Union would continue to try to ``find peaceful solutions'' to the unrest in Lithuania but said certain steps by troops were necessary to protect law and order and Soviet installations. About 4,000 opponents of Lithuania's independence drive attended a Vilnius rally today that Landsbergis had warned might turn violent and serve as Moscow's excuse to intervene. A Soviet military helicopter dropped leaflets on Monday urging people to attend today's rally. The rally lasted less than an hour and remained peaceful _ protesters did not even trespass on the grass in the middle of the square near the parliament building. Inside, parliament officials, convinced the crowd might try to storm the building, had rolled out fire hoses to repel attackers. In all, the official Soviet news agency Tass said troops seized 23 deserters in two hospitals. Rita Dapkus, spokeswoman for the Lithuanian Bureau of Information, said Soviet troops beat 12 Lithuanian deserters ``and the militiamen who came to defend them'' at the psychiatric hospital before taking the deserters away. She said the 26 others at the hospital escaped. There were no reports on the extent of injuries. Lithuanians have fled the Red Army, complaining of beatings and other abuse since their republic took moves to leave the Soviet Union. Soviet troops also took over the republic's showcase Communist Party headquarters today, making it the fifth party building to be seized since Sunday in Moscow's bid to assert sovereignty in the republic. Speaking to reporters today, Landsbergis denounced the ``open acts of aggression'' and accused Soviet authorities of fabricating stories of provocation to justify the use of force. Lithuania's Communists broke with Moscow in December, but a pro-Soviet minority in the party has tried to rally against the pro-independence majority. Until the weekend, Moscow had tried to intimidate the Lithuanians with non-violent tactics. The Kremlin paraded tanks through the capital and ordered Lithuanians to surrender firearms and not to attempt a takeover of Soviet-controlled enterprises. The Lithuanians did not budge and Soviet troops began seizing Communist Party buildings. In official media, the Kremlin portrayed the small peaceful republic as in a state of anarchy and accused its leaders of planning to jail opponents of independence. Tensions seemed to ease with the opening of negotiations between Soviet military representatives and Lithuanian leaders on Sunday. But army helicopters later dropped leaflets inviting people to a rally today to protest the ``abyss of independence.'' The move clearly was aimed at playing on the fears of Russian and Polish minorities, who comprise 20 percent of the state's 3.8 million people. In Kaunas, 65 miles west, Soviet soldiers seized another hospital serving as sanctuary, a police officer said. The officer, who did not identify himself, said two young men were arrested and troops were not allowing local police onto hospital grounds. Moscow had warned that Lithuanian soldiers not returning to barracks by last Saturday would be arrested. Lithuania contends the youths were illegally drafted into an army of occupation. The Soviet Union forcibly annexed Lithuania in 1940 along with the two other Baltic republics of Estonia and Latvia, where pro-independence movements are also strong but more cautiously working toward a break with Moscow. A Lithuanian Interior Ministry official and a Lithuanian journalist both said on condition of anonymity that two Lithuanian police officers were beaten by the soldiers when they tried to intervene. An ABC television crew arriving at the scene was held at gunpoint and forced to surrender all its videotape. Gen. Valentin Varennikov, commander of Soviet land forces, was quoted by Tass as saying the arrests were necessary because: ``Deserters, who have become militants in the Sajudis nationalist organization, were undergoing special training ... in one of the buildings of the hospital.'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov today told a news conference that a U.S. Senate resolution passed last week on Lithuania ``can even detonate the difficult and explosive situation in the republic.'' The Senate on Thursday urged the Soviet Union to halt its intimidation of Lithuania and urged President Bush to consider the republic's request for diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEAD: Small Budget Films `Miss Daisy' and `Left Foot' Take Top Oscars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Denzel Washington,' to DELETE reference to regiment being first to fight; historical material and movie press release indicate it may have been first fighting unit recruited in the North but not first blacks to fight in Civil War. Note a0535 PM-Oscars should have been slugged PM-Oscar-Optional sted as 1st Ld - Writethru.
DOC.HEAD: LaserColor LAA104,102; LaserPhoto LAA4; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The Academy Awards celebrated movies low in budget but rich in talent as ``Driving Miss Daisy'' took the Oscar for best picture and actress, while ``My Left Foot'' won for best actor and supporting actress. Jessica Tandy, who played the combative Southern widow who'd rather walk in ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' became the oldest performer to win an Oscar at age 80. A surprised Miss Tandy wondered aloud why the producers cast an actress whose career has mostly been on stage to play a lead in a movie. ``I think I'm very lucky they trusted me with such a wonderful part,'' she said backstage at the Los Angeles Music Center. ``I never thought of myself as a movie actress.'' The movie, about the widow's growing friendship with her black chauffeur, won four prizes, the most of any in the 62nd annual Academy Awards on Monday night. It took screenplay honors, for Alfred Uhry's adaptation of his Pulitzer Prize-winning play, and the makeup Oscar. Daniel Day-Lewis was named best actor for ``My Left Foot,'' the emotional account of artist-poet Christy Brown's battle against cerebral palsy. Brenda Fricker, who played Brown's selfless mother, won for supporting actress. The Civil War movie ``Glory'' drew three prizes, and another high-priced war film, ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' won two, best director for Oliver Stone and best editing. Denzel Washington, who played a runaway slave turned soldier in ``Glory,'' got the supporting actor Oscar. The account about a black Union regiment that fought in the Civil War also gathered trophies for cinematographer Freddie Francis and for best sound. ``My son said he was going to make one of these out of clay for me, now I've got a model for him,'' an exultant Washington said as he held up his gold statue, first award of the evening. Stone won a directing Oscar for the 1986 movie ``Platoon.'' ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' the account of Ron Kovic's passage from gung-ho soldier to disabled anti-war protester, was among the most hyped Oscar contenders, as was its star, Tom Cruise. But Academy voters seemed determined to ignore the efforts of the immodest, favoring instead those films whose path to the screen was more unconventional. The award for art direction went to ``Batman,'' which was the top moneymaker of 1989 at $251 million but failed to win a nomination in any other category. Another top box-office draw, ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' won for sound effects editing. The Oscar for visual effects went to the $60 million underwater thriller ``The Abyss.'' The makers of ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' on the other hand, had to cut the production budget almost in half _ to $7.5 million _ because studios feared it wouldn't be a commercial success. It is. It has grossed $74.5 million. ``My Left Foot'' was made for a paltry $3 million and distributed by independent Miramax Films. ``Miss Daisy'' was dropped by MGM-UA and picked up by Warner Bros., which provided only part of its budget. Producers Richard and Lili Zanuck found foreign financing and slashed their costs to get the film made. The movie's director, Bruce Beresford, wasn't even nominated for an award, a fact lamented by several award winners and presenters. In his opening remarks, show host Billy Crystal described ``Driving Miss Daisy'' as ``the movie that apparently directed itself.'' ``My Left Foot'' carried the imprint of one man, too _ Christy Brown. ``For everyone involved in the film, all our desire to make the film, all the strength that we needed, all the pleasure that we took in making the film came from Christy Brown,'' Day-Lewis said. The Dublin-born Miss Fricker gave thanks to ``Christy Brown, just for being alive, and to his mother, Mrs. Brown. Anybody who gives birth 22 times deserves one,'' she said, referring to the Oscar. Italy's ``Cinema Paradiso,'' a reminiscence of growing up in a Sicilian village, was named best foreign film. The announcement of the foreign film award came after an ear-rattling satellite feed from Moscow, where Jack Lemmon and Soviet actress Natalya Negoda announced nominees with a triple echo reverberating through the sound system. There also were satellite feeds from Australia, Argentina and England. The show, seen by an estimated 1 billion viewers in 90 countries, ran a long 3 hours and 34 minutes. Disney's much-praised animated fairy tale ``The Little Mermaid'' won two Oscars _ best song for the calypso ``Under the Sea,'' and best original score. Japanese filmmaker Akira Kurosawa, director of such classics as ``Rashomon,'' ``The Seven Samurai'' and ``Ran,'' received an honorary Oscar. In his acceptance speech the 80-year-old master struck a humble note, saying, ``I really don't feel yet that I have grasped the essence of cinema.'' ``Henry V'' took the prize for costume design. Tom Schulman, author of ``Dead Poet's Society,'' won for best original screenplay.

DOC.HEAD: 47 Drowned in Bangladesh, 60 Missing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with 47 dead. Pickup 7th graf ``The river...''
DOC.TEXT: A crowded ferry boat capsized when passengers scrambled to save a child who fell overboard, and at least 47 people drowned, news reports said today. Fifty-six others were missing. The privately owned boat was carrying 153 people back from Burma after a day's trip when it sank Monday during high tide in the Naff River in southern Bangladesh, the United News of Bangladesh reported. The river separates Burma with Bangladesh near Tekhnaf. The area is 180 miles south of Dhaka. The news agency quoted survivors as saying the ferry swayed and sank after the passengers hurried to rescue a child who fell into the river from the boat. The child was among the dead. Among the dead were 24 women and five children. The news agency quoted local officials as saying the final death toll would be higher because many of the missing were presumed dead. Rescuers recovered 47 bodies. Fifty people either swam to safety, or were rescued by fishermen. ``The river was on high tide and many bodies are likely to have carried downstream,'' said Habibur Rahman, who was rescued by fishermen. The trip was part of a border accord with Burma under which people from both countries travel to each other nations for sightseeing and shopping. Monday's disaster was the fifth river accident in Bangladesh in the past three months. Four previous accidents occurred in January in which a total of 33 people died. Boats are the most popular means of transport in Bangladesh, a low-lying nation crisscorrsed by rivers. The Bangladesh Shipping Department said at least 2,000 people have died in 218 ferry accidents since 1971 when the nation was born.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Quiet on Latest Developments in Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 9-10, At the ... to UPDATE with State Department denying U.S.-Soviet deal; picks up 9th graf pvs, In the ...
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today refused to criticize Moscow for seizing army deserters in Lithuania, saying, ``We do not want to inflame the situation.'' The restrained U.S. reaction marked a sudden change in tone after repeated expressions of White House concern about possible use of force and intimidation by the Kremlin against the breakaway Baltic republic. Refusing to characterize the Soviet seizure of deserters, White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We simply are not going to try to give definition to words like force and intimidation.'' A Soviet diplomat in Washington, Sergei Chetverikov, defended the action by quoting Vice President Dan Quayle as saying that every army should have some discipline. On Monday, Fitzwater had said the Soviet army's occupation of Communist Party buildings in Lithuania marked an escalation of developments. However, he declined to characterize the latest actions as a further escalation. ``I choose not to do it today,'' Fitzwater said. ``We simply don't feel inflammatory language is helpful. We do not want to inflame the situation.'' Fitzwater acknowledged that a blowup in Lithuania could disrupt U.S.-Soviet relations, which are proceeding warmly toward expected arms agreements this year. ``We have made it clear that the relationship is one of the factors at stake here,'' Fitzwater said. At the State Department, a spokeswoman said Secretary of State James A. Baker III had not yet received an answer to a message he sent Sunday to Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. But Margaret Tutwiler noted that Shevardnadze had been away on a trip to Africa and said Baker expects to receive an answer in the coming days. Tutwiler denied reports that in his private message to Shevardnadze, Baker proposed a deal whereby the United States would refrain from criticizing Soviet actions in Lithuania in return for a Soviet promise to refrain from using force. ``There was absolutely, positively no deal or agreement,'' she said. In the Lithuanian capital, Soviet soldiers stormed two hospitals to seize at least 23 Lithuanian army deserters in the first violent action by Moscow since Lithuania declared independence. ``They beat them with their fists,'' said a duty nurse at a psychiatric hospital where windows and iron beds were broken in the predawn raid. On Saturday, Quayle told reporters in Phoenix that while the Soviet Union should not threaten Lithuania, ``If the Soviet Union is applying disciplinary measures to people in their own military, that's a different situation.'' ``I do not know what kind of contractual agreement a member of the Soviet army has when he or she signs up,'' Quayle said. But there is a ``certain element of discipline that is absolutely imperative in any armed force,'' Quayle said. The vice president's spokesman, David Beckwith, said today, ``He in no way countenanced the violent rounding up of deserters.''

DOC.HEAD: 47 Dead in Bangladesh Ferry Accident; 56 Missing
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 5 grafs to update death toll. Pickup 6th pvs, `The trip...
DOC.TEXT: At least 47 people returning from neighboring Burma drowned when ferry passengers rushed to save a child who had fallen overboard and caused the boat to capsize, news reports said Tuesday. Fifty-six others were reported missing after the accident Monday, the fifth river disaster in Bangladesh this year. United News of Bangladesh said the privately owned boat was carrying 153 people when it sank during high tide in the Naff River. The river separates Burma and Bangladesh. The agency quoted survivors as saying the ferry swayed and sank after passengers rushed to rescue a child who had fallen into the river from the boat. The child was among the dead. United News of Bangladesh quoted local officials as saying many of the missing were presumed dead. Rescuers recovered 47 bodies. Fifty people either swam to safety or were rescued by fishermen. The trip was made possible by an accord with Burma under which people from both countries may travel to the neigboring nation for sightseeing and shopping. The disaster was the fifth river accident in Bangladesh since January. The four previous accidents killed 33 people. Boats are the most popular means of transport in Bangladesh, a low-lying nation crisscrossed by rivers.

DOC.HEAD: Endangered Squirrels Halt Telescope Construction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 5th, `I'm surprised...', to UPDATE with university saying it will appeal. Picks up 6th graf, `Mount Graham...'. DELETES now outdated 14th graf, `Our attorneys...'.
DOC.TEXT: Fear for the survival of 180 endangered squirrels atop an isolated mountain led a judge to block the start of construction on what could become the world's most powerful observatory. U.S. District Judge Alfredo C. Marquez on Monday granted a four-month injunction barring the University of Arizona from beginning construction on the first two of at least three telescopes at the planned $200 million Mount Graham International Observatory. If all goes smoothly with the first two telescopes, a third device that would have the viewing power o a telescope more than 37 feet in diameter is planned for the mid-1990s. The judge said serious questions had been raised over whether the construction would cause irreparable harm to the Mount Graham red squirrel. ``I'm surprised. I'm encouraged,'' said Dr. Robin Silver, a spokesman for the Maricopa County Audubon Society. ``This has been a tough process all along. I'm encouraged that the system can still work.'' The university has decided to appeal, spokesman Steve Emerine said today. Mount Graham in the Pinaleno Mountains in southeastern Arizona is the only known habitat for the 180 remaining squirrels. In 1988, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service concluded in a biological report for the U.S. Forest Service, the site's landlord, that the telescopes could coexist with the squirrel. Arizona's congressional delegation then pushed through legislation ordering the Forest Service to grant the university a permit for construction. But environmental groups sued, contending that perching the telescopes on an 8.6-acre site on one of Mount Graham's three peaks would assure the extinction of the 8-ounce squirrels by taking away more of the forested land they need to survive. University officials contend poor pine cone crops in recent years have hurt the squirrel population. They said hunting, logging, use of off-road vehicles and Christmas tree-cutting have been stopped because of the planned observatory, and that 60 to 80 acres will be reforested. In closing arguments, lawyers for the university and the Justice Department said that the congressional act precluded any further environmental review of the squirrel's habitat in connection with the first three telescopes. But Marquez said Monday he had some questions about whether the wildlife service's ruling was ``preordained.'' He asked Justice Department lawyer Larry Bradfish, ``What's the harm of saying there are some very serious issues here and Congress, you have 120 days ... why don't you take another look at it?'' University officials said they were disappointed by the ruling. U.S. Rep. Jim Kolbe, R-Ariz., said he did not think Congress would take new action. ``There would have to be a major change in the status of the squirrel or an alteration of the biological facts. Absent that, I can't see any reason for Congress to act,'' Kolbe said. Two biologists who took part in the wildlife service study alleged in depositions that officials at the agency ordered researchers to argue in favor of construction. The agency's regional director, Mike Spear, upheld the study as ``biologically sound.'' But last month, after the construction site was designated as a critical habitat, Spear called for another study.

DOC.HEAD: Another Appeal Filed Seeking Stay of Execution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf to UPDATE with London demonstration. Picks up 4th graf, ``The 37-year-old....'
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers trying to block the first execution in California in 23 years made a last-ditch appeal to the federal courts. Attorneys Charles Sevilla and Michael McCabe filed a 114-page petition in U.S. District Court late Monday seeking a stay for the April 3 execution date of Robert Alton Harris, convicted of killing two teen-age boys in 1978. Even as the appeal was being filed, Nobel Peace Prize winner Mother Teresa was pleading with Gov. George Deukmejian to spare Harris' life. Deukmejian, during a five-minute telephone conversation, told her that ``the public has overwhelmingly decided that the death penalty is a just and appropriate punishment'' for convicted murderers, according to a statement from the governor's office. About 30 members of Amnesty International demonstrated against the execution outside the U.S. Embassy in London today. The human rights organization left a letter for the ambassador saying, ``We are particularly concerned that this case will create a precedent for other states in the United States which are not currently carrying out execution.'' The 37-year-old Harris withdrew from a scheduled clemency hearing Tuesday, saying Deukmejian's longtime advocacy of the death penalty prevented him from receiving a fair and impartial review before the governor. U.S. District Judge William Enright scheduled a hearing for 3 p.m. Wednesday. If Enright rejects the stay request, the defense lawyers' next move would be to file a petition with the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. A denial at the 9th Circuit would leave only an appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court, which has denied Harris' appeals four times. Harris could be the first person executed in the gas chamber at San Quentin since 1967, when Aaron Mitchell was put to death for the murder of a Sacramento police officer. Repeating arguments that were rejected by the state's high court earlier this month, the defense lawyers in their petition claimed that Harris was wrongly characterized during his 1979 trial as a sociopath who killed for pleasure and was incapable of remorse. More recent evaluations and studies indicate Harris' violent behavior was the product of an abusive childhood, ``organic'' brain damage causing him to act impulsively and lingering effects damage caused by his mother's heavy drinking while pregnant with him, the petition said. The lawyers also claimed that it was cruel and unusual punishment to have Harris live under the threat of death for 11 years and that it would be wrong to execute him now. They said Harris is a changed man. Harris shot and killed the boys and stole their car for use in a bank robbery. He had abducted the youths as they sat in their parked car at a drive-in restaurant, ordered them to a remote spot and then shot them.

DOC.HEAD: Winston Churchill's Grandson Joins Americans Honoring Ike
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 5-6, bgng, Later, at ... to UPDATE with Bush comments; picks up 5th graf pvs, John S.D. ...; edits thruout to tighten
DOC.TEXT: Sir Winston Churchill's grandson, saluting Dwight D. Eisenhower on behalf of his wartime ``comrades-in-arms,'' joined Americans today in honoring the man who led Allied armies to victory and became the 34th president of the United States. ``It was under the command of General Eisenhower that Europe _ or at lest half of it _ was liberated,'' Winston S. Churchill told a joint meeting of Congress held to honor Eisenhower on the centennial of his birth. ``How thrilled he and Churchill would be today, to see the peoples of Eastern Europe at last emerging as free nations from a nightmare of 50 years' occupation, first under the Nazis, then the Soviet Red Army,'' Churchill said. ``He will forever be revered among those nations who, like my own, were his comrades-in-arms and remembered with abiding gratitude by those nations which were liberated, under his command, from the most monstrous and vile tyranny that has ever defiled this earth,'' Churchill said. Later, at a White House luncheon, President Bush said Eisenhower was ``a healer, not a hater'' and credited him with helping to bring peace to the world. ``Welcome to the house that Ike and Mamie graced,'' Bush told the luncheon audience that included family members and many friends of the Eisenhowers. ``Every president admirers other presidents ... And so today I say it proudly and very proudly: I always liked Ike,'' Bush said. John S.D. Eisenhower, son of the Republican president who served from 1953 to 1961, said, ``I believe he would like to be thought of simply as the Good Soldier.'' ``He walked with kings but never forgot his home in Abilene, Kansas,'' Eisenhower said. ``He was the vaunted warrior who hated war. He was the five-star general who warned of the dangers of an unbridled military-industrial complex.'' Walter Cronkite, retired CBS television news anchor, saluted Eisenhower as ``the greatest hero of the greatest war in history.'' ``No man did more to rid our planet of the Nazi scourge,'' Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole, himself a disabled veteran of World War II, said in prepared remarks. ``No one gave more in the Cold War against human enslavement,'' said Dole, from Eisenhower's home state of Kansas. ``And no one deserves more gratitude from a world waking up to its own potential.'' Members of Eisenhower's family, including several great-grandchildren, and surviving members of his administration joined senators and representatives in the chamber. Many wore red, white and blue ``I Like Ike'' buttons. The Army Band played a medley of Armed Forces melodies and ``The Battle Hymn of the Republic.'' Eisenhower, who died 21 years ago on Wednesday, spoke 10 times in the House chamber himself. The first time, June 18, 1945, he was supreme commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force, returning from Europe to a hero's welcome that included a joint congressional meeting. One-quarter of the 100 members of the current Senate and 18 members of the 435-member House served in World War II. The second time Eisenhower spoke to a joint meeting of Congress, on Feb. 1, 1951, he was supreme allied commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and appealed for arms and leadership to resist communist aggression. As president from 1953 to 1961, Eisenhower delivered seven State of the Union addresses to joint sessions of Congress _ which are more official in nature than joint meetings. On Jan. 5, 1957, he went before Congress with a special message outlining his ``Eisenhower Doctrine'' of military and economic aid in the troubled Middle East. Eisenhower was born Oct. 14, 1890, in a house that is now part of a state park in Denison, Texas. He was one of seven sons of David and Ida Eisenhower. One of the sons died in infancy. When Dwight was less than a year old, the family moved to Abilene, Kan., where the future president grew up and where he Eisenhower Presidential Library now stands. After West Point and his rise to supreme command in Europe, Eisenhower was twice elected president by large margins in campaigns remembered for red, white and blue buttons reading ``I Like Ike.'' The Dwight David Eisenhower Centennial Commission, established by Congress to observe the 100th anniversary, has planned observances throughout the year, including a hometown celebration in Abilene on Eisenhower's birthday.

DOC.HEAD: Rocky Statue Banned From Museum
DOC.TEXT: ``Rocky'' fans have lost another round in their bout to return a bronze statue of their hero to the top of the Art Museum steps, where it had stood before the skyline as Sylvester Stallone did in the movie. The Art Commission voted 4-3 Monday to prevent the statue from being placed permanently anywhere on the museum grounds. Under the city charter, the commission has final say about the placement of art objects on public land. In another 4-3 vote, the commission turned down a recommendation by the Fairmount Park Commission to return the statue to the top of the steps for up to a year. The Art Commission said it would consider a suggestion to put the statue in the Italian Market, the neighborhood that was home to the fictional Rocky Balboa in the award-winning film. The statue, commissioned for ``Rocky III,'' had been moved back to the museum steps earlier this year to be used in the filming of ``Rocky V.'' Rocky fans wanted the statue left there, but museum president Robert Montgomery Scott said the statue is a movie prop _ not art _ and demanded it be moved. Despite objections from James Binns, an attorney hired by Stallone, the statue was returned a month ago to a spot outside the Spectrum sports complex. The Art Commission decided then to give itself 60 days to find a permanent site for the statue. A month remains in its timetable.

DOC.HEAD: City Educator Shuns Chicago High School for Daughter
DOC.TEXT: The deputy mayor of education says she is sending her eldest daughter to a suburban private academy because the quality of education in Chicago is poor. Lourdes Monteagudo, who was appointed in May by Mayor Richard M. Daley, said the girl is a freshman at North Shore Country Day School in Winnetka, where Monteagudo's former husband lives. Even if the girl lived with her every day on Chicago's Northwest Side, Monteagudo said, she would not send her to Clemente High School, the school she would have to attend. ``I don't have to apologize for it,'' she said. ``Prior to my appointment, I talked with my daughter, and she decided to go to school outside of the city. ... I could not support her staying in Chicago until the system can be reformed, because the system is bad.'' Monteagudo has two other children living at home. Both go to the city elementary school where Monteagudo was principal before her City Hall appointment.

DOC.HEAD: Government Commission Says Racism Spreading Across France
DOC.TEXT: A government commission on Tuesday said racism, particularly against North African immigrants, is spreading in France, and Premier Michel Rocard asked all political parties to combat this ``threat to our national heritage.'' Rocard made his appeal after receiving a 400-page report from a commission appointed to investigate what has become the country's most pressing social problem. Racial tensions intensified during the six-month investigation. This month alone, three Moroccan immigrants have been killed in incidents that prompted protests by human rights groups. The Socialist government and its center-right rivals have called for tolerance, but the far-right National Front has stepped up its campaign against immigration. The commission said racism against North Africans was the most widespread, increasing markedly in 1989. About 4 million of France's 55 million residents are immigrants, mainly Moslems from North Africa. The commission said 75 percent of French people responding to a survey it conducted said they believe there are too many North Africans in France. The report said the number of racial attacks and threats jumped to 237 in November and December, compared to 135 in the same period of 1988. The increase followed a nationwide controversy that focused on whether Moslem girls should be allowed to wear Islamic scarves to public schools. The controversy focused attention on immigrants' place in French society. The nationwide debate began when several local school officials barred Moslem girls from classes because they insisted on wearing traditional Islamic scarves. The officials cited a law prohibiting display of religious symbols in schools. The government eventually relented, saying the scarves could be worn as long as education was not disrupted. Anti-Semitism also persists, the commission said, referring to revisionist theories that the Nazi concentration camps did not exist. It cited ``skinhead'' and facist groups as among the culprits. Racism is found ``at all levels of social life and in all parts of the country,'' said the commission, which decried the exploitation of racial fears by political candidates. In incidents this month, a bus driver was charged with willful homicide for running over and killing a 17-year-old immigrant. A cook shot at two Moroccan brothers, killing one. And a police brigadier was detained briefly after shooting to death a young Moroccan who purportedly tried to escape from a police vehicle after being arrested. The report said political and civic leaders need a two-pronged approach _the will to enforce laws against racism and the foresight to take preventative steps. These priorities should be coupled with efforts to enhance the assimilation of immigrants into French society and eliminate discrimination, it said. Rocard invited leaders of his own Socialist Party, the two center-right parties and the Communist Party to a meeting April 3 to launch an anti-racism initiative. No invitation was sent to the National Front, whose leader, Jean Marie Le Pen, has described the political hierarchy's outcry over racism as ``indecent.'' The recent violence, according to Le Pen, is ``directly tied to social phenomena resulting from immigration policies which they are directly responsible for.''

DOC.HEAD: Late Winter Storm May Have Damaged Wheat Crop
DOC.TEXT: Colder weather slowed winter wheat development in the Great Plains and may have caused some damage in a few southern areas where top growth was heavier, a government report said Tuesday. The Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said a winter storm brought ``some beneficial moisture'' to the northern plains during the week of March 19-25. Wheat growth in Kansas was reported excellent early in the week before the cold front moved through. ``Oklahoma's winter wheat was good to fair, but freezing temperatures damaged some fields with moderate top growth,'' the report said. ``Cold weather slowed growth in most areas of Texas at the end of the week.'' The facility is operated by the Agriculture and Commerce departments. Weekly reports cover crop conditions but do not include production forecasts. Looking at other crops, the report said fieldwork progressed well in the Mississippi Delta as fields dried. Corn planting was more than one-third complete in Alabama, but earlier flooding may force some replanting. Rice planting continued in Louisiana, and cotton farmers continued planting in Arizona and southern California. Tobacco was reported in good-to-fair condition in Georgia and North Carolina, and in fair-to-good shape in South Carolina. The storm in the northern plains was a hardship for livestock and newborn calves, despite its moisture benefits for pastures and crops, the report said. Pastures were said to be in mostly good-to-fair condition in the Delta and East.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises African Entrepreneurs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told entrepreneurs from 14 African nations Tuesday that they were ``doing the Lord's work'' in trying to find business solutions their economic woes. Bush met with 36 African business leaders and executives of the African Development Bank who want to interest foreign private investors in business opportunities. In a departure from usual practice, the White House press office did not list the meeting on Bush's public schedule nor allow reporters to cover it. The White House later released a transcript of the president's remarks to the African Business Roundtable. ``You all are doing the Lord's work and are on the right track in terms of investment,'' he said. ``We all recognize that Africa faces tremendous challenges,'' from poverty to disease to ``needless armed conflicts,'' Bush said. ``But Africa's most fundamental challenge ... is on the economic development side _ harnessing the continent's natural and human resources to create better and richer lives for all of the people there. ``The key to a richer and more vibrant economy across the continent is ... in the private sector, not in the hands of the governments. That's why you and other African entrepreneurs represent the bright promise of Africa's economic future working _ I hope _ more and more with America.'' He said the business leader were ``doing exactly the right thing in looking for investment opportunities at home, seeking support from private investors abroad and working to develop mutually beneficial trade relationships.'' The executives came from Nigeria, Senegal, Zambia, Ivory Coast, Egypt, Cameroon, Burundi, Kenya, Togo, Ghana, Zaire, Morocco, Zimbabwe and Tunisia. None was from South Africa, a White House aide said. The African executives will make their sales pitch in Atlanta, Dallas and New York.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Considers Reining In Lobbyists for Foreigners
DOC.TEXT: Foreigners are not always required to disclose the millions of dollars they pay American lobbyists to promote their point of view, witnesses told Congress Tuesday. Sen. John Heinz, R-Penn., said he has proposed legislation to strengthen the Foreign Agents Registration Act so foreigners will not be able to subvert U.S. policy and national security. He singled out the Japanese as among the biggest spenders. Between 1987 and 1989 the total spent by all registered agents for Japanese entities was more than $120 million, Heinz estimated. The act, first passed in 1938, requires lobbyists to disclose the amount of money they receive from foreign governments and what they do for the fee. But it is fraught with loopholes, witnesses said. Another witness before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee _ Owen Bieber _ said reforms are needed. Bieber is president of the International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America. ``Foreign governments and companies today are spending hundreds of millions of dollars to influence public policy in our country,'' he said. ``The sheer amount of money and the manner in which it is spent are distorting our political process. These excesses demand reform.'' Heinz said his interest was piqued recently by a case involving Toshiba Corp.'s efforts to avoid congressional sanctions after Toshiba Machine sold the Soviet Union precision milling equipment used for the production of submarine propellers. Toshiba paid the law firm of Mudge, Rose, Guthrie, Alexander and Ferndon nearly $11 million to act on its behalf, Heinz said. But Heinz said Toshiba's scores of subsidiaries were not required to register. ``Registration is not presently required for most subsidiaries or for clients where the agent did not engage in any reportable activity,'' Heinz said.
