Provisional Measures 153 and 156 were invoked by police last week to arrest and hold without bail some 30 bankers and businessmen. The measures prohibited selling goods and services above the government-set rate and outlawed tax cheating. Congressmen and legal experts say the measures were unconstitutional. The provisional measures were invoked immediately but required congressional approval within 30 days. Approval seemed unlikely. Collor said he would scrap the measures and resubmit them as a bill to Congress. ``We are not retreating,'' Collor said. ``We want to march in step with the constitution.'' Public opinion polls show Brazilians overwhelmingly support the overall plan, which includes an 18-month freeze on $115 billion in savings accounts and financial market deposits. One survey showed 94 percent favored the two-to-five year prison sentences for tax cheating and illegal price hikes. However, several legislators called the decrees dictatorial. After police invaded the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo to investigate charges of illegal billing, the paper called Collor a ``fledgling dictator'' and compared him to Benito Mussolini. Collor also announced that Economy Minister Zelia Cardoso de Mello would travel abroad next week for talks with creditors of Brazil's $114 billion foreign debt, the largest in the Third World. Brazil will seek a broad renegotiation of terms, he said. The country now pays about $12 billion a year in interest alone, although payments have been suspended since September. Last week, the Economy Ministry said debt payments would be limited to $5 billion a year. Collor said Brazil must guarantee its growth before it can repay its debt. He said the government would avoid ``confrontation'' with creditors and predicted talks would be favorable because of ``the credibility recovered by the country.''

DOC.HEAD: Avianca Pilot Asked for Fuel Emergency, But Co-Pilot Used Other Words
DOC.TEXT: The co-pilot of the Avianca airliner that crashed in New York told the pilot he had radioed a fuel emergency but he used less precise language with ground controllers, a transcript of cockpit talk showed Tuesday. The plane, which apparently ran out of fuel, crashed Jan. 25 at Cove Neck, Long Island, killing 73 of the 159 people aboard, including all three cockpit crew members. ``Tell them we are in emergency,'' said the Colombian pilot in Spanish just after the plane failed its first landing attempt and 10 minutes before it crashed. ``We're running out of fuel,'' the co-pilot told controllers in English at 9:24 p.m., after the crew of the Boeing 707 was instructed to abort the attempted landing at John F. Kennedy airport and loop around for another try. A few seconds later, the pilot again asked the co-pilot to tell the controller there was an emergency. ``Digale que estamos en emergencia,'' the pilot said, also asking whether his order had been carried out. ``Si, Senor, ya le dije,'' said the co-pilot _ ``Yes, sir, I already advised him,'' according to the transcript and translation released by the National Transportation Safety Board. None of the cockpit crew members was identified by name in the transcript. The flight had come from Bogota and Medellin. A source close to the investigation had told The Associated Press in New York on Monday that the transcript appeared to show a pilot who did not seem to be in full charge of the flight and who did not give specific direction to the co-pilot to declare an emergency. The 68-page transcript of the flight's final 40 minutes, however, contained two instances in which the pilot used the critical word ``emergency'' in communicating with his co-pilot. After the crash, the Federal Aviation Administration ordered all airlines flying to U.S. airports to ensure that their crews use specifically worded language in communicating emergencies to controllers. If a ``fuel emergency'' had been declared, the plane would have been given a higher priority in landing, officials said. Board investigators who released the transcript declined to evaluate crew performance. Cause of the crash will be determined by the four-member safety board after the investigation is completed in about 10 months. As air traffic controllers were giving the plane instructions for a second approach to the airport, the co-pilot radioed: ``We'll try once again. We're running out of fuel.'' A few seconds later, the pilot said, ``I don't know what happened with the runway. I didn't see it.'' Both co-pilots repeated the same thing: ``I didn't see it.'' After one instruction from the pilot to advise the controller that ``we don't have fuel,'' the co-pilot said into the radio, ``Climb and maintain 3,000 and, ah, we're running out of fuel, sir.'' The final eight minutes on the tape contained only one further reference to fuel, when the New York controller told the plane he was going to bring it about 15 miles northeast and then turn it back for the final approach. ``Is that fine with you and your fuel?'' the controller asked. ``I guess so. Thank you very much,'' the co-pilot radioed. In the cockpit, the pilot asked, ``What did he say?'' The third man in the cockpit replied, ``The guy is angry.'' The transcript does not make it clear whom he is referring to or why he made the statement. There is also a point about seven minutes before the crash where the pilot says, ``A morir,'' or ``to die.'' But its meaning is not clear from the transcript and there is no other statement to indicate it was a reference to the imminent crash. The final minutes of the tape before the crash were undramatic, full of routine flight instructions, except when the third officer in the cockpit announced that the No. 4 engine had died, followed a minute later by the No. 3 engine, leaving only two in operation. ``Flameout on engine No. 3, essential on No. 2, on No. 1,'' the third crew member said. The final words in the transcript refer to the instrument landing system. The tape apparently stopped recording as power failed several seconds before impact at 9:34 p.m. Preliminary results of drug tests on the bodies of the pilots indicated no use of illegal substances, a board source said.

DOC.HEAD: Award-Winning Actress to Run for Opposition Parliament Seat
DOC.TEXT: The opposition Labor Party on Tuesday chose Academy Award-winning actress Glenda Jackson to run for a seat in Parliament in Britain's next general election. Miss Jackson, winner of best actress Oscars for the 1970 film ``Women in Love'' and 1973's ``A Touch of Class,'' said she would give up acting if elected to the north London constituency now held by the governing Conservatives of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. ``You can't be a part-time MP (member of Parliament) and you certainly can't be a part-time actor,'' said Miss Jackson, 53, after she was chosen by local members of the socialist Labor Party in Hampstead and Highgate, the north London constituency. ``It is one of the proudest and one of the most humbling moments of my life,'' Miss Jackson said following a poll of 800 members of the constituency's Labor Party in which she won 59.16 percent of the vote. She pledged to work hard to win the seat, which the Conservatives hold by a 2,221-vote majority. The general election must be held before mid-1992 but can be called at any time by the government, which is trailing in some national polls by more than 20 percent, primarily because of a controversial new tax. Miss Jackson is considered one of Britain's foremost stage actresses and has also had a successful film career.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Markets Plunge, Rio Stocks Suffer Record Crash
DOC.TEXT: Brazil's two stock markets continued to plunge Monday in the aftermath of draconian economic reforms decreed by new President Fernando Collor de Mello. In Rio, the stock market was off by a record 16.2 percent, and has now fallen by one-third since Collor announced his package Mar. 16. The much-larger Sao Paulo exchange dropped by 6 percent Monday after plunging 49 percent last week. Stock market analysts say the fall on the two exchanges is largely due to a lack of money in circulation. Collor's economic package, designed to cut record inflation of 73 percent in February, included an 18-month freeze on assets of more than $1,200 in private bank savings accounts and $600 on short-term money market deposits. The measure took about $115 billion out of circulation _ 80 percent of all bank deposits. Stock investors, desperate to get their hands on cash, are selling off shares even at low prices, analysts say. The money squeeze has also created a steep drop in business sales and large scale layoffs in some industries, with many economists saying Brazil, Latin America's most populous with 150 million residents, could soon be mired in a deep recession.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Seeks Seabrook License Delay
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts pushed on two fronts Tuesday to halt the start-up of New Hampshire's Seabrook nuclear power plant before summer crowds flock to nearby beaches. State attorneys argued before a Nuclear Regulatory Commission appeal board for a temporary shutdown of the plant. At the same time, the lawyers and other Seabrook opponents pushed to have federal appeals court judges move up the date of a hearing on the case from September to this spring. ``We're trying to get a hearing before summer,'' said John Traficonte, who is handling the case for Massachusetts Attorney General James Shannon. ``That is the time of year when thousands of people will be sitting on the beaches.'' In Tuesday's hearing before the Atomic Safety and Licensing Appeal Board, Traficonte argued that an error made by plant operators during low-power testing in June warranted a second look and that the plant's operating license should be suspended in the meantime. Plant spokesman Ron Sher called the latest legal manuvers by Massachusetts ``just another effort to delay the operation of Seabrook Station for no good reason.'' ``The fact is Seabrook is a safe plant,'' Sher said. Massachusetts and other opponents have argued for years that Seabrook was too close to densely populated coastal areas to allow for safe evacuation in a nuclear emergency. The NRC rejected those arguments March 1 and awarded Seabrook an operating license. The plant already has begun to move toward full power, a process that will take about three months. Traficonte said one of the most dangerous times in the operation of any nuclear plant is the first acceleration to full power. Under the current schedule, Seabrook will be in its first weeks of full-power operation during the summer, when tens of thousands of beach-goers flock to nearby resort towns. On June 22, Seabrook operators conducting low-power testing didn't shut down the plant after a valve failure when guidelines indicated it should have been shut down. The NRC ordered a halt to testing and fined Seabrook $50,000. Traficonte said the NRC made its licensing decision in March without resolving the problems that led to the June incident. Sher rejected those arguments. ``The power ascension program is a very safe, conservative program,'' Sher said. ``More than 100 plants have gone through the power ascension program safely in the United States.'' Sher said that the problems that led to the June incident have been corrected. The appeal board said it wanted more information from Shannon's office and the Seabrook operators and gave both parties up to 17 days to comply.

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Says Israel Stalling to Gain Time Against Palestinians
DOC.TEXT: PLO leader Yasser Arafat said Tuesday that Israel's political leaders were stalling over formation of a new government in an effort to gain time against the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``I expected this,'' the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman told a news conference. ``From the very beginning they are trying to win time.'' Referring to Israel's internal political turmoil following a no-confidence vote against Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and efforts by the more moderate Shimon Peres to form a new government, Arafat said: ``To resign or not to resign, to go to elections or not to go to elections: This will continue, and in the end we will raise our flag'' _ the flag of Palestine on territory now held by Israel. Arafat said after the news conference he thought Peres, who has indicated a willingness to begin some sort of dialogue on the Palestinian question, would win the Israeli power struggle. ``I think he will have a slight majority,'' he said. Asked if a Peres victory would make it easier to start talks on the occupied territories, Arafat gave a slight nod. ``But I don't want to say anything now,'' he said. During the half-hour news conference, Arafat criticized U.S. senators who last week adopted a resolution that said, ``Jerusalem is and should remain the capital of the state of Israel.'' ``This is one resolution, like other resolutions, that the Congress has been adopting without really studying as they should,'' he said. ``This is not a challenge for me only. This is a challenge for (President) Bush, also, who said Israel should not have the right to settle new Jews in East Jerusalem as East Jerusalem is occupied territory,'' Arafat said. The Senate resolution contradicted U.S. policy, which says the sovereignty of Jerusalem should be determined in Arab-Israeli negotiations. Israel captured East Jerusalem from Jordan in the 1967 Mideast war and declared the entire holy city its capital. The United States, like most nations, maintains its embassy in Tel Aviv. Arafat said the United States was partly to blame for the flood of Soviet Jews to Israel and the possibility of them settling in the West Bank. ``The doors for immigration have been closed for these immigrants in America and in other countries,'' he said. Referring to the Moslem uprising against Indian rule in Kashmir, which is claimed by both predominantly Hindu India and Islamic Pakistan, Arafat said the two countries were ``friendly neighbors'' who should find a peaceful solution. He said there was no comparison between Kashmir and Palestine. Palestine, he said, was a question of democracy, not religion. Arafat, flanked by a PLO interpreter and an Indian Foreign Ministry official, spoke from a podium in front of a namecard that identified him as ``the president of the state of Palestine.'' India was one of the first non-Arab nations to recognize the PLO's declaration of Palestinian statehood in 1988. The Palestinian uprising began in December 1987. The PLO chief came to India to receive the Jawaharlal Nehru award for peace and international understanding. The award is named for India's first prime minister. During his visit, Arafat met Prime Minister V.P. Singh, whose National Front coalition government took office last December, and with the opposition Congress Party leader, former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. On Wednesday, Arafat is to fly to Calcutta to meet Mother Teresa, winner of the 1979 Nobel Peace Prize. In 1982, at the height of the Israeli siege of West Beirut where Arafat and his guerrillas were trapped, the frail Roman Catholic nun braved the war to rescue mentally retarded children from a hospital near the front lines.

DOC.HEAD: White House Tones Down Criticism of Soviets in Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with private warnings to Moscow, subbing 3 grafs for grafs 4-6 pvs, Asked if ... weapons.
DOC.TEXT: The White House abruptly muted its criticism of Soviet actions against Lithuania on Tuesday but still reminded Moscow that a severe crackdown could damage superpower relations. ``We do not want to inflame the situation,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, declining to criticize the Kremlin for seizing at least 23 army deserters from two hospitals in Lithuania in a bloody show of force. ``We simply don't feel that inflammatory language is helpful,'' Fitzwater said. While toning down its public rhetoric, the administration was privately warning Moscow against taking a tough stand, officials said. ``We are letting them know that if they really crack down, we will react, and not just the administration. Congress could takes steps and we might not be able to control the reaction,'' said one administration source. Two sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said possible U.S. responses might be to postpone a superpower summit scheduled for June or to delay treaties on nuclear, chemical and conventional arms that both sides want to sign this year. However, one source said, ``We don't want to do something that would punish us as much as the Russians.'' A likely first step would be suspension of trade talks designed to give Moscow most favored nation status in commerce with the United States. Asked if Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had violated his pledge against using force in Lithuania, Fitzwater replied, ``We simply are not going to try to give definition to words like `force' and `intimidation.''' The restrained U.S. reaction was a sudden change in tone after repeated expressions of concern by President Bush and others about escalating pressure against Lithuania, which defied Moscow and declared its independence March 11. With the planned summit and prospect of arms agreements, both Bush and Gorbachev have a huge stake in keeping U.S.-Soviet relations on an even keel. Appealing for U.S. understanding, a Soviet diplomat in Washington defended the seizure of deserters, saying every army has a right to maintain discipline and contending Moscow was not using force against Lithuania. ``Even Vice President (Dan) Quayle admitted the other day there should be some discipline in the army,'' said Sergei Chetverikov, minister-counselor at the Soviet Embassy. On Saturday, Quayle said the Soviets should not threaten the Lithuanians but that there was a ``certain amount of discipline that is absolutely imperative in any armed force.'' Quayle's press secretary, David Beckwith, said Tuesday that the vice president ``in no way countenanced the violent rounding up of deserters.'' Former President Jimmy Carter discussed Lithuania with Bush during an Oval Office meeting concerning Carter's recent trip to the Middle East. Speaking with reporters later in the White House driveway, Carter said, ``President Gorbachev faces a quandary: Is he going to let part of the Soviet Union break off, on the one hand; at the same time, how to treat with compassion and understanding the move that he, himself, has precipitated toward democracy, toward freedom and toward an expression of independence.'' He said the United States ``has played it very well'' by urging a peaceful settlement. Asked if there were a danger that U.S.-Soviet progress could be undone by tensions over Lithuania, Carter said, ``There's always a danger but I don't want to comment on it.'' At a rally on the Capitol steps, organized by the newly formed Americans for Lithuanian Independence, a crowd of several hundred sang Lithuanian and American patriotic songs and heard a parade of congressmen appeal for swift recognition of Lithuania. ``We stood by as the tanks rolled into Tiananmen Square and did very little,'' said Rep. Benjamin Gilman of New York, a senior Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee. ``Let's not stand by and let there be bloodletting in Lithuania.'' Fitzwater, referring to the tense standoff in Lithuania, said, ``This is a very complex, delicate diplomatic situation and we will continue to treat it as such.'' The United States has never recognized the forced incorporation of Lithuania into the Soviet Union, along with the Baltic states of Estonia and Latvia, in 1940. Despite Lithuania's declaration of independence, the United States has refused to grant it formal diplomatic recognition, saying the Lithuanians do not control their territory and calling on the Soviet Union and Lithuania to negotiate their differences. Fitzwater said any outcome in Lithuania other than a peaceful one ``runs a risk of being counterproductive for the Soviet Union itself, for U.S.-Soviet relations and will have adverse international repercussions.'' The spokesman said, ``We have made it clear from the beginning that the relationship is one of the factors that is at stake and that this is a very serious issue that we are watching.'' As recently as Monday, the administration criticized Moscow for occupying Communist Party buildings in the capital of Vilnius. Fitzwater said then that Soviet efforts to intimidate Lithuanians ``seemed to have escalated on a daily basis.'' On Tuesday, he declined to say that the seizing of Lithuanian deserters marked a further escalation. ``I choose not to do it today,'' Fitzwater said, adding that ``we are worried that our comments might be portrayed in such a way as they would be unhelpful.'' He said, ``We were a little concerned at the way some of my words yesterday were played (in the media) with regard to that episode. I want to be more careful today.'' While refusing to criticize the seizure of deserters, Fitzwater said, ``We view with deep concern the developments of last week and yesterday.'' He said his comment ``extends to all events but we are reluctant to pick out one or the other to comment on.''

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Says Negotiations Have Had Little Impact on World Trade
DOC.TEXT: Decades of multinational negotiations have had little impact on world trade in farm commodities, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Tuesday. ``There's no question in my mind that agriculture is the most distortive sector of the world economy, when one evaluates existing trade patterns,'' Yeutter told a meeting of the Food Executives International Congress. In the case of industrial goods, there has been substantial progress in trade liberalization under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. There has been a move under GATT to deal with the international aspects of the financial and service sectors. ``Agriculture has been on the agenda for the past 40 years, and probably nothing has happened,'' Yeutter said. ``We've gone through 40 years of GATT history, through a whole series of multilateral trade rounds, and for all practical purposes we, the members of GATT, have accomplished nothing in the way of agricultural trade liberalization.'' The current Uruguay Round of GATT talks is scheduled to conclude at the end of this year. Yeutter said there are all sorts of ``schemes'' used to avoid trade liberalization and that agricultural commodities are favorite targets. ``If it exists, it's applied to agriculture,'' he said. ``If there's anything that is distortive, you can bet your bottom dollar it's used by some country somewhere to impede agricultural trade.'' Those devices, he said, include export subsidies, high internal price supports, quotas and licensing. Yeutter pointedly used Japan's restrictive import policy on rice as an example. Recently, he said, a U.S. rice industry group participated in a food show in Japan and included samples of American rice. But the Japanese government asked that the samples be withdrawn. ``I wonder about anyone's commitment to trade liberalization when we can't even show a sample of an American food product in Japan,'' Yeutter said. The European Economic Community, for years a favorite target of U.S. trade officials, also was cited by Yeutter for boosting internal soybean price supports to more than $18 a bushel. The U.S. price support was $4.53 for 1989 soybeans. ``I told some of them here recently that if you paid me $18 a bushel for soybeans, I'd grow them on the Alps, and I think maybe somebody's going to grow them on the Alps if that continues very much longer,'' he said. ``If you pay farmers enough money, they'll grow anything anywhere.''

DOC.HEAD: Science Foundation Pledges $10 million
DOC.TEXT: The National Science Foundation on Tuesday announced up to $10 million will be provided to selected states with detailed plans to stimulate major improvements in math and science education. Foundation Director Erich Bloch said the new science education improvement effort supports the goal of President Bush and the nation's governors to make American students first in the world in science and mathematics achievement by the year 2000. ``To prosper in this world the United States must maintain a strong base in science and engineering, because that is the basis for much of our economic strength,'' said Bloch, who stressed the need for systemic changes in state education programs. Bloch said that the foundation expects in the first year to select four to eight states, on a competitive basis, to participate in the program. ``We will look for comprehensive plans to improve statewide science and mathematics education significantly _ not simply to tinker with the details,'' he said. ``Plans will need to deal with teacher preparation, retention, and continuing education; with curriculum improvements, with student motivation, and with upgrading educational facilities.'' Bloch said the plans also must include governors, state legislative leaders, chief state school officers, teacher's organizations, school administrators, unions and parent groups, industry leaders and presidents of colleges and universities. Noting the numerous studies documenting the poor achievements of U.S. students in math and science, Bloch said, ``we want to move beyond studies, and beyond planning in the abstract, to real action.'' For the selected states, the foundation will make grants totaling $5 million to $10 million over the expected life of the project. Bloch said that ``significant systemic changes'' must be supported through ``long-term fiscal commitments from state legislatures and other sources, public and private, to assure permanence of the reforms begun in the program.'' Bloch said states must submit preliminary proposals for the Statewide Initiatives Program by July 9, with the deadline for formal proposals set for Oct. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Carter Says International Peace Conference Necessary for Middle East
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jimmy Carter, just back from a private peace-seeking mission to the Middle East, said Tuesday there will be no end to unrest there without an international peace conference for the region. Carter, who briefed President Bush for 35 minutes on his trip, said he was encouraged about the prospects for peace. ``I think that there's a general acceptance now that a comprehensive peace is not only necessary but I think inevitable,'' he said. Nonetheless, Carter said it was distressing that the Middle East is still in turmoil 11 years after he helped negotiate the Camp David accords between Israel and Egypt. Carter refused to predict when any kind of negotiations might begin in the Middle East, in part because Israel still doesn't have a government. The United States has long opposed such a broad-ranging, many-nations conference, prefering direct negotiations among the states involved. The Israeli coalition government recently fell, not long after Bush stirred controversy by criticizing the settlement of Soviet Jews in East Jerusalem. The United States has been pressing Israel to open talks with the Palestinians of the territories occupied by Israel in 1967, and Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak has been trying to put together a Palestinian delegation, Carter noted. ``I think our government ought to use its maximum influence _ not pressure _ in Israel and the other countries as well to go to the bargaining table to find peace,'' he said. There will be ``no end'' to the intifada _ the term used for the Palestinian uprising against Israel _ until ``there is an international peace conference,'' Carter said in remarks at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a think tank he visited after his trip to the White House. Moreover, Carter said he believes the intifada was caused by the way the Israelis have treated Palestinians. The former president said he brought up human rights repeatedly in Israel, complaining about practices such as detaining Palestinians for 12 months without allowing access to a lawyer. Israelis of all parties have said prospects for talks with Palestinians were threatened by Bush's statement that the United States did not want to see additional Jewish settlements established in the occupied territories, including East Jerusalem. Past U.S. statements on the subjects have not specifically mentioned East Jerusalem, which Israel has annexed. Carter defended Bush's statements. ``I think what President Bush has expressed is a policy that's been our government's ... for the last 23 years.'' The U.S. government has for years insisted that the final status of East Jerusalem could be determined only by negotiations. Carter visited Israel, Egypt, Syria and Jordan on his latest trip. Carter played a leading role in monitoring last month's elections in Nicaragua, in which Sandinista President Daniel Ortega lost to Violeta de Chamorro. He has also tried to mediate a truce between factions in Ethiopia and the Sudan. The meeting between Bush and Carter was the first time the two had talked since the Nicaraguan elections. Secretary of State James A. Baker III also attended the meeting with Bush and Carter. At the White House, Carter told reporters Bush has reacted well to the situation in Lithuania where leaders want to break from the Soviet Union. ``I think our government has played it very well so far by imploring all parties not to resort to force or violence and to resolve this in a peaceful fashion,'' said the former president.

DOC.HEAD: Revenge Arsonist Profile: Poor, Powerless, Rejected
DOC.TEXT: Poor, powerless, alone and rejected, Julio Gonzalez fits the profile of a revenge arsonist, an expert said Tuesday. Most chilling, he said, is that such killers rarely consider the lives they destroy. ``They're angry against society. They feel a need to strike out,'' said John Barracato, a fire investigator and author of a book on arson. ``They only want to vent their frustration. They don't care about the other people.'' Gonzalez, 36, is charged with setting the fire that killed 87 patrons of an unlicensed social club in the Bronx early Sunday. Police charge he was angry with his ex-girlfriend, who worked there. Prosecutors say he has admitted setting the fire in revenge. While details are lacking, accounts portray Gonzalez as a quiet man who lived lawfully but in poverty since his arrival from Cuba a decade ago. Neighbors said nothing foretold the slaughter of which he is accused. But two blows recently shook his life: Six weeks ago he was dismissed from the Queens lamp factory where he worked, and at about the same time he broke up with Lydia Feliciano, with whom he had lived for seven or eight years. Gonzalez allegedly argued with Ms. Feliciano early Sunday at the Happy Land Social Club, where she was a coat checker. A bouncer ejected him and, prosecutors said, he left threatening to shut the place down. Police say he bought $1 worth of gasoline, splashed it into the club's doorway and ignited it. Authorities said his shoes reeked of gasoline when police arrested him 12 hours later, sleeping in his 10-by-10 foot, $80-a-week furnished room. While Barracato could not comment directly about the case, he said arson for revenge _ which accounts for about half of all arson cases _ commonly is started with an accelerant such as gasoline and is intended as revenge against a perceived offense. ``When someone gets locked into an anger stage of emotion he wants total destruction,'' said Barracato, a former deputy chief city fire marshal and now director of the fire and fraud section of Aetna Life & Casualty Co. While emotion incites the crime, ``There's no loss of control,'' said Barracato, who conducted a six-year study of arsonists. ``It's calculated and it's planned. ... They want to assert themselves. They want power, and what can be more powerful than intentionally setting a fire.'' The greatest question about Gonzalez's past is his life in Cuba, which he left in the Mariel boatlift that brought 125,000 people to the United States in 1980. He told authorities he was born in Holguin, in Oriente province, and worked as a mechanic and construction assistant. He said his nickname was ``Pochocho,'' a diminutive with no meaning. Gonzalez told U.S. immigration officials he had been jailed for three years in Cuba for an unapproved absence from the Army, and that he had falsely confessed to drug trafficking so Cuban authorities would let him join the boatlift. After his arrival, he was detained in U.S. camps for nine months, then released. U.S. officials have complained that Cuba used the boatlift to cast off criminals and people with mental problems. Cuban officials in Washington did not return telephone calls Tuesday seeking information on Gonzalez. Barracato said many arsonists have no criminal history, but they often share other attributes: Poverty, low education, broken homes, a lack of idols, personal isolation, extreme introversion, low self-esteem. The underclass status faced by many poor immigrants can contribute to the alienation arsonists seem to share, Barracato said. The result: Resentment, and, if pushed to the brink, an urge for revenge. ``They don't think that by that act they'll kill people,'' he said. ``It's, `I'll get even with them.''' Typically when it comes to revenge, said Barracato, ``he could care less'' about victims.

DOC.HEAD: Writers to Read Poems About Their Time on the Streets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Punctuation in 10th graf, `Her poem ...,' is cq.
DOC.TEXT: She has a steady job and a place to live, but Shelley Woods says she'll feel at ease when she stands up with homeless writers and poets at the Chicago Public Library to read her verse about her life on the streets. ``A lot of people don't like to tell about the dark side of their lives, but I hope this will help people who are down and out,'' the 37-year-old poet, who is also office manager for the Chicago Coalition for the Homeless, said Tuesday. In 1972, Ms. Woods lived out of a car for a year with her two yonother apartment. Ms. Woods said she lost her subsidized apartment in January 1980 after the rent increased and her welfare benefits declined because of her job. ``It was so cold outside with two small children,'' Ms. Woods said. ``It was hard, but I didn't give up.'' A friend helped her out, and Ms. Woods learned secretarial skills. She was hired by the coalition, where she's worked for the past five years. The poet said she wants to send a message to those who've been more fortunate. ``People have this stereotype of the homeless as bums who drink, but that's not true,'' she said. ``People really need to know it can happen to anybody.''

DOC.HEAD: Regulator Asks Congress to Withhold Changes in S&L Bailout Program
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS pvs 10th graf to UPDATE with new numbers on capital plans and deadline extension; ADDS 6 grafs after pvs 14th graf bgng ``The Senate ...'' to UPDATE with FDIC approval of open assistance plan; DELETES last 2 grafs pvs for length
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top savings and loan official pleaded with Congress on Tuesday to give President Bush's thrift bailout program a chance to work before changing or scrapping it. ``What we need now is stability. Constant tinkering, even with the best of intentions, imposes tremendous costs on the industry, the regulatory system and the American public,'' said Salvatore Martoche, acting director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., and his House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions, are reviewing suggestions for changing the S&L law enacted nearly eight months ago. Tuesday's session was the third of five scheduled. Proposals range from abolishing the thrift office and dividing its duties among commercial bank regulators to providing temporary relief from lending rules that some home builders say are crimping their credit. Martoche conceded that some changes might improve the law, but said the benefits were outweighed by the potential harm of disruptive changes. ``I've been around legislative bodies long enough to know that when you do a reopener, everything but the kitchen sink gets taken up,'' he said. The S&L law sharply reduced the maximum amount an institution can loan to one borrower. The intent was to prevent the bankruptcy of a single customer from severely hurting a thrift. However, builders complain that they can't get the loans they need and say the limit should be phased in gradually. Martoche said the thrift office is leaning toward phasing in the restrictions over two years, but is uncertain whether the law will permit that. The agency has given industry lawyers 60 days to suggest a ``creative solution'' to the dilemma, he said. On another matter, Martoche said he was not concerned about the agency's slow pace in reviewing financial plans submitted by ailing thrifts by Jan. 7. The S&L law required weak institutions to get goverment approval for their plans to raise capital. So far, 577 S&Ls have submitted plans. The thrift office has rejected 127, approved 64, and told many institutions to ``go back to the drawing board,'' Martoche said. Later Tuesday, the agency announced it was extending its deadline for approving the plans from the end of March to the end of April. ``I can't help but feel that some institutions were testing us'' to see if lax plans would be approved, he said. ``I want them (agency employees) to do the right thing and however long it takes, it takes.'' Martoche, who is an assistant Treasury secretary, began the thrift job on an acting basis only three weeks ago, after M. Danny Wall left the position under fire. He is already a lame duck. In response to lawsuits from weak S&Ls challenging the constitutional authority of both Wall and Martoche, President Bush last week nominated T. Timothy Ryan Jr. to a five-year term as the permanent director of the thrift office. The Senate Banking Committee has scheduled a confirmation hearing on Wednesday for Ryan, formerly the top lawyer at the Labor Department from 1981 to 1983. In another development, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. approved a controversial plan to pump money into ailing S&Ls before they fail. To qualify, institutions must be in one of eight economically troubled states, managers must be subject to firing, shareholders must be treated ``approximately'' as if the S&L had failed and new private investment must be injected into the S&L along with the government funds. However, it remains unclear if the policy will ever be used. Another agency, the Treasury Department-led Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board has expressed reservations. The board would have to approve any spending for thrift assistance. ``I hate the notion of giving shareholders, who were responsible for running an institution down the tubes, any benefit of a bailout,'' Martoche said. ``I personally find that abhorrent.'' Several members of the House banking panel also opposed the policy, including Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., chairman of a task force overseeing the bailout. FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman, however, says open thrift assistance can be cheaper for taxpayers in some cases. Institutions in eight states will be eligible: Alaska, Arizona, Arkansas, Colorado, Louisiana, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Six Hungarian Parties Qualify for Runoffs
With AM-Hungary-Future, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Six center-right and liberal parties advanced to the second round of campaigning Tuesday to try to win enough support in runoff elections to form Hungary's first post-war, non-Communist government. Janos Nemeth, chairman of the National Electoral Committee, said the final tally in Sunday's parliamentary elections was delayed because the Interior Ministry's electoral office had given the committee incomplete information. Nemeth did not specify whether he thought the Interior Ministry, which many Hungarians still associate with communist repression because of its control of internal security, was purposely delaying results showing a poor performance by Old Guard Communists. They refused to join Communist reformers in founding the Socialist Party in October and failed to win 4 percent of the national vote, necessary to gain representation in parliament. A ministry official, who declined to give his name on the telephone, said the delay in reporting results was due to slow transmission of votes from outlying polling stations. The Electoral Committee announced unofficial, final results, but said the elections would have to be repeated in five districts where fewer than half the eligible voters turned out, the state news agency MTI reported. The conservative Hungarian Democratic Forum received 24.7 percent of the vote to maintain its edge over the center-left League of Free Democrats, who won 21.4 percent. The rural-based Independent Smallholders finished third with 11.7 percent, followed by the Socialists _ the successors to Hungary's Communist Party _ with 10.9 percent. The League of Young Democrats won 8.9 percent and the Christian Democratic People's Party 6.4 percent. The rest of the 29 parties that ran did not clear the 4 percent hurdle. More than 70 percent of Hungary's 7.8 million eligible voters cast ballots, election officials said. Only five of the parliament's 394 seats were decided. Since neither of the two leading parties garnered anything close to the absolute majority needed for decisive victory, a coalition government is likely after runoff elections are held next month, possibly April 8. The biggest issue is Hungary's economy, which is beset by double-digit inflation and a $20 billion foreign debt after four decades of Communist rule. The Democratic Forum and the Free Democrats both want to move toward market-oriented reforms, but the Forum wants to move more slowly. Both parties have said they do not want to join with the other in building a coalition government, and the Independent Smallholders are expected to play a key role in such a government.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Defend Seizing Army Deserters
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 1 graf after pvs 16th graf bgng ``The vice...'' for more Beckwith comment
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lithuania Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union defended on Tuesday its seizure of army deserters from two hospitals in Lithuania and appealed for understanding in the United States of its attempt to maintain order in the secessionist-minded Baltic republic. ``Deserters are dealt with harshly in other countries as well,'' Sergei Chetverikov, minister-counselor at the Soviet Embassy, said at a news conference. He cited a statement by Vice President Dan Quayle as supporting action against deserters. And yet, the Soviet official emphasized that Moscow, while defending its authority in Vilnius, was trying not to use force against Lithuanians. ``The basic premise which is behind the action of the Soviet government is not to use force, not to use intimidation or anything of that sort, to find peaceful ways, peaceful solutions,'' he said. ``But the situation is difficult, as well all know, so we hope we will be understood in other countries and in this country as well,'' Chetverikov said. He spoke to reporters in a chandeliered reception room overlooking Washington's 16th Street, where some 100 demonstrators, many of them waving Lithuanian flags in a soft breeze, shouted their protests of the Soviet moves in a republic they contend is an independent nation. ``No more tanks, no more tanks,'' they chanted. Their protests could be heard over the Soviet official's statement and his replies to reporters' questions. In Vilnius, the capital of the republic, the deserters were forcibly seized by Soviet troops, leaving a trail of blood behind. ``I don't know how they will be dealt with in this particular case,'' Chetverikov said. ``But they have been given appropriate time to get back to their units, and I think this is very understandable from the point of view of any commander who is dealing with deserters in his own unit.'' The Soviet diplomat, an authority on constitutional law, added: ``So I don't see this as any indication of the use of force or anything of that sort.'' In defense of the action, Chetverikov said ``even Vice President Quayle admitted the other day there should be some discipline in the army.'' Quayle told reporters in Phoenix on Saturday that the Soviets should not threaten Lithuania, But, he said, ``if the Soviet Union is applying disciplinary measures to people in their own military, that's a different situation.'' The vice president added: ``I do not know what kind of contractual agreement a member of the Soviet army has when he or she signs up,'' But, Quayle said, there is a ``certain element of discipline that is absolutely imperative in any armed force.'' The vice president was on vacation Tuesday in Hawaii with his wife and three children. His press secretary, David Beckwith, said Quayle's comment ``was in the context of urging the Soviet Union and Lithuania to resolve the situation through negotiation and without any use of force. He did state that the desertion question was somewhat complicated. But he in no way countenanced the violent rounding up of deserters.'' Separately, Beckwith said in a written statement that Soviet authorities ``appear to be broadcasting false reports'' suggesting that Quayle endorsed the violent capture of deserters. In particular, he said the Tass news agency had published a report quoting Quayle as saying, ``The Soviet Union, as an annexing power, has the right to hunt down Lithuanian deserters.'' Chetverikov said he hoped other deserters would return to their units. ``I don't mean to say other deserters will be hunted down,'' he said. ``But the army has the full right to maintain discipline in its ranks.'' On the secession itself, the Soviet official said Moscow recognizes the need for political change in Lithuania. ``Nobody denies the right of self-determination,'' he said. But, Chetverikov said, ``what the Soviet government is opposed to is the intention of Lithuanian authorities to take over federal property that doesn't being to them.'' He also questioned that a majority of Lithuanians support secession from the union.

DOC.HEAD: Capitalist Programs Invade Cuba But Signal Blocked
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs reaction after 5th graf pvs, After that,
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration began beaming American television to Cuba on Tuesday _ MTV videos, a 1971 World Series tape and an old ``Kate and Allie'' _ but the communist government jammed the transmissions and accused the United States of aggression. ``We regret that Cuba has refused to permit the free flow of information and ideas,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. Testing of the long-planned TV Marti began on Channel 13 at 1:45 a.m. EST. In Havana, viewers saw a test pattern ``strong and clear.'' Two hours later came videos from MTV dubbed in Spanish, the World Series tape _ the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Baltimore Orioles in seven games _ and an episode of ``Kate and Allie,'' the long-running sitcom about two divorced women who share a Manhattan apartment with their children. After that, viewers saw ``a report on the success of Hispanics in this country,'' said Jorge Mas Canosa, the chairman of the Miami-based organization that oversees TV Marti. Frank Calzon, who heads the Washington office of Freedom House, a pro-democracy group, blasted TV Marti's show selection. ``The programs stink,'' said Calzon, a Cuban exile who is a long-time TV Marti supporter. He said the debut should have featured the opening of the Berlin Wall and the Chilean and Nicaraguan elections. Officials of the Voice of America responded that the programming was aimed at determining the technical feasibility of the transmissions more than influencing Cuban public opinion. While viewers in outlying areas of Havana had few problems during the five-hour test, residents of downtown Havana encountered the signal of a Cuban jamming transmitter after the first 23 minutes of the test pattern. Mas Canosa said Castro jammed not just Channel 13, but three domestic stations as well, in case TV Marti changed channels. Cuban spokesmen have said they would retaliate beyond the jamming, but there was no immediate announcement of additional measures. Last Friday, however, Cuba broadcast a radio speech by President Fidel Castro to the United States. AM stations along the Florida coast and as far away as Nashville were disrupted. Of TV Marti's premiere, the official Cuban news agency Prensa Latina said: ``The debut was nothing impressive since in a 10-minute interval the principal technological power on the planet could not keep the invading signal from being rejected over the coverage area. ``Cuban authorities have warned that the beginning of these transmissions may form part of a larger maneuver and Washington may be looking for a pretext to unleash military aggression.'' The Cuban government, the agency said, ``has placed responsibility on the government of that country for all the consequences of this action, which is aggressive and violates its sovereignty.'' Mas Canosa reviewed the first broadcast differently, saying that several viewers in Cuba had phoned relatives in Miami to say they were ``very, very enthused, extremely satisfied and really excited.'' The station is a TV version of Radio Marti, which has provided news and entertainment to Cuban listeners since 1985. Radio Marti was not jammed Tuesday morning nor did Cuba interfere with radio or television stations in the United States. The TV Marti signal was sent from an antenna aboard a balloon dangling 10,000 feet above Cudjoe Key off the South Florida coast. Technical problems have delayed testing for months. The project has had strong support from conservative elements of the Cuban exile community who believe that televised exposes about the demise of communism around the world will weaken Castro's rule. Once the testing ends, the Bush administration has three months to make a legal and technical evaluation of the operation, according to the legislation that authorized the station. Ms. Tutwiler said international agreements do not prevent a country from engaging in television broadcasting to another country. She also noted that the U.N. Universal Declaration of Human Rights entitles all people to the freedom to ``seek, receive and impart information and ideas through the media.'' Ariel Ricardo, a spokesman at the Cuban diplomatic mission here, disagreed with the U.S. position, asserting that an international agreement reached in 1982 gives each country exclusive control over its own television programming. Ricardo said ``there is no precedent'' for one country taking over a domestic channel of another country. He added that in parts of the Havana area, Channel 13 is reserved for domestic programming. According to Cuban officials, more than 90 percent of Cuban homes have television. The TV Marti project is designed mostly for the Havana area. In a recent interview with the Associated Press, Gary Gonzalez, a vice president of the Cuban Institute of Radio and Television, said U.S. descriptions of Cuba as a closed society are misleading. He said 42 percent of all movies shown on Cuban television are American-made. There are also a number of U.S.-made programs for children shown in Cuba.

DOC.HEAD: Suriname Frees Guerrilla Leader, 10 Rebels Arrested After Shootout
DOC.TEXT: The government on Tuesday freed a guerrilla leader and 10 of his men arrested by the army after a shootout in which two rebels died. The rebel chief had come to the capital for peace talks. Presidential spokeswoman Claudine Vermunt said the government decided to release former army Sgt. Ronny Brunswijk, chief of the Jungle Commando rebels, and his comrades after discussions with the attorney general's office. Earlier Tuesday, gunmen seized the Afobaka hydroelectric dam 125 miles south of Paramaribo in apparent retaliation for the arrests. Power was knocked out briefly to this capital city of 200,000 and work was disrupted at a nearby aluminum smelter. Although his guerrilla movement denied involvement, Brunswijk issued a message from prison telling the Jungle Commando such action was unnecessary. The military leveled unspecified drug charges against Brunswijk relating to Jungle Commando seizure of 2,200 pounds of unrefined cocaine from Colombia. Brunswijk had said his men confiscated the cocaine Sunday from a plane flying out of Cali, Colombia, that landed because of bad weather near a rebel base in the western village of Moenjo. He and his aides were held overnight at Fort Zeelandia, an army post in the capital. The army had said Brunswijk and three aides were taken into custody, but officials said 11 in all were seized. Two Brunswijk bodyguards were killed in a gun battle with soldiers during the arrest in the capital. No details were available. The rebels, who say they represent the Bush Negro minority, had been in Paramaribo since Friday for new talks with government officials on ending their 3{-year-old insurgency. Bush Negroes, who make up about 10 percent of Suriname's 400,000 residents, want greater economic development for their region. A government source, speaking on condition of anonomity, said the military made the arrests without consulting with the government. The army has shown a growing tendency this year to exercise power independent of the government. Lt. Col. Desi Bouterse, the army chief who was the military ruler of Suriname from, 1980 to 1988, opposes a tentative peace agreement release last June. He complains that it fails to disarm the Jungle Commando, which numbers from 200 to 400 members. Bouterse has continued to wield power behind the scenes even though the country is under nominal civilian rule. Before the rebels' release, the Jungle Commando said in a statement that the arrests ``disrupted the peace process,'' but that it would continue to abide by a cease-fire agreement reached with the army weeks ago. President Ramsewak Shankar's office said the army's action would ``doubtless demand a reorientation with regard to the peace process'' but that the government would continue the effort. Shankar replaced Bouterse in a 1988 election. In the Netherlands, the Dutch government earlier Tuesday said it was ``seriously concerned'' about the arrest by the military ``without prior knowledge of the civilian authorities.'' Suriname, which lies on the northern shoulder of South America, gained independence from the Netherlands in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Tells Council to Work toward Radical Economic Reform
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told the first meeting of the new Presidential Council on Tuesday it must start figuring out at once how to introduce substantive reforms to resurrect the economy. The council advises Gorbachev in the much more powerful presidency that he pushed through Parliament this month. Almost all 16 council members are newly appointed. Among those who attended Tuesday were Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, writer Chingiz Aitmatov and KGB chief Vladimir Kryuchkov, the official news agency Tass said. Gorbachev told the council its immediate task was to formulate ``specific measures to radicalize the economic reform,'' Soviet TV reported. He said later in a television interview that the council's next meeting will focus specifically on economic reform. The economy is foundering as drastic shortages of basic items continue, ranging from soap to sausage, and there continues too to be an overabundant money supply and a slump in production in this nation of 265 million residents. An anchorman read Gorbachev's lengthy speech instead of its being broadcast as it was delivered. Soviet TV offered no explanation. Gorbachev has promised to use his enhanced presidency to accelerate the Soviet economy's transition to a more market-oriented set-up. He called for a ``normal, full-fledged market'' on Tuesday, for eliminating the state budget deficit and for introducing price reforms. He emphasized the importance of a new law on land meant to increase food production by allowing farmers to virtually own their plots. Gorbachev made almost no mention of the turmoil in Lithuania, according to the official report of his speech. He said only that he planned to hold a meeting Friday of his other new advisory body, the Federation Council, which is expected to focus on the relationship between Moscow and the 15 Soviet republics. ``Life and processes we are encountering in Transcaucasia, the Baltic republics, especially in Lithuania, and other regions necessitate the urgent examination and settlement of appropriate issues,'' he said. The Presidential Council is seen as a mechanism to help Gorbachev transfer political power from the Communist Party to the government.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Offered to Help Free Hostages, According to Hearst Report
DOC.TEXT: Japan once volunteered to give Iran and Syria $60 million in economic aid if those countries would use their influence to help release American hostages in Lebanon, a former White House official told Hearst News Service. The deal, to which President Reagan reportedly agreed with enthusiasm in June 1985, fell through because Iran and Syria rejected the Japanese offer on the grounds they had no influence over the captors, said the former official. The Hearst article, appearing at various times in Hearst newspapers and made available by the service on Tuesday, did not identify the former official. Former Japanese Ambassador Nobuo Matsunaga came to the White House on several occasions to discuss the deal, Hearst said. Reagan's knowledge of Japan's offer came three months before the United States first shipped weapons to Iran in what grew into the Iran-Contra scandal, Hearst said. Eight Americans are currently held hostage in Lebanon, but in June 1985 there were only six. The hostages are thought to be held by radical Moslem Shiites in Beirut under the influence of Iran. Terry Anderson, the longest-held American hostage, was captured on March 16, 1985. He was chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. One of the Americans, William Buckley, the former CIA station chief in Beirut, died in captivity, apparently in 1985. In Tokyo, an official at the ministry of foreign affairs said it would be ``just impossible'' for the Japanese to have made such an offer. Reagan could not be reached for comment, Hearst said. Robert McFarlane, the former national security advisor who Hearst said knew about the offer, did not return a telephone call. His attorney, Leonard Garment, was out of the country. According to the Hearst account, the Japanese offer came about in the following fashion: Matsunaga brought the offer to McFarlane, according to the former White House official who was present at the meeting. ``I am instructed to say that my government would like to be helpful and that we are willing to go to both capitals'' _ Tehran and Damascus _ ``to urge their efforts to release the hostages,'' the former official quoted Matsunaga as telling McFarlane. The ambassador, who left Washington last year, mentioned the $60 million aid program his government was willing to offer. Matsunaga ``really wanted to be sure they were going to get credit with the president for anything they did,'' the official said. The next day, McFarlane presented the Japanese offer to Reagan. The president responded, ``Gosh! Terrific! Please!,'' the former U.S. official said. But the deal was never reached because the Japanese were unable to persuade the Iranians and the Syrians to agree to it, the official said. It was not clear what Japan hoped to get in exchange for tying its aid package to the hostages' release. Arthur Liman, the former chief counsel of the JOint House-Senate Iran-Contra Committee that investigated the arms-for-hostages scandal, said he could not comment because ``whatever I know on this is classified.''

DOC.HEAD: House OKs Bill Banning Food Trucks from Hauling Garbage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 2 grafs with `no' votes, those not voting.
DOC.TEXT: The House overwhelmingly passed legislation Tuesday to prevent trucks used to ship food from hauling garbage on the return trip. The legislation, which is opposed by the Bush administration, would also require that asbestos, infectious waste and other health-threatening items be shipped only in vehicles designated for that purpose. The vote was 410-15 to send the proposal to the Senate, where similar bills are pending. The bill's prime target is ``backhauling,'' the practice of using trucks that carry food cross-country to carry municipal garbage on the trip home. ``Backhauling is dangerous, disgusting and legal,'' Rep. William Clinger, R-Pa., one of the measure's prime sponsors, said during the brief floor debate on the legislation. Concern about food-garbage hauls arose after the Centre Daily Times of State College, Pa., reported a year ago that refrigerated food-hauling trucks, known as ``reefers,'' were being loaded with municipal solid waste. The report led Congress to investigate a related practice _ alternating loads of chemicals with shipments of juice or edible oils. An Oregon trucker's shipment log released by a House panel at an October hearing included loads of cooking oil, wine, apple juice, fire retardant, marine lubricant and lime sulphur. Several trucking groups have said that concern by food companies has led many truckers to avoid the practice. But Clinger and Rep. Chris Smith, R-N.J., said checks by their staffs have confirmed that backhauling is continuing. The government says it has not uncovered any instances of contamination due to backhauling. The Bush administration has opposed the backhauling ban largely because of a provision that the Department of Transportation would assume enforcement responsibility. Alan I. Roberts, a hazardous materials specialist with the department, told a Senate panel three weeks ago that existing law ``is adequate to regulate the handling and transportation of food.'' If a bill were approved, he said lead responsibility should more properly rest with the agencies that have food-safety expertise _ the Agriculture Department and the Food and Drug Administration. ``The administration has yet to see fit to correct these practices,'' said Rep. Tom Luken, D-Ohio. ``Evidently the Department of Transportation thinks it is the problem of the Food and Drug Administration; the FDA thinks it's a transportation problem, and the EPA, which has jurisdiction over solid waste, doesn't know what to think.'' Voting against the bill were Reps. Bill Archer, R-Texas; Dick Armey, R-Texas; Dan Burton, R-Ind.; Larry Combest, R-Texas; Philip Crane, R-Ill.; William E. Dannemeyer, R-Calif.; Tom DeLay, R-Texas; Robert Dornan, R-Calif.; Jack Fields, R-Texas; Bill Frenzel, R-Minn.; James Hansen, R-Utah; Edward Madigan, R-Ill.; Ron Marlenee, R-Mont.; Howard Nielson, R-Utah, and Norman Shumway, R-Calif. Not voting were Reps. Doug Barnard, D-Ga.; Jim Bates, D-Calif.; Michael Bilirakis, R-Fla.; Harold E. Ford, D-Tenn.; Jim Leach, R-Iowa; Denny Smith, R-Ore., and Bob Stump, R-Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Flurries Along Lake Ontario, Rain in South
DOC.TEXT: Snow flurries fell along the shores of Lake Ontario on Monday and showers persisted across parts of Texas and Oklahoma, but skies were clear across much of the country. Scattered snow was reported in northwest New York state and along Lake Ontario, and rain fell in scattered bursts over central and western Texas and southwest Oklahoma. But across much of the rest of the nation, afternoon skies were sunny. The temperature dropped to 18 degrees in Wilkes-Barre and Scranton, Pa., tying a record low for the date set in 1971. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states was minus 2 degrees in Caribou, Maine. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 15 degrees in Limestone, Maine, to 86 in Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Sen. Wirth Denies Plane Ride
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., on Tuesday denied an allegation that he accepted a ride on the corporate jet of CenTrust Savings Bank, a failed thrift institution in Miami. Rep. Chalmers Wylie, R-Ohio, the ranking GOP member of the House Banking Committee, on Monday released a list of political contacts of CenTrust Chairman David Paul. The list said Paul's desk calendar indicated Wirth ``used Paul plane'' to attend a political dinner on Dec. 28, 1988. Wirth, however, said, ``I have never been a passenger on any plane owned by either David Paul or his S&L, CenTrust.'' Tony Cole, an aide to Wylie, said the date of the plane trip should have been listed as Sept. 28, 1988, rather than Dec. 28. However, he said Wylie's list accurately reflected the desk calendar. Wirth's denial ``could very well be true,'' Cole said. ``Who knows? David Paul could have put anything on his desk calendar.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Probe Ownership of Club Where 87 Died
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead; SUBS 4th graf, `Gonzalez allegedly ...,' to DELETE incorrect reference to `no fire sprinklers.' SUBS last graf to CORRECT number of other survivors to four, sted three.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY20,21
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors on Tuesday investigated the tangled ownership of the Happy Land Social Club to determine whether the landlords, including actress Kathleen Turner's husband, share responsibility in the fiery deaths of 87 people. The district attorney's office also said a grand jury had begun hearing evidence against Julio Gonzalez, a 36-year-old Cuban emigre who reportedly confessed to setting the fire at the illegal discotheque early Sunday. ``We'll have a made case even if he backs out of the confession,'' said Edward McCarthy, spokesman for the Bronx prosecutor's office. Gonzalez allegedly bought $1 worth of gasoline and ignited it in the doorway to the two-story unlicensed club after a fight with his ex-girlfriend, who worked there. The club had no emergency exits and no second-story windows; the victims had neither the time nor the means to escape. The building that housed the club was leased to Happy Land's operator by Miss Turner's husband, Jay Weiss, who in turn had leased it from one of New York's major real estate operators, Alex DiLorenzo III. McCarthy said the issue of landlord responsibility wasn't clear. Prosecutors still had to determine whether anyone beyond the club operator, Elias Colon, who died in the fire, knew the building had been served with notices of building code violations. Weiss, through a statement by his lawyer, Roger Boyle, acknowledged that Little Peach Realty, a company he owns with Morris Jaffe, leased the building in 1985 from a DiLorenzo company, Clarendon Place Corp. Two years later, Little Peach leased the club to Colon, but Boyle said that since last spring the company had been trying to evict Colon for not paying rent. The case was to have been heard in court Wednesday. Boyle said Weiss would have no further statement. Miss Turner said through her publicist, Susan Geller in Los Angeles: ``This is an act of a violent madman. It's a tragedy. It doesn't reflect on me or my husband.'' Miss Turner is in New York starring in a Broadway revival of ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.'' According to Assistant Fire Chief William Feehan, inspectors are supposed to serve notices of code violations on the responsible person at the scene and not necessarily to building owners. The Happy Land tragedy spurred Mayor David Dinkins to reactivate a police, fire and buildings department task force formed in the wake of another fatal club fire. Fire Department spokesman John Mulligan said the agency received nearly 1,000 calls Monday, the first day of operating a special number for reports of illegal social clubs. Mulligan said the names and addresses of some 500 clubs were divulged. ``The department is elated,'' Mulligan said. ``It shows the public is aware of the problem now and there's not much you can do about it unless the public gets involved.'' The man charged with 87 counts of murder, Gonzalez, remained in the prison ward of Kings County Hospital, awaiting his next court appearance. According to District Attorney Robert Johnson, Gonzalez made admissions to people he had spoken to after early Sunday's fire. The district attorney said Gonzalez gave police a videotaped confession later in the day in which he admitted he torched the Happy Land with gasoline in a fit of pique against his former girlfriend, Lydia Feliciano, who worked at the club. ``We're going to put on (the witness stand) the girlfriend, the guy that sold him the gasoline, the two guys he talked to _ the neighbors _ at his house,'' McCarthy said. ``And then we have the container that held the gasoline, his sneakers, which were soaked with gasoline. We even cut up a hunk of the floor and brought it in to prove the burn pattern was caused by gasoline.'' Ms. Feliciano escaped the fire without serious injury. One of the four other survivors, club disc jockey Ruben Valladarez, was in critical but stable condition at Jacobi Hospital with burns over 30 percent of this body. Hospital spokeswoman Vicki Ciampa said he had about a 50-50 chance of survival.

DOC.HEAD: Church Leaders Seek International Probe Of Lawmakers' Secret Police Ties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to RECAST grafs 3 and 5 for CLARITY. Picks up 6th, `Rainer Eppelmann...'
DOC.TEXT: East German church leaders on Tuesday said an international commission should investigate charges that some newly elected lawmakers had links with the secret police of the ousted Communist regime. The chief administrator of East Berlin's Lutheran Church, Manfred Stolpe, was quoted in a Tuesday interview as recommending that an impartial international commission headed by a former Swiss president and justice minister, Kurt Furgler, investigate the allegations. The charges involve some leaders of non-Communist political parties, including the top candidate for premier. The accusations have slowed efforts to form East Germany's first freely elected government. In the interview with the Bonn-based Die Welt newspaper, Stolpe said the commission should start its probe after East Germany's newly elected parliament has been ``officially constituted'' in its first sitting. An investigation after the parliament's first session would ``prevent any further delays in setting up the country's new government,'' Die Welt quoted Stolpe as saying. Rainer Eppelmann, chairman of one of the three parties in the alliance that won the country's first free elections March 18, said last week that as many as 40 of the 400 newly elected lawmakers might have been agents of the disbanded Stasi secret police. The Stasi once had 85,000 agents and 109,000 informers and controlled all walks of life on behalf of the Communist government. Outgoing Premier Hans Modrow, a reform-minded Communist, disbanded the secret police under pressure for change brought on by the peaceful revolution. Berlin's Roman Catholic bishop, Georg Sterzinsky, said he agreed with Stolpe's recommendation. He added that former Austrian President Rudolf Kirschschlaeger could be another candidate to head the commission. Since the disbanding of the secret police, officials have debated on how to integrate into society the large number of former secret police workers, who are finding it difficult to find new employment. West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble was quoted as saying in an interview with the Freiburg-based Badischer Zeitung newspaper that a ``generous amnesty'' for the former Stasi members could ``prevent further instability'' in East Germany. ``Not everyone who was forced to report to the Stasi was a criminal,'' Schaeuble was quoted as saying. However, ex-Stasi agents ``involved in capital crimes'' would have to be punished, the newspaper quoted Schaueble as saying. Lothar de Maiziere, the chairman of East Germany's Christian Democratic Union, which won the most votes March 18, said he hoped the new parliament could convene next Tuesday. De Maiziere has been accused of having worked for the secret police, allegations he denies. De Maiziere said he hoped to form a coalition government by mid-April following talks with other political parties. He is expected to become the premier.

DOC.HEAD: ``Cosby'' No. 1, New Shows Aimed at Young Viewers Stumble Out of the Gate
With AM-Nielsens-List
DOC.TEXT: A CBS pitch for younger viewers was, like, totally shredded, and ABC's teen-age doctor, ``Doogie Howser, M.D.'' failed to cure rating ills in a special episode after ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' according to Nielsen numbers released Tuesday. ``The Cosby Show,'' on NBC was first in the ratings for the week ended March 25, followed by a repeat of ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' and ``Roseanne,'' both on ABC, according to the figures from A.C. Nielsen Co. For the week, NBC was first in the ratings with a 14.2 average, followed by ABC with 12.2 and CBS with 8.9. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. The week included late-season new show premieres on CBS and NBC and a television movie on Fox to introduce a new series, ``The Outsiders.'' On CBS, Wednesday viewers got their first look at the new half-hour situation comedy ``Normal Life,'' starring Moon Unit and Dweezil Zappa, the daughter and son of musician Frank Zappa. The two play the son and daughter of a playwright. ``Normal Life'' was paired with the debut of ``Sydney,'' a 30-minute show starring Valerie Bertinelli as a feisty private detective in Los Angeles. The numbers for the youth-oriented shows are probably gagging the No. 3 network, with ``Normal Life'' tied for 68th place and ``Sydney'' tied for 60th. The best-rated premiere during the week was NBC's ``A Family For Joe,'' starring Robert Mitchum. The Saturday night show was No. 31. On Fox, ``The Outsiders'' about a tough gang of teen-age boys set in 1966 Tulsa, Okla., was No. 64, failing to hold a strong Sunday night lead-in from Fox's best-rated shows, ``The Simpsons'' and ``Married ... With Children,'' which finished 14th and 13th, respectively. Another show that failed to keep the flag Sunday night was the ``Doogie Howser, M.D.'' special, shown at 8:30 p.m. after ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' It was in the same slot as the mid-season show ``Elvis,'' which had slammed against ``The Simpsons.'' The ``Doogie Howser'' special failed to hang on to the strong 22.6 lead of ``America's Funniest,'' getting only 13.0 for a three-way tie for 36th place. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 23.2; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 22.6; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 22.4; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 21.1; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 20.8; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 20.5; ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC, 20.3; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 19.4; ``The Wonder Years,'' ABC, 19.3; ``L.A. Law,'' NBC, 18.7. ``The Old Man and the Sea,'' a made-for-television version of the Ernest Hemingway book starring Anthony Quinn as the fisherman, was the top-rated movie for the week at No. 22. An NBC News special looking at ``The New Hollywood'' was in 57th place. In the nightly news shows, ABC's ``World News Tonight'' was first in averages for the 11th week in a row with a 10.5 rating. ``NBC Nightly News'' was second with 9.4, followed by the ``CBS Evening News'' with 8.9. The highest-rated of CBS' prime time NCAA basketball semifinals was a 47th place tie for Friday games between Syracuse and Minnesota and Loyola Marymount vs. Alabama.

DOC.HEAD: First Heart, Liver and Kidney Transplant Recipient Dies
DOC.TEXT: The world's only recipient of a heart-liver-kidney transplant died of kidney failure brought on by an unusual form of hepatitis nearly four months after the operation, a hospital spokeswoman said Tuesday. Cindy Martin, 26, died Monday evening at Presbyterian-University Hospital, said spokeswoman Lisa Rossi. Mrs. Martin's family, including her husband, John, were with her when she died. The resident of the Scranton suburb of Archbald underwent a 21{-hour operation Dec. 2-3 in which the heart, the liver and the kidney were transplanted one after another. Mrs. Martin contracted recurrent non-A, non-B hepatitis, an unusual and non-contagious form of the liver disease which resulted in kidney failure, doctors said. Her condition was further complicated by an overwhelming infection called sepsis, a common post-transplant complication, Ms. Rossi said. Infection is a common problem with transplant patients because of the use of anti-rejection drugs, which suppress the immune system, Ms. Rossi said. Since the surgery, Mrs. Martin's condition never improved beyond serious and she often breathed with the aid of a respirator, Ms. Rossi said. Last weekend, Mrs. Martin's condition deteriorated to critical. Mrs. Martin had suffered from familial cardiomyopathy, an inherited heart disease. Her father died at age 31 and many relatives on his side of the family have died young, her husband said in December. On Oct. 20, 1985, one day after getting married, Mrs. Martin was admitted to Presbyterian-University to await her first heart transplant. She received it a month later. She subsequently developed hepatitis and kidney dysfunction and suffered from chronic rejection of the heart, which led to the multiple transplant, the hospital said. There had been no sign of rejection of the heart since December, Ms. Rossi said. Multi-organ transplants have been performed several times, but this was the first involving all three organs, said Dr. John Armitage, who performed Mrs. Martin's heart transplant. Doctors plan to perform similar operations should the need arise. ``We're not recruiting patients with heart, liver and kidney problems,'' Ms. Rossi said. ``But I would imagine if someone presented themselves again who was in critical need of this combination of organs we wouldn't hesitate to give them a second chance.''

DOC.HEAD: Peres Dealt Setback to Form Gov't, Schach Remarks Upset Parties
DOC.TEXT: Shimon Peres suffered an apparent setback to form a new coalition government on Tuesday when three left-wing parties suspended talks with the Labor Party leader, Israel radio reported. The Citizens Rights Movement, Mapam and Shinui parties, which hold 10 parliament seats, said they were postponing coalition talks until it becomes clear Peres still has a good chance to form a government, the report said. Peres said he will push for early elections for the 120-member parliament if he fails to form a new government rather than give the rival right-wing Likud bloc an opportunity to establish a coalition. Earlier in the day, politicians from both the left and right found themselves in rare agreement when they defended kibbutzim following an ultra-Orthodox rabbi's criticism of the secular lifestyle of Israel's communal agricultural settlements. Kibbutzim are held in high esteem in Israel for their history of settling and defending the country. But in a speech Monday night, Rabbi Eliezer Schach, the 93-year-old spiritual leader of two small ultra-Orthodox religious parties, accused the communal settlements of abandoning Judaism. ``There are kibbutzim that don't know what Yom Kippur is or the Sabbath ... and they raise (non-kosher) rabbits and pigs,'' Schach said. ``Do they have any links with their forefathers?'' Peres praised the kibbutzim, which constitute the core of Labor support, but refrained from criticizing Schach in an apparent effort not to alienate the rabbi. ``This is not the sum total of what the kibbutzim have done in this country,'' Peres said. ``They built the land, they settled it ... they spilled their blood for this country.''
