Yossi Sarid of the leftist Citizens Rights Movement argued that ultra-Orthodox Jews, most of whom are exempt from army service, have done little for Israel. ``We've already tried the security doctrine of the Rabbi Schach more than once, the last time in the Holocaust,'' he told Israel radio, alluding to criticism that Jews did not defend themselves against the World War II genocide in which 6 million Jews were killed by Nazi Germany. Also speaking on Israel radio, Likud hard-liner Ariel Sharon stressed that ways must be found ``for all streams of Judaism to live side by side in peace.'' Labor legislator Yossi Beilin said efforts to bridge the gap between religious and secular Israelis had been put ``a step backwards of decades'' by Shach's remarks. Schach, in his speech before 12,000 cheering followers in a Tel Aviv basketball arena, also sharply attacked the Labor Party, saying it had failed to keep Israel on the path of Judaism. ``Labor has severed the link, severed itself from the Torah, from the Sabbath and the past,'' the rabbi said. Political analysts said Schach's remarks made it unlikely that the ultra-Orthodox Degel Hatorah and Shas parties, which hold a combined eight seats in parliament and are loyal to Schach, would leave the Likud camp and join a Peres-led government. Both Labor and Likud claim the support of 60 members of Parliament. To break the tie, Peres needs the backing of one of the religious parties to rule. The Degel Torah party has two seats and the Shas party has six. ``If it is true what the commentators are saying, we basically have to hold new elections,'' Peres told Israel radio, adding he would continue his efforts to form a new government. But caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, head of Likud, told reporters Tuesday that he opposed early elections because, ```I don't think it's healthy for a country to hold elections in such short periods of time. ... The last elections were a year and a half ago.'' The coalition negotiations began after Shamir was toppled by a no-confidence motion in Parliament earlier this month over his refusal to accept U.S. Mideast peace proposals. Peres has five more weeks to try to put together a coalition. If he fails, President Chaim Herzog could then ask Shamir, an option Labor wants to prevent.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Stalls as Peanut Groups Negotiate New Price Support Program
DOC.TEXT: A House agriculture subcommittee postponed action on a new peanut price support program Tuesday after closed-door negotiations between peanut farmers and manufacturers failed to produce agreement. Rep. Charles Rose, D-N.C., chairman of the tobacco and peanuts subcommittee, said the panel will try ``one last time'' to win the support of the manufacturers for the peanut section of the 1990 farm bill before meeting again Wednesday or Thursday to write the subcommittee version. Rose said the manufacturers have dropped their demand for a freeze on the support price for domestic-use peanuts over the five-year life of the new peanut program, but the two sides have been unable to reach agreement on other, more technical issues. ``It seems the so-called concensus has blown up and they're trying to put it back together,'' said John Campbell, a deputy undersecretary of agriculture. The administration has proposed a 20 percent cut in the support price for domestic-use peanuts, from $631 a ton for this year's crop to $504 a ton. That proposal wasn't mentioned Tuesday as the subcommittee worked through a draft bill that would keep the $631 price support and permit it to increase up to 6 percent a year to reflect rising costs of production.

DOC.HEAD: Black Shot by Whites During School Argument
DOC.TEXT: A 14-year-old black student was shot and slightly wounded Tuesday at a public high school by three white teen-agers who taunted him with a racial slur, police said. The shooting took place in the Bensonhurst neighborhood, less than a mile from where another black youth, 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins, was fatally shot during a confrontation with a group of white teens last summer. Tuesday's victim was taken to Coney Island Hospital for treatment of a gunshot wound to the right wrist, according to Detective Joseph McConville. The shooting occurred at 8:42 a.m. inside New Utrecht High School, McConville said. The department's Bias Incident Investigation Unit was assigned to the case and arrests were expected, he added. The youths involved in the shooting had clashed with an older black teen-ager last month, McConville said. He said the 14-year-old who was shot had tried to act as a peacemaker in that dispute. Tuesday's confrontation occurred as the black teen passed the three white youths in a basement stairwell. One of the whites asked, ``What are you looking at?'' and called him by a racial epithet, McConville said. He said the black teen-ager told police he replied, ``If I were looking at you, I'd tell you.'' One of the white youths then pointed a gun at the 14-year-old and shot him. Police found a shell at the shooting scene, but did not say what kind of gun was used.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Couple Coming to Aid of Kentucky Family
DOC.TEXT: Hal and Carol Hill and some friends leave Thursday for Muddy Gut Hollow, Ky. It's a sort of working vacation: they plan to build a house for Willie and Sandra Johnson. The Hills don't know the Johnsons very well, but they know they need help. After seeing a television program about rural poverty in Appalachia, Hal Hill said, ``We decided to see if we could make a little difference and help somebody out.'' The CBS program was ``48 Hours: Another America,'' which focused on the poor living conditions of Floyd County, Ky., and the work of Christian Appalachian Project's building program. Hill, co-owner of Specialty Forest Products, a lumber and building products company, contacted the organization offering supplies and his talents. The agency put him in contact with the Johnsons, an unemployed couple with two infant children and no home of their own. The Hills, who live about 40 miles south of Atlanta in Griffin, will be taking about 10 volunteers to Muddy Gut Hollow, near Wheelwright, Ky. By the end of the weekend, they plan to turn a little hard work and about $3,000 in building supplies into at least a shell of a modest new home. ``It's not large or luxurious by any standard,'' Hill said Monday. The caravan also will carry furniture and clothing collected by Mrs. Hill for the family. Hill said he has traveled to the area to survey the site and meet the family. The Johnsons, he said, already are planting a garden near the site. ``They're already looking at it as a home. It's very pleasing to see the anticipation they have,'' he said. ``We're just glad we've got the opportunity to do this.''

DOC.HEAD: Oscar Show Lowest Rated in Three Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Lee said...' to fix spelling, `than' sted `then'; SUBS penultimate graf, `Television critics...' to add other satellite feeds.
DOC.TEXT: A barrage of on-screen Oscar flaps and overseas satellite feeds failed to rivet television viewers to the 62nd Academy Awards. The show drew its smallest audience in three years. According to preliminary ratings figures released Tuesday by ABC, the Monday night show had a rating of 27.9, or less than 26 million U.S. homes with televisions. Forty-eight percent of all television sets in use were tuned to the show, according the A.C. Nielsen Co. estimates. Last year's much-criticized Oscar show with Rob Lowe and Snow White was seen in nearly 27 million homes, and 1988's telecast was more popular than this year's edition, too. The broadcast in 1987, when ``Platoon'' took the best picture trophy, was rated lower than Monday's show. Highlighting this year's Oscar presentation were several comments critical of the Oscar nominating process. Bruce Beresford, the director of top Academy Award winner ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' spent Oscar night in Africa. It didn't matter, because the director wasn't in line for a trophy at the awards ceremony here. Not since 1932's ``Grand Hotel'' has the best picture winner failed to receive a best director nomination. The Beresford slight _ and the shutout of Spike Lee's ``Do the Right Thing'' _ sparked grumbling into the early morning hours Tuesday. Lee said ``Miss Daisy'' was chosen over his film because Academy voters were more comfortable with black chauffeurs than race riots. ``Miss Daisy'' supporters were at a loss to explain why its director was overlooked. ``I think it was a bewildering thing that will never be known,'' said ``Miss Daisy'' co-producer Richard Zanuck backstage after the film was selected best picture. ``He had his stamp on this film. Why he wasn't nominated, we'll never know.'' Some of those who worked on the Civil War epic ``Glory'' complained, too, that their film should have been nominated for best picture and best director. ``Glory'' won three trophies, including best supporting actor to Denzel Washington. Early in the show, presenter Kim Basinger introduced the first of the best picture nominees. ``We have five great films here,'' Miss Basinger said. ``And they are great for one reason: they tell the truth. ``But there is one film missing from this list that deserves to be honored because, ironically, it might tell the biggest truth of all. And that's `Do the Right Thing.''' Her remarks were met with sustained applause as she thrust clenched fists into the air, shouting ``Yes, Yes!'' Television critics were mostly kind in their reviews of the show. Some said it was too conventional. The broadcast ran 3 hours, 34 minutes and was marred by an echo-filled satellite feed from Moscow. Live segments also were shown from London, Tokyo, Australia and Buenos Aires, Argentina, designed to show that the film industry is international. It was the longest show since 1984's program, which ran 42 minutes over 3 hours.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Who Defied Terrorist Group Shot to Death
DOC.TEXT: A doctor who helped force-feed convicted terrorists on a hunger strike was gunned down Tuesday at his office by a woman who fled with an accomplice, police said. The doctor, Ramon Munoz y Fernandez, intravenously fed two convicted terrorists during a recent hunger strike by members of the ultra-leftist First of October Revolutionary Anti-Fascist Group, a government official in this northeastern city said. Interior Ministry officials in Madrid said witnesses identified the killer from wanted posters as Maria Jesus Romero Vega, a suspected leader of the group. Police said the woman went to Munoz's office, shot him in the head and chest and then fled. Police in Zaragoza set up roadblocks around the city. Munoz worked as an internal medicine specialist at Miguel Servet hospital, where two First of October convicts were treated and force-fed during the two-month hunger strike. The convicts were returned to prison a few days ago, the government official in Zaragoza said on condition of anonymity. Fifty-two convicts began the hunger strike Nov. 30, and several of them were near death before court rulings ordered doctors to intervene in January. The First of October group has claimed responsibility for more than 30 killings of police and army officers since the 1975 attack from which it took its name. A total of 81 group members are serving lengthy prison terms. Police believed they had dismantled the group several years ago, but it resurfaced in December and since has claimed responsibility for the shooting deaths of two police officers and a civil guard.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Will Limit Clean Air Debate
DOC.TEXT: Senate leaders won approval Tuesday night to limit debate on clean air legislation and scheduled a final vote on the complex and controversial bill within a week. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said a final vote on the bill would be held at 8 p.m. next Tuesday. The bill, the product of lenghty private negotiations with the White House, has been under debate for three weeks. The announcement by Mitchell came after the Senate grappled most of the day with a proposal that would ease air pollution permit requirements which industry had complained would create a ``bureaucratic nightmare.'' The issue has closely divided the senators who first voted 50-47 to refuse to set the weakening amendment aside and then rejected the proposal in a second vote, also 50-47. The clean air bill, the first tightening of federal air pollution laws in 13 years, calls for a wide range of new pollution controls on industry, automobiles and electric power plants in hopes of bringing air quality within federal standards in most urban areas by the turn of the century. Mitchell outlined his plans for the legislation after discussions with the minority leader, Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan.; with Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., whose proposal for financial assistance for coal miners at times has held up progress; and with the floor managers of the bill. The majority leader then requested and obtained unanimous consent from his colleagues to limit further debate on the measure and set the time for a final vote. Meanwhile, behind-the-scene discussions continued in an attempt to work out an agreement with Byrd over the coal miner assistance. The White House has opposed the measure vigorously as being too expensive and Senate leaders were attempting to persuade Byrd to agree to a less costly compromise. Mitchell said the Byrd proposal would be set aside until Thursday when it would be brought to a vote. The measure calls for $500 million in assistance over three years to miners who lose their jobs because of controls on emission of sulfur dioxide from coal-fired electric power plants. The permit requirements in the clean air bill occupied the Senate most of the day Tuesay. Sen. Don Nickels, R-Okla., had sought an amendment he said would streamline the permit process, arguing that the current legislation spells ``economic disasters for thousands of businesses'' and would create a ``bureaucratic nightmare'' for businessmen. But critics said the changes sought by Nickels would allow polluters in some cases to avoid some parts of the new law and hinder federal enforcement. It also would allow some polluters to tie cases up in lengthy litigation and inhibit citizen lawsuits seeking enforcement of pollution controls, the opponents maintained. About 35 states already have laws requiring such permits. Under the bill, the EPA would have broader authority to review state permits.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Deserters Rounded Up, Leaders Demand Their Return
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 5 grafs SUB for grafs 18-19, Several thousand ... UPDATING with Moscow crowd estimate, Soviet warning of Europe destabilization. Picks up 20th graf, There was ... DELETING final graf, Senior Soviet ... which superseded
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos VIL1,2,3
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's leaders on Tuesday angrily accused Moscow of ``inexcusable aggression'' and of kidnapping its citizens after Soviet troops stormed two hospitals in a harsh roundup of army deserters. Later, the Kremlin ordered all foreigners to leave the republic, which declared independence March 11. Soviet troops occupied a fifth Communist Party building in Vilnius, the capital. Washington and other foreign governments urged restraint but avoided attacking Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who faces growing independence movements in several republics as he tries to institute reform. The Bush administration, in declining to denounce Moscow, said it did not want to ``inflame the situation.'' Soviet officials defended their actions and condemned the Lithuanians' aspirations as dangerous. ``Even Vice President Quayle admitted the other day there should be some discipline in the army,'' Sergei Chetverikov, minister-counselor at the Soviet Embassy, said at a news conference in Washington. Quayle said Saturday the Soviets should not threaten Lithuania but added that ``if the Soviet Union is applying disciplinary measures to people in their own military, that's a different situation.'' In a furious letter to Gorbachev, Lithuania's president, Vytautas Landsbergis, and prime minister, Kazimera Prunskiene, said their government ``demands the return of its kidnapped citizens.'' They also urged negotiations with Moscow ``in neutral territory.'' Both Landsbergis and Prunskiene said Gorbachev had refused their calls. Soviet soldiers stormed two hospitals before dawn Tuesday and seized 23 Lithuanian deserters who had sought refuge, the official Tass news agency said. Lithuanian television said two genuine mental patients were accidentally seized but that the soldiers let them go later. Witnesses said some deserters were beaten as they were taken from a run-down psychiatric hospital in Vilnius. A trail of blood led down the steps and out the front door of the hospital. ``They beat them with their fists,'' said a duty nurse at the hospital, where windows and iron beds were broken. Gorbachev has called Lithuania's independence declaration invalid and last week ordered Lithuanians to turn in their weapons and stop signing up with a volunteer militia. He had promised not to use force unless lives were endangered in the Baltic republic, which the Soviet Union forcibly annexed along with Latvia and Estonia in 1940. But military authorities had warned Lithuania they would use force to capture deserters if the men had not returned voluntarily by last Saturday. In addition to storming the hospitals, Soviet troops Tuesday took over the Communist Party headquarters in the center of Vilnius. It was the fifth party building Soviet forces have seized in the republic since the weekend. Vladislav Shved, a leader of the Lithuanian Communist Party faction loyal to Moscow, indicated on the nightly news program ``Vremya'' that the troops were acting directly on the faction's request. When the government started to turn party offices over to other groups, ``we had to take measures to protect our property,'' he said. Thousands of opponents of independence _ Soviet television put the estimate at 20,000 _ attended a rally Tuesday outside the Parliament in Vilnius. The gathering lasted less than an hour and was peaceful _ protesters did not even trespass on the grass. Inside, Parliament officials, convinced the crowd might try to storm the building, rolled out fire hoses to repel attackers. At a news conference in Warsaw, Poland, senior Soviet diplomats said Lithuania's independence drive could lead to destabilization of Europe and the rest of the world, but did not elaborate. A declaration read at the briefing in the Soviet Embassy building Tuesday said ``the aspirations of the Lithuanian leadership to speedily separate from the other nations appear unjustified and let's say frankly dangerous.'' It said the situation had taken on a ``sharp'' character recently, and warned that the position of Lithuania's leaders could have a negative effect on the course of perestroika, the name Gorbachev gave his program of reform. There was little response in Moscow to the turmoil. Gorbachev spoke for several minutes on Soviet TV Tuesday evening about the first meeting of his new Presidential Council, an advisory body. He never mentioned Lithuania. The afternoon news carried nothing about the situation. The evening news had only a brief report focusing on the Communist Party members in Lithuania still loyal to their parent party in Moscow. The Soviet Embassy in Washington defended the seizure of army deserters and appealed for international understanding. ``Deserters are dealt with harshly in other countries as well,'' Chetverikov said. Outside, about 100 demonstrators, many of them waving Lithuanian flags, protested the Soviet actions. ``No more tanks! No more tanks!'' they chanted, loudly enough for Chetverikov to hear. The expulsion order announced Tuesday affected foreign journalists, businessmen and diplomats, said Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh. ``Foreigners have been asked to leave the borders of Lithuania and temporarily refrain from entering its territory,'' Gremitskikh told a Moscow briefing. He said foreign reporters currently in Lithuania would be allowed to stay until their previously announced departure dates. The Soviet defense minister, Dmitri T. Yazov, told reporters in Paris on Tuesday he expected the crisis to be defused ``in a peaceful way,'' but he said Lithuanian deserters had to be returned to their units. The Lithuanian government contends the soldiers were illegally drafted into an army of occupation, and deserters have said they were beaten before they left the army.

DOC.HEAD: Sweden Orders Soviet Official to Leave
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet trade official was ordered to leave Sweden for alleged espionage, the foreign ministry said Tuesday. In a statement, the ministry said ``the official has conducted activities not compatible with his official status in Sweden.'' According to the national news agency TT, the unnamed official tried to obtain information about Swedish and foreign technology and about Swedish industry. Foreign ministry spokesman Lars Olof Lundberg would not confirm the official had diplomatic status. The foreign ministry said the Soviet official had already left the country, and that no damage was caused. Last August a Soviet trade official at the consulate in Gothenburg was expelled on the same charges. In October 1988 a Soviet trade official in Stockholm also was expelled, accused of industrial espionage. In April 1988 a Soviet businessman residing in Gothenburg was ordered expelled for trying to obtain information about foreign and Swedish technology.

DOC.HEAD: University Criticizes Judge; Plans to Appeal Telescope Ban
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge temporarily banned construction of a major observatory atop an isolated mountain where 180 endangered squirrels live. An environmentalist praised the decision, but an astronomer called it ``a tragedy for U.S. astronomy.'' A University of Arizona official said Tuesday that the school would appeal the injunction granted by U.S. District Judge Alfredo C. Marquez. The order issued Monday imposes a four-month ban on construction of the planned $200 million Mount Graham International Observatory on a 10,700-foot-high peak of the mountain. The university was ready to begin building the first two of at least three telescopes in what could become the world's most powerful observatory. Congress had authorized the project on U.S. Forest Service land, but did not provide any money. The remote mountaintop is home to an estimated 180 endangered Mount Graham red squirrels. Construction opponents sought the building ban, fearing extinction of the half-pound rodents. Michael A. Cusanovich, the university's vice president for research, said Tuesday that construction would have no impact on the squirrel and that the school would appeal the injunction to the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. ``I don't know what he decided it on. I'm telling you I don't think it was decided on facts,'' said Cusanovich, who added that given the congressional approval, ``delaying tactics are inappropriate and are, in fact, damaging to society.'' The judge said serious questions had been raised over whether the construction would cause irreparable harm to the Mount Graham red squirrel. ``I'm surprised. I'm encouraged,'' Robin Silver, a spokesman for the Maricopa County Audubon Society in Phoenix, said Monday. ``This has been a tough process all along. I'm encouraged that the system can still work.'' ``I think it's a tragedy for U.S. astronomy,'' said Roger Roger Angel, head of the university's Steward Observatory mirror lab and developer of a revolutionary process for fabricating large telescope mirrors. ``In times of very poor funding, we're working like crazy to try to keep our heritage of good astronomy.'' While several European countries have financed development of new telescopes, Angel said there has been no such commitment from the federal government. Project plans call for the Columbus Project, construction of the world's most powerful single telescope, to get underway by the mid-1990s. The telescope would have two 8-meter mirrors, giving it a combined viewing field equal to an instrument with a mirror 37 feet in diameter. That would be five to six times the light-gathering power of the 5-meter Mount Palomar in California, considered the world's most powerful. ``With the Columbus Project as the biggest single telescope, we're right on the track of keeping that in the United States,'' Angel said. ``I don't know how long we can keep collaborators together without a site for the telescope.'' Mount Graham in the Pinaleno Mountains in southeastern Arizona is the only known habitat for the 180 remaining squirrels. In 1988, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service concluded in a biological report for the Forest Service that the telescopes could coexist with the squirrel. Arizona's congressional delegation then pushed through the legislation ordering the Forest Service to grant the university a construction permit. But environmental groups sued, contending that perching the telescopes on an 8.6-acre site on one of Mount Graham's three peaks would assure the extinction of the 8-ounce squirrels by taking away more of the forested land they need to survive. University officials contend poor pine cone crops in recent years have hurt the squirrel population. They said hunting, logging, use of off-road vehicles and Christmas tree-cutting have been stopped because of the planned observatory, and that 60 to 80 acres will be reforested.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Officials Dismiss Jesse Jackson D.C. Statehood Appeal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs to UPDATE with D.C. council voting to hold election for `shadow' representatives to Congress.
DOC.TEXT: U.N. officials shrugged off on Tuesday the Rev. Jesse Jackson's threat to take the case for District of Columbia statehood to the United Nations. ``The U.N. does not grant statehood to states which are members of federations, or independent states,'' Francois Giuliani, spokesman for the secretary-general, said Tuesday in answer to a question. He said it is not for the United Nations to confer statehood, but only to consider membership. He noted that U.N. membership is achieved through a process that includes recommendation by the 15-member Security Council, where the United States has veto power, and by a two-thirds vote of the 159-nation General Assembly. Jackson said Monday he may appeal to the United Nations as a last resort in his attempt to win statehood for the district. He complained that the region was denied basic human rights and political representation, and claimed the district was under political occupation. Lithuania, Tibet and other regions of U.N. member states all have failed so far to achieve U.N. recognition, or often even to win U.N. comment on their independence movements involving the Soviet Union, China and other countries. U.N. judicial experts considered the District of Columbia as one more such case, an internal issue for the United States to resolve. The United Nations frequently shuns touchy political issues, ranging from the use of poison gas to repression of political dissidents. In Washington, meanwhile, the city council voted 12-1 Tuesday to hold elections for a ``shadow'' congressional delegation that would press the city's quest for statehood on Capitol Hill. The council's vote to hold a September primary and a November general election balloting for the posts comes after three separate votes in recent years to postpone the elections.

DOC.HEAD: NTSB Calls For More Natural Gas Explosion Protections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 14th graf bgng: Board members xxx to include DOT comment.
DOC.TEXT: The National Transportation Safety Board on Tuesday called for utilities to install new equipment to help prevent explosions and fires from leaking pipes that supply natural gas to homes. The board recommended ``urgent action'' by the Department of Transportation to require the devices, called excess flow valves, on some residential gas lines. In addition, the board encouraged the utility industry to voluntarily provide customers with the opportunity to buy the equipment and have it installed. The recommendations were issued as part of a report that concluded that the devices could have helped prevent fatal natural gas accidents in Kansas and Missouri. The valves automatically restrict the flow of gas when certain increases occur, possibly from a leak or rupture in the line. Four people were killed and a dozen injured in a series of five explosions between September 1988 and March 1989 on KPL Gas Service lines in the two states. In its report, the NTSB faulted the Kansas-based utility for inadequate training of inspectors and a poor system for identifying steel and cast iron lines that could be particularly prone to corrosion and leaks. However, James L. Kolstad, the board chairman, said the KPL accidents reflect problems found throughout the gas utility industry. ``We don't think this is an isolated case,'' said Kolstad. For instance, the board said gas utilities needed to do a better job of alerting the public to the dangers of leaks and advising customers what to do when they smell gas odors. The NTSB also recommended that federal pipeline safety standards be extended to all portions of gas lines running to customer homes from main supply lines. Currently the regulatory protections, including requirements for corrosion protection and inspections, cover only service lines to a customer's meter from the main line. So-called yard lines, which go from the meter to the house, are the responsiblity of homeowners and utilities have no obligation to inspect or maintain them. The five-member board recommended that DOT change its regulations to extend the safety standards and said utilities should be required to install the excess flow valves on new high pressure residential service lines and those being replaced. Recommendations of the NTSB, which operates as an independent agency, are not binding but can serve as a catalyst for actions by regulators, the industry or Congress. Board members noted that they had suggested the use of excess flow valves in 1981 but that no government mandate had been issued. DOT will consider the board's recommendations, according to Mark Dowis, executive assistant to the administrator of the Research and Special Programs Administration. ``We're going to take it very seriously,'' he said. The agency did not pursue NTSB's earlier recommendation for excess flow valves because of a gas industry study that cast doubts on their usefulness, he said. Carl Ericson, a spokesman for the American Gas Association, said the industry would consider the NTSB recommendations. In the past, he said, there have been questions about the costs and effectiveness of the devices, particularly on low pressure gas lines that often serve residential customers. Several of the accidents in Kansas and Missouri involved bare steel service lines installed before 1971, when federal safety requirements took effect to make utilities responsible for installing corrosion prevention systems and for inspecting for gas leaks on the pipes owned by customers. NTSB recommended that DOT require utilities to safeguard all currently unprotected gas lines over several years, either through replacement of the lines or some corrosion protection system.

DOC.HEAD: China, Indonesia Clear Last Hurdle to Diplomatic Relations
DOC.TEXT: China has accepted Indonesian proposals for settling outstanding debts, removing the last obstacle to restoring diplomatic relations suspended 23 years ago, the government said Wednesday. The official Xinhua News Agency said the countries concluded four days of talks Tuesday and agreed that Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas will visit Beijing in late April or early May to complete the settlement on Indonesia's debts to China. The nations suspended diplomatic relations in 1967 after Indonesia accused China of complicity in a communist coup attempt in 1965. Xinhua did not give a figure for Indonesia's debt. But it quoted an unidentified Foreign Ministry source as saying figures presented by the countries were for the most part identical and that China accepted an Indonesian proposal. Indonesia has said it owes $50 million to China. The Indonesian delegation in the talks that just ended was led by Jusuf Anwar, director of external funds of the Directorate General of Budget of the Ministry of Finance. He met Monday with Vice Foreign Minister Qi Huaiyuan, who welcomed what he said was the first official Indonesian delegation to visit China since 1967. Agreement to normalize relations came when Indonesian President Suharto and Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen met in Tokyo in February 1989 while attending the funeral of Japan's Emperor Hirohito.

DOC.HEAD: Captain Charged With Negligence in Barge Accident
DOC.TEXT: A tugboat captain has been charged with negligence for allegedly veering too close to shore while pushing a barge that ruptured and spilled 30,000 gallons of oil. U.S. Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Frank Whipple said Arthur Sanders, 32, of Houma, La., could have avoided Sunday's spill in the Intracoastal Waterway by staying in shipping lanes. Sanders' tug was pushing the 190-foot oil barge that struck a submerged vessel and ruptured, spilling 830 barrels of light crude into the waterway, officials said. The waterway opened to two-way traffic Tuesday. One-way traffic was restored Monday morning. The charge, issued late Monday, is the first step under maritime law to a license revocation. No bond is required. Coast Guard Warrant Officer Mike Shoul said a federal judge will conduct a hearing and decide by July either to revoke or suspend Sanders' license, or dismiss the charge. Sanders is free and can continue to pilot vessels pending the outcome of the hearing, Shoul said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Allows Evidence From Foreign Banks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with jury sworn in, picks up 4th graf, `The judge ...'
DOC.TEXT: A jury was sworn in Tuesday in the federal fraud and racketeering trial of Imelda Marcos, and the judge said opening arguments would begin next week. Earlier, U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan ruled that bank records from the Philippines, Hong Kong and Singapore could be used as evidence in the trial of the former Philippines first lady and Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi. Selection of the jury and six alternates was completed near the end of the trial's first day. Keenan asked jurors to return to court next Tuesday, when the trial is to resume with opening arguments. The panel consists of three postal workers, two transit and two utility employees, a retired secretary, a teacher's aide, an engineer, a computer operator and an estate manager with a law firm. Mrs. Marcos' attorneys had sought to block the bank documents, but the judge decided they were admissible because prosecutors had filed the proper certification. The judge reserved a ruling on the admissibility of documents from Italy, Switzerland and West Germany, saying he would rule before the start of the trial's opening arguments, possibly next week. Among documents allowed as evidence were 2,000 pages of records from two trust accounts at the Standard Chartered Bank of Hong Kong, which prosecutors alleged were controlled by Mrs. Marcos and her husband, Ferdinand, who died in exile in Hawaii on Sept. 28. Keenan said the government will use the trust account records to try to establish that the Marcoses owned three Panamanian companies that in turn owned a building at 40 Wall St. in New York. The building is among four Manhattan properties that prosecutors claim the Marcoses bought with more than $160 million they stole from the Philippines' treasury. The Singapore bank records relate to the alleged transfer of millions of dollars for the purchase of 40 Wall St., the judge said. The other records found admissible were from the Traders Royal Bank in Manila. Mrs. Marcos, 60, is charged with racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. If convicted, she faces up to 50 years in prison and a $1 million fine. Khashoggi is accused of helping the Marcoses conceal the real estate deals. He faces up to 10 years in prison and $500,000 in fines if convicted of mail fraud and obstruction of justice. Marcos, the former Philippines president, had been named in the original October 1988 indictment. The trial is expected to last three to four months.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Protests TV Marti Transmission as Subversive, Illegal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs with head of U.S. Southern Command calling Castro a clown, more reaction to broadcasts; pickup 7th pvs, `Cuban jamming...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-TV Marti, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Cuba protested the start of U.S. television transmissions to the Communist island nation Tuesday as illegal and a possible prelude to U.S. military action against Fidel Castro's government. Cuban jamming limited the first test transmission of TV Marti to 10 minutes, Prensa Latina said. However, reports from Washington said the jamming began 23 minutes into the transmission in downtown Havana, and that viewers in outlying areas had few problems during the five-hour test. ``Cuban authorities have warned that the beginning of these transmissions may form part of a larger maneuver and Washington may be looking for a pretext to unleash military aggression,'' the Cuban government news agency Prensa Latina said. In Panama, the commander of U.S. military forces in Latin America said the United States doesn't have to do anything to get rid of Castro because the Cuban people will. ``We don't have the slightest intention of invading Castro right now. There is no need to,'' Gen. Marc Cisneros told The Associated Press. ``His own people are going to do to him what ... (Panamanians) did to (deposed dictator Manuel Antonio) Noriega.'' Cisneros was asked to comment on Castro's claim that 500,000 U.S. soldiers would die if the United States tried to invade Cuba. ``He's a clown,'' Cisneros said. ``Castro is smoking marijuana on this point.'' Prensa Latina, monitored in Mexico City, suggested that the danger of an air wave war escalating to armed confrontation could be behind stepped up Cuban militia drills. Division Gen. Ulises Rosales del Toro, the Cuban armed forces chief of staff, said his men are ready to defend Cuba against a U.S. invasion. ``We have high moral and a combative mood in our armed forces, sufficient equipment and the will to defend our revolution and our country,'' he said, according to Prensa Latina. The Foreign Ministry said the Bush administration is on a ``course ever more aggressive and hostile towards the Cuban revolution.'' It said the administration had been emboldened by ``the changes in Eastern Europe, the election results in Nicaragua and a Pyrrhic victory in Panama that massacred thousands of its sons.'' The United States, which invaded Panama in December to oust Noriega, must realize its actions are ``capable of provoking a crisis of great proportions in this part of the world,'' said vice Foreign Minister Oscar Oramas. The TV Marti transmission test included music, a 1971 World Series tape and an episode of ``Kate and Allie,'' a comedy series about two divorced women and their children. ``For the United States the debut was nothing impressive since in a 10-minute interval the principal technological power on the planet could not keep the invading signal from being rejected over the coverage area,'' Prensa Latina said. It said residents called local radio stations in outrage over the ``miserable and cowardly aggression.'' ``The authorities base their rejection of the transmissions not only on the subversive character of their content but on their illegality and above all on the occupation of a locally used frequency within the sovereignty of Cuban national territory,'' the news agency said. It said Channel 13, used for the TV Marti transmission, is a domestic channel used by Tele Rebelde. Prensa Latina said the transmission violates the U.N. charter, conventions on the use of communications satellites and other international agreements. It also protested use of the name of Cuban hero Jose Marti for the transmission. Cuba has denounced the transmissions before the Interparliamentary Telecommunications Union, the Non-Aligned Movement, the U.N. Security Council and other international bodies, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Hubble Mission May be Moved Up, But NASA Still Faces a Few Bugs ... Insects
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATEwith telescope installation delayed until Thursday at earliest; first time launch date moved up during orbiter processing; dead bug count now at 37; picks up 10th graf pvs, ```The Hubble ...'
DOC.TEXT: The shuttle mission to propel the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope into orbit may be moved up a day or two, but NASA said Tuesday that crews still face some bugs: insects. The telescope is to be transferred into Discovery's payload bay no earlier than Thursday, two days later than scheduled because of gnat-like insects in a payload preparation room. NASA earlier gave Wednesday as the earliest transfer time. Still, NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone said technicians needed little if any of the contingency time built into Discovery's prelaunch schedule, making it possible for the agency to take the unusual step of moving up the launch date. ``The processing has gone very smoothly,'' said Dick Young, a spokesman for the agency. NASA occasionally has moved around shuttle launch dates on the manifest because of scheduling changes in the months prior to liftoff, Young said. But it is the first time liftoff has been accelerated once orbiter processing has begun. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Flight Readiness Review Board will finalize the launch date after meeting Friday and Saturday at Kennedy Space Center. Last month, Discovery's launch date was moved from April 18 to April 12 after the lower right segment of the shuttle's solid-fuel rocket booster was replaced more quickly than anticipated. On Monday, shuttle managers determined that problems with Discovery's nose wheel landing gear will not hamper the mission. The mosquito-like midges were found on the orbiter's payload bay doors Sunday when a servicing machine was retracted to receive the telescope. By late Tuesday, 37 midges had been caught in seven traps set up in the preparation room. Technicians plan to inspect the traps again Tuesday night and, provided no more than a few insects are caught, proceed Wednesday with preparations for a Thursday installation. ``The Hubble is so sensitive,'' Malone said. ``They've got very strict conditions.'' Discovery's five astronauts are to deploy the Hubble on the second day of the five-day mission. The telescope will orbit 370 miles above Earth, looking seven times more deeply into space and detecting objects 50 times fainter than the best ground-based observatory. The Hubble originally was scheduled for launch in 1983, but was delayed because of technical problems and the 1986 Challenger explosion.

DOC.HEAD: Filipino Police, Rebels Fight Near Presidential Palace
DOC.TEXT: Police and Communist rebels fought a running gun battle early Wednesday about one mile from the presidential palace, and police said one policeman and a suspected rebel were killed. In other developments: _The U.S. Navy banned most non-essential travel to Manila because of threats to Americans. _The military said Communist rebels killed 15 troopers last Saturday on southern Mindanao island and shot dead a Filipino executive of the Nestle's company in an ambush Monday southeast of Manila. Police Sgt. Florentino Bagallon gave this account of the Wednesday shootout: At 4 a.m. police spotted about four youths painting Communist slogans on a lane divider in Manila's Santa Mesa district. They gave chase and the youths lured them into a dark street where about 12 rebel gunmen waited in ambush. Rebels pulled M-16 rifles from a sack and fired, killing Constable 1st Class Roxy Valguna. Officers radioed for reinforcements, who killed one rebel during a running gun fight through the crowded residential district. Another rebel was arrested. The incident came on the eve of the 21st anniversary of the New People's Army, the military wing of the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines. Police have predicted stepped up guerrilla activity in connection with the anniversary. At the U.S.-run Subic Naval Base, 50 miles west of Manila, Rear Adm. Roger Rich banned most non-essential travel to the capital by the more than 6,000 sailors because of ``threats against U.S. military and military associated personnel.'' Navy spokesman Lt. Cmdr. Kevin Mukri said the order, issued Monday, bans leaves in Manila except for servicemen with immediate family members residing there. The order does not apply to personnel at Clark Air Base, 50 miles north of Manila. Air Force officials said Clark personnel were told not to travel between the base and Manila at night. The military said 12 militiamen and three soldiers were killed Saturday in the ambush of a patrol by guerrillas in Davao del Sur province, 620 miles southeast of Manila. It said three troopers were wounded and 11 were missing. Two rebels died in the 30-minute gunbattle, the report said. On Monday, Froilan Pablo, executive vice president of Nestle's Philippines, was slain by four gunmen as he played tennis in Cabuyao, 25 miles southeast of Manila. The killers escaped. Police said they believed the attackers belonged to a rebel assassination squad that targeted Pablo because of labor problems at his company. Col. Jose Lachica, operations chief of the National Capital Region Defense Command, predicted more rebel attacks on business executives.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Airline Suspends Flights to Beirut
DOC.TEXT: Malev, the Hungarian airline, announced Tuesday the indefinite suspension of flights to Beirut, less than a week after halting flights of Soviet Jews to Israel because of threats from Moslem extremists. A spokesman for the state carrier denied the decisions were related. The measure came 10 days after flights to the Lebanese capital resumed following a five-year lapse, the government news agency MTI reported. The spokesman for the government-owned airline told MTI the suspension was due to a lack of security in Lebanese airspace. MTI quoted the unidentified Malev spokesman as saying the suspension of flights to Beirut would be in effect ``until further notice.'' He said it was unrelated to its move Wednesday to halt flights of Soviet Jews to Israel, a decision Hungarian government leaders have criticized, saying it was made by airline officials who did not consult with the government. The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine issued threats against airlines of all those countries that provide such flights. Hundreds of thousands of Jews are expected to emigrate to Israel in the next few years as the result of relaxed rules in the Soviet Union and tighter entry quotas in the United States. The exodus has sparked an uproar in the Arab world, which fears many of the newcomers could settle in the Israeli-occupied territories, especially the West Bank. The Soviet airline Aeroflot does not run direct flights to Israel. Instead, migrants must change at one of several transit points, including Budapest.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Officials Say Refugees Should Think About Going Home
DOC.TEXT: Senior U.N. officials said Tuesday that the millions of Afghan refugees in Pakistan and Iran should return home and begin rebuilding their war-torn nation. ``It is clear that somehow we've got to help feed them in 1990, (but) this can't go on forever,'' World Food Program Executive Director James Ingram told reporters. Sadruddin Aga Khan, the U.N. coordinator for humanitarian aid, and Thorvald Stoltenberg, the U.N. high commissioner for refugees, also attended the news conference. Ingram said the Afghan civil war between the Marxist government and Moslem guerrillas ``has lasted for 10 or 11 years already and now there is an opportunity to make progress in the return of refugees.'' About 3.8 million Afghans live in a maze of refugee camps scattered along Pakistan's border. Another 2 million live in Iran. While insisting the refugees must go home voluntary, Sadruddin said the United Nations hoped that rebuilding their destroyed country might be the catalyst to spark their return. Most of the refugees fled after Soviet soldiers marched into Afghanistan in 1979 to replace one Communist government with another and to crush the Moslem insurgency. Moscow withdrew the last of its troops in February 1989, but most refugees have stayed in Pakistan while the war continues between the U.S.-backed guerrillas and the Soviet-supported government in Kabul. Sadruddin has made fresh appeals for contributions toward his $1.2 billion repatriation plan. The money is to be used to rebuild Afghanistan, where the war has ruined the economy, wiped out herds and farmlands and destroyed thousands of villages. Sadruddin has suggested the refugees return to parts of Afghanistan where there has been little or no fighting in recent months. These areas would be designated peace zones. He said renewed fighting instigated by either the Kabul government or the guerrillas would end U.N. assistance. ``The price to pay will be no ... U.N. aid,'' said Sadruddin, who returned Tuesday from a daylong trip to Kabul. However, Afghan and Western sources fear another round of fighting will begin once the snow melts and weapons can be ferried from Pakistan across the rugged mountain passes to Afghan cities.

DOC.HEAD: American Fashion Designer Dies of AIDS Complications
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 2nd graf, `He died ...' to UPDATE with planned auction, picks up 3rd graf, `Known worldwide ...'; SUBS grafs 20-end, `In a statement ...,' with 10 grafs to UPDATE with brother's comments on Halston's final years, site of service. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY19, NY25
DOC.TEXT: Halston, the designer who created the pillbox hat that Jacqueline Kennedy made chic and whose star-studded circle of friends included Andy Warhol and Liza Minnelli, has died of AIDS-related cancer. He was 57. He died in his sleep at Pacific Presbyterian Medical Center Monday night. His brother, Robert Frowick, said Tuesday that Halston had suffered from AIDS for the last 18 months and died of a related cancer called Kaposi's sarcoma. Halston asked his family to auction an all-black Rolls-Royce ``dream car'' he bought for more than $200,000 last year and to donate the proceeds to AIDS research, Frowick told a news conference at the hospital attended by his brother, Donald, and sister, Susan Watkins. Halston spent some of his final days touring the California coastline, especially Big Sur, in the Rolls-Royce, Frowick said. Known worldwide for his simple and sexy creations, Halston designed clothes for such celebrities as Lauren Bacall, Minnelli and Bianca Jagger. Bacall dubbed him ``Halstie Baby,'' and once ordered 75 outfits priced at $200 to $1,000 each. Through his work he became friends with Warhol and other celebrities, including model Marissa Berenson. The top-rated designer was responsible for the pillbox hat that Mrs. Kennedy wore at her husband's presidential inauguration in 1961. The hats became popular with millions of women. He later pioneered the use of Ultrasuede, a synthetic fabric much like suede. ``The Halston label on a dress or perfume tells a woman that what she's buying will be recognized as `right,''' Vogue magazine once said, ``that it's more than just stylish, it's in good taste.'' Born Roy Halston Frowick on April 23, 1932, in Des Moines, Iowa, he attended Indiana University and the Chicago Art Institute. Said to have been fascinated with his grandmother's hats as a child, he began making hats while still in college. His first client was Fran Allison of ``Kukla, Fran and Ollie,'' and within months he was creating hats for Kim Novak, Hedda Hopper, Deborah Kerr and Shirley Booth. He moved to New York City in 1957, working in Lily Dache's hat division. The next year, he went to work for Bergdorf Goodman department store as a milliner, and later began designing Bergdorf's ready-to-wear fashions. He opened his own couture house in 1968. ``He was temperamental, spoiled, always threatening to quit,'' Andrew Goodman, Bergdorf's president, said in 1973. ``But we indulged him because he was so talented.'' Halston added a ready-to-wear range, called Halston International, in 1970, and Halston Originals in 1972. But Halston's position at the pinnacle of the fashion industry began to slip dramatically in 1973, when he signed a $16 million deal with Norton Simon Inc. for his ready-to-wear line, his couture operation and the Halston trademark. The agreement let Norton Simon use the Halston name for products the designer didn't design, and Halston couldn't use his name on any product without Norton Simon's permission. J.C. Penney Co. Inc. approached Norton Simon with the idea of a line of inexpensive Halston clothes to be sold exclusively in the moderate-price department stores, and Halston agreed. That deal was signed in 1982. Shortly after that, Bergdorf Goodman announced it would no longer sell Halston clothes because of the association with Penney's. Adding to the designer's woes, Norton Simon was acquired at the same time in a takeover with the Esmark Inc. conglomerate, which in turn was taken over by the Beatrice companies. To cut costs, Beatrice eliminated Halston's limousines, dismissed much of his staff and disassembled his company. Revlon Group Inc. in New York bought the Halston name in December 1986. They used it on a popular fragrance line, called simply, ``Halston.'' ``We are all deeply saddened by Halston's death,'' said Ronald Perelman, Revlon's chairman of the board. ``He was an American leader of design and style who helped to define his entire era. He will be sorely missed.'' Halston won Coty fashion awards in 1962 and 1969, and was elected to the fashion Hall of Fame in 1974. Halston had effectively retired by the fall of 1988 and was diagnosed with the AIDS virus about a year ago, Frowick said at the news conference. The designer moved to California in December. ``There really isn't much to celebrate,'' he was quoted as saying when asked about his increasingly sedate lifestyle. ``People are always asking, `What happened? How are you?' ``It can be very difficult,'' he said. ``I have no answer.'' After he was hospitalized, his family brought him gourmet meals approved by his doctor, his brother said. Halston enjoyed a breathtaking view of the Golden Gate Bridge and San Francisco Bay area from his hospital room, which was filled with orchids and other flowers. ``He was quite lucid up until the last few days,'' Frowick said. `` ... When he was alert, he was extremely alert and he had very strong mental faculties that never left him.'' Frowick described his brother as ``an extremely elegant man ... that's the way he tried to go through his final stages, too.'' In a statement issued earlier in the day, Frowick said the family ``mourns the loss of a magnificent and deeply respected brother and friend.'' ``We thank all those from around the world who have been communicating thoughtful wishes to him. America has lost a true patriot and its greatest designer, one of the greatest designers in the world.'' A memorial service is planned Friday at Calvary Presbyterian Church in San Francisco. Halston's body will be cremated.

DOC.HEAD: `Hill Street Blues' TV Star Rene Enriquez Dies of Cancer at Age 56
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to CORRECT age to 56, sted 58, UPDATE with comment from James B. Sikking' picks up 4th graf, `Enriquez boasted...'
DOC.TEXT: Actor Rene Enriquez, who portrayed Lt. Ray Calletano on the old Emmy Award-winning ``Hill Street Blues'' TV series, has died of pancreatic cancer. He was 56. Enriquez died Friday at his suburban Tarzana home and his body was cremated the following day, said his sister, Violetta Enriquez. The actor, who wasn't married and had no children, didn't want a funeral, she said Tuesday. His motion picture credits included a co-starring role with Gary Busey in ``Bulletproof'' and a plum role as Gen. Anastasio Somoza in ``Under Fire,'' co-starring Nick Nolte and Gene Hackman. He also appeared with Charles Bronson in ``The Evil That Men Do.'' James B. Sikking, who played Lt. Howard Hunter on ``Hill Street Blues,'' learned of the actor's death while on vacation in Hawaii. ``I've lost a friend and a co-worker. I'm shocked. The Latin acting community has also lost a great actor,'' said Sikking, who now stars as the father on ABC-TV's ``Doogie Howser, M.D.'' Enriquez boasted of his role on ``Hill Street Blues,'' viewing his character as pivotal in the former NBC-TV series. Calletano was the precinct's second in command. ``I'm proud of the show. It made a powerful statement on the decay of cities and human isolation,'' he said. In one of the series' most-famous episodes, in 1982, the normally quiet Calletano was honored as the mythical police department's ``Hispanic Officer of the Year.'' The character Calletano was proud and sensitive about his Colombian heritage and unhappy about the status of Hispanics in American society. At his testimonial banquet, after being misidentified as Puerto Rican and served Mexican food, Calletano threw away his acceptance speech and told the stunned audience: ``Why is it ... that I look around this room _ full of ranking officers _ and the only other Hispanics I see are waiters and busboys?'' Long before ``Hill Street Blues,'' Enriquez was a familiar face on such television shows as ``The Defenders,'' ``The Nurses,'' ``Naked City,'' ``Charlie's Angels,'' ``Benson,'' ``Quincy'' and ``WKRP in Cincinnati.'' Born in Granada, Nicaragua, Enriquez was being groomed for the priesthood when he decided as a teen-ager to leave the seminary and head for the United States. His uncle, Gen. Emiliano Chamorro, was a former president of Nicaragua. He attended the University of San Francisco and later switched to San Francisco City College where he studied international relations. He served in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War then returned to San Francisco State University. In 1958, he joined the American Academy of Dramatic Arts in New York.

DOC.HEAD: `Making Movies' by Aaron Sorkin Opens Off-Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: Well, the second act set _ a craggy mountain of rocks made to suggest a hilltop in upstate New York _ was nice. But the play, ``Making Movies,'' which opened Tuesday at off-Broadway's Promenade Theater, is a mistake _ a flat, unconvincing comedy that stymies director Don Scardino and a cast of usually competent actors. It was written by Aaron Sorkin who scored on Broadway earlier this season with ``A Few Good Men,'' a military courtroom drama starring Tom Hulce. There are similiarities between the two works. Both have wisecracking heroes. In ``Making Movies,'' it's a screenwriter trying to make up with his girlfriend who happens to be a producer of the movie. She wants him to do rewrites on the script. In ``A Few Good Men,'' it's a Navy lawyer who defends two Marines accused of murder. Scardino directed both plays. He gave ``A Few Good Men'' a crackerjack production, fast-paced and occasionally funny. But with ``Making Movies'' desperation has set in. The actors push too hard. Intensity is the order of the day. And there's not too much material to get worked up about. Besides fighting with his girlfriend, the screenwriter must contend with the director, an old college friend, who has visions of making a great military epic, set in Guam. Why they are filming on a farm outside Schenectady, N.Y., is never made entirely clear. The dialogue tries for trendy, but ends up turgid. There are a great many jokes in the second act about three cows who happen to wander into the final day of shooting. Some are funny. ``Making Movies'' will not inspire anyone to go into the film business. Animal husbandry, maybe. But not show business.

DOC.HEAD: Arabs, Others Say Soviet Jews in Israeli Lands Threatens Peace
DOC.TEXT: Arab and non-Arab countries said Tuesday during a Security Council session that the settlement of Soviet Jews in the Israeli-occupied territories threatens peace in the Middle East. On Wednesday, the Security Council plans to meet again to continue discussions on the controversial issue of Soviet emigration to the occupied lands. Hundreds of thousands of Jews are expected to emigrate to Israel in the next few years as the result of relaxed rules in the Soviet Union and tighter entry quotas in the United States. The exodus has sparked an uproar in the Arab world, which fears many of the newcomers could settle in the occupied territories, especially the West Bank. Israel says it has no policy of settling the immigrants in the occupied territories. Egypt's permanent representative to the United Nations said the international community ``is dutybound to safeguard the endeavors for peace in the Middle East at this critical stage in the process.'' The representative, Amre Moussa, said Egypt believes ``that immigration to Israel coupled with settling Israeli civilians or immigrants in the occupied territories, constitutes a serious threat'' to Middle East peace prospects. Moussa called on the United States and the Soviet Union to ``ensure that the rights of the Palestinian people shall not be jeopardized.'' ``We must not allow anyone to waste this unique opportunity to achieve tangible progress toward a reconciliation between the Jewish and Palestinian nations,'' Moussa said. Syrian representative Issa Awad criticized Israel and the United States for supporting policies that he said lead to ``the herding of these immigrants like cattle to Israel against all values'' espoused by the United States. Chinese Ambassador Li Luye said Jewish settlement in the occupied lands ``aggravated the already tense situation in the Middle East'' and posed ``new barriers to the peace process in the region.'' Li said China, one of five permanent members of the Security Council, would continue to work for measures to safeguard the rights of Palestinians. The 15-member Security Council originally took up the issue of Soviet Jewish emigration to the West Bank and Gaza on March 15, but adjourned without taking action.

DOC.HEAD: Rockets Hit Mini-Bus in Afghan Capital, 27 Dead
DOC.TEXT: Rockets struck a residential district of Kabul on Tuesday, killing 27 people and wounding 22, according to a radio account monitored in the Pakistani capital. While no one claimed responsibility for the attack, Radio Kabul blamed the U.S.-backed Moslem insurgents who have been fighting 12 years to topple Communist governments in Kabul. Most of the dead were aboard a mini-bus hit by one of several rockets launched, the radio report said. Hundreds of people have been killed in rocket attacks on the Afghan capital the past year. Afghanistan's Marxist President Najib has accused rebel fighters, who insist they target only military installations. The radio report claimed the rockets were fired from Paghman, about 15 miles west of Kabul.

DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin Assembly Speaker Announces Campaign for Governor
DOC.TEXT: The Democratic speaker of the Wisconsin Assembly announced his campaign for governor Tuesday at a high school gymnasium, pledging to make education the No. 1 election issue. Thomas Loftus, 44, is the only Democrat so far to throw his hat into the gubernatorial ring. Republican Gov. Tommy G. Thompson has not formally announced his re-election bid, but said earlier this week he was ``98 percent'' certain he would. Loftus, Assembly speaker since 1983, announced his candidacy at Sun Prairie High School, where he graduated in 1963. He told about 500 students and faculty at Sun Prairie that the state had fallen behind in the worldwide race to prepare students for the future. ``We're not keeping pace. It's not good enough anymore to be better than Kentucky or Mississippi _ or even to be as good as Minnesota,'' Loftus said. ``That's not the competition anymore. ``When you finish high school and begin work, you will be competing with kids from Japan and Korea and a new unified Europe. And many of those kids will have a head start on you because they are getting a better education,'' Loftus said. Thompson is seen as having early advantages in the race _ a campaign chest of $1.4 million, a healthy state economy and widespread popularity in several public opinion polls. Loftus dismissed those advantages. ``It's not Election Day. The governor is on the wrong side of education, property taxes, Indian treaty rights, abortion and welfare,'' he said Tuesday. A backer of abortion rights, Loftus said the issue would be key in the campaign, adding that he would portray Thompson's anti-abortion stand as ``out of step with the people of this state.''

DOC.HEAD: Acid-Tongued Clothes Critic Mr. Blackwell Hurls Oscar Fashion Darts
With AM-Oscars
LaserPhoto LA16
DOC.TEXT: Acid-tongued clothes critic Mr. Blackwell ripped into celebrity Oscar get-ups Tuesday with a worst-dressed list led by Jane Fonda's ``Vegas viking'' look and Kim Basinger's ``catastrophe in white.'' Blackwell also heaped disdain on Julia Roberts' ``bumpy, buxom band-aid of a dress'' and called Brenda Fricker's ``tacky tunic top and baggy black pants an Irish atrocity.'' The acerbic fashion designer, whose real name is Richard Sylvan Selzer, has lambasted celebrity garb for 30 years with his annual worst-dressed roll call. Fitness guru Miss Fonda, who was escorted by cable television mogul Ted Turner, caught his eye Monday night. ``The return of the Vegas Viking ... sequined breastplate effect was over-colorized and overdone.'' About Miss Basinger's attire, he said: ``Scarlett O'Hara meets Miss Majorette in a monstrously misguided fashion flop. A catastrophe in white.'' Blackwell, who has designed dresses for Marilyn Monroe and Zsa Zsa Gabor in the past, said the return of red made big fashion news at Monday night's 62nd annual Academy Awards. He even took time to praise a celebrity trio. ``In a toned down, downright understated ceremony, the predominant fashion focus was on the arrival of the red queens _ Geena Davis, Anjelica Huston and Elizabeth McGovern,'' Blackwell drooled, adding they were ``elegant, regal and arresting.'' Also receiving high marks were Diana Ross, ``a vision in white crepe;'' Candice Bergen, ``a dreamy confection in a cloud of pink beads;'' and Michelle Pfeiffer, ``demure without being dowdy, simple without being boring.'' But there was mostly Blackwell venom. Also getting pans were: Melissa Manchester, ``an escapee from a vampire video;'' Glenn Close, ``black funeral frock ... perfect for a guillotine gathering;'' Daryl Hannah, ``splash trash at its webby worst;'' Dianne Wiest, ``high priestess from a `Star Trek' rerun;'' Pauline Collins, ``looks like she wore her chenille bedspread;'' and Sally Kirkland, ``still the queen of cartoon couture.''

DOC.HEAD: Guatemalan Guerrillas, Government Renew Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: Guatemalan government and guerrilla representatives met Tuesday to renew talks on ending the Central American nation's 28-year-old civil war. The Guatemalan National Revolutionary Unity, an umbrella for guerrilla groups, held its first talks in a year with the government-backed National Reconciliation Commission under the auspices of the World Federation of Lutheran Churches. The guerrillas have been fighting a succession of military-backed governments. Human rights groups estimate 100,000 people have died and 40,000 have disappeared during the war. Both sides expressed optimism but said another collapse in negotiations could leave the conflict more severely deadlocked. Speaking through translators at a news conference, the delegations declined to answer questions or state their opening positions. Statements may be issued as early as Wednesday, but talks may continue until Sunday. Little progress was made when the guerrillas met government representatives in Madrid, Spain, in 1986. A round of talks in Costa Rica broke down last year. Jorge E. Rosal Melendez of the three-member guerrilla delegation said the Oslo meeting was an effort to ``open the door to a process that is bound to be complex and difficult, but not impossible, in search of a final solution.'' Speaking for the three commissioners, Jorge Serrano Elias said he found broad support for a peace initiative among the government, the military, private individuals and opposition parties. ``The feeling of the Guatemalan people ... is that peace must be achieved so that we can put a final stop this conflict,'' he said. ``We also realize that if this meeting fails the consequences would be grave,'' Elias said. The Guatemalan National Revolutionary Unity is the umbrella for three guerrilla groups, the Rebel Armed Forces, Guerrilla Army of the Poor and the Organization of the People in Arms. U.S. estimates put its number of fighters at 1,500.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Argues Governors Have No Power Over Guard Training Missions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS antepenultimate graf: ``Montana later,'' to note that state withdrew support
DOC.TEXT: Governors horned in on U.S. foreign policy when they tried to stop state National Guard units from training in Central America, the Bush administration told the Supreme Court on Tuesday. Solicitor General Kenneth Starr asked the court to squelch Minnesota Gov. Rudy Perpich's challenge of a 1986 law that strips all governors of their veto power over National Guard training missions. ``What the governor has sought to do is to play a role in the foreign policy and defense policy of the United States,'' said Starr, the Justice Department's highest-ranking courtroom lawyer. The case has revived a controversy from the 1988 presidential campaign in which Democratic candidate Michael Dukakis denounced the Reagan administration for what he called a ``failed and illegal'' policy of supporting the Nicaraguan Contra rebels. The Massachusetts governor said that sending National Guard troops to the region was an attempt to intimidate Nicaragua. Dukakis unsuccessfully challenged the same 1986 law, a lawsuit government lawyers called ``a dagger aimed at the heart of national defense.'' Perpich alleges in his lawsuit against the Defense Department that the Constitution gives states the authority to direct or consent to peacetime training of state militia. Rather than attack U.S. policy in Central America, Perpich has portrayed the dispute as a states' rights fight. A Supreme Court decision is expected by July. John Tunheim, chief deputy attorney general for Minnesota, argued Tuesday that the founding fathers created state militia because they ``greatly feared the effect of a large standing army.'' ``They believed that state control would be a very important check on the federal government,'' Tunheim said. But Justice Anthony Kennedy asked how the federal government could properly prepare National Guard units for battle without having the unfettered authority to decide where they are trained. In Minnesota's view, Kennedy said, ``We're in a position where we can't train them to do some of the things we're calling them forth to do.'' The 1986 law, known as the Montgomery Amendment, barred any governor from stopping a National Guard unit from serving on active duty outside the country over disagreement with the mission's location, purpose or schedule. Named for Rep. G.V. ``Sonny'' Montgomery, the Mississippi Democrat who sponsored it, the law was enacted after several governors said they opposed the Reagan administration's Central American policy. Ruling on Minnesota's challenge, the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the law in June. Urging the justices to do the same, Starr noted that National Guard troops are enlisted in the U.S. armed forces as well as in a state organization. Therefore, he said, the president may order them to train anywhere he sees fit. ``They wear two hats,'' Starr said. ``When they were going to Honduras they were wearing their federal hat.'' The National Guard has been under dual state and federal control since Congress made it a component of the Army in 1933. Enlistees enroll simultaneously in the state militia and a reserve unit of the U.S. armed forces. The dual-enlistment system ``worked very well until governors decided to play a role on the stage of foreign policy,'' Starr said. Twenty-nine states filed a brief siding with the federal government and saying that Perpich was ``seeking to arrogate to himself a role in foreign affairs.'' Six other states _ Iowa, Maine, Massachusetts, Montana, Ohio and Vermont _ took Minnesota's side, arguing that the Constitution grants state control of the militia to prevent abuses by the federal government. Montana later withdrew its support of Minnesota, said Gary Blair, adjutant general of the Montana National Guard, on Tuesday. The Army National Guard provides 46 percent of the Army's combat units and 28 percent of its support forces. The Air National Guard provides 73 percent of the nation's interceptor forces, 25 percent of the tactical fighter aircraft and 24 percent of tactical air support.

DOC.HEAD: Burma's Leader Defends Mass Resettlement Program
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Saw Maung, Burma's military ruler, on Tuesday dismissed criticism of his government's mass resettlement program and charges of official corruption in the drug trade. In a statement received in Bangkok, Thailand, Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., compared the resettlement policy to that of the former Pol Pot government in Cambodia, which forced millions of urban residents out into the countryside. The State Department last week also criticized the relocations. Saw Maung accused foreign news organizations of interfering in Burma's internal affairs by publicizing critical reports. ``I hereby categorically deny all these groundless accusations as totally false,'' he said. In a speech during the annual armed forces day in Rangoon, he also attacked foreign media reports about the arrest and suppression of opposition groups. Western diplomats in Rangoon have been quoted by foreign news media as saying the Saw Maung government has moved up to 500,000 people from cities to outlying areas to break up regions of political dissent. Saw Maung said the program was designed to give land to homeless Burmese who were living on religious land, cemeteries and rubbish dumps. Diplomats insisted that it was aimed at preventing a repeat of huge anti-government protests in 1988, which the military harshly suppressed when it seized power that September. Saw Maung attacked what he said was a March 10 Voice of America broadcast reporting that the flow of narcotics from Burma was out of control because of corruption among Burmese, Thai and Laotian officials. In Bangkok, Melvin Levitsky, a U.S. assistant secretary of state, on Monday accused the Burmese government of conspiring with drug traffickers and doing little to stem record outflows of heroin. Moynihan's statement denounced Thailand for ``profiting from the desperation of the Burmese regime.'' The senator quoted a New York Times editorial Sunday that asked Thailand to ``condition its commerce with Burma on elementary standards of conduct.'' Thailand is one of the few countries to establish close relations with Saw Maung's government. It since has secured valuable logging, mining and fishing concessions.

DOC.HEAD: Man Awakens From Eight-Year Coma After Dose of Valium
DOC.TEXT: A man who was in a vegetative state for eight years unexpectedly ``woke up and started talking'' after being given a tranquilizer for routine dental work, a neurologist said Tuesday. ``I have to tell you he was a different man. He knew his name, the name of his family, where he used to work. He could add, subtract and perform complicated calculations,'' Dr. Andres Kanner said in an interview. The man, identified only as a Wisconsin man in his mid-40s, revived after being given Valium at the University of Wisconsin Hospital and Clinics on March 12, Kanner said. The man, who was injured in a traffic accident 10 years ago, was not in a coma, but a vegetative state, meaning his eyes were open and he occasionally uttered words, but could do nothing else, the doctor said. After the tranquilizer was administered for the March 12 dental work, the man fell asleep for about five minutes, Kanner said. ``Then he woke up and started talking. He was able to answer question, say his name, to feed himself and walk,'' he said. Hours later, the man lapsed back into the vegetative state. He was given a second dose that brought him out of it for about 90 minutes. At that point he was able to do calculations and recall aspects of his life. The man, who remains hospitalized, has since received different, longer-lasting forms of benzodiazepines, a family of drugs that includes Valium, and barbiturates that allowed him to remain lucid 10 to 12 hours at a time. Kanner said the main problem doctors face now is trying to find a combination of drugs the man can take orally rather than intravenously that will prevent a relapse into the vegetative state. The traffic accident put the man into a coma that lasted four months, Kanner said. Soon after he recovered, his condition began to deteriorate, leaving him in the vegetative state two years after the wreck. The neurologist said that, as with most such patients, there was little known about how to treat the man's condition and little hope for recovery before March 12. ``I don't know what it is,'' Kanner said. ``It was just luck he had to have some dental work and it was just luck they administered the drugs.'' He said the man's case must be viewed as isolated until doctors have more time to study why benzodiazepines and particularly barbituates have the effect they do.

DOC.HEAD: Pledges Of Support and Boycotts Mount As Andrus Considers Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT spelling of governor's name to `Andrus,' sted `Andus.' INSERTS 2 grafs after 9th, `He acknowledged...' to UPDATE with comments from NARAL; picks up 10th graf pvs, `Andrus has...'
DOC.TEXT: Legislation establishing the nation's most restrictive state abortion law reached Gov. Cecil Andrus' desk Tuesday, and both camps in the abortion battle pumped up the pressure for him to sign or veto the bill. Molly Yard, president of the National Organization for Women, said in Washington that she would urge the group's national conference in June to launch a nationwide boycott of all Idaho products if the anti-abortion Democrat signs the bill. ``We're becoming concerned,'' said state Commerce Director James Hawkins. But Allen Wildmon, associate director of the Tupelo, Miss.-based conservative American Family Association, pledged that his members would buy more Idaho products to counter any boycott. The governor has until next Monday morning to act unless the Legislature adjourns before then. If that happens, as is expected, Andrus has 10 days from the time lawmakers leave. Both camps in the abortion battle flooded Andrus' office with telephone calls, letters and messages, and the governor met with a pro-choice Michigan state legislative candidate to discuss the issue. The candidate, Republican Gwen Dempsey, said she wanted to make Andrus aware of the economic risk he would be taking if he signed the bill. ``There's been a tremendous amount of it, people from outside the state getting involved,'' Andrus said after a 20-minute meeting with Dempsey. ``We in Idaho are perfectly capable of making our own decisions.''
