DOC.TEXT:
``Dead Poets Society'' (Touchstone. VHS-Beta, $89.95. Rated PG)
``Dead Poets Society'' was a surprise theatrical hit last year, winning Academy Award nominations for best picture, actor (Robin Williams) and Tom Schulman's original screenplay. Williams gives a tour de force performance as John Keating, a highly unorthodox and inspiring English teacher at an affluent New England prep school in the 1950s. He encourages his students to take risks and to believe in themselves and all possibilities. The real stars are the boys themselves, who revive a secret literary society, on which the movie hinges. This is a fulfilling video, one that will inspire the entire family. Another recent student-teacher video on the market is MGM's ``The Blackboard Jungle.'' This 1955 black and white movie stars Glenn Ford as a teacher in an inner city school filled with punks and thugs. A young Sidney Poitier plays a student. Here's a brief list of other noteworthy student-teacher videos: _``Goodbye, Mr. Chips'' (1939): Robert Donat gives an Oscar-winning and heartwarming performance as the Latin teacher Chips. Greer Garson is his wife. _``Cheers for Miss Bishop'' (1941): A warm and touching story in the tradition of ``Goodbye, Mr. Chips.'' The movie Stars Martha Scott as a Midwestern schoolteacher who devotes her entire life to teaching. _``The Corn Is Green'' (1945): Bette Davis stars as a school teacher who tries to help a young miner win a scholarship. _``Tom Brown's Schooldays'' (1950): Life at a boys school during Victorian England. Robert Newton is wonderful. Cedric Hardwicke and Freddie Bartholomew star in an earlier version (1940) titled ``Tom Brown's School Days.'' Limp compared to 1950 film, and filled with Hollywood cliches. _``Up the Down Staircase'' (1967): Sandy Dennis as a ditsy teacher in a New York City high school. _``To Sir With Love'' (1967): Sidney Poitier woos and wins over a bunch of trashy punks in London's East End. _``Children of a Lesser God'' (1986): An Academy Award-winning performance by Marlee Matlin as a deaf woman who falls in love with her teacher. _``Stand and Deliver'' (1988): Edward James Olmos was nominated for an Oscar for his portrayal of Jaime Escalante, who led his inner city math students to victory with the Advanced Placement test in calculus. _``The Chocolate War'' (1989): A student takes on a secret society at his Roman Catholic high school and his sadistic teacher.

In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Blue Sky Mining'' (CBS) _ Midnight Oil
``Blue Sky Mining'' represents an important moment in the career of Midnight Oil. The record is a chance for the Australian band to consolidate gains made with its last release, the U.S. breakthrough ``Diesel and Dust,'' in 1987. So what does Midnight Oil decide to sing about? The environment, malaise, world unity _ obvious choices at a time when socially conscious rock is a fad. Except that Midnight Oil has addressed such subjects for years; the band has always been more interested in making a point than making a buck. The point on ``Blue Sky Mining'' is that the world's a mess, if anyone cares. Often that message is eloquently stated by lead singer-social activist Peter Garrett. Two of the best cuts, ``River Runs Red'' and ``Blue Sky Mine,'' lament that man takes from the land but rarely puts anything back. ``Nothing's as precious as a hole in the ground,'' Garrett brays sarcastically in the latter. ``Forgotten Years,'' a variation on Billy Joel's ``We Didn't Start the Fire,'' assesses the current generation's place in history and concludes that it's time to give a damn. ``The desperate and divided years, these should not be forgotten years,'' Garrett sings. The final tracks, ``One Country'' and the wryly titled ``Antarctica,'' punctuate the record with two exclamation marks. The former is a plea for global harmony, the latter a plea for a place not yet fouled by mankind. Musically, the group is more restrained than in the past. For Garrett, the approach makes his words more evocative than ever. But the muted sound, which includes strings on much of Side 2, robs the rest of the band of some of its wallop. While ace guitarists Jim Moginie and Martin Rotsey are occasionally set loose _ the introduction to ``River Runs Red'' is glorious _ such instrumental peaks are frustratingly few. It's ironic that on an album so concerned about natural resources, Midnight Oil wastes some of its own. _ By Steven Wine, Associated Press Writer.

Tafelmusik, by Georg Philipp Telemann (Archiv) _ Musica Antiqua Koln, directed by Reinhard Goebel
If it's been said that Vivaldi wrote the same concerto hundreds of times, the saying also goes that Telemann wrote hundreds of concertos once. Or maybe it's the other way around. Anyway, this amazingly prolific contemporary of Bach and Handel composed more than 3,000 pieces, a bounty for the Telemann fan and a distinctly uninteresting fact for those who prefer Mozart, Beethoven or Brahms. As the fine liner notes in this typically handsome Archiv package point out, Tafelmusik, or Banquet Music, was not strictly intended as background for meals (though the modern CD-owner with a neutral attitude to Telemann may indeed put it to that use). Telemann wrote these pieces for sale to subscribers as a complete set. Scored for small groups of strings with, variously, flutes, recorder, oboes or trumpets, the works are divided into three parts. Each part is subdivided into five multimovement sections: suite, quartet, concert, trio and solo, followed by a conclusion. Tafelmusik is sort of like Telemann's Ring cycle. The sections are often performed or recorded separately. Archiv does a good service by issuing them complete in four discs, totaling more than four hours. The casual listener has the benefit of an excellent sample of Telemann's work, and the connoisseur has a complete version of one of Telemann's finest compositions. The performance is impeccable. In fact, too impeccable. The musicians, playing period instruments, are overly polite in their interpretation. The flutes, albeit not modern instruments, have a timid, almost boring sound. Some quite expressive playing, though, comes from the violins. The harpsichord continuo often overbalances the other instruments. _ By Daniel Wakin, Associated Press Writer.

On Show: Museum and Gallery Shows and Exhibits
DOC.TEXT: Columbia University is opening the first public gallery in New York devoted exclusively to architecture. The gallery space in Buell Hall, which was constructed in 1876, consists of 4,100 square feet. The building also houses the School of Architecture. The first exhibition in the new gallery opens April 4 and runs through May 11. ``The Filter of Reason: Work of Paul Nelson,'' focuses on the work of the American architect, movie set designer, painter and critic who taught and practiced architecture in the United States and France for more than 50 years. Nelson helped develop functionalism in the 1930s and '40s, a movement that rejected beaux-arts traditionalism. Elsewhere, the Solomon R. The Artists: Celebrating van Gogh
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: For a little over a year in 1888-89, Vincent van Gogh painted with a passionate frenzy, producing about 200 oils and 100 drawings. From this creative compulsion emerged some of the most popular works of art ever, van Gogh's vibrantly colored sunflowers, fishing boats and country scenes. A blockbuster exhibit of his most famous artworks is the centerpiece of a four-month extravaganza commemorating the 100th anniversary of the Dutch impressionist's death. More than 380 van Gogh paintings and drawings, insured for a record $3.1 billion, are on display in two Dutch museums. They include ``Self Portrait With Bandaged Ear,'' ``Starry Night'' and ``Night Cafe,'' as well as dozens of drawings so vulnerable to light that they have never been shown in public, according to the event's organizers. Along with the exhibit in Amsterdam's Vincent van Gogh Museum and the Kroeller-Mueller Museum in the central Netherlands town of Otterlo, the commemorative program includes a dozen other art exhibitions, an opera and a film festival. Commemorative posters by 20 contemporary artists, including Czechoslovak Jiri Kolar, Dutchman Willem de Kooning and American Roy Lichtenstein have been run off to help offset the $11.5 million exhibition cost. ``Lots of people can relate to van Gogh's artworks because they're so full of color. But his life fascinates people, too,'' said Madeleine Wardenaar of the Van Gogh 1990 Foundation, which is organizing the program. ``He's really the romantic artist, with drama playing a part in every period of his life.'' Born on March 30, 1853, in the southern Netherlands village of Zundert, van Gogh struggled with poverty, loneliness and periodic bouts of madness until he died after firing a rifle into his chest on July 29, 1890. During his troubled life, van Gogh rode an emotional rollercoaster. After he mutilated himself by removing his ear, he said the Bible had instructed him to cut off the ``offending organ.'' One of his closest relationships was with the French painter Paul Gauguin, with whom he had an affair. They spent endless hours arguing. Van Gogh also was a voluminous letter writer. During that 444-day period in 1888-89, he wrote about 200 letters. In a Sept. 19, 1888, letter to his brother, Theo, van Gogh describes ``Starry Night'': ``The sky is blue-green, the water is royal blue, the soil is mauve. The city is blue and violet, the gas light yellow. ... On the blue-green field of the sky the Great Bear, sparkling green and pink, a reflection whose modest shine contrasts with the powerful gold of the gas light. Two colorful figures of a lovers' couple on the foreground.'' The painting, in which the artist departed from his usual method of applying small dots of contrasting colors on the cloth to form a pattern, has bold, linear brush strokes. Van Gogh enjoyed considerable acclaim among his fellow artists during his lifetime, but experts disagree whether he sold three paintings or just one, according to Wardenaar. Today, his works fetch record prices at art auctions around the globe. His ``Irises'' became the most expensive work ever auctioned when Sotheby's sold it for $53.90 million on Nov. 11, 1987. The painting subsequently was sold to the Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., after Australian tycoon Alan Bond could not repay a loan Sotheby's had posted for the sale. ``Sunflowers'' went for $39.92 million in March 1987. ``The Trinquetalle Bridge'' brought $20.24 million in a June 1987 auction. The van Gogh exhibit is expected to attract 1.5 million visitors. The Amsterdam museum, home of the world's largest van Gogh collection, will display 135 paintings, including 80 borrowed from museums and private collections in Paris, London, New York, Boston, Moscow and Zurich. A total of 248 van Gogh drawings and watercolors are going on display in the museum in Otterlo, 62 miles from the Dutch capital. Despite the theft in Otterlo of three van Gogh paintings in 1988, the exhibit's organizers had little trouble getting the works they wanted from foreign lenders, Wardenaar said. The stolen paintings, recovered unharmed several months later, included an early version of van Gogh's famous ``The Potato Eaters.'' Their total worth was estimated at more than $10.5 million. Security during transport and the exhibit itself is expected to be extremely tight, although no details are being disclosed. Wardenaar said the huge insurance package is costing organizers $2.1 million and will cover only the borrowed artworks. Those owned by the Dutch museums are uninsured, in line with Culture Ministry policy. The centenary exhibit is organized along the thematic lines that van Gogh himself described in the hundreds of letters he wrote to his brother from France, where he lived most of his life. ``He said quite explicitly in the letters how he wanted his paintings displayed,'' Wardenaar said, adding the exhibit will include some works in several versions in order to illustrate their development. In an April 21, 1888, letter to the painter Emile Bernard, van Gogh wrote from the southern French city of Arles: ``Here's a new `Orchard,' fairly simple in composition: a white tree, a small green tree, a square bit of green, a purple patch of soil, an orange roof, a large blue sky. I have nine more `Orchards' coming: a white, a pink, an almost red, a blue-white, and pink and gray, a green and a pink one. Yesterday, I botched a cloth: a `Cherry Tree' against a blue sky, the sprouting leaves were orange and gold, the flower clusters white: all that against the blue-green of the sky. It was simply wonderful.'' Also part of the centenary extravaganza is an opera by the Dutch composer Jan van Vlijmen, ``Unhappy Man Dressed in Black,'' which focuses on the final years of the artist's life. In the western city of Haarlem, there will be an exhibit of 75 works by the 17th century Dutch master Frans Hals, whom van Gogh strongly admired, including works on loan from the National Gallery in Washington and the Royal Academy in London. Several exhibitions in Amsterdam and elsewhere will illustrate van Gogh's effect on contemporary artists. The van Gogh anniversary also has attracted mass merchandising. American Express is offering a van Gogh bust by Dutch artist Theo Melchior. It sells for $490. There also are van Gogh wines, after-shave lotion, T-shirts, watches and gold-framed prints of his paintings for $630 each. Dutch companies sponsoring the van Gogh centenary are setting up a ``Van Gogh Village'' to promote their products on Amsterdam's Museum Square, although Wardenaar said everything was being done to make the display as dignified as possible. The centenary exhibit runs through July 29. Tickets, on sale by Ticketron in the United States, and available in some European countries, sell for $12.50 each and must be ordered in advance. They will give access to one of the museums at a specific time and date, although visitors can then stay as long as they want.

The Artists: Search for Van Gogh Depended on Telephone
With BC-WKD--Van Gogh, b0821
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Ken Wilkie believes his 18 years of digging for facts about Vincent van Gogh lights up hitherto dark places in the life and loves of the world's most popular artist. ``I looked in the places no one had bothered with before, like the telephone book,'' said Wilkie, whose new book about his quest, ``The Van Gogh File,'' was recently published. In the Netherlands, museums are busy preparing exhibitions of paintings and drawings by van Gogh to mark the centennial of the Dutch artist whose works have become the most expensive in art history. Van Gogh was poor all his life and could not sell his work. But in eight months in 1987, three paintings by him of irises, sunflowers and a bridge sold for $114 million. At one time, van Gogh's paintings were used for target practice. Wilkie said he discovered that at St. Remy mental hospital, where Van Gogh was a voluntary patient in 1889, the son of the doctor in charge and a friend used the artist's canvasses that he had left behind as targets for their bows and arrows. ``Only much later, when van Gogh became so famous, did they realize what they had destroyed,'' Wilkie said. He said he was told of the archery targets by the grandson of van Gogh's guard at the hospital. Wilkie tracked down the man and others connected with van Gogh through telephone calls in the Netherlands, Belgium, England and France where the artist lived during his 37 years. ``I called people of the same name in the telephone book,'' said Wilkie, 47, a Scottish journalist from Dundee who lives in Amsterdam. The book revises and updates his first book on the artist in 1978, ``The Van Gogh Assignment,'' which evolved from an article he was asked to write in 1972. His first break in 1972 was a chance meeting with Vincent Willem van Gogh, then 83, son of the artist's brother, Theo. ``Willem was a year old when he was held in the arms of Vincent, who shot himself two months later,'' Wilkie said. ``All the old people I spoke to in the first few years are now dead.'' He listed his most important discoveries as a drawing by van Gogh of the house in London where he lodged in 1873; a photograph of Eugenie Loyer, the landlady's daughter who rejected van Gogh's offer of marriage; and the information out that Vincent and Theo were both treated for syphilis. ``Eugenie's rejection had a profound effect on the course of van Gogh's immediate life, and the disease explains many curious actions of the brothers,'' said Wilkie. ``Vincent was fired from his job in a London art dealer's after he began telling the customers what he really thought of the rubbish on the walls. He then became obsessed with religion and feelings of compassion for the poor,'' Wilkie said. ``I think the syphilis was responsible for his schizophrenia and fits, and for Theo dying paralyzed and insane six months after Vincent.'' Wilkie said that by going to places where van Gogh had been, he uncovered things that aren't in art history books. ``There are scores of art history books about Van Gogh but they tend to rely on what other art historians have written,'' he said. In south London, at 87 Hackford Road, a blue plaque on a three-story row house records that Van Gogh lived there in 1873-74. Arthur Smith, a retired sanitary inspector who is the current occupant, said nothing remains of the artist except an old outdoor toilet that he probably used. ``We get film crews and lots of Japanese tourists and we get nothing for it,'' he said. ``We can't even park the car.'' ``Do you think I could auction the blue plaque?''

Music Makers: The Importance of Laughing at Yourself, and Others
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It's important, Nick Lowe says, for musicians to have a sense of humor. He's hoping English pop star Rick Astley feels the same way. That's because Astley and his hit song, ``Never Gonna Give You Up,'' is the subject of a verse on ``All Men Are Liars,'' a cut on Lowe's new album. Since Lowe rhymes ``Astley'' with ``ghastly,'' it's not exactly a tribute. ``I didn't really go after him, I went after this horrible song that he sang _ `Never going to tell a lie, never going to do anything horrible to you. I'm always going to be this lump of jelly, this pathetic creature,''' Lowe said. ``They tell me _ I've never met Rick _ that he's a very nice man and will think this is quite amusing,'' Lowe said. ``I hope so.'' Lowe's humor _ sometimes perverse, sometimes cornball _ is never far from the surface. This is a man who's written songs such as ``Time Wounds All Heels'' and ``(Hey Big Mouth) Stand Up and Say That.'' When David Bowie released an album called ``Low,'' Lowe retaliated with ``Bowi.'' Critics, however, accuse Lowe of being glib and not showing enough care in his craft. For every joke that hits, several fall flat. After two minor classic albums in the late 1970s, and a hit single with ``Cruel to Be Kind,'' Lowe's name hasn't been seen on too many record charts. The back cover of Lowe's 1987 ``Pinker and Prouder Than Previous'' album shows Lowe with his back to a brick wall, gazing mournfully at an out-of-reach sign that said ``Marketplace.'' Not many people noticed the irony, since few people bought the record. ``I've made some really terrible records,'' Lowe conceded. ``I've done my best, but if you're no good, you're no good. That's the way it goes.'' The 40-year-old Liverpool native said he spent much of the last two years watching television, suffering from a crisis of confidence. ``I went through a pretty desperate time,'' he said. ``My band packed in. ... I couldn't work out how I fit into the music business. ... How is it that on paper I'm a washed-up old has-been? Yet, personally, I feel I haven't started yet?'' Lowe, who favors country and blues-inflected records that sound as if they were cut live in the studio, said he watched with dismay as music became more mechanized through the 1980s. Music by typists, he called it. His first step in a ``comeback'' came when pal Elvis Costello invited Lowe to be an opening act on a solo acoustic tour. Standing in front of an audience with just a guitar teaches you quickly whether a song is working or not, he said. It made him take the craft of songwriting more seriously, he said. And luckily for Lowe, in the audience for a solo show at London's Mean Fiddler club was an old friend, Warner Bros. Records executive Andrew Wickham. Lowe's contract with Columbia Records in the United States had just run out. ``It was a tough crowd, a lot of hecklers and drunken Irishmen,'' Wickham recalled. ``He won them over immediately just through sheer wit. He held the room, he commanded the room. It's not many people who can do that. That's one of the main reasons why I signed him.'' Lowe quips that he ``sneaked into Warner Bros. on Elvis Costello's coattails.'' Costello, who's had several of his albums produced by Lowe, recently switched from Columbia Records to Warner Bros. The 11 compositions on ``Party of One'' are the same frothy pop confections for which Lowe is known. Despite songs such as ``Jumbo Ark'' and ``Shting-Shtang,'' Lowe's choice of colleagues shows a seriousness of purpose he's not always had. Dave Edmunds produced ``Party of One'' and Ry Cooder and Jim Keltner also performed. Lowe likes material that is funny, even when it's not overtly comical. The sneak attack on Astley is not unprecedented. His first album similarly ridiculed the Bay City Rollers. ``I can only do and say what I think,'' he said. ``I'll get up some people's noses, perhaps, but if I get up some people's noses, they've really got to be insecure.'' In the course of a 30-minute interview, he mocks Phil Collins (``Why doesn't he just get out of the way and let someone else have a go?''), Richard Marx and Bad English. And Nick Lowe. For instance, he said the songs on ``Basher,'' his recent compilation CD, were chosen by taking a list of all the songs he's ever recorded and ``crossing out all the ones that under no circumstances did we want to be reminded of.'' Commercial success is nice, but he's not willing to sell his soul for it, Lowe said. It heartens him to see someone whose work he respects does well, such as when Bonnie Raitt won four Grammy awards last month. ``I spoke to her last week, and she's cool enough not to be cool about it,'' he said. ``She's just grooving out. She was so charming. I said to her, `Bonnie, this is great for all of us, you getting rich. It makes all of us look cool. If people find out that I hang around with you, it's going to make me look fabulous.''' Lowe has no band now, but he's thinking about forming one to tour later this year. He turned down an invitation to join Edmunds' tour with Dion, Graham Parker and Kim Wilson because he didn't think his old friend would be able to organize it. He's philosophic about how ``Party of One'' will fare. ``I hope people will hear it, because it's got the ring of truth about it,'' he said. ``If they don't, too bad. We'll just do another.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: What's Wrong With Colleges, Professors ...
DOC.TEXT: The academic world has hardly finished licking its wounds from Allan Bloom's runaway best seller, ``The Closing of the American Mind.'' Bloom's premise, which fit perfectly the college-bashing mood of the 1980s orchestrated by former U.S. Secretary of Education William Bennett, held that all was well on U.S. campuses until the '60s when students began asking rude questions, called ancient verities mere opinions and even placed Mick Jagger and his ilk above Bloom's beloved Plato and Aristotle as popular icons. Now comes a more radical and even bleaker broadside aimed at academe, ``Killing the Spirit: Higher Education in America'' (Viking Press, $19.95), by the historian Page Smith. No, Smith says, all was not well at U.S. colleges before the '60s. Any talk of ``the good old days'' simply doesn't jibe with the history of higher education in this country. The crisis afflicting America's campuses is nothing new, writes Smith. Nor, he admits, are his criticisms. He proceeds in this powerful work to add fresh and fascinating detail to the history of higher education. What we learn is that from its colonial beginnings to this day, the system has been fundamentally flawed, fostering in students and teachers alike a leaden conformity over creativity. And in its obeisance to the great god Science, college education has lost its direction _ and its soul. ``I'm not optimistic about piecemeal reforms at this stage,'' Smith said in a telephone interview from his home in Santa Cruz, Calif., where he writes a syndicated column on old age and is an emeritus professor at the University of California-Santa Cruz. Smith was the founding provost of UC-Santa Cruz and author of numerous historical works, including an eight-volume history of the United States. He said he was moved to write ``Killing the Spirit'' after he learned of an aspiring college teacher who almost saw his career hopes derailed by his academic judges because he invoked the name of a German historian, Eugen Rosenstock-Huessy, whose ideas were considered heretical. By coincidence, Smith had been initially denied for graduate work at Harvard 40 years earlier because he had studied under Rosenstock-Huessy and had similarly invoked that historian's name, to the chagrin of Harvard's history department. It occurred to Smith that colleges were not, and never have been, the ``marketplaces of ideas'' many believe them to be. Instead, schools have long practiced what he calls ``academic fundamentalism,'' meaning woe to any student or teacher with the courage to stray from the intellectual orthodoxy of the moment. ``I thought, my God, can the academic world be that rigid, that doctrinaire?'' Smith said. Indeed it can, he argues. None of academia's sacred cows escapes Smith's critical lance. The tenure system requires that teachers publish mountains of useless research. Academic departments are intellectually stultifying and command a teacher's first loyalty. The lecture system is simply an unnatural and boring way of transmitting knowledge. The ``social nonsciences'' and the ``inhuman humanities,'' as Smith dubs them, have sold their ouls in their wholly unsuccessful efforts to be viewed as Science with a capital S. He calls anthropology ``arguably the funniest academic discipline. There is something faintly ridiculous about a sober white anthropologist asking impertinent questions of quizzical aborigines and writing down the answers.'' Of both anthropology and sociology, Smith writes: ``The treatment of people as objects of scrutiny, scientific or not, is, when one thinks about it, pretty deplorable. ...'' Psychology, supposedly the study of the human psyche, the soul, has denied the existence of the soul as ``unscientific.'' And in this soul-less state, Smith says psychology has much to answer for: lobotomies, shock therapy, involuntary drug experimentation and the perfection of ways to manipulate people into buying things they don't want or need. History, in one of its latest pseudoscientific form, is called Cliometrics by its practitioners, who feed voting data, property rolls and the like into computers. One egregious result of such historical number crunching was a 1974 work, ``Time on the Cross,'' which purported to show with charts and graphs that most American slaves were happy and that slavery as an institution had merely gotten a bad press. And economics is no more a science than the other social ``nonsciences,'' no matter how hard it contends otherwise. ``It has, in the final analysis, to deal with human behavior, and human behavior remains maddeningly unpredictable, fortunately,'' Smith writes. And in a chapter certain to raise feminist hackles, Smith says women's studies that mushroomed on campuses since the '60s are clearly out of hand. ``The image that women students carry away with them on graduation must be of a world hopelessly divided into exploiting males and oppressed females,'' he writes. Professors, meanwhile, complain about the ``publish or perish'' system. They also complain about their ``teaching load'' which, over the years, has grown ever lighter. One wonders what these seemingly misanthropic souls want besides their sabbaticals. Interestingly, Smith singles out community colleges for praise. Teachers in such schools have a sense of mission and closeness to their students too often lacking in loftier institutions, he says. Smith's book is descriptive, in the manner of the historian. It is no blueprint for reform. It offers only the broadest prescription: a belief in smaller, more personal colleges that somehow reconcile the scientific with the spiritual.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Lee Mitgang has covered education for The Associated Press since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Nashville Sound: Earl Thomas Conley Likes To Cry
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Country music performer Earl Thomas Conley says it feels good to get wrapped up in a song and cry. And Conley, who's been at the top of the country charts for the past decade, has broken down a few times on stage and in the recording studio. ``You get so caught up that you are convinced,'' he said in an interview. ``That's when it's really nice. You are totally relating to it.'' His songs about love, yearning and hardships are familiar fare on the nartion's 2,100 country music radio stations. The introspective, philosophical Conley has an impressive 18 No. 1 records to his credit since his first one in 1981, ``Fire and Ice.'' He has two ``greatest hits'' albums. But the 48-year-old performer is not content. ``You get lazy when you get satisfied,'' Conley said. ``You're asleep when you're satisfied. Then you wake up and your career is over because you are only as strong as the record you have out at the time. ``You can work in this business for five years on what you have done, but the idea is to pretend you are never going to quit. That way, you get better with each endeavor. That way you continue to grow and be refreshing. ``And you continue to be totally alive in your music and in your life period. I think you always need a challenge.'' Conley was the third of eight children born to a railroad worker in Portsmouth, Ohio. The family was poor and he wore hand-me-downs. He wanted to paint pictures, but gravitated toward country music while in the Army. Later, he began writing songs during a series of factory and steel mill jobs in Ohio. During breaks on his job at a steel mill, he played his guitar in the locker room. For a long time, he commuted to Nashville every few months, trying vainly to generate interest in his work. In 1970, he moved to Huntsville, Ala., and again worked at manual labor while singing in nightclubs seven nights a week. He finally moved to Nashville in 1973, signed a recording contract and became a country music favorite singing thought-provoking songs he wrote himself. In 1984, his album ``Don't Make It Easy for Me'' had four No. 1 singles: the title cut, ``Holding Her and Loving You,'' ``Your Love's on the Line'' and ``Angel in Disguise.'' His other hit records include ``Somewhere Between Right and Wrong,'' ``I Have Loved You Girl,'' ``Chance of Loving You,'' ``Nobody Falls Like a Fool,'' ``What I'd Say'' and ``Right From the Start.'' He's also been successful singing duets, joining Emmylou Harris on the No. 1 country record ``We Believe in Happy Endings'' in 1988. He also sang a duet with Anita Pointer of the Pointer Sisters, ``Too Many Times,'' which was the title cut of his 1986 album. He said one reason he's done well is because of his attention to originality. ``I always look for new ways of doing things. If I write a waltz, the next thing I do is as far opposite as I can find. And I usually don't go back and review my old material or anyone else's. Instead I look for a new way to do things and new ways of feeling things,'' he said. Despite his steady success, he's rarely received an award for his music. He's gone largely unnoticed at awards shows while country performers like Randy Travis, Hank Williams Jr. and George Strait packed their trophy cases. ``It's disappointing,'' Conley said. ``There are other people doing good things in this industry, but it seems like people turn their eyes to them (and not me).'' In the meantime, though, Conley has been fighting a singer's nightmare: voice trouble. He took 2{ months off the road last fall because of a strained voice and bronchitis. Early this year he rescheduled concert dates for six weeks because of a recurrence of the problem. A biopsy was considered at one point but ruled out as unnecessary.
