DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Miles Davis, the legendary jazz musician whose oil paintings and etchings have won him a new legion of admirers, will be honored at Artexpo NY 1990, one of the world's largest contemporary art exhibitions. Davis, who in February received the lifetime achievement Grammy award to add to his six previous Grammys and 26 nominations, has drawn critical acclaim for his artwork as well. His works, which will be exhibited by Triangle Galleries at Artexpo, have been shown around the world. The reception honoring him on March 29 is to benefit Learning Through Art-The Guggenheim Museum Children's Program, which administers workshops in New York City and New Jersey elementary schools to help children learn to read by stimulating their interest in art. It is affiliated with the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, which provides exhibition space for works of children who participate in the program. Artexpo NY 1990 will be March 29-April 2 at the Jacob K. Javits Center. Approximately 600 exhibitors will be showing more than 50,000 works of art.

Now you can see all the Broadway shows you never got around to seeing all at once. ``Starlight Express,'' ``The Phantom of the Opera,'' ``42nd Street,'' ``Cats,'' ``Me and My Girl,'' ``Les Misarables'' and ``Anything Goes'' will make a collective appearance on canvas. Melanie Taylor Kent, world-renowned Americana artist and confirmed lover of the Broadway musical, has created a unique work of art that details every aspect of the theater _ from performers to costume sets. The painting makes its debut March 28 in Shubert Alley for the benefit of Actors Equity Fights AIDS. Proceeds from Kent's work are expected to garner $80,000 for Actor's Equity.

After an 11-year absence, Radio City Music Hall is bringing back an Easter show to its huge stage. The $5 million ``Easter Extravaganza'' will open April 11 with ``The Glory of Easter,'' a traditional religious spectacle centered around a gothic cathedral surrounded by 150 lily sprays and 100 large candles. Other segments include New York at the turn of the century and the Easter parade, a fantasy rabbit and tortoise bit and performing orchestral instruments. The high-kicking Rockettes also will be featured in the show, which runs to April 23. Radio City's last Easter show was in 1979 when the art deco palace was about to close down. The legendary structure was declared a landmark and saved from demolition and has spent the past decade refurbishing its productions and programs.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Release Anytime

DOC.TEXT: Rising mortgage interest rates last month curbed demand for existing homes, causing sales to drop 2.3 percent to their slowest pace in seven months, a real estate trade group reported. The National Association of Realtors said Monday that resales of single-family homes dipped to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.44 million units as mortgage interest rates remained in the double-digits. Fixed-rate mortgages rose from 10.17 percent to 10.31 percent last month, according to national surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.

The Federal Reserve isn't likely to budge from its tight-money stance when policy-makers meet this week, private analysts say. The forecast Monday would mean that a variety of business and consumer interest rates _ including mortgage rates _ will stay about where they are over the next couple of months. Fed policy-makers will convene behind closed doors Tuesday to review economic developments and make decisions on what adjustments are needed in monetary strategy.

The savings and loan industry lost a record $19.17 billion in 1989 and after posting its worst fourth-quarter loss, the government said. The fourth-quarter loss totaled $6.5 billion, up from $4.97 billion in the July-September period, and pushed the yearly total to a third consecutive record deficit. The deficit was $13.4 billion in 1988 and $7.8 billion in 1987.

Rising prices and growing demand soon will push the U.S. bill for imported oil higher than the nation's 1990 trade deficit, former Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger told Congress. ``There is a strong possibility of a 30 percent or 40 percent increase in prices'' in the 1990s, Schlesinger said Monday in presenting the Senate Energy Committee a gloomy summary of the world oil outlook. Meanwhile, the Bush administration said the U.S. trade deficit is not expected to improve in the next two years to the extent that it did in the past two, and it could worsen.

New York's budget woes took a dramatic turn for the worse as Wall Street's two major rating agencies lowered the state's credit rating, leaving it with the third worst rating among the 50 states. Monday's credit downgradings by Standard & Poor's Corp. and Moody's Investors Service Inc. could cost New York taxpayers millions of dollars in higher interest payments on the state's debt. Only Massachusetts and Louisiana are rated as worse credit risks than New York now. ``We're behind West Virginia, for Christ's sake,'' complained state Comptroller Edward Regan.

AT&T jumped into the credit card business with Mastercard and Visa cards that allow its customers to charge long-distance telephone calls. The phone giant said Monday that its AT&T Universal Card would charge no annual fee ever for customers who sign up his year and make at least one purchase annually.

Gillette Co. said it dropped plans to acquire the Wilkinson blade and razor business in the United States as part of an antitrust settlement with the federal government. Gillette, the world leader in the razor industry, announced in December it was helping finance a buyout of Wilkinson's Swedish owner. Under the deal, Gillette said it would acquire the Wilkinson blade and razor business outside of Europe. But that part of the plan was dropped Monday.

The Supreme Court said it will study the power of employers to exclude females of child-bearing age from hazardous jobs, a case that could affect millions of working women. The court agreed on Monday to review a ruling that let a Milwaukee-based manufacturer of automobile batteries ban women who cannot prove they are infertile from jobs that expose them to lead. The fetal protection policy is being challenged as a form of illegal sex discrimination because it bans women from high-paying, if hazardous, jobs.

A brokerage house that fired a gaming industry analyst who issued a negative critique of Donald Trump's newest casino project has tarnished its image and increased skepticism about investment advice, industry observers said. Marvin Roffman, an analyst for 16 years with Janney Montgomery Scott Inc., was fired last Friday. Roffman said he had refused Trump's demand that he retract comments made to The Wall Street Journal about what he deemed gloomy prospects for Trump's Taj Mahal Casino Resort in Atlantic City, N.J. Janney Montgomery stated Monday that Roffman was fired for violating company policies, not because of his negative public comments about the Taj Mahal. But a number of experts said the dispute highlighted doubts that many investors had about the validity of securities firm research.

The stock market managed a small gain Monday, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials settled for a 3.38 gain at 2,707.66. Bond prices closed slightly higher. The dollar advanced against the Japanese yen but was mixed against other currencies. Gold futures prices plummeted as much as $30 an ounce; soybean futures surged; grains were higher; copper futures fell; pork bellies rose sharply while livestock futures were mixed; and energy futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: NBC, McDonald's Team Up on Promotion for Fall TV Season
DOC.TEXT: For the second consecutive year, the television ratings leader in prime time is taking on a partner in a promotion designed to drum up viewers for its new fall season. The National Broadcasting Co.'s NBC television network and McDonald's Corp., the king of fast food, said Monday they would team up on a game-like promotion this fall that they said would be the most extensive ever for TV, reaching a potential 60 million people daily. The companies declined to provide details of the effort, saying they didn't want to give competitors a chance to copy it. NBC and CBS each had joint promotions with major retailers last fall. The networks say they have had to become more aggressive in getting people to look at their shows because of the growing competition from independent stations, cable television and programs and films on videocassettes. Last fall, NBC had a joint promotion with Sears Roebuck & Co., the nation's largest retailer, that gave viewers a chance to win trips to Hollywood to be on NBC programs plus other assorted prizes. CBS had a joint promotion with K mart Corp. last fall, and may offer another promotion with the Michigan-based retailer this year, according to CBS senior vice president George Schweitzer. Some advertising executies have questioned the value of such promotions, but CBS and NBC executives say last year's efforts boosted awareness of their programs and encouraged more people to tune in at least once. ``Last year's promotion was highly successful for CBS and for K mart,'' Schweitzer said. He said CBS's ratings for season premieres last fall were up 28 percent from the previous year, when the start of the season was delayed by a writer's strike, and 10 percent from 1987, when the season started on time. Schweitzer said the promotion also helped K mart post its biggest sales gain of the year during the three-week period. Mary Jean Houde, a spokeswoman for Chicago-based Sears, said Sears felt its promotion with NBC last year brought more customers into the store even though sales in stores open at least a year fell 1.8 percent last September compared with the previous year. She said the decline in so-called comparable store sales, the indicator many analysts use to gauge how a retailer is doing, reflected weakness in appliance and furniture sales rather than any problem with the promotion. She declined to comment on Sears' plans for promotions this year, but said, ``We don't often repeat a specific promotional event.'' NBC and McDonald's said their effort has the potential to reach many more people every day than either the NBC-Sears or CBS-K mart promotions did. With 209 affiliates, NBC said its schedule of shows can reach 42 million viewers nightly while McDonald's serves 17 million customers a day at its 8,400 U.S. restaurants. John Miller, executive vice president for marketing at NBC-TV, said last year's promotion with Sears ``did increase sampling somewhat although not as much as we would have liked.'' Nonetheless, he said, NBC gained valuable experience that it hopes to use this year. He said about 3 million people entered last year's promotion and that this year it was hoped ``considerably more, maybe a million a day'' would enter. McDonald's has conducted a number of promotions itself in recent years, including games based on the board games Monopoly and Scrabble and giveaways linked to the movies ``The Little Mermaid'' and ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids.''

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Enters Credit Card Business
LaserPhoto NY32 of March 26
DOC.TEXT: AT&T has entered the crowded credit card business with Mastercard and Visa cards that promise no annual fees and offer a discount on long-distance calls. The AT&T Universal Card can be used to charge long-distance phone calls on the company's telephone network as well as the traditional goods and services billed to charge cards. The phone giant kicked off an advertising blitz during Monday night's Academy Awards broadcast to highlight some of the card's features, including: _No annual fee ever for customers who sign up his year and make at least one purchase annually. _Rental-car insurance, purchase protection and extended product warranties, which usually are provided exclusively with ``gold'' bank credit cards aimed at high-income customers. _A 10 percent discount from the regular credit-card rate on phone calls charged to the card. The card carries an annual interest rate of 8.9 percentage points above the prime rate, which currently is 10 percent. Credit card and phone call charges will appear on the same bill. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. officials said the card would be offered to those of its 70 million long-distance phone subscribers who pass credit checks. For customers who choose it, the Universal Card will supplant the existing AT&T phone card, which only can be used to charge calls. About 40 million phone cards are in circulation. Some industry analysts praised the move by the nation's largest long-distance phone company. ``You've got a company with a very well-known name and already in the wallets of a lot of people trying to expand that wallet share into the most profitable segment of financial services,'' said Mark Lynch, who follows the banking industry for Bear Stearns & Co. But Spencer Nilson, publisher of a trade letter on the credit card industry, said AT&T would have a hard time making a profit without charging an annual fee. Nilson said he believed the move was motivated more by AT&T's need to hang on to its long-distance customers, who increasingly are being lured away by MCI Communications Corp. and US Sprint, the No. 2 and 3 long-distance carriers. From this perspective, Nilson called the credit cards ``a very smart move.'' In December, US Sprint began issuing a Sprint Visa Card that also acts as a phone charge card. The card carries a $25 annual fee. The company said its motivation was to increase the use of its phone network. MCI has said it has no plans to issue credit cards. AT&T will issue its cards through Universal Bank, a subsidiary of Synovus Financial Corp., a bank holding company based in Columbus, Ga. Total System Services Inc., a credit card service company controlled by Synovus, will process the transactions from the cards. Under its agreement with Synovus, AT&T will share profits and buy card receivables, the money owed from customer charges. Receivables frequently are bundled into securities that are traded like bonds on Wall Street. AT&T also has the right to buy up to 1.5 million newly issued shares of Total System Services stock. The company has 15.9 million shares outstanding. To run the credit card operation, AT&T hired scores of credit card industry veterans, including Paul Kahn, former head of First Chicago Corp.'s card division, who will run the new division. AT&T originally considered issuing its own credit card to compete with MasterCard and Visa, but backed out after market research showed consumers wanted to consolidate their cards rather than have another one, Kahn told reporters at a news conference. Industry analysts said fierce competition in the credit-card industry also may have dissuaded AT&T from the plan. Sears, Roebuck and Co.'s Discover Card was the last separate card to break into the industry, and the retailer endured several years of steep losses before it turned the operation around. Alex W. Hart, president and chief executive officer of Mastercard International, said the AT&T card could steal customers away from other issuers of MasterCard and Visa. However, he said, the AT&T card should expand the overall market share for those cards.

DOC.HEAD: Wang Plans Future After Founder's Death
DOC.TEXT: Finding a successor to its late founder, An Wang, should not be as difficult for Wang Laboratories Inc. as it may be for the company to rebound from recent losses and regain customer confidence. The board of directors of the Lowell-based company is scheduled to meet Wednesday to discuss who will succeed Wang as chairman and chief executive officer. Wang, who struggled against cancer for months, died Saturday at age 70. But while the company has struggled recently, analysts said the company already made an important leadership change last year when it named Richard Miller as president. Miller took the job from Wang's son, Frederick Wang, who was ousted after the company's fortunes tumbled. Analysts expect Miller to take the CEO job and possibly ascend to chairman. In a statement after his father's death, Frederick Wang said on behalf of his family, ``We support Rick Miller and the other members of the Wang management team in their efforts to build a strong and growing company.'' The statement said the family ``believes that the long-term plan now being implemented to return the company to profitability will achieve its objectives.'' Under the leadership of the company's founder, Wang became a multibillion-dollar company, largely as a pioneer in word processors. But analysts said the company stumbled when it failed to react quickly to the growth in personal computers, which largely replaced the need for word processors. The company moved into the mid-range computer market, but that segment has been slumping, and Wang posted a $424.3 million loss for the year that ended last June 30. Since Miller, a former General Electric Co. executive, took over in August, he slashed the work force and sold off assets to reduce the company's debt. Wang now employs about 22,500 people, compared with 28,000 at the end of the last fiscal year. Its bank debt has shrunk from $575 million to under $100 million. Also under Miller, Wang has moved out of its ``closed,'' or proprietary, products and said it will make more equipment that uses increasingly popular industrywide standards. This strategy is part of Miller's plan to make Wang more responsive to customer needs. ``I think the big changes have already occurred,'' said Fred Pastore, an analyst at Moody's Investors Service Inc. ``I think we will see a much more focused Wang.'' ``Wang has made the kind of moves the company needs to make to survive,'' said Steven Wendler, an analyst at the research firm Gartner Group Inc. Wang is becoming better aligned with the market, Wendler said, but Miller still must solve the company's poor history of customer service that has left many clients unhappy. While some analysts speculate that Wang could become a takeover target, Wendler described the customer service as an ``Achilles heel'' that could dissuade potential suitors. ``Wang has a large installed base, but it's an unhappy installed base,'' Wendler said. ``If you're an investor, you look at it like damaged goods. ``The long term for Wang is still very cloudy,'' he said. In the company statement, the Wang family said it ``intends to retain their ownership position'' in the company. The family effectively has control over the company, with the power to elect three-quarters of the board of directors. Part of Wang's long-term strategy is to concentrate on image processing, in which computers store and manipulate the actual images of documents. Analysts say the market for image processing is expected to grow to $3 billion annually in the next few years.

DOC.HEAD: Gillette Says It Won't Acquire Wilkinson U.S. Business in Antitrust Case
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials say they are protecting competition by blocking Gillette Co. from acquiring the Wilkinson blade and razor business in the United States. Gillette officials say the federal action is not a serious setback, insisting their main interest is in Wilkinson's business in other parts of the world. Gillette and the U.S. Justice Department announced a settlement Monday in which Gillette dropped its plans to acquire the U.S. razor business of Wilkinson. The action follows statements last year by Bush administration officials that the government intends to promote competition through tighter enforcement of antitrust laws. Gillette, the world leader in the razor industry, announced in December it was helping finance a buyout of Wilkinson's Swedish owner. Under the deal, Gillette said it would acquire the Wilkinson blade and razor business outside of Europe. Gillette also said it would gain nonvoting interest in the newly created Netherlands company, Eemland Management Services BV, which would retain the European Wilkinson business as well as worldwide match and lighter operations. But the Justice Department filed an antitrust suit in January, saying the deal could reduce competition in the United States and hurt consumers. Gillette officials said that after the suit was filed, the company indicated it would not acquire the Wilkinson U.S. business, and under the settlement, Gillette agreed not to do so in the future. ``We felt it did not violate the antitrust law. We still feel it doesn't,'' said David Fausch, a Gillette spokesman. But he said Gillette did not consider Wilkinson's U.S. business large enough to justify a lengthy and costly court case. Gillette said the settlement would not affect any other aspect of the transaction. Wilkinson's U.S. business will remain under the control of the Netherlands company, Fausch said. ``The proposed final judgment would permit Wilkinson Sword to remain an efficient and independent competitor in the United States market,'' James F. Rill, assistant U.S. attorney general, said in a statement. Under the proposed settlement, which must be approved in court, Gillette also would be prevented from acquiring Wilkinson's production facilities in Europe that are used to supply the United States. The agreement also would bar Eemland from transferring trademarks to Gillette for blades sold in the United States or Europe. Furthermore, it would prohibit Gillette from acting as Eemland's agent for the U.S. razor market, and would prevent Gillette from acquiring more equity in Eemland, the government said. Gillette said its ``principal purpose was to develop the global potential of the Wilkinson brand outside the European Community and the United States.'' Brenda Landry, an analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York, said the action should not be a big setback to Gillette, noting that Wilkinson represents about 3 percent of the U.S. razor market. ``The U.S. is peanut business,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Firing Raises Questions on Investment Advice
DOC.TEXT: The firing of a securities analyst who had criticized Donald Trump's newest casino project shows that brokerages sometimes face pressures to provide less than objective investment advice, industry observers said. Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. confirmed Monday it had terminated Marvin Roffman in the wake of negative comments he made to The Wall Street Journal about the Taj Mahal Casino Resort in Atlantic City, N.J. ``This should make the individual investor more skeptical about Wall Street research,'' said James J. Cramer, president of Cramer & Co., an investment management firm in New York. ``Most people think analysts are independent, understand their industries and do tough analysis,'' Cramer said. ``It's just not true. Most analysts can't afford to be independent.'' Janney Montgomery said Roffman was fired for violating company policies, not because of his negative public comments about the Taj Mahal. Nevertheless, Cramer said Roffman's situation would serve as a warning to other analysts that they have to recommend the stocks their firm wants to recommend, regardless of their own conclusions. Some others agreed. ``Wall Street (firms) are such idiots about not telling investors bad news,'' said Michael Murphy, editor of the Overprice Stock Service newsletter in San Francisco. ``They will only tell investors good news.'' He said Janney Montgomery ``made a dumb decision,'' and his own firm agreed with Roffman that the Taj Mahal will open at a time when the gaming industry has overcapacity. ``By firing the guy who has thought about this, done his homework, come to a conclusion and put it out there, they're really interfering in the efficiency of the capital markets,'' Murphy said. Robert Sobel, a professor of business history at Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y., said similar actions have been taken against analysts and stockbrokers before, but they usually have not been disclosed publicly. ``This is not going to burnish Donald Trump's image, or the company's,'' Sobel said. ``If I had an account with that company, I'd leave. I couldn't trust their research.'' But Andrew Gray III, president of the New York Society of Security Analysts, said Roffman's firing was an aberration, if a bad one. ``It sort of defeats the purpose of paying someone to determine whether a vehicle is a good investment, or a bad, or something in between,'' he said. Trump has issued $675 million in mortgage bonds to finance the Taj Mahal, which would have to gross $1 million daily to cover interest costs and operating expenses. The Journal quoted Roffman in its March 20 editions as saying the casino initially would flourish, but ``once the cold winds blow from October to February, it won't make it. The market just isn't there.'' Trump demanded Roffman issue a letter of public apology. Janney Montgomery ordered the analyst do so, to take a pay cut and to stop talking to reporters, according to Roffman. Roffman said he initially signed a letter seeking Trump's forgiveness for ``what has turned out to be a very unfortunate interview on my part.'' But he retracted that statement in a second letter, saying he signed the first letter under ``extremely stressful'' conditions. Trump said Monday that Janney Montgomery fired Roffman of its own volition. Norman T. Wilde Jr., president of Janney Montgomery, issued a statement Monday saying Roffman was fired because he had been advised in writing not to send his second letter. Roffman violated Janney Montgomery policies in making comments to the news media about the Taj Mahal before clearing them with top company officials and by not disseminating the recommendations broadly to the firm's clients first, Wilde said. ``Mr. Roffman was well aware of these policies and had been admonished in the past on more than one occasion to follow those policies,'' Wilde said. Philadelphia-based Janney Montgomery, a wholly owned subsidiary of Penn Mutual Life Insurance Co., has 1,050 employees and 40 offices. Roffman said he had received dozens of telephone calls of support from around the country. ``Everyone's saying, `we support you 100 percent in what you're doing. If an analyst does research and comes out with a negative opinion, there's no reason he should be silenced,''' Roffman said. Asked if were considering a lawsuit against his former employer, Roffman said: ``I have an attorney, and it is one of our options.''

DOC.HEAD: Italian Marble Covering Amoco Building to Be Turned Into Rubble
DOC.TEXT: Michelango used it to create masterpieces, and it helped make the world's fifth-largest building a landmark. But the Italian marble covering the Amoco Building appears destined for doom. Despite hundreds of offers to use the 16 acres of Carrara marble covering the building for items such as pen holders and pool decks, Amoco Oil Co. officials say it likely will be turned into rubble starting this May. That's when workers are scheduled to begin removing the 43,000 marble panels that form the facade of the majestic white building and replacing them with granite as a safety precaution. Offers to save the marble proved too costly and raised liability questions, said company officials, who are considering either tossing the marble into a landfill or breaking it up into gravel. ``We're down to those final two'' options, Amoco spokesman Mike Thompson said Monday. The marble covers the 1,136-foot downtown building in 45-inch long panels about 1{-inch thick, each weighing 275 pounds. That amounts to 5,900 tons of glossy white marble, which helped make the 17-year-old building a distinctive landmark among the city's skyscrapers. But planners didn't foresee the effects of Chicago's mercurial weather on the panels, which have warped and fractured in the deep-freeze of winter and summer's scorching sun. Michelangelo used the same type of marble, quarried in the Carrara Mountains of north-central Italy, but he ``didn't leave his work outside,'' Chicago architect Walter Netsch once noted. Fearing that the panels could come loose and turn into deadly projectiles, Amoco announced a year ago that they were being removed and replaced with granite. ``Everybody I've talked to says it's such a shame,'' said Paul Peterson, one of hundreds of people whose offers were rejected by Amoco. Peterson, a Chicago attorney and former artist, had tried to persuade Amoco to donate the stone veneer to a venture using handicapped people to make marble mementos. Another offer came from a homeowner ``who wanted to see if he could get some marble for a pool-decking,'' Thompson said. But the marble is super slick when wet, and Amoco didn't want to be held responsible for any accidents. ``There's serious liability questions here,'' Thompson said. It has taken a year to prepare the building for the removal, which will cost between $60 million and $80 million, Thompson said. The company expects all the marble to be gone and the granite in place by the middle of 1992. Though salt-and-pepper colored up close, the granite appears white from afar and will maintain the building's distinctive appearance, Amoco officials say. The offers to make use of the marble came from schools, churches and even the city's park district, which proposed using the stone to build a facade along the Chicago River, Peterson said. Cost made most of the offers prohibitive, said Shelby Pierce, engineering manager of the Amoco Oil. Co. subsidiary and coordinator of the removal project. During the removal, ``if the contractor is instructed to keep (the marble) intact and try to avoid breaking it, we're going to have to pay a premium on it,'' he said. The contractors ``would like to break it in the middle'' to facilitate the removal, ``but that would destroy the marble for any other use,'' Pierce said. Peterson is not convinced that Amoco has explored all the options for the marble, and said he's encouraging others to come up with suggestions for the stuff. But Amoco officials say the case is closed. ``It's unfortunate,'' Pierce said, ``but we'll be glad to get the granite up.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Default Judgement Entered Against Antar
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ordered a default judgment entered against Eddie Antar after the fugitive entrepreneur failed for a fourth time to appear in court on insider trading charges. The Securities and Exchange Commission alleges that Antar, founder of the now-defunct Crazy Eddie's discount electronics chain, reaped $60 million in profits by overstating the value of his company and selling stock based on false information about the company's financial soundness. The default judgment ordered Monday by U.S. District Court Judge Nicolas H. Politan paves the way for fines and recovery of money earmarked for distribution to allegedly defrauded investors. Penalties would be decided after a trial of three other top Crazy Eddie officials, including Antar's cousin and brother, also charged in the SEC case. The SEC has asked that a special judicial request be made to Israeli authorities to facilitate the return of $52 million the agency says Antar deposited in Bank Leumi, a Tel Aviv-based bank. Antar missed a court date on March 16 after already being found in contempt of court for missing previous scheduled appearances before U.S. Magistrate Ronald Hedges. Hedges then sent the matter to Politan. Antar's defense attorneys requested and were granted the right to drop out of the case after Antar missed the March 16 date.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most major foreign currencies in early European trading today. Gold prices were mixed, but dealers said the markets were recovering following Monday's record drop. Dealers predicted little action for the dollar, saying it was caught in a narrow range. The U.S. currency was supported by tensions in Soviet Lithuania but blocked from rising too far by fear of central bank intervention, traders said. ``When we move higher, the central banks could come into play,'' said a trader at a French bank in Frankfurt. However, Graham Ritson, chief dealer at the Bank of Montreal in London said he was not worried about market intervention yet. Another Frankfurt dealer, at a European bank, said he expected news from the German monetary union and reunification to make headlines and affect the markets again within the next few days. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.56 yen to a closing 156.97 yen. Later, in London, it was unchanged. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.7120 West German marks, down from 1.7155; 1.5213 Swiss francs, down from 1.5275; 5.7617 French francs, down from 5.7745; 1.9230 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9267; 1,258.50 Italian lire, down from 1,261.50; and 1.1770 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1748. In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.6165, compared with $1.6135 late Monday. Gold dealers said the markets were licking their wounds after what they said was the sharpest single-day drop in recent memory. ``There's a bit of consolidation going on,'' said one London broker. ``I think the dealers are still trying to sort through their books after Monday's action. It definitely isn't a hectic market right now.'' Gold opened in London at a bid price of $367.40 a troy ounce, down from $368.50 bid late Monday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $369.75. In Zurich, the bid price was $369.50, up from $363 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $12.47 to close at a bid $372.47. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $4.96 a troy ounce, from Monday's $4.94.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Stocks Dip Lower; Dollar Rises
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's chief index closed marginally lower today after making up most early losses, while the dollar rose against the yen despite selling by the Bank of Japan and by profit-takers, traders said. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 14.53 points, or 0.05 percent, ending the day at 31,825.96. In the afternoon, the index fluctuated wildly after losing nearly 350 points in the morning. The yen continued to weaken against the dollar. The Nikkei index's marginal loss came after a see-saw game between index-related arbitrage buying and profit-taking following the market's large rise Monday, said Kazuyoshi Suzuki, a dealer with Daiwa Securities Co. On Monday, the index rose 1,468.33 points, or 4.83 percent, in its second-largest single-day gain ever. Its largest gain was on Oct. 21, 1987, when it rebounded 2,037.32 points from the worldwide ``Black Monday'' crash. On March 19 the index dived 1,353.20 points to begin a three-day plunge that took it below the 30,000-point level before it began rebounding last Friday. Suzuki said a bullish mood was growing gradually among investors because today was the first day of the new fiscal for stock trading. Japan's fiscal year begins April 1, but the new month for registering stock transactions starts four days prior to the calendar date. ``The market has definitely bottomed out. After the year-end account settlement, companies no longer have a desperate reason to sell stocks,'' he said. ``Spring has come to the stock market.'' Trading was moderate, with the volume on the market's first section estimated at 700 million shares, unchanged from Monday. In currency trading, the dollar closed at 156.96 yen, up 0.56 yen from Monday's 156.40-yen finish. The U.S. currency opened at 156.90 yen and ranged between 156.80 yen and 157.20 yen during the day. Many market players, except for those who needed to buy dollars for year-end account settlements, remained on the sidelines, said Chizuko Satsukawa, a trader with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto told a post-Cabinet meeting news conference today events in Lithuania were greatly influencing exchange-rate movements, and called the current dollar-yen exchange rate ``a headache.'' He said he was continuing to watch foreign exchange market movements with concern. Traders said the central bank sold the dollar actively in the morning to slow its rise against the yen, but the amount sold was not immediately available. The Bank of Japan does not normally comment on its market interventions. The dollar slowed its rise in the afternoon as market players bought the yen against the West German mark, Ms. Satsukawa said. ``The yen is the only one constantly weakening against all the other major currencies. And this trend is unlikely to change,'' she said. Toru Kanai, a currency analyst with New Japan Securities Co., said, ``Unless the United States shows a clear position on an appropriate dollar level, the dollar won't stop rising.'' Kanai said market players also sold the dollar for profit-taking whenever the currency approached the 157-yen level. The price of the benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bond closed at 86.03 points, down from Monday's close at 86.86. Its yield rose to 7.345 percent from 7.170 percent.

DOC.HEAD: T-Bill Rates Drop
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell in the latest auction to their lowest level in several weeks. The Treasury Department sold $8 billion in three-month bills Monday at an average discount rate of 7.85 percent, down from 7.97 percent last week. Another $8 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.83 percent, down from 7.92 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 7.72 percent on Feb. 26, and six-month bills averaged 7.79 percent on March 5. Three-month bills equaled the 7.85 percent rate on March 5. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.12 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,801.60 and 8.26 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,604.20. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-yer Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 8.35 percent last week, down from 8.42 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: BAT To Sell Breuner Stores for $92.5 Million
DOC.TEXT: BAT Industries PLC said Tuesday it would sell its 18 John Breuner Co. furniture stores to Prism Capital Corp., a merchant bank in New York, for $92.5 million in cash. The deal is to be completed in about two months through BATUS Inc., the U.S. subsidiary of BAT, the conglomerate said. Breuners, which is based in San Ramon, California, was bought by BAT in 1982. The sale is one step in BAT's strategy of focusing on its tobacco and financial services businesses to fight off a 13.4 billion-pound, or $22 billion, hostile takeover offer from Hoylake Investments Ltd., an investor group led by Anglo-French financier Sir James Goldsmith. Part of this restructuring includes the sale of all BAT's retail operations in the United States. The others to be sold include Saks Fifth Avenue, Marshall Field's, Ivey's and Breuners' furniture rental business. The conglomerate said it hopes to have all the sales completed by the middle of this year. Prism was founded last year by Dennis and Steven Wong, who have backgrounds in merchant banking, venture capital and real estate, BAT said. Prism also owns a controlling interest in Barker Bros. Co., a chain of 11 high-quality furniture stores in Southern California, BAT said. Prism intends to operate the two retailers independently, it said. The combined annual revenue of Breuners and Barker exceed $200 million, BAT said.

DOC.HEAD: Jaguar Chairman To Leave Luxury Auto Maker
DOC.TEXT: Jaguar PLC Chairman Sir John Egan said Tuesday he would leave the luxury auto maker in June, seven months after it was taken over by Ford Motor Co. Egan, 50, said he has not yet decided what he will do when he leaves the company. He is to be replaced by William Hayden, currently vice president of manufacturing for Ford of Europe. Hayden, 61, has been leading Ford's transition team at Jaguar since the $2.6 billion takeover in November. ``It is exactly 10 years since my appointment as chairman of Jaguar and during that time I have concentrated on the rescue and recovery of a fine British car company,'' Egan said. He said he had been delighted that Ford had acquired Jaguar and was encouraged by Ford's ambitious long-term plans. Ford plans to substantially increase Jaguar's annual production of 50,000. ``I consider I have made my best contribution to Jaguar and my advice to Ford was that the big growth opportunities available to Jaguar under their ownership could only be fully exploited if the company was led by a senior Ford executive,'' he said. Egan has been credited with steering the auto maker through a successful privatization in 1984 and improving the company's fortunes. He had wanted to retain Jaguar's independence and had discussed possible cooperation deals with many car makers. In the government's hands, Jaguar had developed a poor reputation for quality and reliability, and sales had suffered worldwide, particularly in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Government Refers British Airways Plan to Monopolies Commission
DOC.TEXT: The government on Tuesday referred British Airways PLC's purchase of a 20 percent stake in Sabena World Airlines to the monopolies commission for a review of its impact on air service to and from Britain. The referral, made by the Department of Trade and Industry on the recommendation of Britain's Office of Fair Trading, puts at risk a major strategic move by British Airways. The airline had hoped to use the tie with Belgium's Sabena SA to create an additional hub for its European and trans-Atlantic flights. European airlines have been scrambling to form links with each other and with U.S. and Asian airlines to better compete as the air travel industry becomes increasingly global and deregulated. These links have raised concerns about their effects on competition. The trade department said the commission's investigation would not involve the 20 percent Sabena stake bought by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines at the same time the British Airways link was agreed to in December. British Airways and KLM each are paying the equivalent of $57 million for their Sabena stakes. The remaining 60 percent stake is to be held by the government-controlled Sabena. The department asked the Monopolies and Mergers Commission to complete the investigation by June 28. British Airways Chairman Lord King said he was disappointed by the referral, but added that he had ``every confidence that the MMC will conclude its report in our favor.'' King said the deal would expand existing services, increase customer choice and produce long-term benefits for the consumer. Although the newly formed airline was scheduled to have been launched at the beginning of this year, a British Airways spokesman said a further lag would be of no real consequence. The spokesman wasn't identified, in accordance with British custom. British Airways also is waiting for a ruling by the European Commission, which is looking into whether the venture is anti-competitive.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Lawmakers Balk at U.S. Trade Demands
DOC.TEXT: Japanese legislators, meeting with U.S. officials Tuesday, balked at American demands that they enact broad economic reforms to help shrink the U.S. deficit in trade with Japan. Japanese members of the Japan-U.S. Parliamentarians League told U.S. Ambassador to Japan Michael Armacost and other U.S. Embassy officials that reform of Japan's land-use policies and its retail distribution system would be difficult to achieve quickly, lawmakers attending the breakfast meeting said. At Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's request, the Japanese government has drawn up proposals aimed at meeting U.S. requests made in trade talks called the ``Structural Impediments Initiative.'' In remarks to Parliament, Japanese officials have said the reforms should be undertaken for the sake of Japanese consumers. But other leaders of the governing Liberal Democratic Party are less conciliatory, said LDP lawmaker Takujiro Hamada, who chaired the meeting. ``The parliamentarians said that resistance to the reforms was very strong in their constituencies and that it would take a long time to carry out the reforms suggested by the United States in the trade talks,'' Hamada said. ``The opinions expressed by the Japanese legislators were rather severe,'' said Ichiji Ishii, another Liberal Democratic lawmaker. ``They said the `menu' of U.S. demands was much too big,'' said Ishii, referring to reports that Washington has given Japan a list of more than 200 suggestions aimed at eliminating structural barriers it said prevent foreign companies from entering Japanese markets. U.S. officials attending Tuesday's meeting had nothing to add to the account given by Hamada and Ishii. The United States contends that high land prices and inefficiencies in and restrictions on the distribution system make it harder for foreign businesses to enter the Japanese market. Japan says problems on the U.S. side also contribute to the trade imbalance. In the latest round of trade talks last week, the Japanese side suggested the United States tax more, wean itself from energy-wasting cars and limit the use of credit cards, the mass circulation newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun reported. The suggestions were among 80 proposals for cutting the federal budget deficit, increasing savings and investment and improving worker training and education to boost the competitiveness of American exports, it said. The legislators, who eventually will vote on some of the government's reform plans, also argued that a reduction in Japan's $49 billion trade surplus with the United States could be better carried out through other approaches, including ``managed trade,'' or export-oriented industrial policies, Hamada said. He said former Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe, widely seen as a likely candidate for prime minister, stressed during the meeting that charges that Japan had done nothing to resolve the trade imbalance were absolutely wrong. ``It seems almost as if Japan is being scolded for having such a powerful, competitive economy,'' Hamada said. Each nation is to come up with an interim report on the SII talks in early April. A final report is expected in July.

The stock market was drifting at slightly lower levels in early trading today. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 4.06 points to 2,703.60 at 10 a.m. EST, 30 minutes after the opening bell. Declining issues outpaced advancers by a margin of about 5 to 4 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 491 issues down, 393 up and 526 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 17.93 million shares. Analysts said the market appeared uninspired in early dealings following Monday's lackluster session when Big Board volume recorded the second slowest day on Wall Street this year. ``There's not much going on today. Looks like it could be another quiet day,'' said Hildegarde Zagorski, equities analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Analysts said would-be participants were continuing to hold back, reflecting some nervousness about possible disappointing first-quarter corporate earnings as well as concern about Monday's plunge in precious metals prices. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was off 0.16 at 185.44. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 0.20 at 361.11. On Monday the Dow Jones industrial average posted a 3.38 gain to 2,707.66. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 5 to 4 on the NYSE, with 829 up, 652 down and 487 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 116.11 million shares, down from 132.07 million in the previous session. The last slower day this year was on March 12 when volume on the exchange was 114.8 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Split Over U.S. Trade Criticism
DOC.TEXT: Japanese people questioned in a nationwide poll released Thursday were almost evenly split about whether U.S. criticism of Japan's trade policy is reasonable. The financial newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun said 47.4 percent of the 6,186 people who responded to the survey said they view U.S. trade complaints as basically reasonable. This included 9 percent who said they completely agree with the criticisms and 38.4 percent who replied that ``the U.S. claims are basically right although there are a few points that seem unreasonable,'' the newspaper said. Another 32.9 percent of the respondents said the criticism was unreasonable, with an additional 6.6 percent saying the criticism was completely unreasonable. Another 13.1 percent said they could not say if the criticism was reasonable, or did not know. Sixty-three percent of the respondents said Japan should open its rice market at least partially to allow the sale of foreign rice ``despite government attempts to keep Japan's rice market closed,'' the newspaper said. It said a minority of 31.1 percent said absolutely no foreign rice should be allowed into Japan. ``The government's zero-import policy ... is not getting firm public support,'' the newspaper commented. In current trade talks, the United States has asked Japan to revise its land-use policies to reduce the price of land, streamline its complicated distribution system to allow easier access by foreign firms, and boost public works spending. Japan, in turn, has urged the United States to reduce its federal budget deficit, increase its savings and investment rates, and improve worker training and education to help boost U.S. export competitiveness. The newspaper said 85.9 percent of respondents said Japan should do its best to meet the U.S. requests, for reasons such as ``to do so will benefit Japan'' or ``because the U.S.-Japan relationship is important.'' Younger respondents tended to be more supportive of the U.S. trade pressure, the newspaper said. Of respondents in their 20s, 91.9 percent said Japan should respond positively to the U.S. requests. It said 76.9 percent replied that the two countries' relationship would probably either improve or retain its current closeness in the future. The newspaper did not provide a margin of error for the poll, which it said was conducted March 16-19.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Offers Reward in Shootings During Strike
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf pvs, ``We view ... to UPDATE with further comment from Greyhound and union; picks up 5th graf pvs, Greyhound said.
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines today offered a $100,000 reward for information leading to convictions for shooting at a Greyhound bus or terminal in the drivers' strike now in its fourth week. ``The terrorism must stop,'' P. Anthony Lannie, executive vice president and chief negotiator for Greyhound, told a news conference. ``We hope the reward will bring an end to the violence and help lead to arrest and convictions.'' Union officials said Greyhound was focusing on the violence issue ``as a basic tactic to avoid going back to the bargaining table.'' As Lannie announced the rewards, about a half-dozen union members, including union president Edward M. Strait, picketed outside the building. ``They're using that as a smokescreen to avoid coming back to the bargaining table,'' Strait said. ``We told them we don't condone violence. Never have.'' Strait said violence was occuring against striking drivers as well and said there were at least 60 incidents where pickets have been injured. Strait said he was willing to return to the bargaining table at any time. Lannie said the company would not resume talks, which broke down last Sunday in Tucson, Ariz., until management had ``a hard assurance'' from the union that the violence would stop. Lannie said there were 2,100 drivers, including 400 union members, driving Greyhound's routes. Lannie said Greyhound was providing 50 percent of its normal service. Greyhound said it was establishing a toll-free 800 number that will be in operation from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. weekdays starting at noon today. A retired law enforcement officer, usually a former FBI agent, will take information and contact the appropriate law enforcement agency, Greyhound officials said. Someone fired on a bus terminal in Texas and a bus was struck by gunfire in Florida Monday in the latest violent episodes. No one was injured in either of the shootings. Meanwhile, a California judge ordered striking drivers in the Southwest not to threaten replacement drivers for the country's only nationwide bus company. A Greyhound bus was hit by gunfire late Monday on Interstate 4 about 30 miles west of Orlando, Fla., spokeswoman Jeanne Fry said from Greyhound's Dallas headquarters Monday night. The bullet destroyed the vehicle's right-hand mirror but none of the 32 passengers was injured, she said. A shot was fired earlier from a passing car at the terminal in Amarillo, Texas, Ms. Fry said. Workers and passengers initially thought the sound was a car backfiring, Ms. Fry said. But small holes were found in a window, and police found a 20-gauge shotgun cartridge in the street, authorities said. The incidents brought to 28 the number of shootings, including 24 on buses, since the strike began March 2, according to Ms. Fry. Superior Court Judge David Yaffe in Los Angeles issued an injunction against intimidating workers with ``fear of bodily harm or death.'' Greyhound alleged that strikers had blocked or damaged buses and harassed replacement workers. No attorneys appeared at the hearing for the union's southwest region. Nearly 6,300 drivers and 3,000 other Greyhound workers went on strike after negotiators for Greyhound Lines Inc. and the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions failed to reach agreement on wage issues. The company said drivers earned an average $24,743 last year. The drivers took a 22 percent pay cut three years ago before a leveraged buyout of the company. Greyhound is offering a first-year raise of 6.9 percent. No further negotiations are scheduled, Greyhound officials said Monday.

The stock market turned mixed in relatively dull trading, with many would-be investors sidelined by what analysts called end-of-the-quarter blues. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 1.35 points to 2,709.01 at 11 a.m. EST. The blue-chip indicator was down 4.06 points an hour earlier. Advancing issues narrowly outpaced decliners on the New York Stock Exchange, with 586 issues up, 557 down and 537 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 40.02 million shares. Analysts said the market was drifting in uninspired dealings following Monday's lackluster session when the Big Board posted the second lowest volume on Wall Street this year. ``There's not much going on today. Looks like it could be another quiet day,'' said Hildegarde Zagorski, equities analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Nervousness about possible disappointing first-quarter corporate earnings as well as concern about Monday's plunge in precious metals prices kept many would-be participants sidelined, analysts said. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was down 0.22 at 185.82. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off 0.53 at 360.73. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, American Express was down { at 26], Circle K was off ] at 1} and American Electric Power was down [ to 30].
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 438.55 down .29 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Mixed In Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were narrowly mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade with corn futures slightly higher, wheat slightly lower and soybeans fractionally mixed. The modest strength in the corn market reflected slow farmer selling of corn. Gains were limited, though, by lack of confirmation that the Soviet Union recently bought U.S. corn. Soybeans opened lower, then turned mixed on buying linked to the continuing slow movement of soybeans and soybean products out of Brazil and to relatively slack export demand for U.S. soy products, analysts said. Corn and soybean futures also were pressured by a National Weather Service six-to-10-day outlook issued late Monday predicting mild temperatures and above-normal rainfall in the Midwest early next week. Wheat futures were fractionally lower as traders awaited significant news. ``Wheat's just coattailing the fits and spells of the row crops,'' said Pat O'Connell, a grains analyst with the commodities brokerage Refco Inc. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to { cent lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.58{ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1{ cents higher with May at $2.61\ a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to { cent higher with May at $1.50 a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to { cent higher with May at $6.04 a bushel. Livestock futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork belly futures were moderately lower after rising sharply on Monday. Live cattle futures were .10 cent lower to .08 cent higher with April at 77.35 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .10 cent lower with March at 82.85 cents a pound; live hogs were .67 cent lower to .15 cent higher with April at 52.80 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .15 cent to .50 cent lower with May at 52.80 cents a pound. Livestock futures settled mixed on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Corporate Issues Fall; Junk Bond Market All But Dead
DOC.TEXT: Stock and bond underwriting, investment banking fees and other key measures of Wall Street's health show the patient was still sick in the first three months of 1990. Preliminary figures for the January-March quarter reflect the hard times that included the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., turmoil at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and the virtual shutdown of the junk bond market. There have been just three issues of high-yield bonds this year through last Friday, worth $375 million, IDD Information Services said Monday. That compared with 25 issues worth $5.02 billion in the first quarter of 1990. Goldman, Sachs & Co., Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and the Minneapolis brokerage Dain Bosworth Inc. each brought one junk bond offering to market. Conspicuously absent from the list was Drexel, which virtually created and dominated the market for high-yield debt securities used for capital expansion and takeovers in the 1980s. Drexel's parent company filed for bankruptcy protection last month and the firm is liquidating. The total volume of new domestic issues of stocks and bonds for the quarter as of Friday was $68.2 billion, IDD said, down from $72.4 billion in the first quarter of 1989. In underwriting, investment firms sell securities to investors on behalf of companie seeking to raise capital. The fees generated from such activity are a major part of Wall Street's profits. Securities Data Co., another Wall Street numbers-cruncher, reported that initial public offerings of common stock totaled $2.7 billion in the period from Jan. 1 to last Tuesday, off 12.5 percent from the full 1989 first quarter. The IPO market had shown some momentum in the fourth-quarter of 1989, raising $4 billion through 89 offerings. There were only 35 offerings in the quarter through last Tuesday, Securities Data said. ``With the leveraging binge of the 1980s behind us and equity offerings at a standstill, investment bankers became extremely worried about profits,'' Securities Data said. Underwriting fees totaled $412 million in the period compared to $564 million in the first quarter of 1989, Securities Data said. In 1986-88, quarterly fees totaled $1 billion several times, the company said. Merrill Lynch remained the leader in overall securities underwriting for the quarter with more than $11 billion in domestic offerings, down from more than $13 billion in the full 1989 first quarter, IDD said. Goldman, Sachs held on to second place followed by Morgan Stanley & Co., which rose to third place from fifth.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Fall Sharply
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with close.
DOC.TEXT: Prices dropped sharply on London's Stock Exchange Tuesday as a major sell program and some disappointing domestic earnings reports depressed the market. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell 32 points, or 1.4 percent, to close at 2,266.2, just a shade above its session minimum of 2,265.8 and well below its peak of 2,295.6. Mediocre performances on overseas markets inspired little confidence in London equities, while fund managers appeared reluctant to take on new share positions until they were convinced that the market was headed higher, dealers said. The major sell program could not be readily absorbed by the market, dealers said. The market also fell back in reaction to an unsustainable rise on Monday, dealers said. Volume amounted to a modest 385.9 million shares, compared with 353.3 million shares Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Rostenkowski Sees SEC-CFTC Merger As Likely
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, the futures industry's most powerful ally in Congress, has all but conceded defeat in a battle over who should regulate trading of at least some types of futures contracts. Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said ``the cards are stacked'' against the Chicago Board of Trade and Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The two dominate global futures trading and favor continued oversight by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission rather than by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Illinois Democrat also said Congress appears to favor a merger of the two federal regulatory agencies over proposals to transfer to the SEC jurisdiction over only the financial futures markets or over stock-index futures alone. ``If there's any movement at all with respect to partial consolidation, there will be total consolidation,'' Rostenkowski said. ``I think the cards are stacked against the members of the Chicago trading faction.'' Rostenkowski commented on the situation in a meeting Monday with the Chicago Tribune's editorial board. His remarks were reported in Tuesday's editions. The CFTC currently regulates all futures trading. Leaders of the Chicago exchanges fear the SEC, which oversees stock and bond trading, would be a stricter regulator whose actions could raise the cost of trading futures in the United States, driving business overseas. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and SEC Chairman Richard Breeden favor giving the SEC at least some of the CFTC's regulatory authority. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the world's largest market for stock-index futures, is opposed to any transfer of jurisdiction, said spokesman Andrew Yemma. ``The position advocted by some in Washington of shifting jurisdiction to the SEC, we just don't consider that a negotiable matter,'' Yemma said in a telephone interview. The battle over jurisdiction of the industry stems in part from the government's investigation of illegal trading practices at the Merc and Board of Trade. Forty-eight people, mostly traders, have been indicted in the probe, prompting criticism that the CFTC has been lax in policing the exchanges. The turf battle also is rooted in the belief among some experts that stock-index futures trading increases volatility in the stock market. Stock-index futures are contracts that represent baskets of stocks. Rostenkowski portrayed the fight as reflecting a rivalry between New York and Chicago over dominance of the nation's financial markets. ``This shows the strength of the New York operators,'' he said, noting that Brady, former head of a powerful Wall Street firm, ``is part of the Eastern establishment.'' Sen. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., another futures industry ally, on Monday introduced a compromise bill that would put a member of each agency on the counterpart regulatory body. ``I think cross-membership is a good idea to give each agency a better appreciation of the issues the other has to face,'' Dixon said. The measure ``does not call for fundamental restructuring of our regulatory structure,'' he said, noting such restructuring is unnecessary. The debate over jurisdiction is likely to heat up Thursday, when top regulators are expected to testify before a Senate subcommittee headed by Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn. Dodd has said he favors shifting regulation of stock-index futures to the SEC from the CFTC.

DOC.HEAD: Doomsday Economics Professor Elaborates on Eerie Predictions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on vacation.
DOC.TEXT: Ravi Batra was used to making tumultuous global economic forecasts and having nobody listen. Then some of the predictions started to come true. Batra is republishing his 1977 book ``The Downfall of Capitalism and Communism,'' this month, 13 years after the India-born economist predicted the Iron Curtain and Berlin Wall would come down. ``When I took the book around to American publishers in 1977, they fought back laughter and said they weren't interested in such an outrageous forecast,'' Batra said. ``Dr. Doom'' still is scorned by most mainstream economists, but he no longer lacks an audience. Batra, a 46-year-old professor of economics at Southern Methodist University, attracted international attention when his 1987 New York Times best-seller ``The Great Depression of 1990'' predicted a cataclysmic drop in the stock market for that year. That Oct. 19, the Dow Jones average fell 506 points. The crash helped bring Batra's alarming forecasts into focus. He expounded his theories on television talk shows and was invited to advise a U.S. Senate committee on economic growth. Batra's 1987 prophecy and a follow-up called ``Surviving the Great Depression of 1990'' paint worldwide unemployment, deflation, stock market crashes and bank failures beginning this year and lasting at least seven years. ``I predicted then and I am sticking to my guns that capitalism and communism will both endure a complete collapse around the year 2000,'' he said in a recent interview. ``Except for an introduction and one additional chapter outlining what I think will happen in the 1990s, `The Downfall of Capitalism and Communism' is exactly as I wrote it in 1977,'' he said. Britain's Macmillan Press printed 5,000 copies of the book in 1978. Now Batra's publishing it again via Dallas-based Taylor Publishing Co. ``Every depression starts with a recession,'' Batra said. ``We are already seeing signs of a recession with the recent collapses of Campeau and Drexel Burnham.'' Problems in the market for high-risk junk bonds pushed the U.S. retailing operations of Campeau Corp. and investment banking business of Drexel Burnham Lambert into bankruptcy court earlier this year. ``The junk bond market is in shambles and the savings and loan failures are magnifying. Unemployment is also beginning to rise and will probably reach 8 percent by the end of 1990,'' Batra said. By 1995, he said, the country will be plagued with ``soup and kitchen lines worse than in the 1930s.'' Batra wrote in 1977 that communism's bare-bones living standards combined with the continued repression of basic freedoms ``will force Marxism to crumble under its own weight ... perhaps in the next 25 years.'' He's revised that scenario since communist governments began unraveling in the East bloc last year, a result of the liberalizations created by Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. But Batra suggested communism as a system is likely to make a last stand before succumbing. ``Soviet hard-liners and army officers, who have lost out in the recent realignment of power, could take advantage of growing unrest and economic stagnation and overthrow Gorbachev in a military coup,'' the book states. ``Even when communism recovers to make a last stand, it will prove to be a rearguard action, delaying not stopping the inevitable.'' Batra said he hired a bodyguard after Black Monday in 1987 to protect himself from death threats. He has drawn worldwide criticism for columns published in prominent newspapers heralding economic nightmares. Batra said his forecasts are born from the teachings of Indian mentor P.R. Sarkar, a spiritualist whose writings outline a history of social cycles dominating history. Sarkar heads an Indian sect called the Path of Bliss, some of whose followers have been known to take part in rites such as dancing with human skulls.

DOC.HEAD: Convenience-Store Company Losing Ground
DOC.TEXT: Given current business conditions, Circle K Corp. may not be able to complete its restructuring without the protection of federal bankruptcy laws, the convenience-store chain says. In an announcement late Monday, the company said it lost more than $40 million from operations during the three months ended Jan. 31. ``If the company does not achieve a financial restructuring, it will not have adequate liquidity,'' said the company, which is staggering under the weight of $1.3 billion in debt. Circle K blamed a sales slump for its precarious position and acknowledged that its prices had been too high. The company said it would begin cutting prices at its stores in an effort to win back customers. The Phoenix-based company accumulated its debt during a period of explosive expansion as it grew from about 1,000 stores in 1984 to 4,685 just before it announced a restructuring last year. It has been trying to obtain short-term debt relief while negotiating to sell 375 stores in the Pacific Northwest or Hawaii. The four-page statement said Circle K continues to believe that a negotiated restructuring is possible. However, the negotiation of the financial restructuring involves tricky manipulation of deadlines, it said. ``Some of the deadlines and demands will be difficult to meet and will require extension or modification. If any deadline is not met or extended or any unsatisfied demand is not satisfactorily altered, an impasse could result which might prevent completion of the negotiated restructuring,'' Circle K said. Southland Corp., the nation's largest convenience-store chain with more than 7,000 units under the 7-Eleven banner, announced Thursday that it was selling out to a Japanese company which had joined it as a partner in a leveraged buyout. Circle K's statement indicated a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing _ allowing federal protection during reorganization _ was more likely. It also said Circle K had hired Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, a unit of the Wall Street firm, to help work out its financial problems. Robert Dearth Jr., hired as Circle K president in January, has proposed a three-point business plan to improve the company's financial position. The plan includes a price cutback, improved services and product features, and an improved mix of merchandise targeted to the needs of neighborhoods where the stores are located.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Weaker in Europe, Gold Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version for AMs is planned by 5:30 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell against most major currencies in European trading Tuesday but continued its advance against the Japanese yen. Gold prices were moderately higher after Monday's slump when gold dropped as much as $30 an ounce amid reports of heavy Middle Eastern selling. Foreign exchange dealers said they saw no sentiment against the dollar and its weaker tone was due to profit-taking. They said disenchantment with the yen was continuing and the donward rates against the dollar also reflected fairly active buying of European currencies against the yen. The British pound, which sagged after a national budget statement a week ago was judged disappointing by business leaders, advanced for the fourth consecutive trading session. Dealers said sterling was underpinned by the pound's advance against both the yen and West German mark. Dealers said the weaker yen and mark followed an apparent failure of Japanese officials to gain U.S. support for their efforts to strengthen the yen, as well as the yen's weakness against other currencies. They said the mark was affected by uncertainty over a planned monetary union of the two German states and its likely impact on inflation. In London, one British pound cost $1.6255 late Tuesday, more expensive for buyers than Monday's late $1.6135. Other late European dollar rates compared with Monday's late rates were: 1.7108 West German marks, down from 1.7155; 1.5173 Swiss francs, down from 1.5275; 5.7535 French francs, down from 5.7745; 1.9247 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9267; 1,261.75 Italian lire, up from, 1,261.50; and 1.1761 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1748. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose against the yen, closing at 156.96 yen from 156.40 at Monday's close. In London late Tuesday the dollar closed lower at 157.35. Gold traders said their market was active, with gold in physical demand after the plunge on Monday. But when prices pushed above $370, there was another bout of selling, which reduced price levels. Gold bullion closed in London, the major European market, at a bid of $369.25 a troy ounce, up from $368.50. The closing bid price in Zurich, Switzerland, was $369.65 bid, up from $363.
