DOC.HEAD: Big California Pension Fund Backs Simmons in Lockheed Proxy War
DOC.TEXT: A big institutional holder of Lockheed Corp. stock decided Tuesday to support Texas investor Harold Simmons in Simmons' bid to oust the board of directors of the aerospace giant. The decision was made by the California Public Employees' Retirement System, a $56 billion fund that holds 500,000 Lockheed shares, less than 1 percent of Lockheed's stock. The decision by Calpers, as it is known, may carry weight far beyond that number, however. Calpers is a leader among pension funds pushing aggressively for more input into the management of companies whose stock they own. Among other things, it has asked companies such as Lockheed to set up shareholders committees to advise management. Lockheed Chairman Daniel Tellep has not committed to do that, although he has indicated he may be leaning toward supporting confidential voting by stockholders, one of a number of ``shareholders rights'' proposals to be voted on at Lockheed's annual meeting Thursday. Tellep and Lockheed spokesman Robert Slayman did not immediately return a call seeking comment on the Calpers move. Simmons' written agreement to recommend that his slate of directors set up such a committee accounted for Calpers' decision, said Kayla Gillan, the retirement fund's assistant general counsel. ``We met with both Mr. Tellep and Mr. Simmons,'' she said. ``Mr. Simmons provided us a written commitment that if elected he would recommend to his slate the creation of a shareholder advisory committee.'' Simmons' chief lieutenant, J. Landis Martin, said in a telephone interview that many large institutional shareholders, like Calpers, have favorably received Simmons' message. ``We feel a real tidal wave coming,'' Martin said. ``We're just getting a really favorable response from the large shareholders.'' Simmons, through his NL Industries chemical company, began buying Lockheed stock about 18 months ago. He now holds about 19 percent of the common shares outstanding. He spent about $530 million buying that stake, and has shown $100 million in paper losses on his investment as Lockheed's stock price fell. The biggest reason for the plunging stock price was poor earnings. Lockheed's profits fell from $624 million on sales of $10.4 billion in 1988 to $2 million on sales of $9.9 billion last year, chiefly because the company had to take nearly $500 million in special charges after underestimating the costs of developing several programs for the military, including a submarine-hunting plane.

DOC.HEAD: Government Trying To Build Consensus With U.S. On Trade
DOC.TEXT: Japanese government leaders struggled Tuesday to build a consensus before next week's deadline for responding to U.S. demands that Japan foster trade by altering its economy. At Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's request, the government has created a series of proposals aimed at meeting the U.S. requests in recent trade talks. The so-called Structural Impediments Initiative talks are aimed at eliminating factors in each country's economy that hinder reductions in their $49 billion trade imbalance. Chief Cabinet Secretary Misoji Sakamoto met party leaders in a series of meetings Tuesday to ask for their support for the government proposals. But former Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe, an influential politician who is widely seen as a prime candidate to succeed Kaifu, reportedly warned Sakamoto not to accept every U.S. request. ``Japan-U.S. relations are very important and are at the core of Japan's diplomacy, but we cannot say yes to every request,'' Kyodo News Service quoted Abe as saying. ``If we accept everything, it (U.S. demands) will go on endlessly.'' Japan is expected to convey its decisions to the United States at the fourth round of the bilateral talks, set for next Monday and Tuesday in Washington. The Asahi Shimbun, a leading Japanese newspaper, recently printed a list of more than 200 ``suggestions'' made by the United States in the talks. Washington wants to eliminate barriers in Japan's economic and business structure that it contends prevent foreign companies from entering the Japanese market. For example, Washington says Japan's complex distribution system makes it difficult for foreign businesses to sell their products on the Japanese market. It also has pressured Japan to boost its public works spending and tighten enforcement of its Anti-Monopoly Law to assure fair competition for foreign businesses. Toshio Yamaguchi, chairman of the governing Liberal Democratic Party's panel handling issues related to the trade talks, told The Associated Press that Kaifu must tackle those three issues ``without hesitating to accept pain.'' ``He needs to go as far as considering the possibility of scrapping the laws related to those issues,'' he said. ``Or we may not be able to come up with decisions acceptable to the United States.'' But other Liberal Democratic leaders were less conciliatory, said lawmaker Takujiro Hamada, who chaired the meeting. ``The parliamentarians said that resistance to the reforms was very strong in their constituencies and that it would take a long time to carry out the reforms suggested by the United States in the trade talks,'' Hamada said. Separately, the leading financial newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun released results of a public opinion survey in which 47.4 percent of the 6,186 respondents said they viewed the U.S. trade complaints as basically reasonable. Some 9 percent said they completely agree with the demands and 38.4 percent replied that the U.S. claims basically were right but there were a few unreasonable points, the newspaper said. It said 32.9 percent said many of the U.S. requests were unreasonable and 6.6 called them completely unreasonable. The newspaper said 85.9 percent of the respondents said Japan should do its best to meet the U.S. requests ``because to do so will benefit Japan'' or ``because the U.S.-Japan relationship is important.'' No margin of error was provided for the survey, conducted March 16-19. Meanwhile, government officials said Tuesday they had agreed to start considering a U.S. toy company's bid to open a discount store in Japan. Toys R Us has announced plans to open a 53,800 square-foot discount store in Niigata, 160 miles northwest of Tokyo, despite strong opposition by local shopkeepers. Japan's Large-Scale Retail Stores Law _ one item targeted by U.S. trade officials _ requires that small retailers be consulted before any large stores are opened in their areas. While some Japanese retailers have had to wait up to 10 years for permission to set up large new stores, ``consideration is under way to shorten the maximum waiting period required under the law to two years,'' said an official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, who spoke on condition of anonymity. In addition to making entry to Japan's market difficult for foreign retailers, the law works against larger Japanese stores that would be more likely to carry foreign products, U.S. officials say.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Unveils Office Computer System It Calls Unique
DOC.TEXT: AT&T on Tuesday announced an office computer system the company says offers unique features to allow employees to work together on group projects more effectively. American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s new Rhapsody system links personal computers in a network, an increasingly popular computer configuration for offices because it allows workers to share information. But AT&T said its system goes beyond existing networked systems because it can be programmed to gather information from computer files, ask other computers for data, send tasks to employees, schedule meetings, distribute reports for review and continuously track the status of projects. Among other enhancements is the ability to automatically perform routine functions, such as creating expense vouchers or processing insurance claims. Esther Dyson, who edits the computer industry newsletter Release 1.0, said the Rhapsody system is significant because it pulls together all the elements of a networked system: the computers themselves, the server, the networking gear, the software to run it, and applications software, such as word-processing programs. Such a package is not available from computer giants such as International Business Machines Corp. or Digital Equipment Corp., although they provide most of the pieces, she said. Ms. Dyson said AT&T's expertise in communications gives it unique credibility in linking computers locally or worldwide. The AT&T system, like many others, has an on-screen graphics display that uses pictures such as file cabinets, notepads and fax machines to execute commands, rather than typed-in written commands. Although AT&T is selling both the computers and the software to operate the system, it also will sell the software alone to companies that already have desktop computers. The system is based on the ``client-server'' model of computing, in which a server _ essentially a high-powered computer _ acts as the central data repository for personal computers linked on the network, which are called the clients. The Rhapsody system is based on a number of software systems developed by other companies, including Hewlett-Packard Co.'s NewWave software and the Windows graphical-user-interface software made by Microsoft Corp. The system also will run such popular applications software as Lotus Development Corp.'s 1-2-3 spreadsheet program and Microsoft's Word for Windows word-processing program. The first Rhapsody system will be based on desktop computers made by International Business Machines Corp. or compatible models sold by AT&T and others that use the MS-DOS operating system. Later versions will be compatible with computers based on AT&T's Unix operating system. The computer server sold with the system is made by both AT&T and Intel Corp. AT&T said Rhapsody is targeted at medium to large companies. A complete system for a 20-person office, including the desktop computers, will cost about $170,000. The software alone, for companies that already have desktop computers and a server, will cost about $2,000, AT&T said.

DOC.HEAD: Housing Affordability: A Top Issue For The '90s
DOC.TEXT: National Association of Realtors President Norman D. Flynn says housing affordability tops the trade group's list of key issues for the 1990s, but for now ``a buyer's paradise'' exists in some regions of the country. Flynn said the association is pushing for the government to take a more active role in helping prospective buyers, particularly qualifying first-timers, by making it easier for them save for a downpayment and providing more affordable loans. ``Many first-time buyers can't reach the first rung, and that's hurting everyone on the higher rungs, too,'' Flynn said in an interview Tuesday. He suggested that the federal government allow certain homebuyers, and even their relatives, to tap into their Individual Retirement Accounts and 401k savings plans without penalty of withdrawal. He also suggested the government lower downpayment requirements on financing insured by the Federal Housing Administration and establish secondary markets for seller financing, which could lower the cost of such borrowing. States could provide more low-interest loan programs through mortgage revenue bonds or mortgage credit certificates, Flynn added. Even changes at the local government level could help, he said. ``Many communities have no-growth or slow-growth housing policies,'' which have been responsible for artificially driving up many home prices by severly limiting the housing stock, Flynn said. He said that has had a particularly adverse impact on so-called move-up buyers. Flynn said he believes fellow real estate agents should lobby for reasonable growth initiatives within towns and cities, as well as speedier bureaucratic processes to help hold down developers' costs. For those who can afford it, however, there are attractive bargains in certain housing markets these days, according to Flynn. He pointed to the Northeast, where a previous sharp runup in housing prices has subsided. ``The buyer needs to be reminded that this is a buyer's paradise,'' he said. ``There's tremendous opportunity. We've got to get the buyier to look at the market.'' Flynn predicted that interest rates would drop by at least half a percentage point in the next several weeks, reflecting the continued sluggishness in the economy, and that should spur buyer interest. Mortgage rates are now averaging 10.3 percent on conventional 30-year loans, after falling below 10 percent earlier in the year. The rise in rates had curbed housing demand, causing nationwide sales of existing homes to drop an average 2.3 percent in February, to the lowest level in seven months, according to an associaton report released Monday. Flynn said there should be sufficient capital to meet borrowing demands despite projections by some banks and federal regulators that problem real estate loans are likely to increase.

The combination would give Turner & Newall access to J.P. Industries' established U.S. distribution network and give J.P. Industries a cash infusion needed to finance growth, said analyst Gurudutt Baliga with McDonald & Co. Securities Inc. in Cleveland. J.P. Industries issued a statement in February saying it was holding discussions with an unidentified manufacturer. John Psarouthakis, J.P. Industries founder, chairman and chief executive officer, said the company needed capital. J.P. Industries, which employs about 4,500 people and reported 1989 sales of $408 million, supplies parts to many manufacturers, Baliga said. DOC.HEAD: Two-Year Note Yields Rise
DOC.TEXT: Yields on two-year Treasury notes rose in Tuesday's auction to the highest level since May. The average yield was 8.59 percent, up from 8.50 percent at the last auction on Feb. 21. It was the highest rate since two-year notes averaged 8.84 percent on May 24. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8{ percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,983.80. A total of $10.1 billion in notes was sold from bids totaling $28.8 billion.
Stock prices were higher in late afternoon trading. About five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 23.42 points to 2,731.08.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Department Announces Tougher Disclosure Requirements
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Trade and Industry on Tuesday announced tougher requirements for the disclosure of stock purchases, making it more difficult to build up secret stakes in publicly held companies. Starting in June, stock buyers will have to disclose to the companies the purchases of stakes of 3 percent or more, compared with the previous 5 percent or more. At the same time, the disclosures must be made within two business days of the purchases, rather than the previous five business days. ``The steps we are taking will improve transparency in share dealings, providing greater information to investors and to companies that wish to discover the owners of their shares,'' said John Redwood, corporate affairs minister.

The stock market ended higher today after a late burst of buying lifted the market out of its doldrums. Analysts said their was no particular economic reason for the late-day activity, which followed a dull morning session with the market drifting in a narrow, directionless trading range. The market gradually began to show some life after sinking to the day's lows just after midday. The Dow Jones average dipped below the 2,700-mark to 2,699 at around 12:30 EST. Analysts attributed the late gains mainly to normal ``window dressing'' that accompanies the end of a quarter. ``Funds are going into blue chips that investors regard as their favorites,'' said Charles Jensen, chief technical analyst for the New York investment firm MKI Securities Corp. Drug stocks, airlines and oil stocks were among the day's better performers. Volume, nevertheless, was slim as many institutional players remained on the sidelines with what analysts called end-of-the quarter blues in anticipation of possible disappointing first-quarter corporate profits. Corporate profits, which have been in a recession since the second quarter of last year, continued to decline in the fourth quarter and helped dampen the market's enthusiasm at the start of 1990.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: of 1990.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 29.28 points to finish the day at 2,736.94, after falling below the 2,700-mark around midday. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by about 5 to 3 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 903 issues up, 542 down and 506 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 131.61 million shares, against 116.11 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index rose 1.80 to 187.40. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index gained 0.57 to 361.88.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices remained mixed Tuesday, with crude oil and heating oil picking up modest gains and unleaded gasoline declining. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the May contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 2 cents to $20.48 a 42-gallon barrel. The contract gained 7 cents on Monday. Among refined petroleum products traded on the exchange, No. 2 wholesale heating oil for April delivery was up 0.65 cent to 55.33 cents a gallon, after falling 0.78 cent Monday. May unleaded regular gasoline, which edged up 0.04 cent Monday, settled down 0.47 cent. Market watchers said that in the absence of any fresh news, technical factors were largely responsible for the price fluctuations. ``The market seems to be trading in a range ... on very light volume,'' said Peter Beutel, an energy analyst with Elders Futures Inc. in New York. He said the market was quiet as many traders were attending a National Petroleum Refiners Association conference in Texas this week.

DOC.HEAD: UTC, Daimler-Benz Announce Plans for Business Alliance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Edzard'' in 11th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: United Technologies Corp. and West Germany's Daimler-Benz AG announced preliminary agreement Tuesday to operate their jet engine divisions as a single company for certain ventures, a move analysts said makes sense given looming defense cuts. Under the memorandum of understanding, Daimler-Benz will invest in Pratt & Whitney, United Technologies' jet engine division, and United Technologies will invest in Daimler's Motoren-und Turbinen Union, or MTU, Daimler's aerospace and defense division. ``This agreement is setting in stone the relationship that has existed for some time between United Technologies and Daimler-Benz,'' said David Franus, an analyst with the market research firm Forecast International. ``This is a synergistic agreement which will open up new markets for both of these huge companies.'' Franus said the companies will be able to work together on projects by pooling their resources, allowing them to pare research and development expenses. The two divisions already are partners with three other jet engine makers in International Aero Engines, a consortium that produces the V2500 commercial jet engine. The other partners are Rolls-Royce PLC, Japanese Aero Engines Corp. and Fiat Aviazione. ``This agreement comes at a time when the aero industry is undergoing some serious rethinking,'' Franus said. ``With defense cuts, United Technologies will undoubtedly see sales decrease and it needs to approach other avenues in the commercial sector.'' During the past several years, Pratt & Whitney and the Daimler unit also have expanded cooperation in the development and manufacturing of commercial jet engines, including the Pratt & Whitney JT8D-200, PW2000 and PW300 models. ``We have concluded that a formal collaboration between our companies is an excellent strategic step to broaden and expand our historically close relationship,'' Robert F. Daniell, United Technologies' chairman and chief executive office, said in a statement. ``It will allow both Pratt & Whitney and MTU to expand their markets and complement each other's unique strengths in technology and manufacturing,'' he said. Daniell and Edzard Reuter, Daimler-Benz' chairman and chief executive officer, said the agreement comes after more than two years of discussion among top management of both companies. Full details have not been settled, they said. Under the agreement, MTU will be Pratt & Whitney's principal partner for Europe and the preferred partner worldwide. Once new commercial engine programs of interest to both companies are identified, joint teams will coordinate research, development, manufacturing and marketing, the companies said. ``The joint teams will work to minimize duplication in product development and maximize efficiency by concentrating production of certain components for common products at one company or the other,'' the companies said in a joint statement. ``Operations in these programs ... will be conducted as if we were one organization,'' the companies said, although Pratt & Whitney and MTU will retain their own management. United Technologies had sales of $19.5 billion last year and employs 201,000 workers. Its products include Carrier heating and air conditioning systems, Otis elevators and escalators, Sikorsky helicopters, Hamilton Standard aerospace systems, Norden defense systems and UT Automotive components and systems. Daimler-Benz is divided into four corporate units: Mercedes-Benz, the automaker; AEG, an electrical equipment maker; Deutsche Aerospace, which makes aerospace and defense equipment and includes MTU; and Daimler-Benz InterServices, which operates in services and finance. Daimler-Benz reported 1989 sales of $45 billion and has 328,000 employees.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Rally, End Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market staged a surprising late-afternoon rally sparked by computer-assisted futures trading and ended higher Tuesday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 29.28 points to finish at 2,736.94, after slipping below the 2,700-mark just after midday. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a margin of about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 889 issues up, 569 down and 505 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 131.61 million shares, up sharply from 116.11 million in the previous session when the exchange recorded its second-slowest day of the year. The slowest day was March 12, when Big Board volume was 114.8 million shares. The market opened lower then drifted in a fairly narrow range through much of the morning session. Analysts said lack of institutional buying kept the market from gaining any momentum. Global uncertainties, including Japan's volatile stock market and high interest rates, as well as nervousness about the possibility of disappointing first-quarter corporate profits were among the factors affecting the market in early dealings, analysts said. Corporate profits have been in a recession since the second quarter of last year. The first of a two-day meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's policy making arm, also renewed concerns about the direction of U.S. interest rates. ``There is strong belief that the Fed won't be doing anything to ease interest rates here,'' said Richard Ciardullo, head equities trader for Raymond, James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla. The market showed a glimmer of life after hitting the day's lows around midday and gradually began a steady advance. Wall Street analysts said computer-assisted program trading started a wave of buying that soon attracted ``real buyers'' anxious to put spare cash to work at the end of the quarter. ``It was a surprise to most market watchers _ a little program activity and investment activity and trading optimism and we had a nice rally,'' said Michael Metz, technical analyst for Oppenheimer & Co. Drug, airline and oil stocks benefited from the initial advance, which spread to the broader market by the end of the session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 154.02 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market advanced $28.294 billion, or 0.87 percent, in value from Monday. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks climbed 1.80 to 187.40. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, American Express fell \ to 26| after sweetening its stock-swap offer for the shares of Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings it doesn't already own. Circle K, which said it was not in compliance with certain financial covenants and was holding debt-restructuring talks with lenders, declined ] to 1}. JP Industries gained ~ to 16~, IBM added ] to 104{, Philip Morris rose [ to 39{ and General Electric advanced ~ to 64~. Two new issues also were among the most active: Alliance New Europe Fund, among an expanding roster of closed-end mutual funds investing overseas, closed at its initial asking price of $12; and Geneva Steel finished unchanged at $10. Standard & Poor's industrial index climbed 4.54 to 396.48, and S&P's 500-stock composite index gained 3.87 to 341.50. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market edged up 0.66 to 439.50. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 361.88, up 0.57.

DOC.HEAD: Big California Pension Fund Backs Simmons in Lockheed Proxy War
DOC.TEXT: Investor Harold Simmons won a powerful ally Tuesday in his contest to unseat the board of Lockheed Corp.: California's $5.6 billion Public Employees' Retirement System, which owns 500,000 Lockheed shares. The pension fund, known as Calpers, said it would back Simmons ratherthan Lockheed Chairman Daniel Tellep after Simmons agreed to urge his slate of directors to set up a shareholders committee to advise the board. Calpers advocates such panels as a way to exert more control over companies in which it invests. ``We met with both Mr. Tellep and Mr. Simmons,'' said Kayla Gillan, Calpers' assistant general counsel. ``Mr. Simmons provided us a written commitment that if elected he would recommend to his slate the creation of a shareholder advisory committee.'' In waging a proxy election campaign to get his slate elected to the Lockheed board, Simmons has tried to put Tellep on the defensive with proposals to give Lockheed shareholders more input. He says that if his faction is put in charge, he could manage the company so as to increase the price of Lockheed's stock, which has plunged nearly $20 per share in recent months. Lockheed closed up $1.12{ at $37 a share Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange. Tellep, who contends Simmons has no idea how to run a big defense company, countered on Tuesday with his own attempt to woo the big institutional shareholders who hold 60 percent of Lockheed's stock. He promised them a seat on the board after Lockheed's annual meeting Thursday, when the company will announce whether Tellep and the other directors have been ousted in Simmons' proxy battle. ``We will work with our institutional shareholders to develop a list of potential directors from within or outside their ranks who could provide additional perspective to our directors,'' Tellep said in a statement. ``We believe that selection of at least one director from that list could provide important input to the future of the company.'' Calpers holds less than 1 percent of Lockheed's stock, although its influence is greater than the stake might suggest. For example, Calpers has persuaded Occidental Petroleum Corp. to allow Calpers officials access to Occidental directors twice a year. Occidental agreed to the meetings as a compromise after Calpers demanded a shareholders advisory committee similar to the one promised by Simmons. Simmons' chief lieutenant, J. Landis Martin, said in a telephone interview that Calpers is one of many institutional shareholders leaning toward Simmons. ``We feel a real tidal wave coming,'' Martin said. ``We're feeling very good about our position and I'm virtually sure there will be a clean sweep on the shareholders rights issues.'' Those issues, to be voted on Thursday, include confidential shareholder voting, opting out of the tough anti-takeover laws in Delaware where Lockheed is incorporated and eliminating a ``poison pill'' provision that makes it prohibitively expensive for anyone to buy more than 20 percent of Lockheed's stock without the company's approval. Simmons, through his NL Industries chemical company, began buying Lockheed stock about 18 months ago. He now holds about 19 percent of the common shares outstanding. He spent about $530 million buying that stake, and has shown $100 million in paper losses on his investment as Lockheed's stock price fell. A big reason for the plunging stock price was poor earnings. Lockheed's profits fell from $624 million on sales of $10.4 billion in 1988 to $2 million on sales of $9.9 billion last year, chiefly because the company took nearly $500 million in charges after underestimating the costs of developing new programs, including a submarine-hunting plane. Simmons says the company has overdiversified and probably should sell large chunks of its operations that lie outside its core space, missiles and aeronautical businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Delinquent Loan Rate Falls in Last Quarter of 1989
DOC.TEXT: The number of consumers 30 days or more behind on their payments on bank loans fell in the final three months of 1989 after rising sharply to a 10-year high in the previous quarter, a trade group said Tuesday. The American Bankers Association said 2.64 percent of closed-end installment loans were delinquent as of Dec. 31, compared with 2.88 percent on Sept. 30 and 2.49 percent a year earlier. ``Consumers look pretty good for now,'' said ABA chief economist Robert H. Dugger. The delinquency rate is based on a nationwide survey of 800 banks. It includes seven different types of closed-end consumer loans: personal, two types of auto loans, mobile home, recreational vehicle, property improvement and home equity. The delinquency rate for open-ended home equity lines, which are tracked separately, dropped to 0.78 percent in the fourth quarter, down from 0.93 percent in the third quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Law Firm In Lincoln Thrift Suit Announces Settlement
DOC.TEXT: The law firm of Gov. George Deukmejian's top fund-raiser will pay up to $14.3 million to settle class-action lawsuits filed by investors who bought now-worthless junk bonds from Lincoln Savings & Loan Association. The fund-raiser, Karl Samuelian, said Monday that his firm, Parker, Milliken, Clark, O'Hara & Samuelian, agreed to pay at least $4.3 million. If plaintiffs do not recover an additional $10 million from other defendants, the firm will make up the difference, Samuelian said in a statement. The law firm's insurance will cover the $14.3 million in guarantees. That amount is the equivalent of 7{ cents on the dollar for the investors who lost money on the bonds. In return, Samuelian's firm will be dropped as a defendant in the suits. Seventeen lawsuits naming more than 20 defendants have been filed in federal and state courts by attorneys representing bondholders who lost money to Phoenix, Ariz.-based American Continental Corp., Lincoln's parent company. Parker, Milliken was one of several legal and accounting firms hired by American Continental to persuade regulators to permit the sale of American Continental high-yield, or junk, bonds at Lincoln branches. Lawyers from the firm, including Samuelian, argued the case before regulators, who eventually permitted the sales. The lawsuits accuse Parker, Milliken of wrongly using its political influence with the regulators, several of whom had worked for the firm in the past. More than 23,000 investors, many of them elderly people on fixed incomes, lost $200 million on junk bonds they bought at Lincoln branches. Many have said they were tricked into buying the bonds under the pretense they were insured like regular savings accounts. A civil suit filed by the state earlier this month accuses American Continental owner Charles H. Keating of casting a web of fraud and lies to snare investors into buying the bonds. Keating has denied any wrongdoing and suggests he is the victim of a campaign of harassment by government officials who are unable to comprehend his sophisticated financial tactics. Samuelian was the private attorney for Keating, whose corporation has filed for bankruptcy protection. Though Samuelian has never held a government post, he has been the chief fund-raiser for Deukmejian, treasurer of his campaigns and a noted political confidante of the Republican governor. The tentative settlement is subject to court approval. ``We have reached an agreement in principle and the details will be worked out in a final settlement agreement,'' said Seth Aronson, an attorney representing the Los Angeles-based firm. Samuelian declined to elaborate on reasons for reaching the settlement.

DOC.HEAD: Former Allied Executive's Funds Earmarked for Creditors
DOC.TEXT: A $5 million payment by Allied Stores Corp. into a tax-exempt trust fund for a former Allied executive is part of the corporation's bankruptcy estate for distribution to creditors, a judge ruled Tuesday. The ruling was made by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr., who is overseeing the Chapter 11 reorganization of Allied and its sister retailer, Federated Department Stores Inc. Aug upheld Allied's argument that the trust agreement mandates that in the event of a bankruptcy filing, the fund would become part of Allied's bankruptcy estate for payment to creditors under court supervision. Aug rejected arguments by a lawyer for the executive, Thomas M. Macioce, that Macioce was entitled to the $5 million as part of the retirement terms he obtained when he resigned as Allied's hairman and chief executive officer in January 1987 after 27 years with the company. Macioce, now a partner in the New York City law firm Shea & Gould, didn't attend the Cincinnati hearing and could not be reached at his office for a response. Macioce was the only one of nine current or former Federated and Allied executives with such trusts who objected to their inclusion among funds for payment to creditors, said Allied lawyer Greg Gordon. Aug also gave Allied and Federated permission to complete $91 million worth of ongoing store construction projects in Florida, Oregon, Tennessee and Washington state. The projects include construction of two new stores _ a $30 million Bloomingdale's in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., and an $11.3 million Bon Marche in Eugene, Ore. The other projects are a $21.5 million renovation of the Bon Marche flagship store in downtown Seattle, an $11.5 million reworking of a Bon Marche store in Tukwila, Wash., and a $16.6 million renovation of Goldsmith's flagship store in Memphis, Tenn. Federated and Allied must obtain Aug's permission for all corporate spending since their Jan. 15 Chapter 11 filings. Federated and Allied are units of Toronto-based Campeau Corp. Aug also allowed lawyers for Federated and Allied and their suppliers to work out terms that would allow the two retailers to return $25 million worth of Christmas season merchandise for credit. Returns of such merchandise are routine in retailing, but were complicated when some suppliers refused the returns because of questions about the effect of the Chapter 11 filings, company spokeswoman Catharine Wright said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Strengthens Again, Gold Rebounds a Bit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `The dollar ...,' to CORRECT Monday's yen figure in New York to 156.70, sted 157.70.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished higher against most key currencies except the British pound Tuesday, extending a rally that reflected fears of growing political and economic instability abroad. Gold prices rebounded slightly after a tumultuous plunge Monday that strategists traced to the dollar's strength and abnormally large gold sales from the Middle East. By 4 p.m. EST, bullion fetched $368.85 a troy ounce at Republic National Bank in New York, up $2.10 from the previous session. Currency dealers attributed the dollar's rise largely to questions over Japan's ability to manage its unwieldy financial markets and other economic problems. They also said the Soviet Union's resolve to suppress Lithuanian independence was unsettling European markets and raising demand for dollars. ``I'm basically a dollar bull, just based on a fundamental assessment of the world situation,'' said Zlatko Glamuzina, chief trader at the Banco di Sicilia's New York branch. ``As a safe haven, I don't think anybody can beat the United States right now.'' John McCarthy, chief dealer at the New York branch of Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank, also said he foresaw continued appetite for dollars. ``With the situation in Lithuania, I think the dollar has little downside potential.'' Some said unfounded rumors that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev might resign contributed to the dollar's strength. Such rumors frequently have surfaced in the climate of uncertainty surrounding changes in Eastern Europe. ``I didn't see it on any news screens, but I heard it from brokers,'' said Andrew Hodge, vice president of corporate treasury services at the New York office of Bank Brussels Lambert, a large Belgian commercial bank. ``It was clearly associated with the initial runup.'' The dollar strengthened in Tokyo to 156.96 yen, up from 156.40 Monday. Later in London, the dollar traded at 157.35 yen. By the time trading concluded in New York the dollar fetched 157.74 yen, up from 156.70 yen late Monday. The dollar was at the highest level against the yen in more than three years. In London, the pound strengthened for the fourth straight session, benefiting partly from a few large orders and a temporary market shortage of the British currency. It cost $1.6255 to buy sterling late Tuesday, more expensive than $1.6135 late Monday. In New York, the pound fetched $1.6260, more valuable than the $1.6185 rate late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York compared with levels late Monday included: 1.7128 West German marks, up from 1.7075; 1.5182 Swiss francs, down from 1.5205; 1.1765 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1760; 5.7610 French francs, up from 5.7480; 1,258.50 lira, up from 1,256.00 Other late European dollar rates compared with Monday's late rates: 1.7108 marks, down from 1.7155; 1.5173 Swiss francs, down from 1.5275; 5.7535 French francs, down from 5.7745; 1.9247 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9267; 1,261.75 lire, up from, 1,261.50; and 1.1761 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1748. The shaken gold market appeared to stabilize somewhat from its severe beating Monday, when bullion prices plunged as much as $30 an ounce and nearly erased a rally that began six months ago. Some traders said the Monday decline was the worst rout they'd seen in years. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery rose $2.90 a troy ounce to $368.70. Earlier, gold rose 75 cents an ounce to $369.25 in London and rose $6.25 an ounce to $369.25 in Zurich. It fell $13.10 a troy ounce in Hong Kong to $370.65. Silver bullion traded late in London at $4.98 a troy ounce, up from $4.95. On the New York Comex, silver for current delivery finished at $4.954 cents, down fractionally from $4.955.

DOC.HEAD: New Xerox Copier Can `Phone Home' About Problems
DOC.TEXT: Xerox Corp. on Tuesday introduced a new copier that can ``phone home'' for help when it senses a problem developing. The Xerox 5065, a mid-volume copier that produces 62 copies a minute, is the first Xerox copier to offer a built-in ``remote interactive communications'' system, the company said. Xerox's high-volume 1090 copier offers the RIC system as an optional add-on feature, said Xerox spokesman Daniel C. Minchen. The RIC system continuously checks the copier's performance against set standards and alerts a central computer when it notices a potential problem, Minchen said. Information about the problem is transmitted via telephone to the central computer, where an artificial intelligence system analyzes the data and decides whether a service call is needed. Surveys show that customers' highest priority is avoiding copier breakdowns and emergency maintenance calls, the company said. The RIC system should notice most problems before the people using the machine do, Minchen said, eliminating the need for customers to call Xerox for service. ``With every (service) call there's a possibility for dissatisfaction,'' he said. ``This eliminates all that by notifying the company before a potential problem becomes a real problem. We'll call the customer first.'' Minchen said the RIC system will not notice problems such as loose doors or spots on the copy. But it will detect document misfeeds, depletion of the copier's developer or toner, repeated paper jams and other mechanical or electrical failures, he said. The artificial intelligence system decides what the problem might be and sends a service worker out with the right parts, Minchen said. The system also keeps track of how many copies are made, which Minchen said will be a more efficent way of billing than requiring customers to keep track of how much they use a machine. The 5065 copier will sell for $30,650, Xerox said.

DOC.HEAD: Extention Granted to Keep D&H Running
DOC.TEXT: The trustee for the bankrupt Delaware & Hudson Railway was given less than two weeks to find a buyer for the freight carrier or face the liquidation of the nation's oldest continually operated railroad. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Helen Balick on Tuesday granted a request from trustee Francis Dicello for an extension to continue operating D&H while a buyer is sought. The judge set an April 11 date to determine whether the rail line will be sold or if liquidation should begin. Dicello said the deadline for offers is April 6. ``If there clearly are no potentially doable offers on the table, then we will liquidate,'' he said. Shippers who use the D&H lines would be notified that they must find an alternative by midnight April 16, which has been set as the shutdown date. If there is a potential buyer for all or part of the rail line, Dicello said he would ask the court for another extension until the sale is completed. D&H, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in June 1988, is about $100 million in debt. Dicello said liquidation could result in an estimated $70 million to $80 million. ``But I don't want to do that,'' he said. ``I don't see a lot of winners'' with liquidation. With the extension, the rail line will continue to operate with subsidies from shippers, the states of New York and Pennsylvania and with cash collateral that is being held for its secured creditors. The extension was supported by attorneys representing the shippers, the states and a majority of the creditors. John Broadley, attorney for Guilford Transportation Inc., D&H's sole shareholder, opposed the extension, and asked the court for immediate liquidation. ``There is no interest by anyone of acquiring D&H. The trustee has no offer,'' Broadley said. Canadian Pacific Ltd. submitted a bid of $35 million for D&H but withdrew the offer in mid-February after talks broke down with Consolidated Rail Corp. over track rights between Harrisburg, Pa., and Hagerstown, Md. The tracks would give the carrier access to key southern routes. Broadley said there was no assurance that Congress would pass legislation forcing Conrail to negotiate track rights with Canadian Pacific. Dicello said Canadian Pacific indicated Monday that it would submit a significantly lower bid for D&H without the track rights. Dicello indicated in court he would not consider an extremely low. D&H carries freight from Montreal to Washington, D.C., and from Albany to Buffalo in New York. More than 400 workers would lose their jobs if no buyer is found.

DOC.HEAD: Sony Creates New Engineering and Manufacturing Arm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Masaaki cq in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Sony Corp. of America has formed a new division to coordinate its engineering and manufacturing activities in the U.S., the company said. Sony Engineering and Manufacturing of America (SEMA) will oversee plants producing consumer and industrial display products, audio and video products and audio speakers, Masaaki Morita, chairman and chief executive of Sony Corp. of America, said Tuesday. The new division also will contribute to Sony's planning activities and work with global business groups to develop and implement long-range manufacturing plans. It will be based in Park Ridge, a suburban area just outside New York City. Morita will serve as chairman of SEMA. The president and chief operating officer is Junitake Ando. Morita is a deputy president of Sony Corp. and younger brother of the parent company's chairman, Akio Morita. Sony has invested nearly $1 billion in U.S. operations since establishing its first manufacturing facility in San Diego in 1972, Morita said in a news release. ``As we plan to invest a similar amount over the next three to five years, it is important that we develop local mechanisms for directing and integrating the various manufacturing and engineering operations as they grow,'' Morita said. ``We also believe that SEMA will serve to strengthen our long-term commitment to contributing and being a part of the local U.S. communities where we operate,'' he said. Ando holds degrees from Bucknell University in Lewisburg, Pa., and the University of Tokyo. He has been responsible for planning Sony's overseas manufacturing plants and has served as manager of corporate planning for Sony Corp. of America.

DOC.HEAD: UAL's Wolf Was Paid $1.15 Million Last Year
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. revealed that last year's failed $6.8 billion buyout bid by management and employees of its United Airlines subsidiary cost the company $76 million in expenses. UAL also revealed that Chairman Stephen Wolf, who led the buyout attempt, was paid $1.15 million last year, double his 1988 compensation. The company also disclosed that John C. Pope, UAL's chief financial officer, took advantage of last year's steep climb in UAL's stock price to exercise about $5.9 million in stock options or stock appreciation rights. The information was contained in proxy materials mailed Monday to UAL shareholders for the company's annual meeting, scheduled for April 26 in the Chicago suburb of Rosemont. Coniston Partners, UAL's largest shareholder with an 11.8 percent stake, is threatening a proxy fight to replace the 15-member board with its own slate. If successful, Coniston plans to sell the company to UAL employees in a deal valued by analysts at about $185 a share, or more than $4 billion. If the company is sold to its employees at that price, Wolf would stand to make a $13.9 million profit on his stock and stock options. Coniston Partners principal Keith Gollust said he expects Coniston's proxy materials to receive Securities and Exchange Commission approval and be mailed to shareholders by early next week. UAL's board agreed last week to negotiate with its three employee unions in hopes of reaching agreement on a higher buyout price and avoiding a proxy fight. The board was scheduled to meet Wednesday, said company spokesman Robert Doughty. The company's stock rose $3.50 to $161.50 on the New York Stock Exchange Tuesday. The proposal made earlier this month by United's pilots, machinists and flight attendants unions included provisions for UAL to reimburse the unions for up to $65 million if their bid is successful or topped by a higher offer, or up to $25 million if the bid fails. According to the company's proxy, Wolf received $575,000 in salary last year and another $575,000 in bonuses. In 1988, he received $575,000 in salary and no bonuses. Pope and Wolf were criticized last year by the unions for the $114 million they stood to receive for their stock holdings had the $300-a-share buyout bid succeeded. The offer failed for lack of financing in October. UAL incurred a large part of the failed buyout's costs, including $59 million in fees to the buyout group's bankers and lawyers.
Eds: The Washington-dated item AM-Clean Air, which moved on general wires only as a0758, may be of interest.
DOC.HEAD: AP Business News
Italian Tycoon Questioned In Connection With Ambrosiano Case
DOC.TEXT: Financier Carlo De Benedetti was questioned for six hours by a judge about his 65 days as a vice president of Banco Ambrosiano, the bank that touched off Italy's largest banking scandal when it failed in 1982. At the end of Tuesday's questioning, De Benedetti told reporters he was ``serene and satisfied'' because he was able to tell the magistrate ``the total honesty of my behavior.'' De Benedetti, the head of a financial empire that includes the Olivetti computer group, was questioned by Raffaele Invrea, chief judge of the Milan Court of Appeals, after being notified that he was suspected of possible involvement in fraudulent bankruptcy. Invrea declined to give any details of the questioning and said only that ``a judge speaks by taking measures.'' No action was taken against De Benedetti, who had been investigated by a lower court in the same case. Lower court judges Antonio Pizzi and Renato Brichetti, after a long investigation into the Banco Ambrosiano failure, decided last April not to pursue the case in regard to De Benedetti, whose summoning for questioning this week came as a surprise. The scope of the lower court investigation centered on whether De Benedetti made an illegal profit from his investment in the bank _ about 52 billion lire ($40 million) on a 2 percent stake in Ambrosiano. De Benedetti has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing or that he profited from his investment. The financier's vice presidency in Italy's largest private bank, in which the Vatican bank was a major shareholder, lasted 65 days through Jan. 22, 1982. De Benedetti sold the stake once he resigned his post. He cited disagreements with bank chairman Roberto Calvi for his decision to quit. Calvi, nicknamed ``God's banker'' because of his close ties with the Vatican, was found hanging from a London bridge in June 1982. Ambrosiano collapsed two months later following the failure to win repayment of $1.3 billion in loans made by the Italian bank to dummy Latin American companies backed by the Institute for Religious Works, which is commonly called the Vatican bank. De Benedetti said the questioning was long but added that it was difficult to detail his 65 days in a few hours. A trial of 25 Banco Ambrosiano board members and officials, charged following the bank collapse, is scheduled to begin in Milan on May 29. Court sources indicated that appeal judges would decide De Benedetti's position by that date.

DOC.HEAD: Nordstrom Cuts Seattle Newspaper Ads, Denies Link to Labor Coverage
DOC.TEXT: A top Nordstrom Inc. executive called a Seattle newspaper's coverage of the retailer's labor problems ``horrible,'' but he said the company's decision to cut advertising in the paper wasn't meant as retaliation. Co-chairman Jim Nordstrom said the company was only taking a closer look at the effectiveness of its advertising. Nordstrom spokeswoman Megan McKenzie said the company told The Seattle Times and Seattle Post-Intelligencer on Friday that it was cutting back on its ads. The papers maintain separate editorial and news staffs, but The Times handles advertising and printing for both under a joint operating agreement. Cindy Demme, vice president for sales promotion, said Nordstrom has been trying different mixes of advertising media in other markets and wanted to try the same thing in Seattle. Ads were cut from six last Thursday in the Times, including three full-page displays and three smaller ones, to one full-page ad planned for this Thursday. Known for its upscale clothing and attentive customer service, Nordstrom has come under increasing scrutiny for stormy labor relations and declining profits and stock prices. Earlier this year, it was hit by a triple whammy: state findings that Nordstrom failed to pay some employees for work done outside their scheduled hours, unfair labor practice complaints by the National Labor Relations Board and a 34 percent profit slump for the year ending Jan. 31. The Wall Street Journal also ran a front-page article by reporter Susan C. Faludi detailing complaints of past and present Nordstrom workers. ``If we do cut our advertising anywhere, it's because we're not getting a good value for our dollars,'' Jim Nordstrom was quoted as saying in Tuesday's Times, ``and frankly, with the rising costs of your two papers, we need to do some re-evaluating.'' Nordstrom said there was no link between the ad cuts and coverage in the papers but added, referring to the Times: ``We think your coverage is horrible, the worst in the nation, worse than The Wall Street Journal because that girl didn't know us. She just regurgitated what the union said.'' Michael Fancher, Times executive editor, said advertising cuts wouldn't alter the newspaper's coverage. ``I think it's important for readers to understand that when advertisers purchase an ad, they are buying exposure to our readers. Nothing more and nothing less,'' he said. Times ad director Marji Ruiz said Nordstrom is one of the afternoon paper's top 10 advertisers. ``Our rate increases over the last few years have been less than the national average,'' said Jack A. Williams, Times sales and marketing vice president. Meanwhile Tuesday, the NLRB dismissed a petition seeking to decertify United Food and Commercial Workers Local 367 as the bargaining agent for Nordstrom clerks at the Tacoma store. A decertification petition also was filed Tuesday against UFCW Local 1001 in the Seattle area, but Larry McCarger, assistant to the NLRB's regional director, said that attempt might fare no better. McCarger said the board has a long history of refusing to conduct decertification elections while unresolved NLRB complaints are pending. The two locals represent about 1,800 employees at six Nordstrom outlets, the only unionized stores in the chain. Nordstrom has 60 stores and 30,000 employees in Washington, Oregon, Alaska, Utah, Virginia and California. One organizer of the decertification campaign is Kathleen Sargent, a clerk in the downtown Seattle store and goddaughter of Anne Nordstrom, sister of co-chairman Bruce Nordstrom. ``The biggest concern that we've had is the union has distorted the image of what it's like to work for Nordstrom,'' Sargent told the Post-Intelligencer. ``They make it sound like it's a slave house, and it's not. It's a very positive and productive environment.'' The NLRB has accused Nordstrom of attempting to bypass the union and negotiate directly with employees, refusing to provide the union with information for collective bargaining and changing vacation benefits without negotiating with the union.

DOC.HEAD: Board OKs Bankruptcy Filing
DOC.TEXT: Colorado-Ute Electric Association, unable to control expenses and raise rates to its liking, has decided to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. Tuesday's decision came nearly one year after Colorado-Ute, which serves about 600,000 Colorado residents, defaulted on its loans. The utility is $1.2 billion in debt and owes the federal government at least $723 million. Board Chairman Joe deGanahl II blamed the move on the Colorado Public Utilities Commission, which decided March 8 to grant Colorado-Ute an 8 percent rate hike instead of the 23.7 percent increase the utility sought. ``We tried very hard to resolve this in a manner to solve the needs of all the parties,'' deGanahl told reporters after the vote. ``That was unfortunately not to be, because of the actions of others. Clearly the straw was the commission's decision.'' His comments were denounced by the PUC and state Office of Consumer Counsel, who said Colorado-Ute brought its problems upon itself. ``It has taken many years for Colorado-Ute to get in the financial position it finds itself,'' said PUC spokeswoman Barbara Fernandez. ``It is unfair to blame us for what has occurred.'' The director of the consumer counsel office called for appointment of an independent receiver to direct the utility's reorganization ``given what Colorado-Ute's management has done. The court should put the company in the hands of others.'' The board of directors met for two days behind closed doors and emerged Tuesday afternoon to vote 12-0 in public to authorize company president Ray Keith to file for Chapter 11 reorganization at his discretion. ``A Chapter 11 reorganization filing is imminent unless something materially changes in the next few days,'' Keith said in a statement. The board took no action on an order from the U.S. Rural Electrification Administration directing the company to raise its rates by 24 percent to meet loan obligations due the federal government. The board directed Keith to meet with corporate lawyers and report back next month. Directors said the company was surprised by the REA order, which came in a letter on Monday. Calls to REA officials Tuesday weren't returned. The PUC said a U.S. District Court decision in Indiana last May ruled that the state regulatory commission had jurisdiction on rates, not the REA. ``We don't think they have the authority,'' Fernandez said. Colorado-Ute serves 14 rural electrical cooperatives in 49 Colorado counties. It has lost money for three straight years, including an estimated $15 million loss in 1989. Meanwhile, the board of directors nearly doubled its own spending for directors' fees and travel and awarded merit increases to management employees. ``They are symptomatic of the problem,'' said Ron Binz, director of the Office of Consumer Counsel. ``They had the opportunity to turn it around, but all we've seen in the last year is an inability to come to grips with the problem.''

DOC.HEAD: D&H Trustee Asks for New Bids
DOC.TEXT: The bankruptcy trustee for the Delaware & Hudson Railway is seeking new bids for all or part of the failing freight line, the nation's oldest continually operated railroad, a spokesman for the Federal Railroad Administration said. The trustee, Francis P. Dicello, met Monday in a closed session with representatives of about 16 carriers with an interest in D&H and invited them to make offers, said Mark Lindsey, the FRA's general counsel. The talks took place under a special rule that allows competitors to discuss business without violating antitrust laws, Lindsey said. Dicello also is planning to return to bankruptcy court in Wilmington, Del., on Tuesday to seek a month's extension of the order allowing him to run the D&H while he seeks a buyer, Lindsey said. That order is set to expire Tuesday. Dicello, who has been seeking a buyer for D&H since September, was not in his office Monday and did not return a phone call. David Murray, a spokesman for the New York Department of Transportation, said Dicello would entertain bids for the whole D&H system until April 6. The meeting Monday was called after Consolidated Rail Corp. broke off negotiations last week with Canadian Pacific Ltd. over trackage rights. Canadian Pacific had bid $35 million for D&H but withdrew the offer in mid-February when Conrail refused to negotiate use of tracks between Harrisburg, Pa., and Hagerstown, Md., which would give the carrier access to key southern routes. ``We've been at this with them for three months now and when you get the chairmen of the two companies agreeing that they're going to disagree ... there's no higher authority in either company, so that puts an end to it,'' CP Rail spokesman John Cox said Monday. Conrail has maintained that providing the rights would reduce its annual revenues substantially and could lead to the loss of 600 to 900 jobs. D&H carries freight from Montreal to Washington, D.C., and from Albany to Buffalo in New York. The railway filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in June 1988. More than 400 workers would lose their jobs if no buyer is found. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., said Friday he would ask Senate leaders to speed up consideration of a bill he introduced to force Conrail to relinquish its track rights. ``It seems clear that Conrail never wanted to make a deal that would help revive and strengthen the D&H,'' D'Amato said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Registers Lowest GNP Growth in Eight Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Figures are in U.S. dollars.
DOC.TEXT: South Korea's gross national product grew 6.7 percent last year after inflation, the slowest level of real growth since 1982 and a reflection of the country's sluggish exports, central bank officials said Tuesday. Tallies by the Bank of Korea showed the 1989 growth rate was far down from 1988's 12.4 percent and the lowest since the GNP grew 5.9 percent in 1982. South Korea's economic boom took off in 1986, resulting in a double-digit GNP growth for three years _ 12.9 percent in 1986, 13 percent in 1987 and 12.4 percent in 1988. But last year the nation's economy was hit by labor strikes for higher wages and the steady appreciation of the Korean won, which hurt exports. Bank officials said the per capita income stood at $4,968 in 1989, compared with $4,127 a year earlier. By breakdown, the manufacturing sector grew 3.7 percent in 1989, compared to a 13.4 percent growth in 1988, while construction and service industries grew 15.4 percent and 8.3 percent, respectively.
